HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Operating Profit Rises At American Express

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its earnings from continuing operations increased 19 percent in the second quarter, to $359 million, pushed up by strong results in its credit card and investment businesses, the two areas in which the slimmed-down company is now concentrating.
Still, its total net income declined 14 percent, to $357 million, from $416 million in the second quarter of last year. Last year's results included $109 million from its Shearson and Lehman Brothers investment banking subsidiaries. The company spun off Lehman to its shareholders on May 31 and sold Shearson to Travelers Inc. last July. 
 Over all, American Express earned 69 cents a share, exactly what analysts had expected.
"The news is there is not much news," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "The earnings volatility that the company used to have because of Lehman and Shearson is gone, and this certainly was the right quarter not to have Lehman Brothers."
Lehman, like most brokerage firms, has been hurt by the volatile markets.
Separately, the company said it would change the name of IDS Financial Services, its mutual fund and insurance sales unit, to American Express Financial Advisors as of Jan. 1. As American Express divests itself of its other brokerage units, it is moving to tie IDS closer to its credit card business.
American Express announced its earnings yesterday afternoon after the stock market closed. Earlier, its shares finished at $26.25, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company said its credit card and travel agency unit, known as Travel Related Services, reported a profit of $263 million for the second quarter, up 13 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. The company said the increase was mainly a result of growth in business travel and increased spending on American Express cards.
Customers charged $34.6 billion worth of goods and services with American Express cards in the quarter, up 12 percent. But since the company has been reducing the percentage fees it charges merchants that accept its cards, those fees only rose 9 percent, to $983 million. And the income the company receives from annual fees for cards declined slightly to $431 million.
The number of Green and Gold American Express accounts in the United States declined to 11.3 million in the quarter from 11.8 million a year ago, but corporate cards and cards in international markets increased.
The American Express Bank earned $19 million, down from $21 million a year ago, mainly as a result of lower income resulting from rising interest rates.
IDS, based in Minneapolis, earned $109 million in the quarter, up 21 percent from last year. While many brokerage firms have posted sharp declines in earnings this year, IDS's business is more stable.
"IDS is not a transaction-driven business." Mr. Moszkowski said. "It is an insurance company and a money management unit that earns fees from assets." IDS said that sales of mutual funds and investments increased from last year, while sales of insurance declined.
American Express has been planning to change the IDS name for several years and has tested its own name on IDS offices in several cities. The company said that the switch had increased sales.
IDS, which is 100 years old, was bought by American Express 10 years ago and was briefly known as IDS/American Express before reverting to the IDS Financial Services name in 1985.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Edge Up In Day of Slack Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds drifted higher in very thin trading yesterday as traders and investors braced for a fresh batch of intermediate Government notes.
The price of the the 30-year bond increased 12/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 7.52 percent, from 7.56 percent late Friday. Prices of short-term Treasury securities were unchanged to 1/32 higher, while intermediate maturities ranged from 3/32 to 8/32 higher, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. 
 Most market participants refrained from major moves ahead of the Treasury's auction of $17.25 billion in two-year notes today and $11 billion in five-year notes tomorrow.
 
Still on the Weekend?
 "It was one of those days in which you felt like one-third of the market participants were on a long weekend," said Russell Abbott, a government securities trader at CS First Boston.
Some of the gain in the prices of the 30-year bond was attributed to expectations that the Federal Reserve would soon move to raise short-term interest rates.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, warned Congress last week that the Fed might need to raise rates for the fifth time this year to curb hidden inflation pressures.
Mr. Greenspan's comments last Wednesday killed the bond market's biggest rally in three months.
But since his testimony, some investors have sold short-term securities and bought long-term maturities in the hope that another rate increase would stabilize the bond market.
 
Effects of Higher Rates
 Higher interest rates on new securities would probably push down the value of existing bonds. But since the Fed uses short-term rates to carry out its monetary policy, short-term securities tend to be hurt the most by such moves.
Long-term bonds, meanwhile, might possibly gain in value from Fed moves to combat inflation, which has the most corrosive effect on longer-term maturities.
In the day's only major economic news, the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes dropped 3.6 percent in June, the second consecutive monthly decline caused by mortgage rates above 8 percent.
The report was expected and had a negligible impact on bond prices.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.58, to 1,214.86.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9121/32 , up 1/32 from Friday. The average yield to maturity was 6.37 percent, down from 6.38 percent.

HEADLINE: John J. Driscoll, 82, Is Dead; Led Connecticut Labor Council

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
John Joseph Driscoll, who served for 24 years as president of the Connecticut State Labor Council, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport. A Bridgeport resident, he was 82.
He suffered a brief illness, his family said. 
 Mr. Driscoll presided over his state's Labor Council -- representing the constituent unions of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations -- from 1961 until he retired in 1985. During that period he was considered one of Connecticut's most influential citizens.
But Mr. Driscoll resisted the title of Connecticut's "Mr. Labor" that was sometimes bestowed upon him and played down references to his power. "The only power I have is the power of persuasion," he said.
The son of Irish immigrants, he was born in Waterbury and graduated Phi Beta Kappa in philosophy from Wesleyan University, from which he also received a master's degree in English. Earlier, he had wanted to be an architect, but a year at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology convinced him that this talents lay elsewhere. After Wesleyan, a year at Harvard Law School left him with the same impression about law.
He had his first taste of labor at 17 working in a factory in Waterbury for the summer. He said the "horrendous" noise caused muscle spasms that disappeared only when he left the mill gate.
 
Familiar Figure in the Capitol
 Mr. Driscoll went to work in 1937 for 40 cents an hour at the Bristol Company in Waterbury. He was so good at organizing fellow workers that the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers hired him full time. He moved on to the C.I.O., the United Auto Workers and, finally, to the newly merged A.F.L.-C.I.O.
He became executive secretary of the State Labor Council in 1957 and was elected president four years later. After that, his slight figure and white mustache became as familiar in the Capitol corridors of Hartford as they were in union halls.
Mr. Driscoll served on the Governor's Council of Economic Advisers and on the state's first Commission for Higher Education. He often voiced concern that the rising fees at public colleges were shutting out the children of blue-collar families.
He was outspoken in his support of civil rights and marched in Selma, Ala., in 1965. As chief spokesman for his state's unionized labor, he was a delegate to five Democratic National Conventions.
His only serious challenge for re-election as head of the Labor Council came in 1983, but he won handily.
Mr. Driscoll is survived by his wife, Margaret Connors Driscoll, a retired Superior Court Judge; a son, David, of Bridgeport, and a grandson.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes With Losses After Day of Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar declined against leading currencies yesterday in quiet, largely technical dealings, as traders awaited the release of economic data and assessed last week's gains.
The dollar traded in a tight range throughout the day, with no significant new economic data or policy statements influencing dealers to buy or sell. Profit taking erased part of last week's advance against the German mark. On Friday, the dollar settled at its highest level against the mark in a month. 
 "Many people are on the sidelines for the time being," said David Durst, a vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company. "We've had crazy markets in the past few weeks. People are taking it all in, some licking their wounds and others taking profits."
The dollar was quoted in late New York trading at 1.5892 marks, down from 1.5985 late Friday.
The dollar fell to 98.60 Japanese yen, from 98.95.
Market participants said few dealers were willing to take new positions ahead of the Government's release later this week of economic data that could influence Federal Reserve action on interest rates.
Signs of inflation could prompt the Fed to raise short-term interest rates, which are currently lower than rates in Europe. That would lift the dollar both by attracting short-term deposits to American banks and by calming the inflation-wary American bond and stock markets, stimulating demand for dollar-denominated assets.
This week's data will include the July consumer confidence index to be released today by the Conference Board, a private research group. The Commerce Department reports June orders for durable goods tomorrow and second-quarter gross domestic product on Friday.
Mr. Durst of Bear, Stearns said traders were concerned about the G.D.P. report. "They're trying to get a feel for whether growth is going to be inflationary," he said. "That's putting things on hold."
Matt Porio, a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, said the dollar's surge against the mark last week after a monthlong slide "surprised a lot of people."
"The market wants to see whether this is real," he said.
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.3475 Swiss francs, down from 1.3560 on Friday; 5.4290 French francs, down from 5.4640; 1,578 Italian lire, down from 1,586, and $1.3778 (Canadian), up from $1.3768.
The British pound rose to $1.5305 from $1.5270.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Demands New Spending Cuts From All Agencies

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Barely a month after New York City adopted a budget with sharp cuts in spending, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered city agencies yesterday to make $250 million in additional cuts immediately and to prepare for the possibility of cutting yet another $200 million.
The $250 million cut, to be made over the six months that began July 1, represents an across-the-board reduction of about 2.6 percent for every city agency, including the Police and Fire Departments and the Board of Education. The move follows a reduction of 15,000 municipal jobs and program cuts of $1.1 billion already approved as part of the $31.6 billion budget. 
 Abraham M. Lackman, Mr. Giuliani's budget director, said the call for new cuts was prompted by an unexpected drop in state and city personal income tax collections in June, and by the possibility that the State Legislature might not reconvene in a special session this summer. Without state legislation, the city would not be able to implement initiatives that were supposed to save $70 million this year.
Mr. Lackman said it was also uncertain whether $200 million in additional Federal aid, promised by city representatives in Washington, would materialize.
Mr. Giuliani described his decision last night to order more spending cuts "as a management tool" and said that if the fiscal situation improves, it is possible "we'll be able to spend that money in the latter part of the year."
The actions came as New York State's Financial Control Board prepared to release a formal critique of Mr. Giuliani's budget this week. The report is expected to identify a number of risky fiscal assumptions in the Mayor's plan. The steps announced yesterday were more far-reaching than Mr. Giuliani's earlier pledge to the Financial Control Board to reduce spending in order to raise the city's reserves by at least $100 million.
 
Giuliani 'in Denial'
 But even as he acted yesterday, Mr. Giuliani criticized the state fiscal agency, whose executive director, Allen J. Proctor, had said Mr. Giuliani appeared "in denial" over the severity of the city's fiscal problems.
"As you solve one set of risks in ways in which they predicted we couldn't solve, they then move on to another set," Mr. Giuliani said.
The Mayor added: "Some of it is a complete misunderstanding of the way in which we are managing this budget, because it's never happened to them before. The Financial Control Board has never dealt with a city government that has actually reduced spending."
Mr. Lackman said the initial $250 million in savings would be held in a city reserve fund. He said the agencies would be asked to report on August 22 on how they would change their programs to manage the spending reductions. "I expect there will be significant head-count reductions," Mr. Lackman said.
The Mayor's order sends agencies from the city's welfare system, to the Parks Department, to the agency for the homeless scrambling once again to find ways to reduce spending at a time when most have not yet adjusted to the sudden loss of more than 6,000 workers through a severance buy-out offer in late spring.
"We have been through a tough budget process and I recognize how difficult it is to have to develop another program this early," Mr. Giuliani wrote in a memorandum to agency heads. "Nevertheless, we must ensure fiscal stability if we are to attain the goals we set forth for this fiscal year."
Mr. Lackman said that once the agencies report to him and the Mayor in late August, the administration would present a modification of the budget to the City Council for approval in September. He said that while a 2.6 percent across-the-board reduction would actually result in $290 million in cuts, the administration was leaving the Mayor some leeway to make choices and only relying on a net cut of $250 million.
While the Council overwhelmingly approved the budget in June, many members expressed misgivings at the time about the program reductions. Richard A. Riley, a spokesman for Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, said last night, "While we agree that the sooner you solve the problem, the better, the Council will be very concerned about where the cuts fall."
Mr. Riley added, "We think it's a good sign, though, that the Mayor has asked all agencies -- including police and fire, which had been held harmless in previous budget negotiations -- to make a significant contribution."
Mr. Lackman said that agencies could choose how they wanted to reach their budget targets, whether through job cuts, service reductions or finding ways to increase fee collections, without levying any new taxes. He said that if some agencies chose layoffs, it was possible that severance packages could be offered once again. He said that the city still had not spent $60 million of $200 million that the Municipal Assistance Corporation had made available earlier this year to pay for cash packages to lure city employees off the payroll.
Mr. Lackman said it would be clearer in the fall, when the Federal fiscal year begins, whether the second round of contingency cuts would be needed. He said city officials were uncertain whether the June drop in tax revenues was a one-time anomaly or a sign that the economy was not recovering as well as had been expected.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;
JORDAN AND ISRAEL JOIN IN PACT AIMED AT BROAD MIDEAST PEACE

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel today reached across 46 years of war, uneasy coexistence and furtive attempts at peace to sign a Washington Declaration ending the state of war between their nations.
As President Clinton sat beaming between them on a stage on the South Lawn of the White House, the two leaders also agreed to reaffirm King Hussein's role as guardian of Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem, a step intended by Israel to forestall Yasir Arafat's aspiration to claim that right for himself. 
 It is an open question whether today's declaration will lead to an early agreement between Israel and Syria, the last major holdout among the Middle East belligerents.
In practice, Jordan and Israel have functioned for years as civil neighbors. But on a day that marked the first time their leaders have ever met in public, the sweep and detail of their accord appeared to have surprised even the principal participants.
"Out of all the days of my life, I do not believe there is one such as this," King Hussein said in a voice quiet with emotion after Mr. Clinton escorted him into the Rose Garden to join Mr. Rabin at a welcoming ceremony.
The leaders perched themselves three abreast on a stage on the South Lawn at the same 19th-century desk at which Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat initialed the accord between Israel and the P.L.O. on the same lawn last fall. The occasion today was warmed with so many handclasps and grins of delight that what might have been a stiff encounter was transformed instead into a celebration of hope that the Middle East conflict might at last be entering its final days.
"It is dusk at our homes in the Middle East," Mr. Rabin declared just before he and King Hussein picked up their pens to sign the 11-page accord. "Soon darkness will prevail. But the citizens of Israel and Jordan will see a great light."
In fact, the accord is just one step on a long and tortuous road, as was evident by the telephone call that Mr. Clinton placed to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria soon after the signing. Administration officials expressed new hope today that the improvement in Israeli-Jordanian ties will nudge Mr. Assad along a more conciliatory path, but aides said Mr. Clinton had taken pains to reassure the Syrian leader that the United States was not trying to isolate him.
At the same time, while King Hussein has expressed hope that a final deal between Israel and Jordan could be reached by year's end, it remains unclear how willing he will be to complete a peace treaty if his powerful Syrian neighbor remains stubborn in opposition.
With his move toward accommodation with Israel today, King Hussein has also made himself a likely target for Muslim extremists. (The King, then a 16-year-old, was with his grandfather, King Abdullah, when he was assassinated by a Palestinian militant in 1951 in Jerusalem.)
But as King Hussein stood today at the side of Mr. Rabin, who commanded Israeli forces in the 1967 war that cost Jordan the West Bank, the King declared that he and the Prime Minister would now meet "as often as we are able and as required to shepherd this process."
Officials from all three countries taking part today said the extensive terms of the declaration reflected the substantial progress made by their representatives in hurried preparatory talks that began on the Israeli-Jordanian border last Monday.
"After generations of hostility, blood and tears and in the wake of pain and wars," the Washington Declaration began, "His Majesty King Hussein and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin are determined to end to bloodshed and sorrow."
 
A Message for Arafat
 The language that guarantees "high priority" to maintaining King Hussein's "special role" in administering the Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem was proposed by Israel last week, officials here said, after Mr. Arafat declared that if the King wanted to visit Jerusalem, he should seek Mr. Arafat's approval in advance.
Israeli officials said they wanted the Palestinian leader to understand that when it comes to the status of Al Aksa Mosque and other Islamic holy sites in East Jerusalem, they will deal with the Jordanian leader, as they have since Israeli troops occupied all of Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East war.
While that is bound to anger Mr. Arafat, Secretary of State Warren Christopher described the statement today as simply "a recognition of the reality of Jordan's responsibility for the religious shrines."
"I don't think it should cause any trouble," Mr. Christopher said.
Beyond that sensitive issue and their formal agreement to end the state of war and move toward a full peace treaty, the two leaders agreed immediately to take a number of unexpected steps to cement their closer ties.
They pledged that their police forces would cooperate to combat crime, that both countries would seek to discourage economic boycotts, and that they would quickly establish direct telephone links, a shared electricity grid, new border crossings and easy passage for tourists.
 
Making Friends From Foes
 Several times in the document, the two leaders paid homage to the instrumental role played by Mr. Clinton, who looked on like a proud father all day and signed the document as a witness.
In turn, their host welcomed King Hussein and Mr. Rabin to the White House by quoting from both the Koran and the Talmud in tribute to the virtue of making friends from foes.
"Before us today stand friends," Mr. Clinton said, "and heroes."
The ceremonies in the Rose Garden and on the South Lawn were the first in an extraordinary series of joint public appearances here by Mr. Rabin and King Hussein, who have met before, but always in secret.
They strode with Mr. Clinton across Pennsylvania Avenue for a working lunch at Blair House, the official guest residence, then returned to the White House to join the President, Hillary Rodham Clinton and 130 guests at a black-tie dinner.
On Tuesday, they will become the first pair of foreign leaders ever to address a joint meeting of Congress, then will return to the White House for a news conference with Mr. Clinton.
As their host, Mr. Clinton, whose foreign-affairs troubles remain the greatest weight on his popularity ratings, was able today to bask in some of the glory of a foreign policy gone right.
He described the gathering this afternoon as one that had come "to bear witness to history," and recalled not only the Camp David accords of 1979, when President Jimmy Carter brokered an Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, and the renewed quest for peace that was begun by President George Bush, but also "that shining September day last year" when he watched as Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat signed their accord.
"As this century draws to a close," Mr. Clinton said, "a new era of peace opens before us in ancient lands as brave men choose reconciliation over conflict."
A slow-motion depiction of the famous handshake between Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat is already a centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's political fund-raising videotape, and aides said today that they did not doubt that the Israeli-Jordanian version would be given a similar place. But while Mr. Clinton again positioned himself at its center, today's first handclasp between Mr. Rabin and King Hussein needed none of last fall's encouragement.
Instead, an aura of warmth and confidence suffused each touch and glance between the long-declared adversaries, whose wives sat side by side with Mrs. Clinton during the ceremonies and who themselves wandered through the Rose Garden this morning to make introductions, as King Hussein did in presenting Mr. Rabin to two of his young sons.

HEADLINE: THE MIDEAST ACCORD: THE IMPACT;
2 Neighbors Agree: Now It Can Be Told

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
There is a saying in the Talmud that the Messiah will come when he is no longer needed. And so peace between Jordan and Israel is coming because it already exists.
King Hussein of Jordan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel did not need much coaxing to come together publicly for the first time today and sign a declaration ending the state of war between their countries. 
 They based their diplomatic breakthrough on a recognition of their mutual self-interest and on the comfort that what they were doing was endorsed by their peoples.
The ceremony at the White House today was different from the high-anxiety encounter last September between Mr. Rabin and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. That was a forced marriage between two lifelong foes who had been wishing each other dead for years.
By contrast, today's event was more like a sedate engagement between longtime neighbors who knew they had a lot in common, had secretly cooperated for years and now, in this new era in the Middle East, could finally allow their relationship to flourish in the light of day.
The body language said it all. When Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat held their public reconciliation, Mr. Clinton used his long arms to nudge them into a handshake. With Mr. Rabin and King Hussein, Mr. Clinton was a proud witness who stood by with his arms at his sides as the Israeli Prime Minister and the Jordanian King repeatedly pumped hands in front of him.
Israel and Jordan have more or less coexisted in a cold peace since the 1967 war, when Israel captured the Sinai Peninsula from Egypt, the Golan Heights from Syria and the West Bank and East Jerusalem from Jordan. King Hussein concluded that the war had been a disaster for the Arab world, and in 1973, when Syria and Egypt moved against Israel, the King sent a symbolic division of troops out of Arab solidarity, but much too late to make a difference.
The euphoria today was palpable. There at the White House stood Mr. Rabin, who was chief of staff of the Israeli Army when it defeated the armies of Egypt, Syria and Jordan in 1967, alongside King Hussein, a descendant of the prophet Mohammed who had lost the holy places of Jerusalem to Israel in that war.
At one point Mr. Clinton told his aides how he was struck "by the personal warmth between them and how they couldn't talk enough together."
It took the peace agreement between the Israelis and the Palestinians both to free King Hussein and to force him to accelerate the pace of his peacemaking with Israel. Suddenly the Palestinians were making peace on their own. The King, whose country's population is some 80 percent Palestinian, was freed from the responsibility for the fate of the Palestinian people and their claim to Israeli-occupied land.
He was also confronted with the prospect that the Palestinians would reap the benefits of peace in the Israeli-occupied territories without him. President Hafez al-Assad of Syria was holding back, but other Arab leaders were moving forward to receive Israeli cabinet aides and beginning to negotiate joint economic projects.
 
It Is, After All, the Economy
 What finally impelled the King was his concern about economic security.
He saw the value of the Jordanian dinar, the main currency in the West Bank and Gaza, fall as Palestinian autonomy took hold, and he saw the uncertainty that the decline engendered about Jordan's economic future there. He saw the Agency for International Development break ground for a $12 million housing project for Palestinians living in Gaza.
When Mr. Clinton told the King during a meeting at the White House last month that he would press Congress to forgive Jordan's $700 million debt with the United States if Jordan took a bold step toward peace, it was just the nudge the King needed.
The declaration signed today does not complete agreement over some basic issues: how to share scarce water resources, the final border between Israel and Jordan, the Palestinian refugees in Jordan. Those details will have to wait, although both sides are confident a final settlement will come within the next few months.
 
Shaping a Peace
 But the accord illustrates how the two sides are shaping the peace by immediately setting into motion practical measures and by breaking down important barriers to Israel's lingering pariah status in the Middle East.
Callers in Jerusalem will be able to telephone Amman, for example; the electricity grids of the two countries will be linked; two new border crossings will be opened; Jordanian and Israeli police will cooperate to combat crime.
"This is a situation where the economics of it may be driving the politics of it," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in an interview on Sunday. His aides acknowledge that Mr. Christopher's whirlwind tour last week of the Nabatean ruins at Petra, where Steven Spielberg filmed the last scenes of "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade," was largely aimed at encouraging American tourism.
 
Returning to Diplomatic Fold
 Today's event also symbolizes King Hussein's redemption in the eyes of Washington. This was the man who tacitly supported Saddam Hussein after the Iraqi leader invaded Kuwait, calling him "an Arab patriot." The king opposed the deployment of United States troops in Saudi Arabia and enraged President George Bush, who told intimates he felt betrayed by a "friend" whose signed photos hung in the residential quarters of the White House.
The only crucial player still awaiting redemption is Mr. Assad.
Last week Mr. Christopher described the Syrian as "relaxed" about the Jordanian-Israeli meeting, and Mr. Christopher was said to be heartened that during one of their meetings, Mr. Assad spoke approvingly of Mr. Clinton's statement last January that if all parties did not take advantage of every opportunity for peace, their children and grandchildren will not forgive them.
Administration officials also note that the predictions that Mr. Assad would challenge Mr. Arafat's legitimacy did not come true. The officials are so intent on keeping Mr. Assad moving forward that Mr. Christopher plans to return to the Mideast in early August.
And Mr. Assad cannot be happy that King Hussein, like Mr. Arafat last September, was welcomed at the White House while Syria is subject to economic sanctions and remains on the State Department's list of nations supporting terrorism.
Thus, the "new landscape" in the Middle East that Mr. Christopher talks about so glowingly still has vast areas of rough terrain.

HEADLINE: Rule Pumps Dollars Into Decayed Housing

BYLINE: ADAM NOSSITER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, July 25

 BODY:
Roofless buildings yawning to the sky, gaping windows without glass, inside walls stripped to rough planks, outside walls pitted with holes: it isn't the emptiness of the Desire public housing development that is disconcerting, but the presence of any residents at all. About 3,000 people live in a project that was designed for more than twice that number.
In March, the Inspector General for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Susan Gaffney, told Congress that renovating the isolated 97-acre reservation for the poor would cost $14 million more than tearing it down and starting over. Yet work is under way on a renovation plan that is expected to cost $90 million to $100 million. The housing agency has already approved the first $12 million. 
 The project, which is on the street immortalized by Tennessee Williams in his play "A Streetcar Named Desire," is a case study of what critics say is an irrationality of the Federal housing policy, one that has also affected cities like Newark, Cleveland and Washington. The root of the problem, the critics say, is a Federal housing agency policy that funnels large sums of money into decrepit apartments but provides little for new construction, and a law requiring that for every demolished apartment, a new unit be built, to keep the supply from dwindling.
This "one-for-one" law seems particularly irrational in New Orleans, which has the highest housing vacancy rate in the country, 16.6 percent, the Census Bureau says.
On Friday, the House overwhelmingly approved a bill that would revise the policy and ease the law. It would allow the demolition of the most decrepit public housing while freeing money designated for renovation to build new apartments. A housing bill is also before the Senate but it does not discuss the "one-for-one" law.
A leader in the drive for the House legislation was Representative Collin C. Peterson, Democrat of Minnesota, who toured Desire this year, and cited the project as an example of waste produced by the current policy. Mr. Peterson is the chairman of a House subcommittee on housing.
In the grim universe of decaying housing projects, Desire is "probably one of the worst in the country," a district inspector general for the housing agency, D. Michael Beard, said in a recent interview. Mr. Beard was in charge of an agency audit of the New Orleans Housing Authority completed last month.
The sprawling complex of two-story barracks-like buildings, built from 1953 to 1956, sits atop a landfill that was once a swamp. The ground is sinking beneath it, so that in many places porches have fallen away.
 
Exodus Began a Decade Ago
 Since the early 1980's, when Desire was almost full, residents have been moving out steadily as the project deteriorated and violence grew. The project is about 58 percent vacant. Of the 810 households there, 745 are headed by single women.
The project, two miles east of the French Quarter, is cut off from the rest of the city by two sets of railroad tracks, the New Orleans Industrial Canal and acres of warehouses and factories.
The complex was deliberately built of wooden frames, susceptible to the area's high humidity, as opposed to concrete and masonry, because the Federal Public Housing Administration, as it was known then, said it wanted to save money. It was built "as a colored project," according to the housing agency report completed last month, and only blacks still live there.
 
Violence Amid Wreckage
 Today, some of the apartments look as if they have been pillaged by marauding armies. Remains of plaster walls lie heaped on rotting wood floors. Vandals have taken everything, down to the window frames and copper piping.
There were 86 murders in the complex from 1989 to 1993, more than in any of the city's other housing projects in the same period, even though some of the others are larger.
But even before the first tenants moved to Desire, a public housing tenants' association report called it a "waste of public money" and "unsafe for human habitation." Those words have echoed through the years and were heard yet again as the New Orleans Housing Authority considered the renovation.
In addition to the public housing laws, the pride of local housing officials and some of the tenants were behind the renovation. "The neighborhood should exist," said Shelia Danzey, manager of the New Orleans Housing Authority. "It's like preservationists saying these 1832 houses should exist."
Ms. Danzey also questioned the credentials of the independent consulting concern that advised against rebuilding Desire, even though it is the same one hired by her agency in 1990. The concern, EA Technical Services Inc. of Atlanta, said renovating the project was neither "viable or feasible."
The decision by the New Orleans housing authority to push the renovation plan was essential for getting it approved by Federal officials. Yet the Federal audit of the New Orleans agency called its operations "inefficient, ineffective and uneconomical."
Joseph Shuldiner, the Assistant Secretary for public and Indian housing, said of the renovation plan, "There are legitimate questions here, but in our judgment they didn't outweigh the official policy of going along with the local request."
 
$12 Million Commitment
 In the first phase of the renovation, about $12 million has been awarded to the Rex K. Johnson Company, a Lampasas, Tex., concern that specialized in public housing work, to rebuild about 180 apartments. They have been redesigned as town houses, with each apartment having its own access to the street.
The overall plan calls for spending $71,000 to $78,000 for each apartment, which exceeds the housing agency's own spending limit for a new apartment by as much as 37 percent. The amount being spent to renovate each apartment could buy comfortable three-bedroom dwellings in many parts of New Orleans.
Under the renovation plan, a third of Desire's 1,800 apartments would be demolished and the rest would be gutted and rebuilt. The tenants would remain during the renovation. To conform to the one-for-one rule, for each Desire apartment demolished the housing authority will subsidize the rents for the same number of apartments.
 
Law Behind the Rebuilding
 In 1987, the tide had long since turned against construction of big public housing projects when Congress mandated that every housing unit torn down had to be replaced with a new one. In practice, the rule forced local authorities to leave deteriorating housing projects standing.
In addition to limiting money for new constructions, the housing rules bar new developments in areas that already have large poor and minority populations. Neighborhood opposition to new public housing is often intense.
For the current fiscal year, Congress appropriated $559 million for new housing against $3.2 billion for renovation. It also appropriated $7 billion for rental vouchers to be used for private housing. But there are limits on the number of vouchers that can be used to replace housing that has been demolished.
 
Rules Leave Empty Projects
 The national landscape is littered with decaying, empty housing projects. Newark has long wanted to demolish 21 high-rise apartments. The one-for-one rule made this difficult, so the city's housing authority received $17 million in Federal housing operating subsidies for closed and sealed buildings from 1985 to 1992, enabling the authority to accumulate reserves of $31 million and "become financially sound," in Inspector General Gaffney's words.
The Cuyahoga Housing Authority in Cleveland has received $47.3 million in operating subsidies for vacant units since 1987, and the Washington authority $5.5 million in 1992.
These accounts of subsidies for empty apartments, recited in March before Mr. Peterson's subcommittee, led to the legislation passed on Friday. It would allow all local housing officials to use up to half their renovation money for new housing. It would also allow them to ask the Federal housing agency to waive the rule requiring one new housing unit for each one demolished if it interfered with the development of new public housing.
An amendment to the bill would also allow New Orleans housing officials to use money designated for the renovation of the Desire in other ways, including renovating some of the city's many vacant dwellings for housing the Desire tenants.
The new Mayor of New Orleans, Marc Morial, who inherited the Desire renovation plan, says he supports the amendment that would give the city more discretion with its Federal housing money. He suggested that some of the $100 million may be better spent repairing the city's many abandoned houses, some of them with distinctive Creole architectural features still intact. But he said he wanted the first phase of the Desire renovation to be completed.
At Desire, there is suspicion of politicians, anger about the conditions and, in some residents, no interest at all in moving somewhere else. Charlene Slack, for one is glad to see the construction crews. "I'm happy about it," she said. "But I wish they would hurry up."
Bonnie Rodgers, vice chairman of the tenant council, said: "Don't send us somewhere else. Let us change where we live."
But others don't see much hope in change. Penny Jones stood by the rotting wood of her kitchen floor, near the bathroom where the sink was coming off the wall, and by the stairwell that looked like an elongated piece of Swiss cheese.
"I think they should tear it all down," she said. The summer heat had aggravated the stink of the sewage beneath her building, she said. Indeed, the Atlanta consulting firm found that the "subsidence of the soil has caused continuous problems with the sewer and water systems."
There were a "million" mice in the apartment. "They need to just tear it all down and start from scratch," Ms. Jones said. "They can fix it up. I don't care. I'm going to move."

HEADLINE: Polish Posters, Briefly Derailed, Are Back on Track

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, July 25

 BODY:
In the Communist era, Poland's poster artists were among the world's most acclaimed as they turned out graphically distinctive and politically bold designs. From the uneven red lettering on a white background that became the famous signature for the Solidarity movement in the 1980's to vivid cultural motifs that often used sly visual metaphors, Polish posters were collected and admired in Europe and the United States for their inventiveness.
After a lean four years since the Communists fell, the Polish poster is back, along with works from other nations, at the 14th Warsaw Poster Biennale, where 425 entries are on display. A Japanese artist, Mitsuo Katsui, won first prize in the main category of the competition with a hotly disputed entry created with computers. Poster collectors complained that the gaily colored abstract pattern held no message and was executed as a single copy instead of in multiples, as usual. 
 A Polish graphic artist, Mieczyslaw Wasilewski, a former gold medalist in the Biennale, came in second with a stark black Star of David burning in white flames. Designed to commemorate last year's 50th anniversary of the uprising by Polish Jews against the Nazis in the Warsaw ghetto, the poster pleased Polish poster aficionados because it reflected the strong heritage of Polish design.
And Henryk Tomaszewski, the grand eminence of Polish poster art, who is now in his 80's, won a bronze medal in the advertising section for his amusing yet simple piece, which was designed to advertise his own 1991 show of posters at an Amsterdam museum. The poster has the word "love" in quirky black type on a white background.
The Biennale, which was canceled two years ago when the post-Communist cultural administrators could not decide where it should be held, has traditionally attracted big crowds of European poster collectors. In the past the show was at the National Gallery in the center of Warsaw. This year, it is being held at the Poster Museum, on the grounds of a 17th-century Baroque royal palace on the city's outskirts. Though the Poster Museum has two halls, the entries are squeezed together with barely an inch between the frames.
The hiatus in the Biennale reflected a troubled period for Polish poster artists and revealed one of the many paradoxes of the changes after Communism. With the coming of a market economy and freedom of expression, poster artists, whose Polish income was from Government sponsored cultural assignments, found it harder than ever to make a living.
"This is because their kind of art doesn't produce money," said Mariusz Knorowski, the assistant curator of the Poster Museum. "Real artists don't want to produce for toothpaste companies."
And as the cities here became ablaze with bright, Western-style billboards hawking everything from sodas to underwear, the more discreetly sized poster with less brazen images seemed crowded out.
Waldemar Swierzy, a well-established poster artist who works in a studio in Warsaw's Old Town and is a professor of art at the University of Poznan, has been attracting overseas commissions for many years. But he liked to complement this international work, mostly devoted to poster portraits of jazz and rock musicians, with home-grown assignments.
"In the past there were 22 theaters in Poland, each had eight premiers," Mr. Swierzy said. "And there were 250 movies, Polish and foreign, that would be shown, and we'd make posters for them. Now the theaters do posters less frequently because the printing costs are expensive. Now most films are imported, and they bring the art with them."
As for new Western advertising agencies in Warsaw: "They are not commissioning us," he said, meaning the big names of Polish poster art. "They pay little and hire younger people."
Mr. Swierzy entered three posters in this year's Biennale, including a silhouette of Thelonious Monk that is a part of a series on jazz musicians. The first jazz posters were commissioned by the Polish Jazz Foundation, but now European jazz organizations ask him to create posters for special events. They sell particularly well in France, he said.
The Biennale is accompanied by the publication of a book called "The 100th Anniversary of Polish Poster Art" edited by Poland's foremost poster collector, Krzysztof Dydo, who runs a private poster gallery in Cracow. He owns about 25,000 posters, most of them Polish.
The book traces the Polish poster from the 1890's, when the influence of Toulouse-Lautrec was clear, to the 1930's, when Art Nouveau travel posters were popular, and through the Communist era. It ends with the beginnings of the post-Communist period. One of the most intriguing periods was the 1950's, when poster artists entered into what Mr. Knorowski calls an "unofficial contract" with the Communist Government. The artists made posters in the Social Realism style, extolling the system by showing smiling women carrying cement trowels and men with pickaxes slung over their shoulders. This pact enabled poster artists to work and to create posters for cultural events in which they could sometimes make allusions to the grim living conditions, Mr. Knorowski said.
In those days, Mr. Tomaszewski was able to show obliquely that May 1, the Communist Labor Day, was not the time of euphoria that the regime's propaganda described. In a now famous example of this lack of enthusiasm for the supposed worker's paradise, Mr. Tomaszewski drew a poster that displayed only half a tractor (the machine was drawn at the edge of the canvas so only the end showed) and a few cherry tree branches and a piece of the Polish flag.
"For those days it was close to parody," Mr. Knorowski said.
Mr. Tomaszewski remains one of the few graphic artists of the postwar period to have stayed in Poland. Others left in the 1960's and 70's, weary of the political situation. Several of them live in the United States.
For poster historians like Mr. Knorowski and Mr. Dydo, Mr. Tomaszewski remains the favorite, not only because he stayed behind but also because he is seen as a purist.
"He is always the most intellectual," Mr. Knorowski said, "he always leaves something to think about and usually he is hiding something."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Land of the Free but Also a Home of the Bigoted

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG 

 BODY:
Behind the Mask of Chivalry
The Making of the Second Ku Klux Klan
By Nancy MacLean
Illustrated. 292 pages. Oxford University Press. $30.
 
Anti-Semitism in America
By Leonard Dinnerstein
369 pages. Oxford University Press. $25.
It's appropriate to link Nancy Mac Lean's "Behind the Mask of Chivalry," about the Ku Klux Klan, and Leonard Dinnerstein's "Anti-Semitism in America" because racial and religious bigotries are companions. Historically, they are rooted in ignorance and intolerance. Both books suggest that old-fashioned demagogy has surfaced in new forms in American politics and broadcasting. 
 The framers of the Constitution placed the First Amendment clause against establishing a national religion ahead of even the one that assures freedom of the press. But listening to spokesmen for the religious and radical right on the hustings and on the radio, you would not believe that the First Amendment's anti-establishment clause existed. Political hopefuls of the religious and radical right profess to speak for the one true American way, but their way clashes with what President George Washington told the elders of Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I., about religious liberty in the new United States: "To bigotry, no sanction."
Professor MacLean, who teaches history at Northwestern University, confines her book to the second coming of the Klan, in the 1920's. Its members weren't quite like the original night riders, who flourished during Reconstruction, perpetuating white supremacy. The estimated three million dues-paying members who joined the Klan after World War I were neighborly men and women, Professor MacLean says. But, the author adds, they believed that "Catholics were stockpiling weapons to take over the country, that a cabal of Jewish bankers controlled world affairs, and that white people must ready themselves for an imminent race war with people of color."
The second Klan was out in the open. During its heyday, families marched in parades, patronized only Klan merchants and voted for Klan-endorsed political candidates. The members were less interested in the lynchings that were performed by their criminal element than in winning elections. The Klan was particularly strong in Indiana, Oklahoma, Oregon and the Deep South.
In its most original chapters, "Behind the Mask of Chivalry" concentrates on the activities of Klan No. 5 in Athens, Ga., the home of the University of Georgia. The author sifted through the chapter's records and found membership rosters, propaganda tracts and correspondence. The men of property and social power who made up the local economic elite were less likely to join the Klan than were clerical workers, small-business owners, independent professionals and farmers.
Professor MacLean briefly mentions the success a few years ago of David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Klan, in using elections to build a following, but she then drops the subject and has little to say about the Klan's modern ideological soul mates in mufti on the far right. "Behind the Mask of Chivalry" is too narrowly drawn to have significance for readers seeking parallels to the national political arena today.
Professor Dinnerstein, who teaches history at the University of Arizona, gives the subject of American anti-Semitism a grand overview, from its colonial origins to the present. Along the way, he doesn't pull any punches about the forces in and outside churches who keep the theme of Jewish villainy alive.
The author finds that the hostility toward Jews was brought to the New World by the first settlers, instilled by Christian teachings and reinforced by successive waves of Protestants and Roman Catholics. He writes that an ancestral European Christian obsession with Jews became "an irrevocable part of the American heritage." Yet he notes that in recent years, the Roman Catholic Church has been in the vanguard of trying to change attitudes toward the Jewish people: "Not only did Pope John XXIII inaugurate a new emphasis on interfaith dialogue, but the Second Vatican Council specifically 'exonerated' Jews for Christ's death."
At times, Professor Dinnerstein makes the situation sound worse than it may have been for many Jews across the country. "From the end of the Civil War until the beginning of the 20th century, the United States witnessed the emergence of a full-fledged anti-Semitic society," he writes in one sweeping statement. "Like the hysteria exhibited during the war, the institutionalized bigotry that developed afterward reflected the biases of practically every stratum in society. As immigration figures soared, and as a significant Jewish presence emerged in the United States, people in every walk of life, from respectable working, middle and upper classes to agrarian protesters, Protestant and Catholic spokesmen, and members of the lunatic fringe increasingly focused on the allegedly deleterious characteristics of Jews that they believed impinged on American lives."
Such a judgment makes the reader wonder why, if a "full-fledged anti-Semitic society" existed here, so many millions of Jews chose to immigrate to the United States in the first quarter of the 20th century. After all, as full-fledged American citizens, Jews were allowed to enter colleges (albeit with quotas), make their way in most (though not all) businesses and professions, own property (almost anywhere), vote by secret ballot and practice their religion freely, just like Christian immigrants.
Professor Dinnerstein brings his account up to the moment with a discussion of anti-Semitic comments by Louis Farrakhan and Leonard Jeffries. Aware that Jews have been in the vanguard of the civil-rights movement, and that some died for the cause of black freedom in the Deep South, the author points out that enlightened black leaders have said they want to stop black anti-Semitism, but that it could take several generations before centuries-old beliefs are eradicated.
"Anti-Semitism in America" ends on a half-hopeful note: "By comparing the strength of anti-Semitism in the United States today with what it had been in previous decades or centuries, the obvious conclusion is that it has declined in potency and will continue to do so for the foreseeable future." It's a challenging book that deserves attention.

HEADLINE: El Nino Said to Predict Rain and Crops in Africa

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
FLUCTUATING sea-surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean can reliably predict both rainfall and corn harvests halfway around the world in Africa, scientists have found, in a discovery that may offer a powerful new tool for agricultural planners.
Climatologists say they are able to forecast with some confidence the two-to-seven-year oscillations in Pacific temperatures, associated with the phenomenon known as El Nino, that set off long-distance atmospheric chain reactions which influence climatic conditions in many parts of the globe. The new findings suggest that these predictions can be used to forecast crop conditions in Africa as much as a year in advance, enabling planners to anticipate and cope better with droughts and shortened rainy seasons. 
 Reporting in the current issue of the British journal Nature, scientists in the United States and Zimbabwe say they have established a statistical correlation of "astonishing" strength between the temperature cycle in the Pacific and rainfall and corn yields in Zimbabwe. Similar links have previously been discerned in Australia and Peru. But both those countries are close to the gigantic pool of Pacific water where El Nino fluctuations take place, while the new link spans much of the world.
The researchers found that between 1973 and 1990, Zimbabwean rainfall and corn yields fluctuated in lock step with the oscillating surface temperatures in the tropical Pacific, dropping in years when the temperatures were above normal (El Nino event) and rising in years when the temperatures dropped below normal (La Nina event).
Since El Nino's influence is global, the scientists wrote in Nature, "it may be rewarding to search for similarly predictable food crops in other vulnerable areas of the world."
 
Early Warning of Droughts
 The scientists are Dr. Mark A. Cane and Dr. Gidon Eshel of Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory and Roger W. Buckland of the 10-nation Southern African Development Community's Food Security Technical and Administrative Unit in Harare, Zimbabwe. Dr. Cane, an oceanographer, climatologist and pioneer in the making of El Nino predictions, and Dr. Eshel, an oceanographer, are authorities on climate. Mr. Buckland is an agricultural economist.
The researchers were surprised, Dr. Eshel said in an interview, to find that the correlation between the cycle of El Nino-La Nina and crop yields was even stronger than that for rainfall. This means, he said, that crop yields respond to other factors in addition to rainfall, and that those factors are also linked to El Nino oscillations. He speculated that these factors might include the distribution of rain during the rainy season or even the population of field mice, but acknowledged that "we don't have a very good handle" on the precise mechanisms.
Corn is Zimbabwe's most important food crop, and it was devastated in 1991 and 1992 by the worst drought in this century in southern Africa. The drought was not anticipated, leading to greater agony and higher relief costs than might have been the case had there been a warning.
Now, "an effective early warning system is in place," Dr. Cynthia Rosenzweig wrote in a commentary in Nature. "Next time we will be better able to anticipate and react early to minimize the cost and the damage." The potential for warning farmers in advance of drought "brings science, literally, right down to ground level," wrote Dr. Rosenzweig, an agronomist at Columbia University and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goddard Institute for Space Studies in New York and an expert on the relationship between climate and agriculture.
The study is important, she said in an interview, because it shows that scientists who use computer models to predict El Nino fluctuations "have come far enough along in the predictive work that they are really ready to go work with the agronomists and agricultural planners to really move into an operational mode."
 
Help for Farmers
 This year, for instance, the annual rains in southern Africa ended prematurely, leading to a poor corn crop, said Mr. Buckland. "With adequate warning," he said, "farmers could shift to short-maturing varieties or to sorghum and millet." But he said "a lot of development work" lies ahead "before we can use the data with any confidence."
Dr. Rosenzweig noted that the study involves only one variable, rainfall, and applies to only one part of the world. Bigger strides in agricultural forecasting will come when more variables are included and the reach of this kind of analysis becomes global, she said.
El Nino, recognized for some time as a major global weather-maker, is emerging as the most important element in climate variability and its effect on human activities, Dr. Rosenzweig said. Climatologists have had somewhat better success in predicting El Nino's fluctuations a year or so in advance than might be expected for such a relatively long period.
But the predictions are not perfect. Forecasters failed, for instance, to forecast that El Nino that began in 1991 would last for nearly three years. Still, the forecasters say, they can gauge with fair accuracy the probability that a warm El Nino phase or cold La Nina phase will develop, and when.

HEADLINE: Filling In the Peace Map

 BODY:
Israel and Jordan moved the map of a peaceful Middle East a large step closer to completion yesterday when they agreed to end 46 years of formal belligerency and begin normalizing their relations. A peace treaty is still months away, but already the two countries are ready to resolve concrete issues like boundaries and water rights, open direct telephone communications across the Jordan and work together against what remains of the Arab economic boycott.
President Clinton rightly placed this Washington Declaration in the sequence that began with the Camp David agreements with Egypt and included last September's accords with the Palestine Liberation Organization. For the first time in Israel's history, most of its borders are peaceful. Only Syria and Lebanon remain without agreements, and progress on those fronts may not be far off. 
 Israel's accords with the P.L.O. made it both possible and urgent for King Hussein to move ahead. Possible because Jordan, with a large Palestinian population of its own, cannot now be accused of dealing behind the back of the P.L.O. Urgent to protect Jordan's economic position in the West Bank and religious rights in Jerusalem from rival Arab claims.
Jordan's Hashemite rulers have been more nuanced in their relations with Israel than Egypt under President Nasser or the P.L.O. before Yasir Arafat embraced diplomacy and peace. Yet Jordanian armies fought Israel in 1948 and 1967. Now King Hussein, who claims descent from the Prophet Mohammed, and Yitzhak Rabin, who made his name as a soldier in Israel's wars for survival, have openly taken the path to peace.
Yesterday's declaration is fresh evidence that the Middle East is adapting to the changed environment after the cold war. Religious and territorial rivalries may have been at the heart of the conflict, but superpower competition encouraged both sides to pursue military rather than diplomatic strategies. After the Gaza-Jericho agreement in May, Jordan felt it could no longer afford to stay aloof. Peace with Syria and Lebanon will be harder, but yesterday's declaration will increase the pressure on President Hafez al-Assad, who speaks for both countries, to make a deal.
King Hussein, who saw his grandfather murdered 43 years ago for deviating from the solid Arab front against Israel, would not have taken the risks he now accepts unless he believed that Syria and Saudi Arabia, for all their protests about a "separate peace," would not retaliate against Jordan. His country is financially and militarily vulnerable to outside pressure, all the more so after it alienated the U.S., Saudi Arabia and their allies by opposing the forcible expulsion of Iraq from Kuwait.
Any residual American coolness toward Jordan over that episode should be put to rest by yesterday's declaration. Prime Minister Rabin himself will now urge Congress to approve the $700 million debt forgiveness measure for Jordan that the Clinton Administration seeks. By heeding his plea, Congress can reinforce Jordan's initiative for peace and encourage Syria and Lebanon to complete the new map of Middle East peace.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Roper Starch Buys Crossley Surveys

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
Roper Starch Worldwide Inc., a marketing, public opinion and advertising research company in Mamaroneck, N.Y., has acquired the Crossley Surveys division of Westat Inc. in New York. Though terms were not disclosed, Roper Starch said last week that it had paid cash. 
 Crossley, which has nine employees, will be merged into Roper Starch's New York office. Staats Abrams, 61, senior vice president of Crossley, continues in that role at Roper Starch. Crossley Surveys has clients like Eli Lilly and AT& T to be added to Roper Starch's clients like Anheuser-Busch, Colgate-Palmolive and Business Week magazine.

HEADLINE: Kitchen-Sink Bonds: Paine Webber's $180 Million Misstep

BYLINE: By LESLIE EASTON AND PATRICK J. LYONS

 BODY:
Few investors would deliberately buy toxic waste. But a lot of them ended up owning the Wall Street equivalent, because they -- or their mutual funds -- bought what are called kitchen-sink bonds.
 Last Friday, Paine Webber Group said it would spend $180 million to buy two of these issues from its troubled Short-Term U.S. Government Securities Fund, which has fallen by more than 7 percent this year, far more than similar funds. The bonds made up about a quarter of the fund's assets. 
 If the brokerage manages to sell these bonds within the next two years, any profits will go into the mututal fund, said Thomas F. Eggers, managing director of marketing and sales for Paine Webber fund group.
 But making a profit may not be easy. Paine Webber told regulators it had not been able to get any other investors to bid on the bonds, whose names are a mouthful: Fund America Investors Corporation II and Fannie Mae Guaranteed Remic Pass-Through Certificate-Remic Trust 1994-74.
 Why? "It turns out kitchen-sink bonds are so complicated and backed by so many pieces of collateral that they are nearly not subject to analysis," said James I. Midanek, chief investment officer of Solon Asset Management in Walnut Creek, Calif. "We just aren't going to be able to figure this out if we look at it for the rest of our lives."
 Each kitchen-sink bond is different. "You can't compare one to another," said Paul D. Kaplan, senior vice president of the Wellington Management Company. But they all follow the basic recipe shown here. And they all share an Achille's heel: When interest rates move sharply, the assumptions they are built on go out the window, and so do the bonds' values. LESLIE EASTON AND PATRICK J. LYONS

GRAPHIC: Chart: WHERE THEY COME FROM
 
1 -- Instead of keeping mortgages on the books until maturity as most banks used to do, today banks and other mortgage lenders gather the notes they hold from borrowers and sell them to an investment banking house or an agency like Ginnie Mae or Freddie Mac in exchange for cash that can be used to write more new mortgages.
 
2 -- The buyer of the mortgages bundles them into a large pool, which is known as a "pass-through" because principal and interest payments from borrowers are passed through to investors. A simple pass-through is a popular investment. But Wall Street engineers also use the pools to back complex securities known as collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s
 
3 -- The C.M.O's are pools of mortgages that have been cut into separate pieces called tranches, which are tailored to suite different investors' tastes for risk and return. A given tranche may include only principal or only interest; it may mature in 3 years or in 30; its value may move with prevailing interest rates or against them.
 
4 -- Leftover odds and ends that are very risky and offer unpredictable returns are lumped together into catchall securities called cash-flow notes or kitchen-sink bonds. The various quirks of the components are supposed to offset each other, in theory adding up to a worthwhile investment. But the offsetting effect comes apart when interest rates jump, as Paine Webber discovered.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE OVERVIEW;
Democrats Issue Draft of Health Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
House Democratic staff members have drafted a summary of health insurance legislation for their leaders to discuss with other Democrats, but the preliminary document does not resolve many delicate issues, like timing.
As expected, the seven-page summary, widely circulated on Capitol Hill today, closely follows the lines of the bill adopted last month by the House Committee on Ways and Means, which aims to provide health insurance to all Americans, financed in large part by mandatory payments by employers. 
 Additions include allowing small businesses to enroll their workers in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, the same plan that covers members of Congress. Two Senate committees had also provided for opening that program to non-Federal employees. Some other provisions appear to be taken literally from the Ways and Means bill, although they concern issues on which the leaders remain open to compromise.
 
A 'Work in Progress'
 For example, the document speaks of requiring employers to pay 80 percent of workers' insurance premiums, while the Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, made it clear today that he would be open to reducing this to a 50-50 split between employers and employees.
Nevertheless, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, is using at least some parts of this document as talking points with other Democrats.
Laura Nichols, Mr. Gephardt's press secretary, said tonight that the document was a "work in progress." She said it was prepared so leaders "can begin to not only educate members but talk them through what we could do in improving what the committee had done."
Ms. Nichols said the most sensitive issues, like how to structure the required employer payments toward workers' premiums, had not been resolved. The document, for example, does not discuss the possibility of exempting very small businesses, saying only, "In general, all employers would be required to contribute toward the cost of private health insurance for all employees."
She said, "The big policy decisions have yet to be made."
But as their leaders worked to turn legislation passed by committees into proposals for consideration on the House and Senate floors, Democrats were also busy using the health care issue to attack the Republicans.
Mr. Foley said the recent Republican National Committee meeting showed that Republicans wanted to defeat any health bill. He said their desire to "see any bill defeated is a remarkable confession of their putting politics above the interests of the people."
 
Issue of Medicare
 And Vice President Al Gore, addressing the National Council of Senior Citizens, said legislation proposed by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, would "raid Medicare," provide "virtually no help with costly medications" and allow insurance companies to go on charging "older people four times as much as younger people" for health insurance. He said Democratic bills, unlike the Dole version, banned discriminatory rates and provided for prescription drugs and long-term care for the elderly.
Mr. Dole replied in a statement: "One day they attack me. The next day they attack employers. The next day it's insurance companies. It's politics as usual at the White House. They are looking for enemies instead of solutions."
And Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 House Republican, said Mr. Foley was wrong in accusing the Republicans of opposing all health legislation. "We are working very hard to write a bill that can be passed," he said. "In a city where Rabin and Hussein spoke from the same microphone, we might even have the Democratic and Republican leadership work together."
Mr. Gingrich said he had repeatedly offered to work with the House majority leader and had been rebuffed. He contended that Republicans wanted to pass a moderate bill. "It's not just an effort to upstage and defeat the President," he said.
House Republicans have insisted that they would not consider any bill that would require employers to pay part of the cost of their workers' insurance. Democratic leaders regard that as an essential ingredient.
The attack on Mr. Dole in particular has been a determined Democratic strategy for the last few days. Rather than argue against compromise measures that have some bipartisan support, the Democrats have taken Mr. Dole's bill, which relies on insurance law changes and subsidies for the very poor but would leave many people uncovered, as the enemy. They have attacked it sharply, seeking to define the nation's choice as between their universal coverage measure, whatever it turns out to be, and his minimal measure.
In a day of heavy lobbying by the disabled and the elderly, New York City also weighed in, when hospital executives, labor leaders and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo traveled to Washington to demand that any bill provide universal coverage and not leave New York worse off than it is today.
Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, and Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the hospital workers union, were among a group who called on Mr. Gephardt. They warned him that proposed cuts in Medicare and Medicaid payments for graduate medical education and for hospitals providing a disproportionate share of care to poor people would badly hurt New York's teaching and public hospitals, especially if legislation did not include coverage for everyone.
 
Lobbying by Cuomo
 In midafternoon, Mr. Cuomo made many of the same points at a meeting with the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, before going off to see Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and the dean of the state's House delegation, Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan. Mr. Cuomo said he had told Mr. Panetta that he thought that not enough Americans understood that universal coverage was not merely an altruistic goal but the linchpin on which successful change depended, even if it took several years to achieve.
"I think many of the people in the country misperceive the rationale for universal coverage," Mr. Cuomo said. 'They think it is purely a matter of compassion and concern for 36 or 37 million uncovered people. And that leads some of them to believe that you are asking the covered people to give up wealth for the benefit of the uncovered people, when the better rationale is in order to protect the covered people -- at least eventually -- you have to get the uncovered people into coverage, because they're receiving health care, but it's too expensive and the burden of that expense falls on the shoulders of the premium-payers, which is the rest of us."
Ross Perot said today that he was disappointed that the television networks had refused to sell broadcast time to the Republican Party for half-hour advertisements on health care. He said he had been willing to spend more than $1 million for the Republican commercials. Echoing what some leading Republicans are beginning to say, Mr. Perot added: "Right now there's this feeling that if you don't pass it during the election, all life on the planet will stop. We should take our time and do it right."
Mr. Perot said he would not have appeared in the Republican commercials and simply wanted them to be an even-handed analysis of health care options. But he made clear his belief that employer mandates would be a grave mistake.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, at right, discussing health care yesterday with a delegation from New York including, at left, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the hospital workers union, and Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine. (Kirsten Bremmer for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "DIARY: Health Care Developments"
 
YESTERDAY
 As a proposal drafted by Democratic staff members of pivotal House committees began circulating on Capitol Hill, Republicans and Democrats criticized the ideas and tactics of their rivals.
 
CONGRESS
Democrats and Republicans traded barbs over rival proposals. Speaker Thomas S. Foley said Republicans were "putting politics above the interests of the people," while Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said Democrats "are looking for enemies instead of solutions." The Congressional Budget Office said it would be unable to deliver an assessment of a legislation approved by the Senate Finance Committee on July 2 until staff members finished writing its precise language. The plan relies on changes in insurance regulations and Government subsidies to low-income families to provide insurance coverage to about 95 percent of Americans; its backers hope that the budget office report will strengthen their argument that the plan would be effective and affordable.
 
WHITE HOUSE
Vice President Al Gore criticized Republican health care proposals as shortchanging the elderly, and his wife, Tipper, pressed for universal health coverage, including virtually unlimited coverage for mental illness. She spoke at the National Press Club.
 
LOBBYING
New York politicians, hospital executives and labor leaders from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo down descended on the Capitol to emphasize the need for universal coverage and to insist that any health care bill take account of New York's historically rich system of health care benefits and its large population of poor sick people and not leave it worse off.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
 In a rebellion against business travelers' higher fares, many companies are seeking ways for their employees to squeeze costs and are pressing airlines for better deals. The new aggressiveness by business could become a nightmare for airlines, which have been plagued by losses and are hoping for increased revenues from business passengers as the economy recovers. [Page A1.] 
 More investors are joining class-action lawsuits against funds that used exotic investments like derivatives, lawyers say. A rise in interest rates earlier this year made a lot of the complicated investments go sour. Amid the rush to sue, investment companies are left without a handle on their ultimate liabilities. [D2.]
 Consumers' confidence in the economy slipped slightly in July, according to a survey by the Conference Board.[D5.]
 
Business Technology
Bids continued to climb at the first auction of public airwaves by the F.C.C. Bids had more than doubled from Monday's opening round of the sale of 10 nationwide licenses, which are expected to be used for advanced two-way paging services. [D1.]
Microsoft has big plans for electronic publishing, a rapidly growing market. The company has been busily acquiring information for CD-ROM titles. But unlike its earlier battles for emerging markets, this time the territory is less familiar to Microsoft. [D1.]
 
Companies
 RJR Nabisco showed gains in its food and international tobacco operations despite a 40 percent drop in quarterly earnings. [D1.]
Digital Equipment reported a $1.75 billion loss for the fourth quarter as it took a $1.2 billion charge to cut jobs and plants. [D2.]
Royal Dutch/Shell will sell metals and mining assets to Gencor, a large South African mining company, for $1.22 billion. Gencor is acquiring stakes in operations in 15 countries. [D3.]
Nervous Russians have besieged an investment company, MMM, fearing that it will collapse. Panic selling of shares of the investment fund started after Moscow said it would not guarantee money put in any of the numerous, and often highly aggressive, funds that have sprung up in the last year. [D3.]
Procter & Gamble will buy Giorgio Beverly Hills, a perfume business, from Avon Products for $150 million in cash. [D3.]
Genzyme plans to acquire Biosurface Technology. [D20.]
The New York Times Company said earnings rose 53.2 percent in the second quarter, helped by gains in advertising volume. [D19.]
 
Markets
 Uncovered short sales of Nasdaq stocks increased to a record for the third consecutive month. [D5.]
Stocks were dragged down by disappointing earnings reports from Chevron and Eastman Kodak. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 6.16 points. [D8.]
Prices of platinum and palladium jumped as speculators focused on forecasts for strong Japanese demand. [D15.]
The dollar slipped against the yen as traders were pessimistic about trade talks between the United States and Japan. The dollar surged against the Italian lira. [D15.]
Bond prices fell as traders absorbed the Treasury's sale of $17.3 billion in two-year notes. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
 William H. Donaldson will end his reign at the New York Stock Exchange without having become the pre-eminent spokesman for Wall Street that some had hoped he would be. Mr. Donaldson said he would not seek another term as chairman and chief executive of the exchange. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
 The impact of a Macy-Federated merger on advertising is still unclear. Will it result in less advertising, or more? Who will be hurt the most, television or print? Ask two experts and there will probably be two different answers. Advertising. [D19.]
