HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: CAMPAIGNING;
Swept Into Office on Health Care Issue, Senator Struggles in Re-election Bid

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: READING, Pa.

 BODY:
As the man who put health care on the national agenda, Senator Harris Wofford, who is up for re-election this year, is determined to prove he has something to show for his troubles.
On a recent campaign swing through the Fairgrounds farmers' market here, he seemed oblivious to the summer swelter while he implored voters not to lose faith in his efforts to improve the health system. 
 Standing over Dorothy Waid's shopping cart, Mr. Wofford plodded through the ins and outs of mandates, deductibles and health alliances for 10 minutes as Mrs. Waid's plastic jugs of lemonade blistered in the sun and her bag of corn fell limp.
 
Message in Election
 Few politicians are identified as closely with health care as is Mr. Wofford, a Democrat. While his 1991 campaign for the Senate was not primarily about the health system, his upset victory demonstrated the appeal of even the vaguest advocacy for change. He beat former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in a special election to fill out the term of John Heinz, who was killed in an air crash.
Now, as this 68-year-old former college president and discursive intellectual seeks a full six-year term, he is struggling to portray himself as a man of action, "at the center" of the health care vortex as it spirals toward a conclusion.
Congress is trying to forge a health care bill before its August recess. Leaders worry that if they have no bill by then, they will have nothing to show voters in November. For Mr. Wofford, the worry is whether, having let the health care genie out of the bottle, it will haunt him or help him.
Beyond that, Mr. Wofford's campaign is being closely watched both for its potential as one of several that could shift control of the Senate to the Republicans and as a barometer of President Clinton's personal fortunes.
 
Links to Clinton
 Although Mr. Wofford leads his Republican opponent, Representative Rick Santorum, in opinion polls and has four times as much cash on hand, his support is viewed as soft for a Senator seeking re-election. The Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan Washington publication, calls the race a toss-up, and some Democratic leaders in Pennsylvania say Mr. Wofford could be in trouble if Mr. Santorum raises more money. Their hope is that, whatever Mr. Wofford's vulnerabilities, Mr. Santorum's ties to the religious right will prove too far out of the mainstream for most voters.
Part of Mr. Wofford's problem is his close alliance with Mr. Clinton. The Senator's 1991 campaign, based on strong domestic priorities, served as a harbinger for Mr. Clinton, who hired Mr. Wofford's political consultants for his race for President in 1992.
Mr. Wofford's election was perceived in part as a "wake-up call" to President George Bush to pay more attention to domestic matters. The danger for Mr. Wofford now is that voters will use him as a vehicle again -- this time to send a message to Mr. Clinton. The President's popularity here is flagging, particularly in the important Republican suburbs of Philadelphia, where Mr. Wofford and Mr. Clinton both received unexpectedly strong support.
"Wofford caught a wave coming in," said Charles G. Kopp, a Philadelphia lawyer and prominent Republican fund-raiser. "He's liable to catch a wave going out."
For his part, Mr. Wofford seems to be dancing an uneasy minuet. He portrays himself as intellectually independent of the President, while continuing to link himself with the White House in other ways. In an interview, he said, "Bill Clinton was looking to me on health care when he was a candidate." In the next breath he added that the bills now under consideration were "fundamentally different" from what Mr. Clinton proposed and that "I'm one of those who helped shape the difference."
Mr. Wofford's staff has prepared a four-page, single-spaced list of "significant Wofford/Clinton policy differences." It includes the Senator's opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement and his support for the balanced budget amendment. It notes that Mr. Wofford "votes less often with Clinton than over half of the Democrats in the Senate." But Congressional Quarterly says he voted with the President 90 percent of the time in 1993.
When Hillary Rodham Clinton held a news conference last month in the Capitol, Mr. Wofford, who arrived late, dashed up behind her and nudged aside the diminutive Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota so that Mr. Wofford's own visage would appear with Mrs. Clinton's on the news.
He had also planned to attend a recent health care rally with Mr. Clinton in Greensburg, Pa. But since Mr. Wofford and Mr. Santorum have been dueling over who has been present for more votes in Congress, Mr. Wofford did not dare leave and miss a vote. (Congressional Quarterly reports that in 1993, Mr. Santorum was present for 93 percent of the 553 votes in the House; Mr. Wofford was present for 97 percent of the 395 votes in the Senate.) Mr. Wofford, who addressed the rally by speaker phone, did attend a $10,000-a-person fund-raising reception with the President that evening in Philadelphia.
 
Image Among Voters
 Indeed, David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, calls Mr. Wofford's campaign a "great opportunity" to make the case for what he cited as the Clinton Administration's successes in job creation, deficit reduction, the beginning of national service and progress on health care.
But voters here have a rather vaporous impression of Mr. Wofford. None of those interviewed could pinpoint any activity beyond his admittedly sizable feat of putting health care on the map. At the farmers' market, Michael Aulenbach, a 30-year-old factory worker, said that the Senator "seems like someone who's trying to help people out," but that it was "hard to tell" what he had done.
Rose Anne Engle, who works in an industrial plating plant, said she would not support Mr. Wofford because "I can't believe that he won't go along with whatever Bill-the-President wants."
Most of those interviewed said their main concern about health care was that they were already losing benefits and were afraid they would lose more.
 
'He's Become Furniture'
 Whatever happens on health care, the perception that Mr. Wofford has not been his own man or made a discernable mark in Washington is shaping up as the central campaign issue.
"The real issue is Harris Wofford's failure to give himself an identity," said David Buffington, editor of a nonpartisan political newsletter in Harrisburg.
The Republicans are already pounding this theme. "He came to Washington in '91 with a tremendous amount of momentum and the potential to build on that, but he's frittered it away," said Gary Koops, spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which expects to give Mr. Santorum the maximum $1.1 million that it is allowed. "He's become furniture in the U.S. Senate."
Paul Begala, the political consultant who, with his partner, James Carville, engineered Mr. Wofford's 1991 victory and who is working for Mr. Wofford again this year, acknowledges that the Senator has not made his case to voters. "He doesn't play the game of posturing particularly well," Mr. Begala said. "But that's what a campaign is for."
 
'Not a Big Lion'
 Seated in the back of his campaign van, Mr. Wofford, a former Bryn Mawr College president and co-founder of the Peace Corps, seemed surprised that anyone might be unaware of his activities in Washington. "I'm not a big lion in the seniority system," he said. "But am I Mr. Universal Health Care?"
In listing what he viewed as his accomplishments, Mr. Wofford said repeatedly that he was the first to dissuade the Administration from its support for requiring people to join health cooperatives to pay for their insurance. He said he was also instrumental in writing bills that would provide support for long-term care and home health care and would protect retirees.
It takes Mr. Begala to trumpet Mr. Wofford's achievements outside of health care. He said the Senator was the driving force behind the national service law, which will allow students to repay college loans with some form of community service. In addition, Mr. Begala said, Mr. Wofford was the author of a provision to allow a family to exempt their home from their worth when calculating student loans and sponsored a measure to make it easier for high school students not going to college to get vocational training.
Although pollsters say the economy, jobs and crime are more important to voters here than health care, the latter remains a defining issue for Mr. Wofford.
"Whatever Congress does will be very, very important in his election," said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville University. "If there is an employer mandate or loss of benefits, he might not do so well. But if they pass one of these more market-oriented plans that doesn't take decision-making away from people, he could be O.K. The fascinating thing is that no one quite knows how it will play."

HEADLINE: Police in Lagos Break Up Protest

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 26

 BODY:
The police fired tear gas and bullets into the air today to disperse protesters in Lagos after four weeks of a strike and protests over the arrest of an opposition leader.
Nigerian oil workers are on strike over the detention of Moshood K. O. Abiola, who is thought to have won a presidential election in June 1993 that was annulled. On the anniversary of the election, he declared himself President, and he was later arrested. 
 "We remain on strike," said a spokesman for Pengassan, the union that represents the white-collar oil workers. Other workers, including university lecturers, have threatened to join the strike within a week if the military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, does not yield to Mr. Abiola.
Many people were arrested in Lagos today, as clashes between policemen and demonstrators continued. Policemen and soldiers patrolled Tinubu Square, near the Central Bank, intermittently firing shots in the air.

Jackson Warns of Violence
 WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- As he departed for Nigeria with a White House mission, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the potential for bloodshed there is greater than in Rwanda. Mr. Jackson and his colleagues hope to meet with officials and influential Nigerians, including Moshood Abiola.
In an interview, Mr. Jackson said Mr. Abiola's detention, coupled with labor unrest and a plummeting economy, has brought on a crisis "that could be much bigger than the one in Rwanda."
The White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said Mr. Jackson would "convey the President's concern over the recent detention of prominent Nigerians."

ESCAPE FROM ABUSE, BUT NOT NEGLECT

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Bids Soar At Auction By F.C.C.

BYLINE: By TERESA RIORDAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
By the time the Federal Communications Commission's first auction of the public airwaves adjourned for the day today, bids had more than doubled from Monday's surprisingly steep opening round and were still climbing.
"It's a slugfest," said David H. Brock of Metrocall, a paging company in Alexandria, Va., that was not participating in the bidding. The sale covered 10 nationwide licenses, which are expected to be used for advanced two-way paging services. "From what I've seen so far, several companies must have budgeted $150 million, $200 million for this auction," Mr. Brock said. 
 Of the 29 bidders who registered, about half appeared to have dropped out by midday, and action in the Blue Room in the Omni Shoreham Hotel, which was teeming with bidders and observers, had dwindled to the major players and some hard-core stragglers. By day's end, a clearly exhausted array of bidders had pushed the combined total of high bids for the 10 licenses to $343 million.
 
Group of Big Bidders
 Most of the action seemed to focus on fewer than five big players, who were identified only by bidding identification numbers displayed on television monitors around the room. Two companies alone bid $50 million each for four of the 10 licenses being auctioned.
Late this year, a set of potentially more valuable licenses, for personal communications services, will go on the block. The yield for the Treasury had been estimated at $10 billion, but given the intense competition this time around, the figure could go much higher.
Industry executives said this round's heavyweight bidders probably included Paging Network, BellSouth, Mobilemedia Communications Inc., Airtouch Paging and McCaw Cellular. The auction will end only when each of the registered bidders has either dropped out or won one or more licenses, up to a limit of three.
Gamesmanship and psychological warfare have been in full evidence. BellSouth, McCaw and other big bidders planned their strategies from carefully guarded hotel rooms, each one filled with computers.
One of the biggest bidders -- suspected to be BellSouth -- had hung back and placed almost no bids until the final round of bidding had closed on Monday. Then it abruptly bid $30 million for each of three different licenses, and bumped two of those bids to $50 million today.
 
Crucial for Some
 Capturing at least one nationwide license that will allow for two-way paging is thought to be crucial for companies like Paging Network, the country's largest paging company. The company announced in April that it had teamed up with Motorola to establish a two-way paging service. Today's paging services offer one-way communications and are most often transmitted through regional broadcast spectrums.
Some minority businesses continued to complain publicly that the stiff bidding had shut them out. On three of the licenses for sale, companies owned by women and members of minority groups, and small businesses -- identified as "designated entities" by the communications commission -- have an advantage, in theory at least. On those licenses they have to pay only 75 percent of their bids.
"The show of muscle in the opening bid was designed to knock the designated entities out of the competition from the beginning," said Clarence O. Smith, president of Essence Communications Inc.
The National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters had warned the commission before the auction that a 25 percent bid credit was not sufficient, Mr. Smith said. "Apparently those comments were not taken seriously," he added.
Competing bidders not in the designated entities category had little sympathy for Mr. Smith's position.
"Twenty-five percent isn't enough of a break?" said Wayne Perry of McCaw Cellular, who has been a flamboyant presence in the bidding room. "Give me a break. McCaw started with nothing. We were a small company. We had to claw and scratch our way up."
Charlie E. Jackson, president of Airtouch Paging, said that "if 25 percent isn't enough for them, I'd be glad to take their credit."
But others involved in the auction suggested that Essence's public complaints might simply be part of the company's bidding strategy given that its shareholders, which include Bill Cosby and Johnson Publications, the publisher of Jet and Ebony magazines, are believed to have deep pockets of their own. Essence acknowledged it was still an active bidder after the 11th round on Tuesday.
"We're not paupers, but there's a difference between big money and superbig money," said Thomas A. Hart Jr., a telecommunications lawyer with the Washington firm of McManimon & Scotland who is representing Essence.
The idea of auctioning the public airwaves to the highest bidder was first proposed in the late 1950's by Ronald H. Coase, the economist and Nobel laureate. The Reagan Administration pushed the idea during the 1980's, but Democrats in Congress resisted. After the Clinton Administration embraced auctions as a way to fatten Federal coffers, Congress converted, voting last year to require auctions for most nonbroadcast licenses.

HEADLINE: Queens Residents Criticize Plan for an Airport Rail Link

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
A proposed $2.5 billion rail link between Manhattan and the two New York City airports -- the largest public transit project in 50 years -- drew sharp criticism yesterday from residents of several Queens neighborhoods that the automated line would traverse. Many said the system would damage their areas while benefiting only Manhattan residents.
"They're building this monster for business executives," said Patricia Dolan, president of a homeowners' association in Kew Gardens Hills, who spoke yesterday at the first public hearing on the project's environmental impact statement. "But the noise and shadows and the filth will be devastating to neighborhoods like mine." 
 Proponents of the system, which is scheduled to be in operation by the year 2003, said it was intended to solve a decades-old problem: the lack of adequate transportation to the city's busy airports. They said the principal benefit to the borough would be a large reduction in the number of cars on congested highways and side streets leading to La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports.
Edward J. O'Sullivan, the project director for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said the rail line would eliminate 30,000 cars from the road each day, reducing traffic by 7.2 percent to Kennedy and 10.4 percent to La Guardia.
The system would cut air pollution in Queens, he said, and provide an economic boost to the area by making the airports more accessible.
As outlined in the 2,000-page impact statement, the rail line would begin on the East Side of Manhattan, probably at 59th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. It would cross the East River on the outer roadway of the Queensboro Bridge, follow the Sunnyside Rail Yard and the Amtrak and Conrail tracks through Long Island City, and then go along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and the Grand Central Parkway to La Guardia. It would then turn south along either the Grand Central or the Van Wyck Expressway to Jamaica Station, and continue south along the Van Wyck to Kennedy.
Using computerized, driverless trains similar to those at Disney World, the system would take 12 to 15 minutes to travel from Manhattan to La Guardia, according to the Port Authority, and 35 to 40 minutes to get to Kennedy. Each train would hold about 35 or 40 people, and the trains would be spaced 5 to 10 minutes apart at peak periods.
The prospect of reduced traffic congestion, however, did little to assuage many of the 75 people who showed up at yesterday's hearing in Queens Borough Hall before officials of the Federal Aviation Administration, the agency that prepared the impact statement. Residents who live alongside the proposed line said the noise and the sight of the train -- which would be elevated over roadways along some stretches -- would damage their neighborhoods while giving them no transit benefits.
Joan Vera DaCorta, president of the Astoria Heights Homeowners and Tenants Association, which represents people living just west of La Guardia, said her group voted unanimously to oppose the plan. The missing cars on the highways, she predicted, would immediately be replaced by other drivers, not bound for the airports, who would then find the routes more attractive.
Francis McDonald, an aide to the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who represents the Astoria area, said that if the line were built, it would have to be heavily landscaped and prevented from having any visual or aural effects on surrounding neighborhoods.
"Queens County can benefit from a reduction of auto traffic, but we in the county must suffer the pain of construction and even give up an access lane on the free bridge to Manhattan," she said.
Several transit advocates who spoke at the hearing said the Port Authority was taking the wrong approach by building an "exotic" rail system instead of simply extending the existing subway and commuter rail system to the airports. Stephen Dubrow, president of the Committee for Better Transit, said the authority was spending a huge amount of public money for the single purpose of getting people to the airport. Better, he said, to integrate airport rail into the existing transit system so that all riders can benefit.
Mr. O'Sullivan responded that the system is being financed by a $3 fee paid by departing passengers at the three regional airports and collected by the F.A.A. By law, he said, that money can be used only for airport passengers, visitors and employees, and not for a general expansion of the local rail system. He added that the airports contribute an estimated $25 billion to the local economy, and deserve a dedicated system that allows easy access.
The draft environmental impact statement, completed last month, says the environmental consequences of the system "are relatively minor or may be mitigated to levels that are not significant." Though the rail line would have a visual impact on areas like Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the statement says, it would not affect the use of the park.

HEADLINE: Quoting Bible and Koran, Two Old Foes Pledge Peace

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
With words filled with emotion and history, King Hussein of Jordan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel brought their message of reconciliation to Capitol Hill this morning, reaffirming before Congress their commitment to make peace in the Middle East.
"Mr. Speaker, the state of war between Israel and Jordan is over," King Hussein announced to a minute-long standing ovation in the Capitol. 
 Mr. Rabin echoed the King's remarks, telling Congress, "If my people did not desire peace so strongly, I would not be standing here today."
Their appearance -- the first time that two world leaders have addressed a joint meeting of Congress -- so moved lawmakers of both parties that Representative Bob Michel, the Republican leader, removed his eyeglasses several times to wipe away the tears, and Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat, couldn't put her white handkerchief away.
 
Smiles and Grins
 Facing the Congress, the Cabinet and the diplomatic corps, King Hussein smiled throughout the nearly hourlong meeting; the normally dour Mr. Rabin flashed broad grins in the direction of the King.
When their speeches were over, the two men met for a hearfelt handshake, but not quite an embrace, to cheers and cries of "Bravo!" from the audience.
"I daresay that the two speeches we heard today were the most moving, dramatic and historic speeches that any of us have ever heard," Representative Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, said. The Senate minority leader, Robert Dole, was also overcome by the history of the moment, saying, "I've been around here for a while and I can't remember a day like today."
At a luncheon in the Capitol's Statuary Hall, King Hussein said the past two days "have had a dreamlike quality" for him. He called the declaration signed with Mr. Rabin at the White House on Monday to end the nearly half-century state of war between Israel and Jordan "the crowning achievement of all my years."
 
Condemns Terrorist Attacks
 But at a news conference at the White House later, the King and the Prime Minister reminded their audience of the minefields standing in the path of peace in their region and strongly condemned recent terrorist acts against Jewish targets in Buenos Aires and London. When Mr. Rabin said that Iran and Syria could stop terrorist acts against Israel if they wanted to, neither President Clinton nor the King contradicted him.
For the King, today was in a sense a final forgiveness for his tacit support of Iraq's 1990 invasion and occupation of Kuwait and his opposition to the American-led coalition in the Persian Gulf war.
The appearance by the King and Mr. Rabin before Congress brought the two men before the body most able to help implement their peace with economic aid.
King Hussein in particular appealed for the help of Congress. "I have come before you today to demonstrate that we are ready to open a new era in our relations with Israel," the King said. "With the help and cooperation of this august body the peace we all want can be achieved."
 
$700 Million Response
 The warm response from American lawmakers to King Hussein also set the stage for Congress to respond positively to Mr. Clinton's pledge to forgive Jordan's $700 million debt with the United States and to help the country modernize its military.
Congress cut off aid to Jordan in March 1991 because of the King's support for Iraq during the gulf war and later blocked President Bush from releasing some military aid because of Jordan's blatant violations of the United Nations-ordered economic embargo against Iraq. Mr. Clinton later released all of the remaining aid, citing Jordan's cooperation in Middle East peace talks and American national security interests.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, White House chief of staff Leon Panetta and other senior officials have begun to work with Congress on a plan to pay off Jordan's debt over three years, senior Administration and Jordanian officials said today.
Despite the fact that this year's budget is nearly completed, the Administration told Congress today that it will seek to forgive $193 million in Jordan's debt in a pending appropriations bill, the officials added. The Administration will also seek Congressional approval for providing Jordan with still-unspecified American military equipment.
 
Different Agendas
 The warmth between the two leaders in the appearance on Capitol Hill did not disguise their different perceptions of history and the divergence of their political goals.
"For our part, we will never forget Palestine," said King Hussein, whose Hashemite Kingdom controlled the West Bank and East Jerusalem until the Israeli victory in the 1967 Middle East war, and whose "special role" in administering the Muslim holy places in Jerusalem was reaffirmed in the Washington declaration. The King said that only God could exercise sovereignty over the Muslim, Christian and Jewish holy sites in Jerusalem. He was not applauded when he made those remarks.
For his part, Mr. Rabin stressed the suffering and bloodshed of the past, reminding his audience that Jerusalem is "the heart of the Jewish people."
Mr. Rabin, who led a brigade in the defense of Jerusalem in 1948 and was chief of staff of the Israeli Army in the 1967 war that brought the West Bank and East Jerusalem under Israeli control, was given a standing ovation when he said: "I, who sent regiments into the fire and soldiers to their deaths, I say to you, Your Majesty, the King of Jordan, and I say to you, American friends, today we are embarking on a battle which has no blood and no anguish. This is the only battle which is a pleasure to wage: the battle for peace."
 
Blessings and Exhortations
 Mr. Rabin donned a yarmulke, the Jewish prayer cap, and intoned the ancient Hebrew blessing to "our Lord who has preserved us and sustained us and enabled us to reach this time."
King Hussein reached into the Koran for inspiration, quoting the verse, "Then if they should be inclined to make peace, do thou incline toward it also, and put thy trust in Allah. Surely, it is He who is all-hearing, all-knowing."
Throughout their appearance, Mr. Rabin was both exhilarated and uncomfortable with the prolonged burst of applause and the standing ovations, at times gesturing to King Hussein that they should sit down. But King Hussein reveled in the adulation. And when the two men left the dais, they mingled among American lawmakers, who reached out to shake their hands.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Co. Profit Up 53% As Ad Volume Increases

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that it earned $34.3 million in the second quarter, up 53.2 percent from profits of $22.4 million a year earlier. Most of the increased profit resulted from increases in advertising and circulation revenue at The New York Times and the company's regional newspaper group, as well as improvements in its magazine and broadcasting groups, the company said.
Total revenues for the company rose 31.4 percent, to $635.5 million, from $483.6 million, mainly because of the inclusion of The Boston Globe, which was acquired last October. 
 Because of additional shares issued to acquire The Globe, earnings per share increased only 14.3 percent, to 32 cents, from 28 cents.
 
 
Slight Circulation Declines
 Advertising volume in the most recent quarter was higher than the levels a year earlier at The Times, The Boston Globe and the company's 28 regional newspapers. Circulation declined slightly at The Times and the regional papers, but was offset by higher prices. The Globe reported a slight increase in daily circulation and a small decline for Sundays.
Eric S. Philo, a media analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the 4.5 percent increase in advertising volume at The New York Times was a sign of "the grudging recovery of the New York economy."
The earnings announcement had little impact on Times Company stock, which closed yesterday at $23.50 on the American Stock Exchange, down 25 cents, and well below its 1994 high of $28.50. The company said that since June 1993, it had spent nearly $305 million to buy 12.2 million of its shares in the open market.
The company does not disclose profit levels for individual newspapers, but analysts noted that The Globe's contribution to net income had been overshadowed by a $6.5 million write-off of good will every quarter since the Times Company bought The Globe.
But excluding depreciation and amortization expenses, the presence of The Globe was a primary reason for the 44 percent rise in the company's operating profits, to $112.2 million, from $78 million a year earlier. For the last six months, operating profits totaled $194.2 million, up 41 percent from $137.3 million for the period in 1993.
Among the divisions of The New York Times Company, the magazine group earned an operating profit of $10 million in the second quarter, more than double the $4.9 million of a year earlier, as revenues increased 4.4 percent, to $108.9 million. The increase in profits was a result primarily of higher advertising revenues at Family Circle and timing of certain costs for the women's magazines.
The second-quarter figures did not include the profit from the recently announced sale of the women's magazine division to Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing for $275 million, plus the assumption by the German company of $50 million of Times Company debts. The after-tax profit of that sale, which was completed yesterday, was estimated by the company at $1.10 to $1.20 a share and will be included in third-quarter earnings.
Higher advertising revenues in the broadcast division led to a 35.1 percent increase in operating profits to $7.7 million for the second quarter for the broadcasting/information services group.
Mr. Philo noted that the acquisition of The Globe had not been followed by much cost cutting, but added, "That was not the primary reason for the acquisition." In a research report issued last month, he said the Times Company was financially healthy enough, despite the expense of a new printing plant, to be "in a position to make a significant acquisition."

HEADLINE: One Top College's Price Tag: Why So Low, and So High?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
The faculty, with one professor for every eight students, offers unparalleled access to eager young scholars. The research facilities include everything from a 24-inch refracting telescope to a library with three-quarters of a million volumes. And when collegians need a break, there is always the option of a game of squash or a stroll around the 325 lushly planted acres.
Swarthmore is one of a handful of colleges that offer a superb liberal arts curriculum to a bright and diverse student body. "It's the Lexus of higher education," William Spock, Swarthmore's vice president for finance, says with pride. 
 But excellence comes at a stiff price: roughly $40,000 annually per student, as Swarthmore calculates costs. In the month families must write checks for their share of that awesome sum -- $25,900 for full tuition, room and board -- educators and economists are again wondering whether such elite colleges are pricing themselves into extinction. Even Swarthmore, with its enormous endowment and generous alumni, may some day be vulnerable.
A detailed analysis of Swarthmore's expenditures and income suggests that this college, like other elite colleges and universities, is treading a dangerously fine line between spending enough to keep itself competitive and spending so much that it may price itself out of the market for highly qualified students.
"I am not sanguine that enough Americans will have the cash and the dedication to pay" for this sort of education, said Morton Owen Schapiro, the dean of the University of Southern California's College of Letters, Arts and Sciences.
As they write their steep tuition checks, many families may wonder what they are paying for. Where does the money go? And where does the $40,000-plus per student come from to cover a Swarthmore education, since that figure far exceeds tuition? Swarthmore offered The New York Times an inside look at what makes the college tick financially.
Swarthmore's tuition, room and board is about $10,000 more than the typical private, four-year college and just below the perennial leaders including Yale, Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But that is the "list price," not the average charged to students.
 
'Need-Blind' Admissions
 Swarthmore is one of the last colleges to remain "need-blind" -- admitting students without reference to need -- offering scholarships (economists would call them discounts) averaging about half the $25,900 fee to about half of its 1,300 students. So families will pay, on average, $18,000 from their own pockets -- or from the proceeds of Government loans and grants made directly to students.
Most of the rest of the $40,000-plus, more than half the total cost of a Swarthmore education, comes from affluent alumni. The college's biggest single source of cash, after student fees, is income from its endowment, accumulated from gifts over the decades. After subtracting debts, Swarthmore's financial wealth is roughly $400 million, which puts it eighth nationally when calculated per student.
While the endowment funds have earned 11 percent annually over the last 20 years, the college draws considerably less, so that it can sustain the purchasing power of its nest egg. Thus roughly $13,000 per student will be available from the endowment.
If this year is like the previous two, gifts from alumni and parents to cover current expenses will probably total $10,000 per student -- a figure that puts Swarthmore well above Yale, Princeton and Dartmouth. Direct government aid to the college (as opposed to tax breaks linked to the college's nonprofit status) will round out the total, yielding just under $2,000 per student.
All told, then, the college will have a bit more than $42,000 to spend per student, a comfortable margin over its current costs but more than the average American family's income. On what can Swarthmore be spending that much -- and considerably more, when the cost of the capital sunk into buildings and land is included?
In 1992-93, the most recent year for which figures are available, some $10,000 per student went to cover faculty salaries and benefits. Swarthmore pays well -- $70,000 on average for a full professor, $40,000 for an assistant professor -- putting it in the top 5 percent of colleges surveyed by the American Association of University Professors. But the figure was barely satisfactory by Swarthmore's own benchmark, an index of salaries at elite small colleges ranging from Amherst to Wesleyan.
 
The Cash Outlay
 "Academic support" and "general institutional support" -- everything from computers to secretaries' salaries -- ate up $9,000 per student. Maintenance and additions to the physical plant came to $7,000 per student, while "student services" -- food, recreation -- consumed almost $4,000. When a few other categories are added, the cash spent came to $37,633 per student.
That is a lot of money, but still a serious underestimate of the true cost of a Swarthmore education. It omits the value of services from the college's investment in its physical plant, a sin the Securities and Exchange Commission would not forgive if General Motors omitted from the costs of a car today the cost of assembly lines built in the past.
A conservative reckoning puts the cost of rebuilding Swarthmore from scratch at more than $300 million, not including the purchase of the choice suburban acreage where it now stands. Thus if the college could rent out the property at a return equal to what it expects to earn from its portfolio of securities, it would have an additional $10,000 per student.
This implied total cost of a Swarthmore education, more than $47,000 in 1992-93 and surely over $50,000 in the coming year, is astronomical compared to most colleges but consonant with the ones that aspire to academic heights. Indeed, extrapolating from calculations made by Gordon Winston, an economist at Williams College in Massachusetts, the figure is comparable for his own institution.
Is it necessary to spend $40,000 a year in cash and consume $10,000 worth of capital resources to provide a Swarthmore-quality education?
Many economists are skeptical that any business-like entity can operate efficiently in a market where "output" is hard to measure and "consumers" rely on the generosity of strangers to cover half the product's cost. In a 1991 interview Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate, allowed that he had "no doubt whatsoever that it would be possible to make money on half the tuition charged by the Ivy League schools."
 
Two Options for Savings
 Economists are also inclined to be wary of the incentives of leaders in a "business" that eschews the label. Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's Stern School, suggests that since administrators at colleges like Swarthmore personally have little to gain and much to lose from cutting costs or radically redesigning the product, they are "deeply reluctant to test the system."
But the view from the trenches -- though very comfortable trenches -- is quite different. Robinson Hollister, an economist and member of Swarthmore's executive planning committee, says there are only two ways for the college to save large sums without sacrificing faculty quality.
One would be to raise the number of students per teacher by eliminating less popular departments and by halting the accretion of new courses.
Swarthmore already allows students to take courses at nearby Haverford and Bryn Mawr -- Japanese, for example -- that it does not offer, and now need not offer, on its own campus. But the college consciously swims against the tide by supporting out-of-fashion disciplines, like religion. And it is unwilling to increase minimum class sizes or ignore relatively new fields like Asian studies. "Knowledge expands," explained Mark Kuperberg, a member of the economics department.
The other cost-saver, Mr. Hollister suggests, would be to cut back on need-based aid. With 10 applicants for every opening in the freshman class, Swarthmore could probably reduce the average discount offered on tuition with only modest reductions in students' qualifications. But that is one price the college is loath to pay, said Jennie Keith, the provost. "Need-blind admission," she said, "is vital to the college's sense of itself."
But this is not the whole story. From 1980 to 1990 Swarthmore cash outlays per student nearly doubled, even after accounting for inflation. Some of the increase can be attributed to what economists call "Baumol's disease," the observation by William Baumol of New York University that productivity gains in service industries like education tend to lag behind those in manufacturing. Some is related to investments in making the academic product better -- lab facilities, new courses and the like.
But part of the increase covered the cost of fund raising and marketing. Still more was linked to improved amenities like sports facilities, an intercultural center, staffing for the new $14 million theater complex and comfortable student lounges. Last year each student received a separate telephone line, with voice mail.
 
Pressures of the Market
 Mr. Spock argues, however, that these outlays were driven by market forces that cannot safely be ignored. Swarthmore, he said, must show its best face to prospective students to maintain its share of top-flight undergraduates whose families can pay the bills. Michael S. McPherson, an economist at Williams, echoed that point. Colleges produce a unique product, he said, in that "a primary input is the quality of its customers."
Swarthmore's administrators know the risks in upscale marketing: As tuition rises, the numbers of first-rate students who can pay list price fall, potentially forcing the college to lower admissions standards. But they have cut the rate of growth of spending, and they are reasonably confident that they can hold future increases in student charges to the rate of growth of average family incomes without compromising educational standards. The expectation is that this will keep the college attractive enough to sustain demand.
The administrators may be right. Since most of Swarthmore's costs are for white-collar salaries, one would expect those costs to more or less track the incomes of the high-income white-collar families who currently pay full price when they enroll their children at Swarthmore. But economists still worry that rocky times lie ahead for many, if not all, high-priced liberal arts institutions. Dramatic curriculum cutbacks, announced just last month by Bennington College in Vermont, feed the conviction that no college is invulnerable.
One concern, said Mr. White of New York University, is that "excess capacity" among colleges with lesser reputations will cause a "ripple effect," reducing the number of gifted students willing and able to pay $25,000-plus tuition. In the last decade the market has segmented; demand for places at the highest ranked colleges increased even as second- and third-tier colleges were unable to fill classes with qualified students. But no law of economics, he argues, guarantees that these trends will hold.
David Breneman, an economist at Harvard's School of Education, fears that competition will force colleges to offer discounts to attract the most desirable students. Swarthmore already gives merit scholarships to bag the occasional music prodigy or star soccer player. But most aid is rigidly linked to need. And now that the Justice Department has frowned on the long-standing practice of collusion among elite colleges in determining need-based discounts, there is a good chance bidding wars will break out.
Yet another concern is that politicians will react to tight budgets and taxpayer resentment by questioning elite colleges' exemption from property and income taxes, as well as the tax deductibility of gifts. Private colleges think they already are slighted because they educate thousands of students who would otherwise be a burden to state universities. But Mr. White wonders whether government will continue to accept an "open-ended obligation to subsidize $50,000-a-year education."

HEADLINE: French Premier to Visit Africa To Show Continued Commitment

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 26

 BODY:
With France confident that Rwanda's refugee crisis justified its military intervention there last month, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur leaves for Africa Wednesday on a trip aimed at underlining to its former African colonies that France remains their best friend in the West.
French Government officials said Mr. Balladur's visit to Senegal, the Ivory Coast and Gabon was not prompted by the Rwandan tragedy. They said that the Governments of all three "understood" France's reasons for sending 2,500 soldiers to protect refugees fleeing Rwanda's civil war. 
 Until the refugee crisis, France was on the defensive, forced to deny that it intervened to help its former allies in the now-ousted Hutu-led Government. But when hundreds of thousands of Rwandans fled into Zaire, France was the only Western power with forces in place to aid them.
Now, having pledged to withdraw its forces from Rwanda by Aug. 21, the French Government is taking undisguised satisfaction from the fact that both the United Nations and the United States have appealed to Paris not to pull out its troops until they are replaced by United Nations soldiers.
France is no less eager to remind its former colonies that, more than any other major power, France is still ready to invest politically and economically in Africa's future.
There are nonetheless signs that Mr. Balladur's conservative Government is changing the focus of a policy that traditionally involved a combination of economic paternalism and support for local dictators whose main attributes were loyalty to France's top politicians.
In 1990, in a summit meeting with African leaders, President Francois Mitterrand signaled that, with the end of the cold war, one-party African countries were expected to start moving toward democracy. The results of that new policy have been mixed, with some African countries holding free elections, but others remaining under army-backed one-man rule.
Since Mr. Balladur took office in March 1993, France has also begun arguing that its former colonies can only achieve stability if they put their economies in order, by eliminating official corruption and stimulating exports and the creation of jobs.

HEADLINE: Investors Rush to Join Suits Over Derivatives

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
Investors will continue to join class-action lawsuits over the recently self-destructing financial instruments known as derivatives and "exotic" securities, lawyers are saying.
First there was a rash of suits against mutual funds, brokerage firms and others that were said to have made bad judgments in buying complex, financially engineered products without making investors aware of the risk. Now, lawyers say, because of continued publicity about problems with derivatives, their phones are still ringing, as investors seek to join the "classes" of investors who contend harm was done to them in risky securities, including collateralized mortgage obligations. 
 Paine Webber said last week that it would spend an additional $180 million to bail out a mutual fund that was devastated by holdings in exotic mortgage securities known as "kitchen sink" bonds. The news, in the wake of an earlier announcement by Paine Webber that it would reimburse customers for some losses in the same fund, is leading more investors to consider suing, lawyers say.
 
Companies Unsure of Liabilities
 With investors continuing to discover that they may have a case against a company or a financial institution, companies are left without a handle on their ultimate liabilities. A rise in interest rates earlier this year made a lot of the complicated investments go sour.
"I think you're going to see a lot more suits," said Steve Berman, a lawyer at the Seattle firm of Hagens & Berman.
In New York, Mel Weiss of Milberg, Weiss said: "Lots of people have been contacting my firm -- and I'm sure others -- claiming that the mutual funds they invested in were not supposed to be taking the kinds of risks we now know they were taking."
The rush to sue goes beyond mutual fund companies that marketed "safe" short-term funds without emphasizing that those funds owned volatile securities, although several such big cases exist. Paine Webber Group Inc., Fundamental U.S. Government Strategic Income Fund, and Piper Jaffray have all been the targets of class-action suits related to poor performance earlier this year by mutual funds that held derivative and "exotic" securities.
 
Brokerage Managers Named
 In addition, investors have cited managements of brokerage firms that sold them risky mortgage securities typically reserved for sophisticated institutional investors, and publicly held companies that have lost money in derivatives. The General Electric Company's Kidder, Peabody unit was hit with a class-action suit in late May, as a result of the scandal in which a top trader was said to have executed billions in phony government bond trades.
And Salomon Brothers, the brokerage unit of Salomon Inc., has already received arbitration complaints from 10 investors who say they should not have been sold highly risky collateralized mortgage obligations in which they lost millions of dollars this spring -- and potentially millions more because Salomon told them they must ante up "margin calls" of three times the amount of their initial multimillion dollar investments.
David Guin, a lawyer at Ritchie & Rediken in Birmingham, Ala., said he had heard from several individual investors and small banks in recent weeks. They were sold collateralized mortgage obligations and now claim not to have understood the risks. The individuals who have called him "are not the kind of people who read the business pages every day," he said.
Lawyers say that the companies most vulnerable are those that were less than forthcoming in disclosing their risky securities in the documents they filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
"To tell about derivatives on page 33 of a mutual fund prospectus is not enough," said Sam Schwartz of Bezar & Martin. "Generally investors don't read the prospectus in great detail. Page 1 is generally enough, and they're falling asleep; they hardly ever get to page 33."
Similarly, publicly held companies that have been less than forthcoming about their risky securities positions are also vulnerable to suits, Mr. Berman said. "A meritorious suit would be one in which the company hadn't said much about having made the derivative investments," he said.
And then, added Raymond Peffer, who is representing investors in one of the arbitrations against Salomon, there is the issue of whether the investors had been given the documents. "My clients didn't get the prospectus," he said. "But even if they did, it would have been difficult even for a sophisticated investor to evaluate the risk."

HEADLINE: Low Profits Push Dow Down 6.16

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders, having spent much of the year worrying about an inflation that has yet to appear, had a more immediate concern yesterday: souring corporate earnings.
It also did not help the market that bond prices fell and that the dollar declined against most leading currencies. 
 The damage was modest but noticeable because of the stocks involved. Stocks fell after Chevron and Eastman Kodak reported disappointing earnings and Boeing, among the leading American exporters for the last several years, reported poor profits and also warned of lower sales in the second half.
Chevron opened sharply lower, after a delay of nearly a half-hour. The company said second-quarter profits from continuing operations fell 54 percent. Eastman Kodak's earnings were hurt by failed currency-hedging strategies and weak demand for office equipment. Kodak's continuing profit fell 16 percent. Boeing's second-quarter net fell 43 percent as the recession in the aviation industry continued.
 
Components of the Dow
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.16 points, to 3,735.68, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.89 point, to 453.36. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.22 points, to 715.66.
Chevron, Kodak and Boeing are all component stocks of the Dow industrial average and the S.& P. 500 index, dragging down those indexes when their shares prices dropped. Kodak fell 1 5/8, to 47 7/8; Boeing fell 7/8, to 45 1/8, and Chevron dropped 3/4, to 43.
Many other stocks fell. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing stocks lagged behind the number of declining stocks, 935 to 1,165.
On average, however, many traders may still be on the sidelines. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal with 231.1 million shares changing hands, or 20 percent below this year's average of 289 million shares.
Blue chips like Texaco and United Technologies, conglomerates like General Electric and military contractors like Rockwell International, as well as over-the-counter stocks like Microsoft and MCI Communications all declined.
Long-term interest rates rose, perhaps because bond traders are awaiting more than $68 billion in new securities to be sold at auction over the next three weeks. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.54 percent from 7.52 percent. Bond yields rise and prices fall when traders perceive existing bonds as riskier than future bonds.
 
Dollar vs. Yen
 The dollar fell against the yen as currency traders bet that the United States and Japan would not succeed in trade talks scheduled to end next Monday. The dollar fell to 98.30 yen from 98.60 yen.
Commodity prices continued to fall, signaling a more stable inflation outlook. The closely watched Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities was largely unchanged, continuing a two-week trend. It fell 0.26 point, to 232.52, led by falling futures contract prices for such economically important raw materials as copper, lumber and crude oil.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.48 point, to 250.24. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.44 point, to 434.50.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 fell, led by Kodak and also Texaco, which fell 7/8, to 62 1/8, in part because of Chevron's disappointing quarter.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 261 fell, led by General Electric, which fell 3/4, to 49 1/8.
The most active stock, at 6.3 million shares, was Tele-Communications, the nation's largest cable-television operator, which rose 1/2, to 23 1/2.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Fall As Traders Absorb Notes

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday as traders absorbed the Treasury's sale of $17.3 billion in two-year notes.
"The market's going to have to show me more of a concession before I step in and buy," said Fred Leiner, a market strategist at Continental Bank. 
 Earlier in the day, traders tried to drum up demand for the two-year notes by raising yields through the sale of seasoned securities. At the auction, demand for the new notes was stronger than expected. The average yield at the auction was 6.17 percent, the highest in almost three years and a basis point lower than anticipated. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.54 percent, from 7.52 percent on Monday. The long bond's yield was 6.30 percent before the Federal Reserve began pushing up short-term interest rates in February.
Demand for all Treasury securities dropped this week amid anticipation of as much as $68 billion in new securities in the next three weeks, investors said.
 
Main Issue in the Market
 "The main issue in the market now is supply," said Dennis Bushe, managing director at Prudential Investment Advisers, which has about $12 billion in fixed-income securities.
Besides yesterday' s sale of two-year notes, the Treasury will sell $11 billion in five-year notes today and is selling $40.25 billion in 3- , 10- and 30-year bonds in the second week of August in its biannual refunding.
"Until you get through the glut," of Treasury auctions, said Robert G. Smith 3d, "yields are probably going to hang out around this level." Mr. Smith manages $1.25 billion in bonds at the Smith Affiliated Capital Corporation of New York.
Some investors are also reluctant to buy Government securities until the Fed raises interest rates for the fifth time this year, as many analysts expect.
 
Efforts to Dampen Inflation
 The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said last week that it was an "open question" whether four previous rate increases were enough to dampen inflation.
The Fed is likely to raise rates by 50 basis points between now and the end of September, said Henry Kaufman, the head of Henry Kaufman & Company, which manages $750 million in fixed-income assets. Higher rates may "have a negative effect on the fixed-income markets" if the economy doesn't slow, he said.
Raising rates amid a big jump in the amount of new securities would hurt investors. "It would not be a pleasant thing for the Fed to turn around right after the auctions and raise interest rates," Mr. Bushe of Prudential said.
Buying notes at current yields could also be a dicey investment if Friday's report on economic growth last quarter shows a more robust expansion than expected, analysts said.
Economists surveyed said that the gross domestic product expanded at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the second quarter, up from the 3.4 percent rate of the first quarter.
Some investors, however, said the Fed would probably not raise rates soon. The economy is already slowing because "higher rates are having an impact," said Ken Windheim at Strategic Fixed Investment in Roslyn, Va., which has $2.3 billion in fixed-income assets. "If they raise rates at any point here, I think it would be pretty hard to justify," he said.
Nonetheless, the bond market's fall earlier this year points to a better future, said Robert DiClemente, a senior economist at Salomon Brothers. "The market has already built in insurance against inflation," Mr. DiClemente said. "It doesn't need to sell off twice" because of an inflation scare.

HEADLINE: Expense Account Heyday Over, Companies Demand Cheap Fares

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Many American companies, eager to cut costs, are rebelling against the airlines' 16-year-old policy of making business travelers pay higher fares than leisure travelers. These companies are finding ways for their traveling employees to save money, even if that sometimes means inconveniencing them. They are also driving harder bargains with the airlines.
Apple Computer Inc., for instance, has set up a network that provides employees, working on computers, options for planning their trips, including information about the potential savings from discounts the company has negotiated with airlines. 
 The company's department heads then evaluate employees on how often they use those discounts compared with their fellow employees. In the first five months of this year, Apple spent 25 percent less on travel than in the corresponding period last year, even though its employees took 14 percent more trips.
The Boeing Company keeps for its own use the frequent-flier miles its employees earn on business trips. The Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies is more generous. Last year it began offering to pay its workers to use their frequent-flier mileage for business trips, giving them $300 for a trip that would have cost the company $600 or more.
Dr Pepper/Seven-Up also encourages its traveling employees to stay over on a Saturday night, so they can take advantage of discount fares requiring a weekend stay. But to ease the strain of cutting into weekends, the company encourages its employees to take their spouses with them and picks up the tab.
Companies are also pushing the airlines for better deals. Corporate travel managers have increasingly entered negotiations with detailed information on employee travel patterns, showing just how much business their companies give the airlines. With such evidence, they have been able to wring sizable discounts from the airlines, which in turn have been more vigilant in insuring that companies deliver the number of passengers they promised.
In an attempt to increase their bargaining power, 17 companies, including General Motors and Merck, announced their support last month for a fledgling venture that plans to negotiate with the airlines for lower fares in exchange for sacrificing frequent-flier miles and eliminating commissions to travel agents.
The new aggressiveness by businesses could become a nightmare for the airlines, which have been plagued by losses and are hoping for increased revenue from business passengers as the economy recovers. Many analysts say business travelers may no longer be the customers they were in the days when they traveled with little regard for cost.
 
Pledges of Frugality
 Indeed, many corporate travel managers say that despite the moderately improving economy, they are more determined than ever to squeeze costs out of travel budgets.
The Georgia Pacific Corporation, for example, recently told its employees to avoid Delta Air Lines when possible because Georgia Pacific believed it was not getting a large enough volume discount for a company its size. Georgia Pacific, which has about 50,000 employees, has also chartered buses occasionally to drive groups of employees to meetings up to 300 miles away.
Conrail Inc. has cut its budget for air travel by 5 percent every year since 1990, and plans to cut 5 percent more this year and next. To help reach that target, the railroad, based in Philadelphia, has installed video-conference rooms in 12 locations, part of an industrywide network of video-conference sites set up by the Association of American Railroads to help member companies avoid having to fly employees to regular meetings.
"We don't ever expect to go back to the level of travel of a couple of years ago," said Michael W. Kabo, Conrail's director of administrative services.
The new frugality is not only affecting air travel. Many companies have told their employees to stay at less expensive accommodations like the budget hotels of Red Roof Inns or the "upper economy" lodging offered by La Quinta Inns. John Kaegi, senior vice president of marketing for La Quinta, which has 220 hotels, said the number of national contracts the company has with medium-sized and large companies had risen to more than 450, from about 80 two years ago.
To be sure, many companies have decided to send their employees on more trips as the business outlook brightens. "You can't fax a handshake" is a popular saying at Boeing.
And some industry analysts say that in keeping with history, more corporate purse strings will be loosened as profits improve. "There is definitely more of a cyclical element to this," Paul Karos, an airline analyst for CS First Boston, said.
But when employees travel, they are often traveling more inexpensively. American Express Travel Related Services, which has hundreds of large corporate clients, said that while the average number of trips its clients booked rose 10 percent from January 1993 to May of this year, the average fare paid by business travelers dropped more than 15 percent. Changing travel policies and more diligent use of negotiated discounts with airlines accounted for most of the decline; less than half the drop was attributable to lower fares.
Tenneco Inc., an industrial company in Houston, is a good example of the trend. It issued 11 percent more tickets to its employees in the latest 12 months than in the previous corresponding period. But after consolidating its six travel offices into a single office last year, giving Tenneco more leverage in negotiating air-fare discounts, the average price of each ticket dropped 14 percent.
The airline industry is worried.
"Clearly, it's a threat," said David A. Swierenga, chief economist for the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group in Washington. "Business travel has always been the backbone of air travel, and if we suddenly find that there is a big change in that part of our market, the airlines will have a hard time in the short term coming to grips with that."
 
Making Changes
 Airlines are trying to lower their costs so they can profitably offer the low fares that business and leisure travelers demand. Continental Airlines has bet that by drastically lowering fares and simplifying its fare structure to charge everyone the same fare on many routes, it can fill its planes and more than offset the drop in fares with extra passengers.
The cost-cutting efforts by companies underscore the gamesmanship that characterizes the relationship between the airlines and their passengers. Before deregulation in 1978, fares were based on mileage, and most people aboard a flight had paid the same fare.
Then airlines started using computers to develop complex fare structures that charged what the market would bear, meaning business travelers paid much higher fares than leisure travelers.
Companies tolerated the high fares when the economy was strong. But the recent recession prodded many companies to scrutinize their travel budgets, typically the third-largest controllable expense after salaries and data processing.
 
Applying Technology
 Corporate travel management evolved into a science, and technologically sophisticated travel agencies found their services in demand, as did auditing firms that checked the work of those agencies.
Now, many companies want to eliminate such layers of complexity, believing they add unnecessary costs. That is the point of the new venture endorsed last month by more than a dozen large companies. Called the Business Travel Contractors Corporation, it plans to negotiate with individual airlines -- pending review by the Justice Department -- for a new fare system that would exclude the cost of travel agency commissions and frequent-flier programs.
The airlines, which have said they will not respond until they see a specific proposal for the venture, say that frequent-flier mileage represents only a small additional cost.
Earlier this year, the International Business Machines Corporation approached airlines with the suggestion of sacrificing frequent-flier mileage for its employees in exchange for lower fares. The airlines said no.
Even though requests for such drastic departures from the norm have a questionable future, many companies have made minor changes that chip away at the status quo.
 
Revising Commissions
 The Hewlett-Packard Company, for example, pays a flat fee to its travel agencies, but takes the commissions the airlines pay the agencies. The company says the policy eliminates the conflict of interest that arises from agencies earning more on higher-priced tickets, even though clients want the cheapest fares.
Hewlett-Packard, an electronics company, has also cut the percentage of tickets to Europe booked on business class rather than coach class to about 25 percent, from 85 percent four years ago. And the company has started encouraging employees to take advantage of discounts for Saturday-night layovers. Even though employees are not required to take the discounted trips, the use of the excursion fares has grown 50 percent at Hewlett-Packard in the last year.
"There has been a sea change, especially in travelers' minds," said Fred Swaffer, corporate travel manager for Hewlett-Packard. "They are looking for ways to cut costs, and that has a much broader impact than anything I can do. It has changed the way they behave, and it's not going to swing back."

HEADLINE: Consumers' Confidence Fell, Conference Board Reports

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Consumers' confidence in the economy slipped slightly in July but still remained near four-year highs, according to a survey released yesterday.
The Conference Board, a business research group in New York, said its July survey found consumers' assessment of economic conditions continued to improve, though their expectations for the next six months fell slightly. 
 The group said its monthly consumer confidence index, in which 1985 equals 100, was at 91.6 in July, down slightly from its four-year high of 92.5 in June.
"While consumers continue to grow more satisfied with ongoing conditions, their expectations for the immediate future have tapered off," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's consumer research center.
"Still, the expectations component of the index, which has an impressive record as a leading economic indicator, suggests a continuation of steady, moderate economic growth in the second half of the year," he added.
The board said the survey, based on a representative sample of 5,000 households, found more respondents than in June reporting that economic conditions were "good," while about the same number as last month said the conditions were "bad."
Slightly less than 16 percent of the respondents said jobs were "plentiful," about the same level as last month, but slightly fewer said jobs were "hard to get."
Looking ahead to the next six months, slightly more than 17 percent of the respondents said they expected business conditions to improve, down moderately from last month, while nearly 10 percent said they feared conditions would worsen, up from 8 percent in June.
Regarding future job prospects, more respondents than last month said they feared there would be fewer jobs in the months ahead.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Haiti, U.S. and the Murk in Between

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
When a network presents an hourlong special on Haiti, you can be confident that the current military bosses of that sad country will get their lumps. More surprising in "House on Fire: America's Haitian Crisis" is the force and directness of Peter Jennings's attack on President Clinton's policy, or lack of one.
Mr. Jennings begins this pungent look at Haiti's tumultuous history and present distress with the promise that he will be asking "whether America should send its young men and women" to put out what the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the deposed President of Haiti, has called a house on fire. The question is indeed asked. Mr. Jennings puts it squarely to Father Aristide: "Of what value are you to the United States?" To which Father Aristide responds, "We are men." 
 Mr. Clinton is criticized not for taking a position one way or the other, but for taking contradictory positions, and Mr. Jennings is careful to take no position at all.
Tonight's timely report begins with a group of boat people, accompanied by Mark Atkinson, an ABC News producer, making the dangerous journey to what they hope will be a better life in the United States. But very few are welcomed, because American officials maintain a legal, possibly artificial distinction between those fleeing political persecution and those seeking economic opportunity.
There seems to be no doubt that paramilitary gangs have been murdering, raping and otherwise terrorizing pro-Aristide Haitians. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who now lords it over the island, assures Mr. Jennings that any soldier found guilty of violating a citizen's human rights is prosecuted. Then he adds a philosophical comfort: "You know, on this earth, there is no just society." On the evidence of United Nations observers recently expelled by his Government and interviewed for the program, that certainly applies to Haiti.
Back in the United States, the dispute over what to do has taken on racial overtones. Randall Robinson, the lobbyist who went on a hunger strike in protest against Washington's closed-door policy, tells Mr. Jennings that if the Haitian refugees were white, they would be better treated. He calls the current policy "profoundly racist." Representative Charles Rangel, the New York Democrat and member of the Congressional Black Caucus, agrees. Their opinion may be confirmed by an ABC poll for this program, which found many more Americans willing to use military power to stop Haitians from entering the United States than to oust the Haitian regime.
Television has carried mixed messages. The pictures of the boat people, including babies, being turned back by the Coast Guard must have stirred sympathy. The feelings stirred by the pictures of an American warship carrying American and Canadian military advisers retreating after a hostile welcome by armed thugs are less clear. Mr. Jennings calls it "the single most humiliating moment in the entire Haiti crisis," but Administration officials may have been worried about the impact of pictures of Americans being hurt or killed, as in Somalia.
Father Aristide's incitement of his supporters, the poorest of his poor nation, to violence against his opponents in Parliament is duly noted, as are charges that the Central Intelligence Agency spread reports of Father Aristide's purported psychological problems. But what really riles Mr. Jennings is the "series of stunning policy reversals by the Clinton Administration."
"I consider the Haitians to be political refugees, not economic refugees," the candidate Clinton is heard to say, as a reproach to the Bush Administration for sending the refugees back where they came from. But President-elect Clinton decided to continue that policy. And since then, beset by conflicting political pressures at home and adamant resistance by the Haitian military clique, the White House, Mr. Jennings notes sharply, has alternated between threats and retreats.
You can't be sure, but Mr. Jennings seems to prefer the threats. There is nothing ambiguous about his dire summation, however. He says President Clinton "appears to be drifting toward either another humiliating reversal, or taking the one step he most wants to avoid, invading Haiti."
