HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
THE Clinton Administration has finally named an Administrator for the Food Safety and Inspection Service, the hot seat at the Agriculture Department. On Aug. 15, Michael R. Taylor, Deputy Commissioner for Policy at the Food and Drug Administration, will become responsible for meat and poultry inspection.
Many highly publicized incidents of illness and death from contaminated meat and poultry have occurred in the last few years, and in an interview this week, Mr. Taylor acknowledged that consumer interests, not politics, must be the overriding concern for his agency. 
 "There's a long way to go and a lot of contention, but the food industry has got to figure out a way to get food safety off tabloid TV," he said.
One problem Mr. Taylor will have to address first is why the Agriculture Department allows frozen chickens to be sold as fresh.
He must also wrestle with the tricky question of whether to exempt ground beef from the regulations that define "lean" for all other foods.
And he will have to decide if meat and poultry can be irradiated to reduce bacterial contamination.
"I am going over there to carry out consumer protection provisions," Mr. Taylor said. "The focus of my tenure will be to reduce food-borne illness."
Mr. Taylor is moving from an agency where decisions are generally based on public health concerns and consumer protection into an agency that has always worn two hats: food industry advocate and consumer protector.
The agency is constantly criticized by consumer advocates and health professionals who say that it bases decisions on politics rather than science or consumer protection.
Caroline Smith DeWaal, who is the director of food safety for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington advocacy group, and has worked with Mr. Taylor on seafood safety, said if anyone can forge a consensus it is he.
"He's trusted not only by us but by the industry," she said.
Janet Riley, a spokeswoman for the American Meat Institute, agreed. "Mike Taylor has a great background in food safety," she said, "but the job has got to be one of the toughest in Washington with all the different pressures from Congress, consumers, labor and the meat industry."
Mr. Taylor said he hopes to bring current scientific thinking to the antiquated system of meat and poultry inspection, adding microbial testing for bacteria to the current system, which now calls only for visual inspection.
It is not a moment too soon, critics say. The public has been bombarded for several years by newspaper and television reports about contaminated meat.
Carol Tucker Foreman, the Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for the Food Safety and Inspection Service during Jimmy Carter's Administration, said the meat and poultry inspection system is archaic.
"Public health problems have changed, but the Food Safety and Inspection Service hasn't changed," she said. "Mike Taylor has the ability to get the agency into at least the last half of the 20th century."
Mr. Taylor, who was a lawyer specializing in food and drug law before he went to the F.D.A., says he hopes to do better than that. He has been deeply involved in proposed regulations for seafood based on a system known as Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point, or Haccp (pronounced HASS-ip). This system calls for comprehensive analysis and control of hazards, with monitoring and record keeping.
"My immediate task is to initiate Haccp rule making for meat and poultry," he said. "I certainly hope this fall to have a very credible Haccp proposal out there. A good solid year after the proposal, I hope to have a final rule. I want to send a signal that microbial monitoring is out there, and we've got to come to grips with how best to use it in Haccp."
Many meat and poultry producers use some form of microbial testing in their plants. Yet, even though the National Academy of Sciences said in 1985 that the Agriculture Department should switch to a science-based inspection system -- and Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy promised a Haccp program a year ago -- the department does not require microbial testing.
But improving the safety of meat and poultry will not include irradiation, Mr. Taylor said. A recent conference on the hazards of the E. coli bacteria that were responsible for the deaths of four children and the illness of 700 people from eating undercooked contaminated hamburgers recommended irradiation of raw meat as a solution. Mr. Taylor says such a solution will not work.
"Because of public fear irradiation is not going to be incorporated into the system in the near term," he said. "Not until the public is convinced everything else has been done. We need to be open to any technology that improves food safety, but that solution to today's problems is not credible."
And he said the Agriculture Department would stop blaming people for becoming ill from eating contaminated meat. After outbreaks of illness, the department and the meat industry always remind consumers that if they handle meat properly and cook it long enough, the bacteria will be destroyed.
"We can't put the onus on consumers to compensate for what the system is not doing right," Mr. Taylor said. "But people still need to cook and handle meat properly."
Not all the vexing problems facing Mr. Taylor are safety issues. Whether frozen poultry can be called fresh is a matter of economics. Experts generally agree that fresh is more desirable than frozen, and most people are willing to spend more money for fresh food than for frozen.
In the late 1930's the Agriculture Department decided that poultry was not frozen until it was at or below 0 degrees Fahrenheit. In the late 1980's an effort was made to define fresh poultry as that between 26 and 32 degrees, fresh-frozen between 0 and 26 degrees and frozen at or below 0 degrees.
The attempt failed because poultry producers who ship chicken frozen all over the country said that fresh-frozen was a perjorative term; the 1930's law remained in place.
Then California passed a law to prevent poultry frozen to below 26 degrees from being called fresh. It did so to protect local producers, who do not freeze their chickens, from national companies that want to sell their chickens in California as fresh when they have been frozen. Secretary Espy signed an order declaring the California law invalid because it overrode Federal law. Such a decision, critics say, was based not on good science but on politics.
"That issue obviously needs real serious re-examination," Mr. Taylor said. "The question is, How do we truthfully, in a non-misleading way, inform consumers? To my mind that is what this issue is all about."
Mr. Taylor will also have to make a decision about a proposal to continue to permit ground beef to be labeled with expressions like "70 percent lean, 30 percent fat," or "80 percent lean, 20 percent fat." Under regulations that go into effect Aug. 8, ground beef can be called lean only if certain criteria are met: a 3.5-ounce serving must contain less than 10 grams of fat, less than 4.5 grams of saturated fat and less than 95 milligrams of cholesterol.
Ground beef seldom meets those criteria, and some members of the beef industry are looking for an exemption. And now the poultry industry wants to use the "percent lean" labeling if the beef industry is given permission.
"The question here, like on any labeling issue, is, How do we accurately and fairly inform consumers?" Mr. Taylor said. "The test in every case is, Does it make sense to consumers?
"We are not going to be adjusting labeling rules just to meet marketing needs of companies. The same is true on safety issues."
A lot of people who see eye to eye on very little are expecting assorted miracles from Mr. Taylor. He has a tall order to fill.

HEADLINE: Retreating on the Trade Pact

 BODY:
Sam Gibbons, who replaced Dan Rostenkowski as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, came to his new position with a reputation as a dedicated free-trader. But he tarnished that reputation last week by pushing a number of trade-closing amendments through his committee.
The committee was voting on the Administration's proposed legislation to institute the Uruguay Round trade pact, which the U.S. signed with over 100 other nations in April in Marrakech, Morocco. The Senate Finance Committee takes up the legislation today. The most controversial issue concerns "anti-dumping" statutes, which govern how the U.S. will retaliate against countries that export goods at unfairly low prices -- for example, prices below the exporter's manufacturing cost. 
 Anti-dumping statutes are a valid tool for enforcing fair-trade rules. But they have evolved into a favorite device of protectionists. The Administration, responding to lobbying by manufacturers of steel, textiles and cement, is seeking in effect to rewrite the Uruguay Round accord so that domestic manufacturers can use the anti-dumping statutes to shut out legitimate foreign competitors. Mr. Gibbons has now signed on to this malodorous effort.
One misguided provision would make the American market look far smaller than it really is, thereby magnifying the harmful effect of imports and justifying retaliation by the U.S. The House committee would shrink the American market by having the Government disregard the large amount of goods that American companies produce for their own use rather than for sale, as when U.S. steel companies produce steel that they use in other products they sell.
Mr. Gibbons would also allow the Government to find dumping even when no domestic producer is available to serve customer needs. And the committee may be preparing language to prevent foreign companies from temporarily cutting prices below cost to preserve market share during recessions -- a tactic routinely used by domestic businesses.
President Clinton points to the signing of the Uruguay Round pact as a hallmark of his economic and foreign policies. But when it came time to wrestle with Congress over putting it into effect he sided with special-interest manufacturers rather than the large number of U.S. companies that rely upon imports to help keep their output high and consumer prices down. Mr. Gibbons caved in. Today consumers will find out if the Senate Finance Committee will protect them from his retreat.

HEADLINE: In America;
Blacks' Problems, Seen Plain

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The speech was delivered in Indianapolis without a lot of flamboyant rhetoric. It spoke the truth, unadorned, without crude appeals to prejudice. It was courageous, intelligent and important.
Hugh P. Price, the new president of the National Urban League, said it was time for a new and more realistic approach to the problems plaguing African-Americans. He warned: "We must not let ourselves, and especially our children, fall into the paranoid trap of thinking that racism accounts for all that plagues us. The global realignment of work and wealth is, if anything, the bigger culprit." 
 In the overheated, oppressive, finger-pointing atmosphere in which much of our racial discourse is conducted, Mr. Price's speech was a welcome breeze. He was direct and unapologetic in his opposition to racism of any kind and to the fantasy of black separatism.
"Belief in racial inclusion goes to the marrow of my bones," he said. ". . . I fully understand the instinct to separate when we are incessantly under economic siege, when we're still discriminated against some 40 years after the Brown decision, and when, thanks to those recurring images on evening newscasts of black youngsters being hauled off to jail, even our honor students are trailed like common thieves when they enter stores.
"Even so, it's suicidal economically to become so bitter that we isolate ourselves from others."
Mr. Price's speech, the keynote address to the Urban League's national convention, was the latest acknowledgment that the role of traditional civil rights organizations has changed. Like the N.A.A.C.P., the primary focus of the Urban League is on finding remedies to the desperate situation facing poor blacks in America's inner cities. But the N.A.A.C.P. has alienated many of its traditional supporters by embracing Louis Farrakhan and others whose messages have been divisive at best, and at worst blatantly racist and anti-Semitic.
Mr. Price was clear on the direction the Urban League would take under his leadership. He said: "Many whites of good will have accompanied us on our long journey for racial, social and economic justice. None has matched the Jewish community as long-distance runners in the civil rights movement. Just as we denounce misleading media stereotypes of African-Americans, it is morally repugnant as well to impugn an entire people, especially longstanding allies, like Jews, because of the unconscionable behavior of some of them."
The essence of Mr. Price's speech was his recognition that the catastrophic circumstances enveloping so many African-Americans are in large part the result of changed economic conditions that are having a devastating effect on many whites as well. Blacks, with the least in the way of resources, are being hammered worst; but no ethnic group has been spared. Long gone are the days when the local manufacturing plant was the gateway to the middle class. The new world of employment is one that is steadily buffeted by technological innovation, radical corporate downsizing and the wholesale transfer of low-skilled jobs to low-wage workers overseas.
Said Mr. Price: "This ruthlessly competitive world waits for no nation, no ethnic group and no individual."
No substantial improvement in the condition of African-Americans in general and inner-city residents in particular can be achieved without a heroic effort to cope with these complex economic forces. That will require sophisticated leadership, unrelenting hard work, intellectual rigor and a firm commitment to reality. The belief that all evil is the result of the white man is worse than not helpful, it's monumentally destructive.
Hugh Price is one of many African-Americans throughout the country who have long since rolled up their sleeves and gone to work in a serious way on what has become a hideous array of social and economic problems. They have the talent and the will to succeed but not nearly enough support. Needless to say, they don't get the same attention as Jew-baiters and celebrities in handcuffs. But they are the true leaders. They are the ones who will make things better for future generations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How a Dollar Coin Hurts Ordinary Folks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Change for a Dollar" (editorial, July 15), recommending the dollar coin, would unleash a round of inflation that would hurt "little people" the most. Sodas may already be $1 in New York, but everywhere else they are mostly 70 to 80 cents. 
 As soon as a dollar coin is in wide circulation, all machine operators across the land will have the incentive to jump their prices to an even $1. They can't do it now because those dollar-bill slots are unreliable.
I did my part and kept using Susan B. Anthony dollars as long as my bank kept them in stock. But your Gotham-view idea will raise a child's or working person's cost 25 percent to 40 percent.
 
LEE D. VINCENT
Groton, Conn., July 18, 1994

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Now, Microsoft Wants To Gather Information

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation, fresh from a Federal antitrust settlement that did little to curb its dominance of the business software market, is now hoping to conquer an emerging field where the company's computer-nerd skills may, or may not, give it an edge: electronic publishing.
Like many traditional paper-and-ink publishers, and many other software companies, Microsoft is busy acquiring information to fill CD-ROM's, shiny disks that look like music CD's but can each contain the equivalent of 250,000 pages of text for playback on personal computers. When done right, the technology can combine true-to-life video images, sound and animation in a multimedia package that both entertains and educates. 
 Although the market for consumer CD-ROM titles was only about $325 million last year, it is growing rapidly and is expected to reach $1 billion a year by the end of 1996. And Microsoft ranks fourth in the field, on the strength of popular titles like "Cinemania," a $50 interactive guide with 19,000 movie reviews, and the $100 "Encarta," a leading CD-ROM encyclopedia.
 
Trying Something New
 But it is far from certain that Microsoft can ever dominate this new publishing market in the same way that it now leads in computer operating-system software and word processing programs. Unlike its earlier battles for emerging markets, this time the territory is less familiar to Microsoft.
"I don't think Microsoft will ever dominate the content business as thoroughly as they do the operating systems or word processing or spreadsheet businesses," said Charles H. Finnie, a multimedia analyst with Volpe, Welty & Company, an investment banker in San Francisco. "The content business is similar to the book or record business -- where people want to buy a lot of different things from a lot of sources."
And yet, as the publishing industry turns increasingly to the computing medium, Microsoft brings considerable technical skills, deep pockets and a well-developed distribution system for getting its shrink-wrapped software onto retail shelves.
"Our goal is to combine great software with great information," said Patty Stonesifer, head of Microsoft's consumer division.
At Microsoft -- the world's largest software company -- CD-ROM publishing is still a relatively small market: in the 1993 calendar year, it accounted for $30 million of Microsoft's revenue; for the fiscal year that ended June 30, Microsoft reported $4.65 billion in total revenue. But Microsoft officials say the company hopes to expand its CD-ROM business. Officials at the research house Dataquest Inc. said they expect Microsoft's CD-ROM revenue to grow more than six times, to $200 million annually in 1996.
The current market leaders are software companies far smaller than Microsoft. At the top, with an 18 percent market share, is Compton's New Media, acquired last year by the Tribune Company, whose holdings include The Chicago Tribune newspaper.
But virtually all the big publishing companies in New York have started new media businesses. The book publisher Simon & Schuster will soon enter the field with its first two CD-ROM titles: "The Macmillan Dictionary for Children" and "Firefighter," a children's book about firemen and women. Time Warner Inc., the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company and Grolier Inc. are already well established in CD-ROM's. And the magazine publishers the Hearst Corporation and Conde Nast Publications Inc. are both thought to have their sights set on the market.
It may be that when it comes to this unusual business, which resembles the music industry more than it does the software business, Microsoft may simply be one of the pack.
Microsoft's sprawling headquarters in a pine grove east of Seattle are far from the New York publishing scene and the Los Angeles entertainment capital. And the distances may be more than geographic.
 
Partnerships Promise Challenge
 In the emerging industry of electronic publishing, the key is building partnerships with the owners of "content" -- writers, photographers, film makers -- and Microsoft's critics are skeptical the company is capable of making such relationships work.
"Name a significant Microsoft partnership that has worked out for the partner," said Nick Arnett, president of the Multimedia Computing Corporation, a consulting company in Santa Clara, Calif.
Mr. Arnett is one of the many Microsoft critics who contend that Microsoft, with its techie staff and tough negotiating tactics, will be unable to work with what is collectively called "talent."
Such criticisms have evidently not been entirely lost on Microsoft, which two years ago hired Peter Mollman, a longtime executive in book publishing, to handle its licensing arrangements with information providers. Mr. Mollman had recently retired as president of the encyclopedia company World Book International in Chicago when he was lured to Microsoft as director of intellectual property development.
Under Mr. Mollman, Microsoft appears to be going after a wholesome, World Book-type of audience. Compared with the titles list of some other publishers, which include CD-ROM's of rock musicians and wildly offbeat games, such as the Voyager Company's "Freak Show," about the behind-the-scenes shenanigans at a fictional carnival, Microsoft's product list is decidedly uplifting. Five of its titles, for example, are about classical music.
 
A Veteran of Young Market
 Microsoft is hardly new to the consumer publishing field. Seven years ago, it became the first large software company to offer a mass-market CD-ROM title when it released a collection of reference works, "Microsoft Bookshelf." But like most of the CD-ROM's of that era, "Bookshelf" was strictly text, lacking the multimedia embellishments standard in today's products.
And even three years ago, Microsoft was having a tough time convincing the movie industry of the viability of a CD-ROM guide to the movies. "They really couldn't envision it," said Nils von Veh, program manager in Microsoft's consumer division, which publishes "Cinemania," an interactive compendium of movie reviews and other information that includes actual film clips. "Now they're just mad when you leave something out."
Though still small, Microsoft's consumer division is one of the fastest growing in the company. There, about 600 of the company's 15,000 total employees toil away on Microsoft's growing CD-ROM line, which now includes about 50 titles and is expected to double within one year.
The best-selling title is the "Encarta" encyclopedia, which illustrates the equivalent of thousands of pages of reference material with video clips, still images and sound. Increasingly, Microsoft plans to link reference works like Encarta to on-line network services, enabling users to retrieve the latest information about a particular entry. Already, with the brand-new "Microsoft Complete Baseball" CD-ROM, users can connect to Microsoft's Baseball Daily, an on-line service that provides updated statistics from the day's major league baseball games.
"I think it's pretty clear that in the future, information and tools will come together," Ms. Stonesifer said. Determining which information will be sold on the CD-ROM disk and which should be updated over the network will depend on what the company calls the data's "freshness factor."
 
Distribution Advantage
 One of Microsoft's major advantages in entering any new market is distribution, and in the competitive retail software market, where shelf space is limited, Microsoft already has a strong presence. Moreover, the American Booksellers Association conference in June, Microsoft announced it had signed a deal with the Ingram Book Company, the large book wholesaler, to start putting its CD-ROM titles into bookstores.
And while some "content" owners may prefer to deal with publishers perhaps more savvy in the ways of Hollywood and New York, others seem happy to sign on with a technology giant like Microsoft.
Scholastic Inc., itself a New York book publisher, is one. The company recently selected Microsoft to develop and publish an electronic version of its children's books, "The Magic School Bus" because, said Deborah Forte, executive vice president, it wanted the most advanced multimedia technology available.
"We were very capable just doing an electronic book, but that's not the experience we wanted," she said. "We're not there yet in terms of technical expertise. We wanted someone who could push the limits."

HEADLINE: THE WHITEWATER AFFAIR: THE PRESIDENT;
The Contrasts of Clinton, Only a TV Click Apart

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's Presidency has always spun from its reel so fast, with scenes of achievement and grace swiftly eclipsed by scenes of dishevelment and awkwardness. So it did not seem at all odd today to see both on the screen at once, separated only by the click of a tuner.
 There was Mr. Clinton in the White House between Yitzhak Rabin and King Hussein, basking in his second Middle East diplomatic triumph, hearing Jordan's leader say he was "proud to have you as our partner." And there -- click -- was Mr. Clinton's counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler, parked before a microphone, telling a House committee investigating Whitewater that Administration officials had done nothing wrong, really, but that they shouldn't have done it. 
This happened occasionally to Mr. Clinton's predecessors -- George Bush threw up on television, after all, at the climax of a Tokyo trade conference -- but not since William Henry Harrison caught pneumonia at his inauguration and died 32 days later has Presidential triumph seemed so closely dogged by fate.
 Some of it is fate, and a past that refuses to stay in the past. But a large measure is rooted elsewhere, in Mr. Clinton's unmade-bed style of policy-making, in his and his staff's newness to governing and in the rise of tabloid-style news, both in print and on television. Together, they are eroding not only the President's political and moral standing, but the policies he is trying to promote.
 "A cloud does tend to be there that's always following him through the fields," one White House official said this week, attributing much of the problem to "naivete and hubris."
 
Victory-Loss Cycle
 In this case, the Whitewater cloud fogs not only the Middle East accord but also the last-minute drive for health legislation, perhaps the central issue of the Clinton Presidency. Mr. Clinton's European summit conference this month, essentially a bid to establish his foreign-policy credentials, was negated by his Administration's foundering Haiti policy.
 In January, the naming of a Whitewater special counsel drowned out the signing of a nuclear-arms accord in Ukraine. The President's first State of the Union Message, a booming call for fiscal restraint and wise investment, was wiped from memory weeks later when the White House's first budget bill -- a $20 billion package of "stimulus" spending -- was denounced as pork, and rejected.
 Some White House officials suggest there is little the President can do about a victory-loss cycle they say is dictated by the news media and his critics and that, in effect, Mr. Clinton is a victim of his own good intentions.
 Mr. Clinton was not legally required to name a Whitewater special counsel and thereby prolong public scrutiny of his Arkansas real-estate venture, they say. And no recent President has faced such vociferous critics, or a press so ravenous for bad news and bristling with technology to spread it.
 
Product of the Process
 "This President has an ambitious agenda," another senior official said today, "and whenever you have an ambitious agenda, you're going to draw energetic enemies and risk both criticism and defeat."
 Mr. Clinton sometimes loses, that official argued, because he fights for important matters. President Bush won the Gulf War and asked Congress for a highway bill in return.
 But if critics celebrate it and the press spreads it, much of the cloud that follows Mr. Clinton is a product of the process that got him to the White House to begin with. Political parties no longer vet candidates or even choose them; increasingly, the candidates rise from outside Washington on the skill of commercials and press relations as well as ability.
 Mr. Clinton is the latest modern master of the campaign, and his political aides once boasted of using the instant technology of modern news coverage during his race to bat down stories about Whitewater and his sex life. Such tactics did not bury those issues, it now turns out, but only postponed them until candidate Clinton became President Clinton and the center of global attention.
 "He procrastinates," said Stephen Hess, the veteran student of Presidents at the Brookings Institution, "and things catch up with him. He'll let something slide, and then he throws the energy, the intellect and the power of the Presidency into it. It's been a high-wire act for one and a half years."
 
Victories, but No Credit
 Indeed, White House officials say the foreign-policy dilemmas that have horned in on Mr. Clinton's Presidency in places like Haiti and North Korea are both inherited and unavoidable in the post-Soviet world. Others argue that Mr. Clinton has put off meeting those trouble spots head-on, only to discover that they just get bigger instead of going away.
 One result of Mr. Clinton's inability to string together any victories is confusion among the people who elected him President. For instance, consumer confidence in the economy is at the highest level in at least four years -- six, by some polls -- but according to the latest New York Times-CBS News survey, Mr. Clinton has reaped almost none of the credit in the last year. Indeed, more people disapprove of his handling of the economy than approve of it.
 Similarly, the President's foreign travels and peacemaking have failed to halt the drop in approval of his handling of foreign policy, now at the lowest level since his inauguration.
 It is true that the President's approval ratings have had their own peaks and valleys in the last 18 months, themselves a function of his performance in office. "When he's good," Mr. Hess said, "he's very, very good. But when he's bad, he's horrid."
 But judging by polls, people seem not to know whether the man in the White House on any given day is the Good Clinton or the horrid one. And so for now, they trust neither.


GRAPHIC: The House Banking Committee opened hearings today on what has become known as the "Washington phase" of the Whitewater investigation -- in particular, on the propriety of contacts between the White House and Treasury Department officials involved in investigations of a failed Arkansas savings and loan. That bank, Madison Guaranty, was owned by James B. McDougal, the Clintons' partner in their Whitewater real estate venture. Here is a chronology of such contacts that have been publicly revealed, drawn from documents submitted to the committee and from an account provided today by the White House counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler.
 
1993
 
March 24 -- A fax of a 1992 newspaper article about the Clintons and Whitewater is sent from the office of Roger C. Altman, Deputy Treasury Secretary, then acting head of the Resolution Trust Corporation (R.T.C.), to Bernard W. Nussbaum, then the White House counsel.
 
Sept. 29 -- Jean E. Hanson, the Treasury Department's general counsel, alerts Mr. Nussbaum that the R.T.C. plans to issue a criminal referral asking the Justice Department to investigate Madison Guaranty, a request that names the Clintons as possible beneficiaries of illegal actions.
 
Sept. 30 -- In a memorandum to Mr. Altman, Ms. Hanson says she has briefed both the Treasury Secretary and White House officials about the investigation.
 
October -- President Clinton is briefed about the request by Federal regulators for a criminal investigation into Madison.
 
October 4 or 5 -- Bruce Lindsey, a top White House aide, tells the President about press inquires on the referral.
 
Oct. 8 -- The R.T.C. formally asks the Justice Department to look into the matter.
 
Oct. 14 -- A meeting is held in Mr. Nussbaum's office to discuss how to handle the press inquiries. Those attending include Mr. Nussbaum; Mark D. Gearan, White House director of communications; Mr. Lindsey, Neil Eggleston and Clifford Sloan, White House lawyers; Ms. Hanson, Joshua L. Steiner, chief of staff to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, and Jack DeVore, then Mr. Bentsen's press secretary.. Dec. 30 -- During an annual New Year's retreat, Eugene A. Ludwig, comptroller of the currency, has a brief exchange with the President about Whitewater. After consulting with White House lawyers, Mr. Ludwig decides it would be unwise to have further discussions with Mr. Clinton on the matter.
 
1994
 
Jan. 4 or 11 -- Mr. Altman notes in his diary that Margaret Williams, Hillary Rodham Clinton's chief of staff, told him that Mrs. Clinton was "paralyzed" by Whitewater. He also records his impression that the White House was trying to negotiate limits on the scope of an independent counsel's jurisdiction, if one was appointed.
 
Feb. 2 -- Mr. Altman meets with Mr. Nussbaum, Mr. Eggleston, Mr. Ickes and Ms. Williams to give the White House a "heads up" on how the regulators would proceed on potential civil claims arising out of Madison's failure. Mr. Altman raises the question of whether he should remove himself from supervising the Madison investigation. Mr. Nussbaum argues against such a move and the other participants question its necessity.
 
Feb. 3 -- Mr. Altman decides not to remove himself. Sometime later in the month, in separate conversations with the President and Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Ickes informs them of Mr. Altman's decision.
 
Feb. 12 and Feb. 27 -- Mr. Steiner comments in his diary that Mr. Altman is under "intense pressure" by the White House not to remove himself from the case and that the officials present at the Feb. 2 meeting told Mr. Altman that recusal was "unacceptable."
 
Feb. 24 -- Mr. Altman testifies before a Senate hearing and acknowledges that there have been discussions between Treasury and White House officials about the investigation. Later White House officials express concern to Mr. Altman about the completeness of his testimony.
 
Feb. 25 -- Mr. Altman announces his decision that he will remove himself from the Madison investigation and that he will step down as R.T.C's acting head. George Stephanopoulos, a senior Clinton advisor, complains to Mr. Steiner about the manner in which Mr. Altman's decision was announced and also complains about the decision of the R.T.C. to hire a former Republican prosecutor, Jay B. Stephens, to investigate the collapse of Madison. Mr. Stephanopoulos and Mr. Ickes, in a conference call with Mr. Altman, criticize Mr. Altman for failing to give the White House advance notice of his decision. In a diary entry, Mr. Steiner writes that they said that the President was "furious."

HEADLINE: Defector Says North Korea Has 5 A-Bombs and May Make More

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, July 28

 BODY:
The South Korean intelligence agency presented on Wednesday what it said was a high-level North Korean defector who said that, despite repeated denials, the Government in Pyongyang had five nuclear bombs and might soon develop five more.
If his remarkable story is true, Kang Myong Do, 35, may be the most damaging defector ever to escape from North Korea, one of the most closed societies on earth. His story could also spur a reassessment of efforts to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear program. 
 Mr. Kang was introduced at a news conference in Seoul as the son-in-law of North Korea's Prime Minister, Kang Sung San. He said North Korea's new leader, Kim Jong Il, sees the development of nuclear weapons not as a bargaining chip, but as the only way to save his Government in the face of a collapsing economy. Ten bombs, Mr. Kang said, would give him the muscle he needs to stand up to the United States.
"There is a firm belief that the only way to sustain the Kim Jong Il system is to have nuclear capabilities," he said.
There was no way to confirm the veracity of Mr. Kang's claims, which would contradict even the gloomiest estimates by the Central Intelligence Agency. In a statement issued today, the North Korean Government denied that Mr. Kang is related to the Prime Minister, and said he was a fugitive. And some western intelligence officials and diplomats expressed deep skepticism after analyzing Mr. Kang's comments.
[Defense Secretary William J. Perry said the Pentagon was taking the defector's report seriously, though he still stood behind a United States intelligence estimate that the North probably had reprocessed enough plutonium to build one or two nuclear explosive devices, not five.]
True or not, there was concern about the South Korean intelligence service's motives in choosing this sensitive moment, two months after it said Mr. Kang had defected, to put him on display. The South Korean action could be interpreted as an attempt to poison the atmosphere at high-level talks between American and North Korean officials on the nuclear issue. Those talks are scheduled to resume in Geneva on Aug. 5. They were suspended three weeks ago after the death of the North's leader, Kim Il Sung.
There are some officials in Seoul who say the American and South Korean Governments may be induced to give up too much in the negotiations with Pyongyang, which they do not trust. So there was speculation that the officials might have been trying to pre-empt such a prospect by painting the North Korean nuclear program in the starkest possible terms.
The North Koreans have long denied that they are developing nuclear bombs, but they have refused to give international inspectors access to several nuclear sites where they may have produced or stored plutonium, the raw material for nuclear bombs.
Mr. Kang said he was vice president of a trading company under the control of the President's office. He said he decided to defect in May, during a business trip to China.
Neither he nor the intelligence officials offered any details on how he escaped, other than to say that he passed through a third country. No reason was given regarding why it took roughly two months for South Korea to release information on the defection or to present Mr. Kang.
Mr. Kang said he had learned details of the nuclear program, being carried out at a site 60 miles north Pyongyang at Yongbyon, from a senior official in the security service.
Mr. Kang said that Kim Jong Il is determined to build the bombs, and rockets capable of delivering them, in a desperate struggle for survival. Mr. Kang said North Korea already has five nuclear bombs. When it has ten, Mr. Kang said, Kim Jong Il will disclose their existence as a deterrent and potent tool in negotiations, while tryng to strengthen the North's battered economy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
The Export-Import Bank of Japan is negotiating a huge, politically sensitive loan to the Ford Motor Company. The low-rate loan, which could run to as much as $300 million, would help Ford manufacture right-hand drive autos for export to Japan. [D1.]
Ford reported all-time record quarterly earnings of $1.71 billion for the three months ending in June, as strong demand more than doubled the average profit the company made on every car and truck it sold. [D1.] 
 Bidders for Madison Square Garden are competing for a glamorous group of assets that includes one of the world's most famous arenas, a cable television sports network, an N.B.A. finalist basketball team and a Stanley Cup-winning hockey team. What the package does not include is a lot of profits. [D1.]
Ball is struggling to refocus in the face of uncertainty about who will lead the company, the overcapacity and slow growth that are bedeviling its mainstay can and bottle businesses, and cutbacks in military spending that have hurt its aerospace business. [D1.]
Thinking Machines is in danger of going out of business unless it can find a big investor or buyer soon. [D1.]
The stock of Biogen soared after the biotechnology company announced promising results in slowing the effects of multiple sclerosis. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Durable Orders Up 1.3%, Showing Factory Health

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
In the latest sign of robust health in the nation's manufacturing industries, orders and shipments of cars, industrial machinery and other durable goods rose in June, the Commerce Department announced today.
Stock and bond prices fell sharply on the news, as traders and investors concluded that continued strong growth in the economy made it more likely that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates soon to prevent the economy from overheating. Investors also worried about declining earnings. 
 Orders for durable manufactured goods rose 1.3 percent in June, while shipments rose 1.1 percent, the Government announced. Private economists had expected orders to rise around five-tenths of a percentage point.
 
Orders Are Volatile
 Durable goods orders tend to be volatile and sometimes send contradictory signals about the economy's direction. But orders have now risen for four straight months and 10 of the last 11 months. Because new orders exceeded shipments in June, the backlog of unfilled orders at factories around the country also grew by two-tenths of a percentage point.
"It portends strong industrial activity in the next several months at least," said Eugene J. Sherman, the director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, a brokerage firm.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown welcomed today's figures, particularly a rise in orders for big-ticket factory and office equipment, a category that includes everything from steam turbines to computers. "Not only is the economy growing at an appropriate rate, not only do interest rates remain at a relatively low rate but consumer confidence is up and more importantly, business confidence is up," he said in a telephone interview today.
Orders fell only for military goods and primary metals like steel and copper.
The big mystery in the American economy today lies in who will buy all the goods that American factories are producing. Economists estimate that consumer spending grew only 1 percent in the second quarter after growing at a 4 percent pace in the previous three quarters.
 
Inventories on Rise
 Because consumers account for two-thirds of all purchases in the economy, their new caution has resulted in a sharp rise in companies' inventories. Much of the nation's strong economic growth in the second quarter seems to have gone into inventories, said Kenneth P. Mayland, the chief financial economist and senior vice president at Keycorp, a Cleveland-based bank.
The Commerce Department is scheduled to announce on Friday morning its first estimate of economic growth in the second quarter, an announcement that traders have been eagerly awaiting as a clear signal of the economy's overall health and of the Federal Reserve's likely course on interest rates in the coming weeks. Today's durable goods figures showed strengthening activity in many different manufacturing industries, from cars to railroad equipment, suggesting that second-quarter economic growth was quite strong, Mr. Mayland said.
The durable goods announcement seems likely to fan concerns at the Federal Reserve about two possible sources of future inflation that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, described in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee last week.
One concern is that the economy will grow so fast that production bottlenecks will appear and companies will be forced to bid up the prices for scarce materials and skilled workers, he said. The central bank has already noted spot shortages of truck drivers and construction workers as the economy moves closer to operating at full capacity, he added.
The other possible source of inflation could arise if bank loans rise sharply, Mr. Greenspan said, while adding that he had not yet seen any sign of this. A sharp rise in borrowing would feed more money into the economy and allow individuals and companies to bid up the prices of goods and services.

HEADLINE: Financing for Times Square Leads to Harsher Criticism

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Less than a week before a critical deadline in the long-delayed plan to redevelop Times Square, a new report from one of the project's most prominent critics suggests that the deal for four huge office towers has created a financial quagmire that could cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.
The report, issued this week by the Municipal Art Society, calculated that because of tax abatements the state has promised the developers of the proposed towers, the city and the state would receive from $1.5 billion to $4.2 billion less in taxes paid than they would get from a similar office complex built without subsidies. 
 "This is an unbelievably large subsidy going to four buildings that never made sense for the site, and are even worse now," said Kent Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society.
The abatements were promised to a development team led by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, to compensate it for the money it has agreed to put up so the state can condemn property for the towers as well as theaters and retail space. The developers have already paid more than $270 million for condemnation, an amount that state officials say may increase.
 
Facing a Deadline
 Next week the project is expected to take a significant step forward. The developers face a deadline on Monday for committing themselves to $20 million in improvements on the shabby and vacant buildings that now line the redevelopment area.
Renovation would mean that new businesses could move in, providing the basis for what state officials call their interim plan to reinvigorate the area until the developers decide that Manhattan's weak real-estate market has recovered enough to build their office towers.
State officials, and a spokeswoman for the developers, said they expected an agreement on the interim plan, and even the harshest critics of the redevelopment plan said they would welcome new street-level businesses.
But it is the long-term plan for four huge office towers that has provoked criticism from its inception and that some analysts now say has become a far worse deal over time.
Mr. Barwick's group recommended that the state pay back the developers' money that they have already used to condemn property. Then, if the developers want to build office towers, they would do so without public subsidies, the group said.
 
Long-Term Tax Relief
 State officials angrily rejected the analysis, saying that if anyone loses money on the Times Square plan, it will be the developers.
"To suggest, at this point, that the developers are getting a sweet deal is just absurd," said Rebecca Robertson, head of the 42d Street Development Project, a state agency. Though Prudential and its partner, George Klein, will receive long-term tax abatements, perhaps extending more than 50 years, she said the tax break may not fully reimburse the developers for the $270 million investment they have made in the project.
Still, the Municipal Art Society's analysis is not the first to criticize the project. "The subsidies go off the chart," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of urban planning and economics at New York University, who said the tax breaks would extend through the life of the 99-year lease the developers are to hold on the land under their buildings. Even so, he said, the developers may lose money.
No one denies that the project has been overtaken by a boom-and-bust cycle in the city's real-estate market.
Since th mid-1980's, more than a dozen large office towers have been built in the area, mainly at the north end of Times Square, creating a surplus of office space that has now persuaded Mr. Klein and Prudential to delay their project.
The developers took a critical step in 1990, when they turned over a letter of credit of $241 million to cover the condemnation costs.
The letter of credit came on top of $88 million that the developers had already paid for condemnation, a reflection of the rising value of real estate in the nine years since 1981, when Prudential and Mr. Klein won the right to develop the property.
So far, Ms. Robertson said, $192 million of the developers' letter of credit has been used. And since property owners have gone to court seeking more than the state has offered, the costs could grow beyond the limits of the developers' $241 million note, requiring them to commit more money or walk away from the huge investment they have already made.
The potential cost to taxpayers has also grown. That is because the developers' contract with the state gives them long-term tax abatements in return for their land costs.
When state officials first estimated that it would cost no more than $88 million to condemn the property, they thought it would take no more than 20 years worth of tax abatements for the developers to recoup their investment. Now, with the costs exceeding $270 million and growing, Mr. Tobier said, the developers may never get their money back.
Further complicating the deal is that the developers are to begin receiving interest on that money when construction starts on the office towers. The money would come through tax abatements. According to several scenarios calculated by the Municipal Art Society, the accumulated interest would eventually exceed $1 billion. But Ms. Robertson said taxpayers would not be obligated to pay those costs beyond the tax breaks Prudential would get.

HEADLINE: A Russian Pyramid Collapses, Burying Belief in Capitalism

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 27

 BODY:
Driven by equal doses of panic and greed, thousands of investors swarmed stock exchanges, offices and the headquarters of Russia's largest stock fund today, desperately trying to sell the company's shares, which have lost half their value in less than a day.
With at least five million shareholders, the company, MMM, had become the most visible, and aggressive symbol of the rowdy new capitalism here, churning profits seemingly out of air, and turning everyone from penny- pinching grandmothers to college kids into stock market addicts. 
 In the process, the company's outspoken chief, Sergei Mavrody, turned himself into a populist icon: a man who promises to deliver a piece of the good life to anyone willing to risk a little money to get a lot more back. He considers his investors a "political force," and says their growing power rivals the Kremlin.
That was before Tuesday, when the company abruptly refused to buy any of its own shares at dozens of offices throughout Moscow. This evening, every Moscow news show was filled with news of MMM and the possibility that its magic was made only with smoke and mirrors.
 
Investors Camp Out
 "How could I not invest in this company?" asked one forlorn woman, Galya S. Bondaryan, who like hundreds had slept on the company's grounds Tuesday night in an effort to be one of the few who could sell her shares back today. "They promised everything. And it seemed like they were going to be honest. I thought this was how the stock market worked."
Unfortunately her confused understanding of capitalism and her attraction to seemingly impossible returns on investment are still common in Russia. And beneath MMM's lucrative veneer and behind the ubiquitous television ads that promise apartments in Paris and vacations in San Francisco, the company is nothing but a classic, and monumentally huge, pyramid scheme. Aware that its collapse could do irreparable damage to the fragile image of a free market, Russian leaders, including President Boris N. Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor K. Chernomyrdin, have begged people to find another place to put their funds.
They and most other political leaders here -- from right-wing nationalists like Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky to liberal reformers like Yegor T. Gaidar -- have denounced the potbellied, lascivious stars of MMM's advertising campaign. The two middle-aged men, who are always pictured on television lounging in foreign capitals swilling beer, have become heroes.
"People don't want to believe that this firm is built on air and is going to collapse," the newspaper Izvestia said in an editorial today. "All they want to hear is that the value of their shares will grow every day no matter what. They want to believe that MMM has never in any way tried to deceive them. Its always easier to blame these problems on the Government."
 
Warnings on Other Companies
 But the warnings of doom have been sounding with increasing frequency lately, not only about MMM but other, similar companies as well. Many well known economists and Government officials have predicted that further investment in these elaborate schemes could not only ruin the economy but destroy any hope of generating confidence in capitalism.
"Companies like MMM siphon enormous amounts of money from credulous people," Andrei Koshevarov, head of the Ministry of Finance's department that oversees stock markets, told the Itar-Tass news service today. "The campaign by MMM has assumed all the signs of financial drug addiction. Original investors are dividing the money invested by those after them."
That, of course, is what a pyramid scheme is all about. Each new round of investors supplies the money for the previous group. Such schemes offer higher and higher returns to lure new investors. Shares that cost 1,600 rubles in February (then worth about a dollar) had climbed to 105,000 (about $50) on Monday.
By today, however, shares were back to 13,000 rubles (a little more than $6) and rumors spread rapidly across Moscow that the company was on the verge of collapse.

HEADLINE: Supercomputer Pioneer Seeks Investor or Buyer

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 27

 BODY:
The Thinking Machines Corporation, the company that pioneered the technology for today's fastest supercomputers only to see larger companies invade its market, is in danger of going out of business unless it can find a big investor or buyer soon.
Several industry executives said today that Thinking Machines was negotiating with both Sun Microsystems and AT&T to invest in the company or buy it outright. If the talks fail, it is unlikely that Thinking Machines will survive, said the executives, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 Thinking Machines' president, Richard P. Fishman, declined to comment on which companies might be negotiating with the privately held supercomputer maker. But he did say the company had been looking for a partner for many months.
"We're trying to work things out under extremely difficult constraints," Mr. Fishman said. "We're pushing against the clock."
Although Thinking Machines is relatively small, with an estimated $90 million in revenues last year, it has the second-largest share of the $450 million market for a type of supercomputer known as massively parallel processing machines. But the world's largest chip maker, the Intel Corporation, is the leader in the field, and other giants like I.B.M. are also threatening to surpass Thinking Machines.
The company may be the victim of having invented a successful technology that bigger companies are better equipped to pursue. Thinking Machines is also feeling the effects of the end of the cold war, which has eroded Federal financing for supercomputer research and has curtailed the Federal Government's budget for buying such machines, which have typically sold for $10 million or more.
Founded in 1983 by a group of former Massachusetts Institute of Technology students and based in Cambridge, Mass., Thinking Machines originated the idea of massively parallel computing: chaining together tens of thousands of inexpensive microprocessor chips to reach supercomputer speeds. The tiny start-up company ultimately transformed the very top of the computing world with this approach, which breaks big problems into millions of discrete elements and solves them simultaneously.
The older approach to supercomputing, which is based on a small number of powerful, more expensive processors, still constitutes a larger market, estimated to surpass $1 billion this year. The leader in this field is Cray Research. But even Cray is now moving with the market toward massively parallel computers.
The technology takes advantage of the rapidly collapsing cost of off-the-shelf chips that are used in personal computers and work stations. It has changed the economics of the high-performance segment of the computer industry and is beginning to infiltrate corporate mainframe computing as well. American Express, for example, uses a Thinking Machines computer to plow through its wealth of credit-card information for detailed information about customers.
But machines for the corporate market tend to be priced much lower than the $15 million to $30 million machines that the Government was once willing to buy in computing-intensive military research programs like Star Wars.
 
 
A 'Replacement Market'
 "All the people in the world who want to buy $15 to $30 million supercomputers already have one," said Chris Willard, an analyst at the International Data Corporation, a market research company in Framingham, Mass. "It's now a mature replacement market."
With initial funds from the Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Defense Department, the Government virtually created the market for massively parallel computers in the 1980's. Indeed, the Pentagon agency gave Thinking Machines a $12 million grant in 1989 as seed money to develop a supercomputer capable of achieving a teraflop -- a trillion mathematical operations a second. But that was only a fraction of the cost that Thinking Machines and other companies said the project might cost, and no computer maker has yet achieved the goal.
Since then, the Government has seemed less interested in pursuing the teraflop goal. And Thinking Machines, which has been pursuing new avenues of support from the Government, has been told that several large orders for its supercomputers are unlikely to materialize until next year.
 
 
Energy Secretary Laments Fate
 Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, whose department helps subsidize supercomputing research, said today in a telephone interview that the demise of Thinking Machines would be unfortunate. "If we lose this jewel of a company, as a nation we are doing ourselves a disservice," she said.
Although she had no comment on financing for Thinking Machines, she did say it was in the Government's interest to support such companies. "You have to create a policy that insures that the pie is cut so there is an opportunity for both small and large companies."
But without the pressures of a cold war, industry executives said, and because supercomputing remains a field in which American industry holds a significant technical lead over the rest of the world, it is unlikely that Federal officials will be motivated to step in to save an ailing company.
Danny Hillis, Thinking Machines' co-founder and currently chief scientist, voiced frustration today that the Government had lost, since the end of the cold war, its urgency in pushing private industry to develop increasingly faster computers. "If the cold war had stopped in the middle of Apollo program," he said, "we never would have reached the moon."
But analysts say some of troubles of Thinking Machines are of its own making, citing a difficult product transition with its newest model, the CM-5, which was introduced two years ago.
 
Missed Opportunities
 "They missed a product cycle with the CM-5," said Terry Bennett, a computer industry analyst at Infocorp, a Santa Clara, Calif, market research company. After the CM-5 came on the market, it took more than nine months for the company to add a special math processing chip to provide its full performance.
Several years ago, moreover, Thinking Machines had an opportunity to merge with Cray Research, industry executives said. But the deal apparently collapsed after the two companies deadlocked over the value of Thinking Machines. Cray subsequently introduced its own massively parallel computer, called the T3D, which is challenging the CM-5.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford's Profit In 2d Quarter Set a Record

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., July 27

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company today reported all-time record quarterly earnings of $1.71 billion for the three months ending in June, as strong demand more than doubled the average profit the company made on each car and truck it sold.
Ford attributed the results, which amounted to $1.63 a share, to continued robust sales in the United States and a stronger than expected recovery in the European auto market. 
 But Ford was quick to say that its earnings, which exceeded the expectations of analysts, still lagged behind its own aspirations. "It isn't good enough," said David N. McCammon, the auto maker's vice president for finance and treasurer. "Our return on sales isn't to the level that we believe it needs to be."
 
Foreign Earnings Up Steeply
 Worldwide, Ford's revenue for the quarter was $33.8 billion, up 14.8 percent from $29.4 billion in the comparable quarter of 1993. The earnings were more than double last year's level of $775 million.
Still, Mr. McCammon said, Ford, the No. 2 auto maker, made only 69 percent as much as the Chrysler Corporation on each vehicle it sold in the quarter. To close the gap, he said, Ford must lower its vehicle-development and purchasing costs, and continue shifting production from cars to more profitable light trucks like sport utility vehicles.
Light trucks accounted for 53 percent of production in the second quarter, he said, up from 49 percent in the comparable period a year ago.
Given the strength of the recovery in the domestic auto market, Wall Street analysts said they were pleased yet appeared a bit blase about the earnings.
"They were obviously very strong results," said David Bradley, auto analyst for J. P. Morgan in New York. "The auto industry is doing fine, they're doing fine, and they should continue to do fine."
But in a down day on the market, shares of Ford fell $1, to $30.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Many investors have already discounted solid earnings from the Big Three auto makers.
Ford's previous earnings record for a quarter came in the second quarter of 1988, when the company made $1.66 billion. Partly because customers flock to dealerships in the spring, the second quarter tends to be the strongest of the year for the car companies. Chrysler reported all-time record earnings two weeks ago, and General Motors is expected to report strong earnings on Thursday.
Like Chrysler, Ford has been reducing rebates and other incentives to customers as demand has strengthened. The average incentive cost per vehicle during the second quarter was $550, down from $755 in the comparable period a year ago. In the first quarter this year, the average rebate was only $15 more, or $565.
Some analysts said they were worried that the costs were not dropping as fast as expected, which may help explain why Ford's profit margins were not fatter.
In addition, the company still sells a relatively high portion of its vehicles to commercial fleets, which negotiate lower prices by buying in bulk. In the second quarter, 25 percent of Ford's sales were to fleets, compared with 28 percent in the quarter a year ago.
 
More, Sooner
 While Ford's per-vehicle profit has jumped, it has not happened as fast as the company would like. Its after-tax return on automotive sales during the quarter was 4.2 percent, up 2.5 percentage points from the comparable quarter last year but below its goal of 6 percent for a strong second period. After taxes, the average profit per vehicle in the quarter was $945, more than twice last year's level of $462, but well below Chrysler's average of $1,360. G.M. makes less per vehicle than Ford.
With sales rising in an expanding market, Ford ended June with 25 percent of the United States car and truck sales, the same as a year ago.
Amid all this, the company has been hiring workers. At the end of the second quarter, Ford had 74,046 salaried workers in the United States, about 2,700 more than a year ago. It had 100,845 hourly workers, an increase of about 2,800.
The auto maker's earnings were bolstered by its performance in Europe, where its substantial reduction in employees and other cost-cutting moves in the last two years appear to be taking hold as economies begin strengthening. The company's European operations, excluding Jaguar, earned $244 million, compared with a loss of $66 million last year.
"The European economy is coming back quicker and stronger than we expected," Mr. McCammon said.
Jaguar continued to struggle during the quarter, losing $62 million, the same amount as last year. Mr. McCammon said Ford expected Jaguar to become profitable as soon as 1995. In December 1989, it paid $2.5 billion for the British luxury auto maker, and has since invested hundreds of millions more in it.
Also augmenting Ford's earnings was the strong performance of the financial-services subsidiaries. The wholly owned finance arm, Ford Credit, posted earnings for the quarter of $368 million, up 20.3 percent from $306 million in the comparable quarter last year.
The earnings were helped, as well, by a one-time gain of $31.4 million from the sale of Ford's minority interest in Manheim Auto Auctions, and another one-time gain of $13 million from the sale of receivables.

HEADLINE: State Says Giuliani's Budget Leaves a Gap of $600 Million

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Three days after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered up to $450 million in contingency cuts in the city's budget, the State Comptroller issued a stern critique of New York City's finances yesterday that concluded that the Mayor had still not done enough to avert a budget crunch in the coming months.
In a report that tempered enthusiasm for some of the Mayor's initiatives with criticisms of others, the Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said the budget still included a gap of more than $600 million, caused by the failure to account for spending on things like overtime and pensions. 
 The Comptroller's report also identified another $150 million in risky assumptions or initiatives that have not yet come to pass, including increases in Federal aid and concessions from the city's municipal unions.
Mr. McCall said the city's budget problems had not been this severe this early in a fiscal year since the city regained full control of its budgets from the state's Financial Control Board in 1986, during the economically robust years under Mayor Edward I. Koch. And he warned that the city's fiscal position could worsen if the Mayor did not move quickly to plug the hole.
"If the Mayor doesn't close the gap with actions that produce recurring savings, the city will face larger gaps in future years," Mr. McCall said.
The report by Mr. McCall -- a Democrat who faces an election contest this fall -- is the first of three to be issued this week by the city's fiscal monitors. All are expected to point out serious risks in the Mayor's $31.6 billion budget, which was adopted by the City Council in June and took effect with the new fiscal year on July 1.
The state's Financial Control Board and the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, are to release similar reviews of the Mayor's budget today. Their reports are expected to identify as much as $1 billion in risky assumptions or initiatives and also to call for more steps to avert a shortfall.
The State Comptroller has no power to change the city's budget. But his critique, like those of the other fiscal monitors, is likely to influence Wall Street bond raters and investors, whose assessment of the city's fiscal health affects the interest rates New York must pay on money it borrows.
On Monday, Mr. Giuliani ordered the commissioners of each agency to come up with a 2.6 percent cut in spending across the board to build up the city's reserves by $250 million, to a total of $400 million by the fall. He also told them to prepare to cut another $200 million in case other parts of his budget unravel.
The Mayor's action, less than a month after his budget took effect, appeared to be timed at least in part to blunt the criticism from the monitors, although Mr. Giuliani said it was part of his long-planned strategy to control spending. He also had to address an unexpected $160 million hole in his budget caused by his failure to win legislative approval for money-saving initiatives in Albany and a shortfall of tax revenues in the last quarter.
 
Mayor's Brief Response
 Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani issued only a brief, muted response to the State Comptroller's report, focusing largely on Mr. McCall's praise of some initiatives, including the effort not to raise taxes.
"As I stated during my campaign and numerous times since then, this administration will continue to monitor city spending to insure that unnecessary expenditures are not made," the Mayor said.
The reports of the fiscal monitors underscore the difficulties that now confront Mr. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor who wants to show he has more control over the city's finances than his predecessors, particularly Mayor David N. Dinkins. Mr. McCall is an old friend and political ally of Mr. Dinkins.
Last July, Mr. Dinkins ordered new budget cuts totaling $130 million only two days after his $31.2 billion budget took effect. That budget, too, was roundly criticized by Wall Street bond raters and fiscal monitors, including Mr. McCall.
In his report, Mr. McCall said Mr. Giuliani had "moved aggressively" to close a budget gap of $2.3 billion without raising taxes. He also said the newest round of contingency cuts -- which he characterized as a spending freeze -- would help keep the budget balanced.
The Mayor's actions, though, risked violating government and legal mandates to provide certain levels of services, primarily for the poor or ill, the report said. And the contingency cuts "may strain the city's ability to provide essential services," it said.
The Comptroller's report concluded that the Mayor's budget would leave a shortfall of $600 million because it failed to address a number of problems.
The most serious of those were: $110 million in unbudgeted payroll and other costs at the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation; $150 million more in overtime costs than now estimated; $50 million in higher pension costs, and $45 million in savings from changes in laws regarding the city's liability in lawsuits, which have so far failed to win legislative approval in Albany.
The report also identified about $567 million in risky assumptions that had not yet panned out, including $200 million in new aid from the Federal Government, $200 million in savings in health benefits for city workers that must be approved by the unions and $65 million for the sale of the United Nations Plaza Hotel.
The risks still total $150 million -- on top of the $600 million in gaps -- even after accounting for the Mayor's contingency cuts and about $165 million in lower-than-anticipated bills left outstanding from previous years.
"I think the Mayor is stepping up to the problem," Mr. McCall said in an interview.
But noting that the city faces a budget gap of $2 billion next year and more in the years after, he said, "I think he's going about it incrementally."
Mr. McCall also said the Financial Control Board -- which includes himself, the Governor, the Mayor, the City Comptroller and members of the private sector -- should meet more frequently to create a forum for solving the city's long-term fiscal problems.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Fall on Surge In Durables

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday as the bond market gave a lukewarm reception to the Government's auction of $11 billion in five-year notes.
Behind much of the selling was an unexpected surge in orders for durable goods in June, which raised traders' worries about new inflationary pressures. Bond prices fell sharply and quickly in the morning after the Government released the report. 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond closed off 21/32 , or $6.56 for $1,000 of face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 7.61 percent, from 7.54 percent on Tuesday.
 
Back a Bit in Afternoon
 The bond market bounced back a bit in early afternoon trading after the Treasury's auction of five-year notes sale produced an average yield of 6.98 percent, the highest in three years. Still, some traders were disappointed by the five-year note sale, especially after the Treasury's surprisingly successful two-year note sale on Tuesday.
But other traders said the outcome was not so bad, considering that this week's new auction came on a day that the Commerce Department reported that orders for big-ticket items like automobiles and washing machines rose 1.3 percent in June -- triple the increase that many economists had expected.
Moreover, they said the bond market was concerned about a report scheduled for tomorrow on second-quarter gross domestic product, which could provide more hints of inflation.
"Some people may have expected a bit of an uptick once the auction was out of the way and they may have been disappointed because the market held in very well," said Matthew Alexy, government-trading strategist at CS First Boston.
"It was a fair auction, though, given that we have G.D.P. coming out this Friday," he said. "Ahead of that number, we're not going to see any major market move."
 
Economists Estimate G.D.P.
In a survey, economists estimated that the G.D.P. rose at an annualized rate of 4 percent in the second quarter, exceeding the 3.4 percent increase of the first quarter.
Traders fear the Federal Reserve could raise short-term interest rates for a fifth time this year if the economy grew faster than expected.
"People are very interested in G.D.P. and after that the employment report," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America. "But I'm surprised that many people are thinking the Fed could respond if G.D.P. growth is strong.
This is because the G.D.P. report is based on partial data, he said.
Nevertheless, the market has little else to focus on now that Congressional hearings on the Whitewater affair are "turning out to be a yawner," Mr. Moran said.
Dealers are also awaiting July's employment report due Aug. 5, and the Treasury's quarterly refunding during the second week of August to raise an estimated $40 billion for spending and maturing debt.
Meanwhile, the Fed added temporary reserves to the banking system via $2.5 billion customer repurchase agreements. Traders expects funds to open today around 4 1/4 percent, the Fed's target rate.

HEADLINE: Confusion Abounds as Stocks Head Down

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Traders and investors differed yesterday over the outlook for the economy but stock and bond prices both still declined. Bond traders decided the economy was growing too fast and could spark inflation. They bid prices down for bonds. But stock traders concluded it was growing too slowly and could hurt earnings. They bid prices down for stocks.
The confusion continues the puzzlement that has gripped the markets all summer, as economic data continue to prove ambiguous, the course of the dollar defies Washington policy makers, and the Federal Reserve Board still appears ready to raise interest rates for the fifth time this year. 
 So far, the Dow Jones industrial average has given back about a quarter of the gains it made in the first two weeks of July.
The bond market, after rallying sharply in the second half of the month, has given up almost all those gains and is essentially back to where it was July 1. But long-term interest rates are still below the high yield for the year of 7.72 percent set for the 30-year bond on July 11.
 
Inventories Report Awaited
 Tomorrow both stock and bond market traders and investors will have to confront another key barometer of the economy -- the gross domestic product report for the second quarter. A rise in product inventories held by businesses could signal a slowing economy as consumers and businesses slow down spending.
Yesterday, the Dow dropped 15.21 points, to 3,720.47. Bond prices fell, prompting the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond to rise as high as 7.612 percent before settling at 7.61 percent, up from 7.54 percent the previous day.
The immediate cause of the sour bond market was a Government report that showed unexpectedly strong orders for business durable goods, such costly purchases as computers, automobiles and railroad equipment. Durable goods orders in June were nearly triple the level expected by private economists -- 1.3 percent, instead of five-tenths of 1 percent.
Bond traders saw the orders as a sign of an unusually robust economy, which, so the thinking goes, is bound to lead to higher inflation or, at the very least, another increase in interest rates from the Federal Reserve Board.
 
Concern Held Unwarranted
 Bond traders therefore sold bonds, which decline in value if inflation is thought to be rising. But Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist for CS First Boston, said bond traders' concern was unwarranted.
"It does not deserve the attention that we're giving it," Mr. Alexy said, because the modest durable goods increase did not necessarily signal inflation. Bond prices improved quickly in the early afternoon after the Treasury Department sold $11 billion in five-year notes for a 6.98 percent yield, he noted, the highest in nearly three years but not exorbitantly expensive.
"The economy is growing steadily and solidly," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities. "The economy is never quite as strong as the people who are afraid that it is strong say it is and it is never quite as weak as the people who are afraid that it is weak."
The cause of the stock market drop was more subtle. As in the first quarter, earnings in the second quarter have been strong. Three stocks contained in the Dow industrial average -- Du Pont, Walt Disney and Allied Signal -- reported record earnings that were above analysts' expectations.
Yet the Dow over all declined because some traders apparently concluded that the strong earnings were too strong and that corporate earnings had peaked -- the sign of an economy slowed by four increases in short-term interest rates by the Fed. The Dow fell because prices dropped for economically sensitive stocks like Aluminum Company of America, International Paper,and Caterpillar.
Ford, which doubled its quarterly profit, contributed to the too-strong-for-its-own-good talk when David N. McCammon, Ford's treasurer, told reporters the second quarter would likely be the best quarter of the year. Ford's stock fell 1 1/4, to 30 1/4.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was again low at 251.8 million shares, or some 12 percent below this year's average of 288 million shares. The Standard & Poor's 500 fell 0.79 point, to 452.57. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 3.53 points, to 712.13.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.40 point, to 249.84, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 897 to 1,272. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.48 point, to 434.02.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 14 fell, led by Aluminum Company of America, which fell 2 3/4, to 77 7/8, on no immediate news. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, some 235 fell.
