HEADLINE: 21 Enterprise Zones Created, Including 4 in New York City

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
To encourage economic development in impoverished areas across the state, New York State officials yesterday named 21 special new enterprise zones, including four in New York City, to receive tax breaks and other incentives aimed at attracting business to distressed neighborhoods.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, seeking to spread around one of the few bounties he has to offer as he seeks a fourth term, announced the expansion of the state's existing economic development zone program from the current 19 areas to a total of 40 different locations. 
 Under the state program, which was first established in 1986, businesses that locate in designated areas of high unemployment and poverty are eligible for a mix of tax credits, low-interest loans, reduced property taxes and discount utility bills. The size of each zone is limited to two square miles.
 
'Aggressively Hospitable'
 "The zone program is an important part of our strategy of being aggressively hospitable to business and increasing jobs," Governor Cuomo said. "We want to make sure that the new prosperity we are bringing to New York reaches every part of our state and benefits all New Yorkers."
Asked whether the expansion, which was authorized in legislation approved last year, was timed to help his re-election bid, Mr. Cuomo replied, "The only way I can escape the question of such programs being politically motivated is to drop dead."
"When I do my job," he added, "you guys say that it's politically motivated."
New York State, based on a review of its seven-year-old enterprise-zone effort by a consulting firm, contends that its program has helped create 4,500 new jobs and stimulate nearly $750 million in business investments. Officials did not put a price tag on the how much the state was giving up in tax revenues because of the program. They argue that much of the investment would never have occurred -- and therefore the taxes would never have been collected -- if the zones did not exist.
But some critics assert that local enterprise zones, which have been put in place in 37 states and the District of Columbia, often do little more than shift jobs and business from one site to another.
 
Some Advantages
 Recent academic research suggests that enterprise zones, while of limited benefit, do offer some advantages. Margaret G. Wilder of Cornell University and Barry M. Rubin of Indiana University found that "enterprise zones appear to have some capacity to stimulate new employment and investment in certain areas," but warned that they "do not possess magical qualities which can overcome all physical, social and economic barriers to revitalization."
The expansion of the state program comes as the Clinton Administration is planning by the end of the year to designate six sizable "empowerment zones" within impoverished areas of major American cities to receive $100 million in grants and other Federal benefits. A part of New York City beginning as a broad swath of Harlem and extending into the South Bronx around Yankee Stadium is expected to be one of the six.
An additional 65 smaller urban neighborhoods around the country will also be named as "enterprise communities," receiving $3 million each.
The new state zones range from one end of New York to the another.
 
New Zone for Buffalo
 Buffalo, for instance, will receive a new zone divided into three sections, aimed at redeveloping the Ellicott District, an area in the northeast of the city around two General Motors factories, and a section that includes the former Republic Steel plant. In Ulster County, Kingston and Ulster are to benefit from a zone that includes several large buildings vacated by I.B.M.
Within New York City, four new areas were selected to go along with the existing zones, which are at Port Morris in the Bronx, East Harlem in Manhattan, South Jamaica in Queens and East New York in Brooklyn. The new zones in the city are the Hunts Point area of the Bronx, Sunset Park and Red Hook in Brooklyn, Far Rockaway, Queens, and the north shore of Staten Island from the Goethals Bridge to the home port naval station.
In the wider New York metropolitan area, the Bellport area of Brookhaven on Long Island was named as a new state economic development zone. It joins a zone in Islip and another in Yonkers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark On Surge in Durable Goods

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark again yesterday after an economic report raised concern about American inflation and sent bond prices lower.
But the dollar rebounded from early losses against the Japanese yen after an influential economist with close ties to the Clinton Administration said the United States and Japan were likely to reach an agreement on opening Japanese markets to American goods, making trade sanctions unnecessary. 
 Falling Treasury bond prices dragged the dollar lower after the Commerce Department said durable goods orders rose 1.3 percent in June -- more than expected. The report suggested that the economy was growing fast enough to generate higher inflation. Currency traders watch bonds' performance for signs that international investors might be selling off dollar-denominated investments.
"The durable goods report put the fear of God into the bond market, and that sent the dollar lower as well," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5749 marks, down from 1.5839 marks on Tuesday. But it rose to 98.45 yen from 98.30 yen.
The robust rise in durable goods orders raised speculation that a report to be released tommorow on gross domestic product will show that the economy grew at a rapid clip in the second quarter, analysts said.
Strong growth could raise concerns that the Fed is not raising interest rates fast enough to control inflation, said Amy Smith, senior currency market strategist at IDEA. If that is the case, bonds and the dollar will be vulnerable, she said.
The dollar fared better against the yen today after C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, was quoted on the cable television channel CNBC as saying that the United States and Japan were likely to make progress in coming months in talks aimed at balancing trade between the nations. He also said the American trade deficit with Japan was beginning to narrow.
Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States means that its exporters have a constant supply of dollars they must sell for yen when they return revenue to Japan.
Every Japanese exporter "has dollars to sell," said Peter Gloyne, manager of institutional foreign-exchange trading at the First National Bank of Chicago. As long as that is the case, he said, "the dollar won't break back above 100 yen."
The dollar weakened against most other leading currencies yesterday, falling to 1.3345 Swiss francs from 1.3455 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5325 from $1.5245.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Who will pay for universal health care? Well-off households.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHO wants to pay for universal health coverage? The answer, as the current debate is making all too clear, is no one. Indeed, for some interests who have campaigned for change -- notably big business -- the whole idea is to shed part of their financial burden.
But as a flock of studies have shown, the contretemps over who pays is a shell game: One way or another, households with above-average incomes, not businesses or government, would almost certainly pick up the tab for broader coverage. And President Clinton's understandable wish to obscure this reality may prove too clever by half. "He may end up without a good bill -- or the support to push a mediocre one through Congress," said Uwe Reinhardt, an economist at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton. 
 Most Americans below age 65 have private medical insurance, and most of them receive it as a fringe benefit. So it was easy to see why the White House chose to build on the current system, requiring all employers to do what most now do to attract and keep valued workers. In fact, the political case for expanding the employer mandate seemed like a no-brainer when the President's task force was assembling the Health Security Act.
Those working without insurance would obviously be delighted by the prospect of something for nothing. More important, big businesses would be pleased, since they had much to gain: Their current premiums are inflated by doctors and hospitals, who look to private insurance to cover the costs of the uninsured and to supplement reimbursements offered by Medicare and Medicaid.
Organized labor, too, likes the idea of an employer mandate. Among other virtues it would take the pressure off unions, which have been asked to share employee medical costs by companies claiming to need the break to remain competitive.
But the politics of mandates has proved subtler than was widely reckoned.
To woo small businesses, which typically do not provide health insurance today, Mr. Clinton offered subsidies linked to the number of employees. The subsidy rate has proved inadequate to break small- business resistance, however -- indeed, the concession seems to have invigorated lobbyists who scent weakness like wolves on the hunt. And the subsidy has alienated big businesses, which assume they will somehow be stuck with the cost.
Most galling from the perspective of economists, the subsidy is sloppily targeted. While small businesses do employ a disproportionate share of low-wage workers, tens of thousands of beneficiaries of the subsidy would be middle- and upper-income employees. "It doesn't make any sense at all," Mr. Reinhardt said.
The broader economic problem is that the employer mandate is built on a misunderstanding. Virtually everyone thinks the money would come from employers' pockets. But there is a huge body of research by labor economists suggesting that employees as a group bear the costs. In one classic study published in 1991, Jonathan Gruber of M.I.T. and Alan Kreuger of Princeton found that 85 percent of workers' compensation insurance costs were reflected in lower wages.
This finding implies that an "individual mandate" requiring families to buy health insurance, with subsidies for those who can't afford it, would generate roughly the same impact on incomes. And indeed, a new study by John Holahan, Sheila Zedlewski and Colin Winterbottom of the Urban Institute confirms it.
The research, commissioned by the Kaiser Family Foundation, estimates that the President's employer mandate would transfer roughly 6 percent of the income from families in the top fifth of the economic pecking order to pay for the care of the bottom fifth. So would an individual mandate, with insurance premiums linked to income. For that matter, so does the current system, in which a portion of private health insurance premiums along with tax revenues are siphoned from the rich to pay for both the uninsured and those insured by the Government.
But while the individual approach would certainly make it clear who was really paying, it is hardly an ideal way to finance medical costs. Subsidies that made insurance affordable to the near-poor, Ms. Zedlewski notes, would discourage work effort by sharply rising insurance bills as incomes approached middle-class levels.
Isn't there a better way? Mr. Reinhardt is a fan of the German system, which fudges the political issue of whether employers or employees pay by collecting a fixed percentage of payrolls to cover health costs.
If Americans really understood the bottom line, he believes they would opt to eliminate mandates entirely and cover medical costs from a broad-based tax, much the way they pay for Medicare and Medicaid today. For contrary to the conventional wisdom about "single payer" systems, the approach need not go hand in hand with socialized medicine.
"You could collect the money in one pot," Mr. Reinhardt said, "and still use it to finance Clinton-style managed competition."

HEADLINE: Japanese Offering Ford a Loan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 27

 BODY:
With the Japanese Government struggling to reduce anger over the nation's towering trade surpluses and financially pressed Japanese investors pulling their capital back home, the Export-Import Bank of Japan is negotiating a huge, politically sensitive loan to the Ford Motor Company.
The unusual loan being considered by the Government-controlled bank, which could run as much as $300 million, would be aimed at helping Ford manufacture right-hand-drive autos for export to Japan. That, in turn, could help reduce the Japanese trade surplus with the United States, which is expected to be as high as $60 billion for 1994. 
 The negotiations with Ford are one sign that the Government, which has resisted the Clinton Administration's demands that it guarantee increased purchases of American goods to whittle down the surplus, is anxiously looking for other ways of narrowing the deficit and, not least, earning some good will in the United States.
 
A Favored Rate
 Though the loan is not yet final, its motivation was evident in the terms under which it would be made.
Interest would be paid at a concessionary rate of slightly more than 4 percent. The Export-Import Bank says that is normal for its specialized lending. It is, however, well below the 7.25 percent prime lending rate offered by commercial banks in the United States, even below the more favorable rates often available to big corporate borrowers, like Ford. Thus, it could save Ford many millions of dollars in interest payments.
Officially, the Export-Import Bank denied a report of the loan this morning in Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading business newspaper.
"It is not true that anything like this has been done," said Seiichiro Shimamoto, a bank spokesman.
 
Breadth of Discussions
 However, other officials said that while no decision had been made, talks had been under way with Ford. "At this point, the report was premature," one official said, "but there have been discussions."
Indeed, all three United States auto makers said today that they had discussed the low-rate loans with the Japanese Export-Import Bank, but Ford appeared to be furthest along in the negotiations.
David N. McCammon, vice president for finance and treasurer of Ford, confirmed that the company was in preliminary negotiations with the Japanese lender. "We didn't ask them; they came to us," he said. "Anybody that comes forward and has low-rate financing, we're interested in." He said Ford had discussed a loan of $300 million, but emphasized that the terms remained uncertain.
Whether or not the loan goes through, it demonstrates the lengths to which Tokyo is willing to go to improve badly strained relations with the United States. This is particularly true now, with the two nations having only a few days to a deadline for completing negotiations on increasing Japanese Government procurement of foreign telecommunications and medical equipment.
The Clinton Administration insists that after more than a year of fruitless talks the Japanese institute procedures to insure a steady increase in purchases of the telecommunications and medical products. Tokyo, in turn, refuses to establish what it regards as quotas.
If no deal is reached by July 31, the United States may begin a procedure that could lead to sanctions against Japanese imports within 60 days, the first shot in a possible trade war.
 
Japanese Agency's Evolution
 Several years ago, this country's Export-Import Bank was transformed from a low-key institution that provided cut-rate loans to assist Japanese importers and exporters into a bank with a political as well as economic mission. Japan was trying to develop an argument that the huge trade surpluses piling up here were actually benefiting the global economy because they were being "recycled" in the form of productive investments in other countries.
Those efforts were redoubled as the flood of capital that Japanese investors sent abroad during the late 1980's dried up because of a recession at home. A greater burden fell on the Government to show that recycling was working.
The Export-Import Bank took on a new life, providing multibillion-dollar loans to developing countries that needed funds -- Mexico, for one. These loans were not, as had sometimes been true in the past, tied to the purchase of Japanese goods or services. More recently, the bank turned its focus from the third world to industrial nations.
 
West London to California
 For instance, the Export-Import Bank made a loan of 125 million -- slightly more than $190 million -- to help finance construction of a rail line from Paddington Station in London to Heathrow Airport. It invested $12 million in construction of a new Los Angeles harbor facility for the export of coal.
The bank has also starting making low-cost loans to private companies to assist them in exporting products to Japan. These have included a $46.6 million loan to Space Systems/Loral Inc., a maker of satellites, and a $117 million loan to help a subsidiary of LM Ericsson of Sweden export cellular-telephone equipment to Japan.
Export-Import Bank officials have said the bank is actively scouting for more opportunities to make targeted loans in the United States, particularly to state and local governments. The money could be used to develop local infrastructure projects and possibly earn good will from organizations in need of cash.
In fact, three years ago the bank seriously considered a plea for such loans from three Southern governors eager to get the low-interest loans and in the process increase their national stature, including the then-Governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: BEHIND THE SCENES;
Hybrid Organization Serves as a Conductor for the Health Care Orchestra

SERIES: Special Pleaders: A periodic look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
These are heady days for Families USA, an unusual advocacy group that has become the de facto public relations manager of the Clinton Administration's campaign for comprehensive health care legislation.
Using a careful mix of statistics, hard-luck stories and staged political events, Families USA has played an important behind-the-scenes role in shaping public perceptions of the nation's health care problems. 
 For example, when the "Oprah Winfrey Show" and all four major networks reported on the man who went to jail last year for lending his insurance card to an injured friend rather than risk letting the friend, who had no insurance, be turned away from the emergency room, it was Families USA that brought the case to the networks' attention. The group organized a news conference the day before the man went to jail.
And last month, when NBC broadcast a two-hour special on the health care debate, with money from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, several of the people who told their stories came from the Families USA "misery bank," a listing of people who have had problems with health insurance. In the four years since the list was compiled, it has been used by scores of reporters looking for examples to use in their reports on health policy.
 
Wealth of Statistics
 Then, each time lawmakers and health experts cite statistics like the 2 million Americans who lose their medical insurance each month or the 50 million Americans who lose or lack health insurance for at least part of every year, they are relying on Families USA, which circulates data inglossy monthly research reports.
These days, many of the staff workers from the Families USA headquarters are in the basement boiler room, where representatives from unions, health and other groups are organizing the Health Security Express, the bus caravan now driving across the country to rally support for universal health care.
So far the caravan has not been a ringing success, neither drawing large crowds nor the kind of favorable news reports that organizers hoped for. On a recent morning, the boiler room was going full tilt, with dozens of people from dozens of organizations cranking out press kits, recruiting riders, figuring out how much time the fish barbeque should get on the schedule and wooing local politicians to join the rallies.
At the center of it all was Arnold Bennett, Families USA's media director. For weeks now, he has started his mornings with an early visit to the White House, to discuss the selling of universal health care.
Mr. Bennett's most important contribution, though, may have been the strategy he devised three years ago for selling the middle class on the need for health care overhaul, a strategy that has been adopted wholesale by the Clinton Administration and many members of Congress. It comes down to a simple spin on the issue: emphasize people's fears of losing their insurance and play down the plight of the uninsured.
"Most Americans are not uninsured, but most Americans are afraid of losing their insurance," said Ronald Pollack, executive director of Families USA. "Generally, people act out of self-interest, not out of altruism. So if you want them to care about health reform, you don't talk about the uninsured, you talk about people who have lost their insurance. We shaped that message."
Unlike other interest groups that have tried to retain more independence, and more leverage over the White House, while promoting the same basic goals, Families USA has cast its lot squarely with the Clintons.
"We don't see it as Families USA doing Clinton's work," Mr. Pollack said. "We think Clinton has adopted what we've pushed since before he was a candidate."
 
Others Use Techniques
 In contrast to Families USA, the Health Care Reform Project, a broad coalition of labor, consumer and health groups headed by John Rother of the American Association of Retired Persons, describes itself as "a coalition of groups that support health reform but have not endorsed the Clinton bill."
That group, adopting some of the selling techniques used by Families USA, was responsible for the recent commercials accusing Pizza Hut of hypocrisy for insuring workers abroad but not at home.
Families USA is the creation of a rich Massachusetts businessman, Philippe Villers, who founded the $40 million Villers Foundation to help the elderly and then orchestrated its evolution into today's advocacy group, known first as Families United for Senior Action and more recently as it took on broader health care issues, as Families USA.
Families USA, which calls itself a national consumer group, operates both a tax-exempt educational foundation and a lobbying arm, contributions to which are taxable. Using direct mail appeals, it has put together a modest membership, including a network of 12,000 people who will write letters to Congress or make calls whenever Families USA sounds the alert.
 
Without a Constituency
 But while most advocacy groups exist to represent their constituencies (the American Association of Retired Persons, for example, serves the interests of its 33 million members), Families USA has no real constituency. Instead, its staff of 36 seeks to advance the goals of Mr. Villers and his hand-picked board of directors.
It was not always clear that health care would be the target of the fortune Mr. Villers amassed as founder of the Computervision Corporation.
Mr. Villers said he had known all along that he wanted to devote his money to bringing about some kind of social change. He said he settled on health care for the elderly as his group's mission after he had been convinced that his initial idea of trying to do something about unemployment caused by economic cycles was unworkable.
After deciding to focus on health care, starting with long-term-care for the elderly, his organization began giving grants, passing out some $16 million to strengthen or develop state and local groups interested in the subject. These days, Families USA receives far more grant money than it gives out: only about $1 million of the group's $4 million annual budget is Villers money, compared with $2 million from other foundations.
 
Models for Action
 "My role models, in thinking about what I wanted to accomplish, were the women's movement and the civil rights movement," said Mr. Villers, a small mild-mannered man who works out of a modest office above a bank in Concord, Mass.
And if health care legislation passes, he said, he will feel he has achieved something of comparable scope.
"It's been very gratifying," he said. "If we get health care reform passed, there will be many people who played a role, but it might not have have happened without us. How many people can say they had a chance to influence the most important social policy change in their lifetime? That's heady stuff."
While not everyone would agree that Families USA has played the central role in promoting health care change, it is beyond dispute that the group has been effective both in getting the issue to the top of the political agenda and in framing the debate.
 
Consistent Message
 Last week, amid the commotion over whether Mr. Clinton would stick with the goal of universal coverage or accept something less, like 95 percent coverage, Mr. Bennett was working overtime to keep the message consistent and to keep the spotlight on those who might lose insurance and away from the question of who will pay for the uninsured.
"Of course we're for universal coverage," he said. "No one is backing away from that. But the message is that this plan means no American will ever again have to worry about losing their insurance. When you talk about universal coverage, people start to worry about paying for someone else. When you talk about losing insurance, it sounds like something that will protect them."
The ties between Families USA and Bill Clinton were forged even before Mr. Clinton became President. Mr. Pollack and Mr. Bennett first met Mr. Clinton in September 1991, after Mr. Pollack and Phyllis Torda, the group's director of health policy, published an article arguing that while a Canadian-style single-payer health care system would work well for Americans, political realists would do better to push for less radical change.
At this point, the line between Families USA and the Clinton Administration has blurred somewhat. Mr. Bennett himself says it is not always clear to his audience whether he is talking for Families USA or for the White House.
But he and Mr. Pollack bristle at charges that the group has lost its independence. "It's untrue and it hurts our image," Mr. Bennett said. "Of course, it hurts our image. But who cares? What's important is winning the fight for health reform, not protecting our image."
Still, Mr. Pollack said, Families USA has paid a price for its closeness to the White House.
"We haven't gotten some grants we otherwise would have gotten," Mr. Pollack said.
Lately, there have been some tensions between the groups who are pushing to revamp the health care system.
 
Tension Between Groups
 Some groups have become loath to work with Families USA, feeling that Mr. Bennett and Mr. Pollack hog too much publicity. Others dismiss Families USA as a co-opted lobbying arm of the Clinton Administration, although a few concede that they envy its freedom to pay more attention to the White House agenda than to the more narrow interests dictated by their own members.
And for their part, both Mr. Pollack and Mr. Bennett express irritation that the other groups are not more willing to put aside their own agendas and work harder for health care legislation.
"There's been this chorus of 'I like the plan but,' and that does not help the bill get passed," Mr. Pollack said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arnold Bennett, center right, Families USA's media director, has been in the center of the fight for universal health insurance. Yesterday he was with Dwight Kirk in a Washington basement office from which a coalition of groups runs the caravans that are traveling the country this summer. (Kirsten Bremmer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Chinese Repression: Still an Issue

 BODY:
Last year President Clinton found a constructive way to heal the rift between Congress and the White House on China, linking Beijing's trade privileges to modest improvements in its human rights performance. But this year, after an aggressive business lobbying campaign, the President junked his own solution and extended trade privileges unconditionally. Now it is up to Congress to try to repair the damage. It can begin by passing legislation that would re-link tariff rates for certain Chinese goods to minimum human rights standards.
The annual struggles over China's tariffs stem from the outrage many Americans felt when Deng Xiaoping ordered army tanks to mow down students demonstrating for democracy in Beijing's Tiananmen Square five years ago. But the issue is no longer just Tiananmen. That one barbaric act unmasked the true nature of a regime that was known abroad mainly for its economic reforms. 
 Now people are more aware that China tortures prisoners, persecutes religious believers and is waging a sustained assault against the indigenous culture of Tibet. It also profits from selling Americans the products of prison labor and violates human rights pledges to Washington. China will continue to flout international norms as long as it believes it is immune from serious retaliation.
Today a House subcommittee holds hearings on a bill introduced by Nancy Pelosi, Richard Gephardt and David Bonior that would impose high tariffs on products made or exported by the Chinese Army or associated military companies or by certain state industries previously named by the U.S. Trade Representative as possible targets for retaliation in trade disputes. Exports from private businesses and joint ventures would be exempt. About a sixth of Chinese exports would be affected.
The bill also asks the Administration to encourage U.S. businesses in China to follow a voluntary code of conduct, a step Mr. Clinton said he favored at the time he abandoned his own human rights sanctions but seems to have lost interest in since.
The point is not to punish China, but to maximize the positive influence the U.S. could exercise as China's biggest customer. Beijing's sales to the U.S., from which it earns almost four times as much as it pays out for purchases here, are indispensable to China's development. China's leaders understand this very well, even if America's do not.
The Pelosi-Gephardt-Bonior bill enjoys wide support and could win a majority when it comes to the House floor, probably next week. A companion Senate bill has been introduced by George Mitchell.
Given the likelihood of a Presidential veto, it is doubtful that these bills will ever become law. Still, they may help teach both Chinese leaders and Mr. Clinton that the human rights issue will not go away until China starts treating its people decently.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Sharply Vs. the Yen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to its highest level against the Japanese yen in a month yesterday, breaking back through the psychologically important 100 yen level and extending a bounce that began more than a week ago.
Analysts said the main reason for the dollar's rally yesterday was a rumor that the longstanding bilateral trade dispute between the United States and Japan would be resolved by July 31, the deadline Washington has set for deciding whether to take steps toward trade sanctions. 
 But in the next breath foreign exchange traders cautioned that there was more sum than substance to the dollar's performance. The day's gains, they pointed out, came during a session when trading was quite light, which means the dollar's surge may have been exaggerated.
 
Trade Deadline Looming
 "I don't think anyone made any portfolio changes," Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. "Big numbers were not being thrown around. There were trades in the $10 million and $20 million range, not in the hundreds of millions or billions."
Indeed, the dollar slipped slightly below 100 yen in morning trading in Tokyo today, then hovered at about 100 yen in the early afternoon.
With the trade deadline looming and an important economic report scheduled to be released in Washington this morning, Mr. Witten and other traders said traders and investors did not want to speculate against the dollar. The Commerce Department this morning releases the first report on second-quarter economic growth.
"It's a little confusing trying to differentiate between a shift in portfolios or a shift in positions in advance of two significant events," said one foreign exchange trader, who asked not to be identified.
"After this weekend, the signals will be a little clearer on what the investor world is thinking," he added.
 
Late New York Figure
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 100.10 yen, up 1.5 percent from Wednesday's closing quote of 98.45 yen. In yen terms, the dollar has not been this strong since June 28. The dollar hit its post-World War II low against the yen on July 12, at 96.60 yen.
"That was the drop-dead low," Mr. Witten said. "Ever since then things have been sort of positive. Today's move was a continuation of a trend that has been in place, and now we have this trade news."
The dollar also rose against the German mark in New York yesterday, to 1.5920 marks from 1.5749 marks on Wednesday.
Even though trading volume was light, rumors about people buying dollars were everywhere.
The Bank of Japan was said to be a buyer, first in Asia and later in New York through its account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. And some traders said they had heard that Saudi accounts were buying dollars to purchase United States Treasury securities and were selling bonds denominated in yen.
Analysts said that if the rumors about a trade settlement were borne out, the dollar could quickly move higher, perhaps by as much as 10 percent against the yen.
The long-simmering trade dispute has thrown foreign investors into a funk since February, the analysts said, making them unwilling or fearful of putting money into dollar-denominated assets and masking over positive fundamental factors -- an expanding economy in a low-inflation environment -- that would otherwise be helping the currency.
"Starting with the collapse of trade talks with Japan in February, most investors concluded that the Clinton Administration was at best indifferent to or at worst was actively trying to depreciate the dollar against the yen," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said.
"The unfortunate side-effect of that conclusion was that foreign investors, including the Japanese, were reluctant to increase holdings of dollar-denominated assets," he added.
Even coordinated intervention by the United States and its allies to buy dollars to support the American currency has had little impact on investors' views.
Rumors that the trade impasse might be broken were somewhat surprising, because in recent weeks Clinton Administration and Congressional officials with trade responsibilities have been increasingly gloomy about the likelihood of a breakthrough in the talks.
 
Trade Talks to Resume
 American and Japanese negotiators are scheduled to sit down again today, and talk of the potential for a trade accord took hold in the currency market even as American officials played down the possibility.
Currency traders took heart from a comment by Charlene Barshefsky, a deputy United States trade representative, who said early in the day that the Administration did not plan to delay the July 31 deadline. Some dealers interpreted that to mean that the Americans expect to strike a deal and therefore will not need to extend the deadline.
"It's hard to tell if the rumors and leaks we are getting are real, or if they are a negotiating ploy by one side or another," the unnamed foreign exchange trader said.
"Most people are of the view that there will be an agreement, but that it will not be terribly significant."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Seeks Continued Federal Funds for Housing Police

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Pressing his plan to merge New York City's three police departments, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sought assurances today that the Federal Government would maintain its financial support for policing the city's housing projects in exchange for a city commitment to maintain or improve police services there.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development now pays about one-third the cost of supporting the 2,500-member housing force, or roughly $75 million a year. Any withdrawal of that support could jeopardize Mr. Giuliani's plan to transform the housing force, along with the transit police force, into a bureau of the main Police Department. 
 Mr. Giuliani, who came here to lobby Congressional leaders to protect the city's interests in fields from crime to health care, met with the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Henry G. Cisneros, to discuss the housing police.
The Mayor said he pledged to maintain police services at existing levels, or improve them, in exchange for the Federal money. Speaking to reporters later, he said that the city would draft proposed arrangements soon and that Mr. Cisneros had been encouraging.
 
Support Contingent on Results
 The Assistant Secretary for Public and Indian Housing, Joseph Shuldiner, said in a telephone interview that the department's concern was in maintaining public safety in the Housing Authority projects and that precisely how the city policed them was a local decision. He said the department had asked the Mayor for a detailed plan that would show how the proposed merger would affect safety conditions.
Mr. Giuliani said he suggested that if the city could improve safety conditions in public housing, it might deserve more Federal money. One of the Mayor's arguments for the merger was that while reported crime had fallen in the subways and the city as a whole, it had not decreased in public housing, and that a merger could improve management of police resources.
Mr. Shuldiner said the department might consider making its continued support contingent on "certain results or outcomes," like reduced reports of crime, or surveys showing that residents felt safer.
 
Bonus Payments Possible
 Mr. Shuldiner added that such an arrangement could result in bonus payments if the city improved conditions, or be simply a requirement of continued support. He acknowlegded that it might be hard to agree on what would constitute improvements.
As Mr. Giuliani sought support for the plan, City Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens announced that he would introduce a bill in the Council that would force the Mayor to get the Council's authorization before the merger could take place. Complaining that the administration had not "presented us with a single piece of paper," Mr. McCaffrey said the final determination on the merger "should be an executive and legislative decision."
He said he had major reservations about the merger, and he raised questions about whether transit or housing officers would be diverted from their duties to cover big events like the ticker-tape parade held last month for the New York Rangers. But he added that he had not seen enough information from the administration to decide whether he would support the merger.
Mr. McCaffrey said he felt he would have the support of a solid majority of Council members.
Meanwhile, the proposed merger met with near-unanimous opposition last night at a public hearing in Harlem held by Assemblyman Keith L. T. Wright. Many people in the audience of about 300 said they feared that the Police Department would neglect housing projects and would be less sensitive to racial tensions than the housing police force, which has a higher proportion of minority officers.

HEADLINE: Minorities Get More Mortgages

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
A group of financial regulatory agencies announced today that the number of mortgages issued to black and Hispanic borrowers rose sharply last year, but that these applicants remained substantially more likely than whites to be denied home loans.
The group, the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, which is made up of five agencies, announced that the number of home loans issued to blacks rose 36.1 percent last year while the number issued to Hispanic borrowers climbed 23.6 percent. For whites, the increase was 17.1 percent. 
 Loan applications were denied less often last year than in 1992 for all ethnic groups, the council said. Blacks remained twice as likely as whites to be denied home loans, and Hispanics were one and a half times as likely. But the gap narrowed slightly in each case.
Even when income differences were taken into account, blacks and Hispanics remained substantially more likely than whites to be denied loans, the council said. Financial institutions attributed most of the denials to applicants' lack of adequate credit histories, the council said, but it added, "The extent to which racial discrimination may account for these differences is not known."
 
Two Trends Seen
 Deepak Bhargava, the legislative director of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, a New Orleans-based group that advocates affordable housing, said the slight improvement announced today appeared to reflect two trends: Regulators are putting a little more pressure on banks to avoid racial discrimination, and low interest rates have helped make it possible for more people in low-income neighborhoods, including some blacks and Hispanics, to buy homes.
Loans rose the most last year for families earning less than 80 percent of the median family income in their metropolitan areas, the council said.
The volume of mortgages soared in 1993 as many people refinanced their homes, taking out new mortgages at low interest rates and using the money to pay off older mortgages at higher rates. The increases in volumes of loans are for financial institutions that reported figures in both 1992 and 1993.
Clinton Administration officials have repeatedly urged banks, savings and loan associations and mortgage companies to examine their lending procedures to avoid any unfairness toward people in low-income neighborhoods or minority groups.

HEADLINE: Fidelity's Bet on Macy Debt Paid Off

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Perhaps the most active behind-the-scenes player in the Macy-Federated drama was Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund com pany.
Fidelity is no stranger to the close-knit world of bankruptcy investing, where it has used its substantial financial muscle to influence the outcome of several big bankruptcy cases including Bally's Grand, Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino and Mcorp. 
 But Fidelity's investment in Macy -- bank debt with a face value of $522 million and bonds with a face value of $81 million -- is the largest position Fidelity has ever taken in a company that is in bankruptcy.
Despite its hefty stake, the Macy case did not unfold as Daniel Harmetz, Fidelity's 31-year-old bankruptcy Wunderkind, and his colleague, Judy K. Mencher, 37, its associate general counsel, anticipated. They had bet that they could ally themselves with management and get Macy out of bankruptcy quickly, a strategy they had used to reap fat profits in several large bankruptcy cases.
 
 
A Complex and Bitter Case
 But the complexity of Macy's capital structure and the company's high profile guaranteed a level of contentiousness. And Macy's retailing problems were worse than anyone had known, which slowed its progress in bankruptcy.
Fidelity nonetheless reaped a handsome 30 percent rate of return on its Macy investment, which will enrich shareholder returns for its Capital and Income and Magellan mutual funds, among others.
Getting involved in the Macy bankruptcy was unusual for Fidelity. "I have always been very negative on retailers in bankruptcy," Mr. Harmetz said. He avoided them because retail companies are heavily reliant on the good will of their suppliers, which can hold up needed merchandise in bankruptcies. Customers may also be put off by the notion of bankruptcy. And retailers are always susceptible to fluctuations in the economy.
 
 
A Retailing Gem
 But David Glancy, now the manager of Fidelity's Spartan High Income fund but then a retailing industry analyst at Fidelity, convinced Mr. Harmetz that Macy's was a gem among retailers, with a national reach and some of the nation's best shopping mall real estate. "The bricks and mortar were not really replicable," Mr. Harmetz said. "They had true value."
Ms. Mencher's analysis of the legal technicalities and Mr. Glancy's estimates of the real estate values indicated that the $560 million of bank loans issued when Macy bought Bullock's, the West Coast department store chain, was the best buy. So shortly after Macy's filed for bankruptcy protection on Jan. 27, 1992, Fidelity began assembling a share of that debt.
Ultimately, Fidelity acquired enough of a stake in Macy's debt to block any reorganization proposal that was not to its liking.
But the size of its stake did not make the proceedings any easier for Fidelity. "I found it extremely difficult to deal with the slow progress," Mr. Harmetz said. "You would have two steps forward, one step back -- and the steps forward were baby steps."
The peculiarities of the Macy case forced Fidelity to abandon some of its tried-and-true methods for gaining the upper hand in a bankruptcy. Typically, Fidelity would ally itself with a debtor's management, but Macy's executives, while polite, were aloof.
 
 
Sharing With Creditors
 Unable to build a strong alliance with management, Mr. Harmetz and Ms. Mencher set out to unite their fellow senior creditors, each of which believed its claims against the company were better than the others. Fidelity's motives were questioned by other creditors who suspected the Fidelity team was looking to enrich itself at their expense. So Fidelity, as a show of good faith, handed negotiating power for one set of claims over to two fellow creditors, Chemical Bank and Credit Lyonnais.
"Ceding some control seems like a bad idea, but it took the pressure off of us," Mr. Harmetz said.
Hiring outside advisers was another first for Fidelity, which usually relies solely on Ms. Mencher's and Mr. Harmetz's skills at working the bankruptcy laws. But on the Macy case, Fidelity retained Wasserstein, Perella & Company for advice on merger issues and Stutman, Treister & Glatt, a prestigious Los Angeles law firm, for legal counsel.
Hiring such high-priced professionals raised Fidelity's costs, but Mr. Harmetz said their involvement helped increase Fidelity's returns by more than a few cents on the dollar. And by his reckoning, every extra penny allocated to cover Fidelity's claims increased its total return by $5.5 million. "We figured we could allocate a cent for outside advice," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judy K. Mencher, left, associate general counsel for Fidelity Investments, and Daniel Harmetz, a portfolio manager, discussed the merger of Macy and Federated Department Stores at Fidelity's office in Boston. (Michael Quan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Looks At Ex-Fed Official's Role

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
A former governor of the Federal Reserve System has become the target of an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission over the possible misuse of secret central bank information.
The S.E.C. is looking into whether the former governor, Wayne D. Angell, illegally received or passed on inside information this spring. At the time he was warning clients that the Federal Reserve was likely to raise interest rates significantly. Mr. Angell, who completed an eight-year term at the Fed in February and became chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in April, said there was nothing to investigate.
 
Cleared in One Inquiry
 The inquiry comes on the heels of an internal Fed investigation that found no evidence of wrongdoing and after calls for further scrutiny of Mr. Angell from Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, the chairman of the House Banking Committee. People familiar with the case said that it was highly unusual and that they could not remember another like it in Fed history. 
 Mr. Angell's lawyer, Dennis J. Block of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, said the S.E.C. was trying to determine whether Mr. Angell had violated Federal securities laws that prohibit fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of a security, including a Government bond or a futures contract or option.
Specifically, according to Mr. Block, the S.E.C. is examining whether Mr. Angell violated Section 10B of the Federal securities code, which he said forbids "somebody passing nonpublic information with respect to a security and somebody who trades on that information."
But he added that in his view, "anything anyone in America does that the S.E.C. doesn't like comes under that small section."
The commission would not confirm or deny the existence of an inquiry. "I can't comment on whether anything is under investigation," said William R. McLucas, the S.E.C.'s director of enforcement.
One focus of the inquiry, according to Mr. Block, is an April 19 meeting of hundreds of Bear, Stearns clients. At that meeting, which took place four weeks before the Fed raised its short-term interest rate target for the fourth time this year, Mr. Angell said he thought that 8 to 10 of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks had asked the Fed's board of governors to raise the discount rate, as well. Someone familiar with an account of Mr. Angell's remarks said he disclaimed any direct knowledge at the time.
 
A Clue to Other Rate
 Requests for changes in the discount rate are a closely guarded secret because a change can be an important clue to how the Fed's monetary-policy committee is likely to vote on the Fed funds rate, its more important short-term interest rate target, now 4.25 percent. In the late 1980's, a former director of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, Robert A. Rough, was imprisoned for leaking discount-rate information to a broker.
Mr. Angell's estimate of sentiment within the Fed -- which he repeated before and after the April 19 meeting -- was sufficiently on the mark to prompt J. Virgil Mattingly Jr., the Fed's counsel, to ask Brent L. Bowen, its inspector general, to look into the question. Mr. Bowen sent his report to the House Banking Committee at the end of May and, about a month later, referred the matter to the S.E.C.
Mr. Block said the S.E.C. had requested, among other things, an interview with Mr. Angell as well as his telephone log, a transcript of an April 19 client meeting and Mr. Angell's trading records. He characterized the S.E.C. effort as a "staff inquiry," a preliminary investigation that is supposed to determine whether a full-blown investigation, approved by the entire commission, is warranted.
The Fed's own inquiry apparently found no evidence that Mr. Angell received or passed on inside information. It nonetheless prompted Mr. Gonzalez, a frequent critic of the central bank in matters ranging from monetary policy to employment practices, to demand a wider investigation. He has accused Mr. Angell of "selling inside knowledge to the highest bidder," and wants the central bank to adopt new rules to prevent its former officials from jumping directly to lucrative Wall Street jobs.
In interviews, Mr. Angell and his lawyer called the S.E.C. inquiry and the accusation by Mr. Gonzalez "baseless" and suggested that both had been politically motivated.
"There isn't anything to find," Mr. Angell said. "I have never had any secret information. And I wouldn't use it if I had it. "
Mr. Angell is a contrarian, someone who relishes a good fight and rarely doubts that he is right.
"Back in the Nixon days," he added in his defense, "there was a list and they even sicked the I.R.S. on people. We know that the Nixon group and the group that's in today aren't any different."

HEADLINE: Investing in the Inner City;
Small-Business Owner Sees Revitalized Future

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Jose Aguiar is the Kleener King.
The alliterative name is plastered in royal blue and yellow lettering on the 12 stores he owns in the Bronx and upper Manhattan. And if Mr. Aguiar has his way, it may soon become a household phrase in many more inner-city neighborhoods, emblazoned on a small fleet of trucks shuttling clothing back and forth between his dry-cleaning plant and dozens of Kleener Kings in northern New York City. 
 Mr. Aguiar is walking evidence of how a small-business owner can make it in some of the toughest neighborhoods of New York City. Not only is his business prospering, but he sees his future in expanding throughout the Bronx, upper Manhattan and lower Westchester County, where, in his view, the crowded neighborhoods provide an untapped market for a chain of dry cleaners providing low-cost, high-quality service.
It is businesses like his that many see as a lifeline of New York City's future economic success. As bigger corporations leave the city or shed employees, companies with fewer than 100 workers now account for almost half of the private work force in the city. Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, said these companies tended to be more resilient in surviving the recession of the early 1990's.
Mr. Aguiar's business is emblematic of the success of such companies. He hires locally, training neighborhood residents for stable jobs. And he hopes to expand his business greatly in the coming years with a large new cleaning plant in an industrial area of the Bronx.
"My market is the Bronx," said Mr. Aguiar, who is 32 and who owned only one store just seven years ago. "I think the Bronx is headed in the right direction, and I want to help rebuild it. I drive around and I feel proud sometimes that it's coming back, back to the heydays when my parents first came here."
Mr. Aguiar is one of the lucky ones. Despite small businesses' relative success in weathering the recession, economists say they are still risky ventures, with one in three failing in the first three years nationally.
 
'I Didn't Want to Sell His Dream Short'
 Mr. Aguiar got his start running a dry-cleaning shop when, as a student at Columbia University, he was forced to take over his father's company upon the elder Mr. Aguiar's death. Until then, the younger Mr. Aguiar had seen the business merely as a source of summertime employment. But with his father's death, he felt an obligation to take over the family store, on Creston Avenue near Fordham Road in the Fordham section.
"I really knew nothing about the business," Mr. Aguiar said. "He had a lot to teach me, but I just didn't want to hear. The reason I stayed is I didn't want to sell his dream short. If I would have sold his store, that would have been the end of what he fought for."
After spending three years learning every aspect of the business, Mr. Aguiar attended a national dry-cleaning convention in 1986. That trip, he said, changed his life.
He returned with the dream of setting up a string of stores that would serve the neighborhoods he had always known: the blue-collar and largely minority areas of the Bronx and upper Manhattan. Two years later, he opened a second store at Longwood Avenue and Southern Boulevard in Hunts Point, two blocks from the site of his father's original shop.
Lucille Gonzalez remembers when that store opened. "I used to bring my clothes with me to work, and leave them at a cleaners downtown," she said. "I just couldn't trust the places around here. Then this nice, clean store opened and I knew whoever owned that would take care of my clothes."
Mr. Aguiar has two basic tenets that he says have helped him create a successful, fast-growing business. The first is offering reliable, affordable quality. The second is creating an attractive, recognizable look for his stores.
Mr. Aguiar realized that the wealthier markets were not for him when he was forced to close a store he opened on West 90th Street because of intense competition. Unlike some higher-priced stores, he does not concentrate on difficult-to-clean fabrics or complicated trimmings, instead offering his customers basic cleaning they can afford. He also runs sales and pricing gimmicks, particularly in poorer neighborhoods.
 
A Goal of Consistent Quality
 "I'm not going to say that Kleener King is the best dry cleaner in the world," Mr. Aguiar said. "I may not even make the high-end market happy, but I know that my average customer's walking around happy because they have dependable, reliable quality. I can't do everything. I can only do certain things, and I look to polish what I do."
Mr. Aguiar patterned his chain on enormous enterprises like McDonald's and Blockbuster Video. He says those stores are successful because wherever customers go, they know they will receive the same quality.
For that reason, Mr. Aguiar chose a common name, Kleener King (which he hit on in a Burger King), and a common look for all his stores: every store has baby-blue floor tiles and royal-blue counters and the recognizable Kleener King logo out front. A team of carpenters visits each store twice yearly for cleaning and maintenance.
In poorer neighborhoods where many owners are unwilling, or unable, to spend the time and money to maintain their shops, his stores stand out. He points to the success of his stores in Hunts Point, on St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem, as well as one he is about to open in a new shopping center just north of Crotona Park in the Bronx, as evidence of how his strategy has worked.
"You look in that general vicinity and there are no really attractive-looking stores," he said, referring to the East Tremont area. "Everything is run down. I feel that the minute somebody comes in and revitalizes an area and introduces something nice, people are going to notice and take a little pride."
 
Plans for a Central Plant
 Mr. Aguiar's flagship store, on Creston Avenue, is a gleaming white two-story plant that he built with a Small Business Administration loan on an empty lot across from the site he inherited from his father, which is now a restaurant.
The plant, where 20 employees clean clothing from five stores in the area, is a model for Mr. Aguiar's next big plan, a central plant in an industrial area, perhaps Bathgate Industrial Park in Tremont. Predicting that concerns over chemical emissions in the dry-cleaning process may eventually lead the government to outlaw cleaning plants in residential buildings, he wants to build a large plant that would service 40 to 50 drop-off stores throughout the Bronx. He also wants to franchise, by next year, about 40 of the stores, some with laundromats.
"I think there's a lot of people other than myself that believe in the Bronx and are willing to invest money here," Mr. Aguiar said.
With 12 stores open now, four more under construction and large plans for the future, Mr. Aguiar is often asked if he is moving too fast. "My gut tells me no," he said.
"To me this isn't work, it's my life," Mr. Aguiar said. "I guess that's why it comes so easily to me, because I really, truly enjoy it. I enjoy going into a devastated neighborhood and making a statement, going in and seeing a vision of what I can do there."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally on Rumors Of Purchase by Saudis

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The bond market rallied sharply yesterday, bolstered by a stronger dollar and speculation that Saudi Arabia had bought a large block of notes.
The Treasury's 30-year bond rose 20/32 of a point, or $6.25 per $1,000 bond. Its yield fell to 7.54 percent, from 7.61 percent on Wednesday. 
 Bond traders had begun the day betting on lower prices amid concerns that faster economic growth would lead to more inflation and higher interest rates. But traders were forced to reverse their bets once the dollar rallied, rising above 100 Japanese yen for the first in a month, since it indicated higher demand for dollar-denominated assets like Treasury securities.
"We are pretty much coupled" to the rebound in the dollar, said Chris Madell, a trader at First Chicago Capital Markets.
 
 
Bought Bonds Back
 Like other traders, Mr. Madell covered his positions by repurchasing bonds he had sold short on Wednesday. "For once I did the sensible thing and bought the bonds back," he said.
Traders typically sell borrowed securities short in a falling market in hopes of buying them back at a lower price.
Earlier, the 30-year bond fell as much as 8/32 of a point after the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing for unemployment dropped last week by 59,000, to 331,000, more than three times the decline expected by many economists. The report raised concerns about economic growth.
Yesterday's rebound does not mean the bond market is less concerned about faster growth. Indeed, traders will be looking for signs of increased growth, and hints of inflation, in the Government's report today on the nation's gross domestic product in the second quarter.
 
 
Are Buyers in Line?
 Much of yesterday's buying reflected speculation that ready buyers like the Saudis were ready to snap up Treasury issues, traders said.
There were unconfirmed reports that the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, the nation's central bank, bought as much as $1 billion of 10-year notes. Calls to the authority in Riyadh were not answered.
"It's one of those things where you never know for sure, but in this case it wasn't just a vague rumor," said James Hale, senior fixed-income strategist at MMS International in San Francisco. "Usually when it's got numbers attached, it's got some legitimacy."
So many traders and speculators were betting that bonds would fall yesterday that they were caught off guard when prices rebounded, said Michael Marzano, head of bond futures trading at Yamaichi International (America).
Once bonds began rising, speculators were forced to reverse their bets that another decline would occur, which helped to accelerate the gain.
"We've got a nice little squeeze going," Mr. Marzano said.
A drop in the Conference Board's help-wanted advertising index for June also gave speculators a reason to reverse their bets, traders said.
 
 
G.D.P. Report Poses Threat
 The report due today from the Commerce Department on the gross domestic product last quarter could send bonds tumbling, traders and analysts said. Some economists are forecasting a growth rate as high as 5 percent, which would put pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year to pre-empt inflation.
"It's just a matter of time before the market goes down," said Michael McGlone, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company.
Also, traders said bond prices were being kept in check by the Treasury's quarterly refunding early next month, when the Government plans to auction an estimated $40 billion in 3- , 10- and 30-year securities, he said.
With such a large supply, "and all this uncertainty about the Fed, any rally in here will be short-lived," said Eric Cheung, who manages $2 billion of fixed-income investments at Wilmington Trust in Wilmington, Del.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
DOW CHEMICAL CO. (DOW,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that its second-quarter net income climbed 69 percent on a slight gain in revenue, pushed up by strong volume and price increases in its plastics division.
Net income rose to $251 million, or 91 cents a share. Wall Street had been expecting about 88 cents a share. Excluding one-time charges in last year's quarter, Dow's per-share results increased 21 percent. 
 "Dow's strength came from cost-cutting and volume growth," said Paul Raman of S. G. Warburg & Company. "They've done a very good job of controlling overhead."
Officials at Dow, based in Midland, Mich., attributed the overall improvement to gains in productivity and rising demand. Revenue rose 2 percent, to $4.93 billion. Operating income rose 55 percent, to $602 million.
Analysts said Dow's results underscored the cyclical recovery throughout the chemical industry. Improvement in the United States economy and a sluggish recovery in Europe are spurring demand that is catching up with the overcapacity that has hurt the industry for years.
Higher prices should bolster results for Dow and other chemical makers in coming quarters, said Stephen E. Roberts, an analyst with Roney & Company in Detroit. "Demand is soaking up excess supply," he said. "The U.S. economy is strong, Europe is picking up, and Japan is hanging in there, so things look good."

HEADLINE: Stocks Move Up, With Dow Gaining 10.36

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In the latest swing in a seesaw week, the stock market rallied modestly yesterday in moderate trading.
The rise was due in part to a jump in the value of the dollar above 100 yen for the first time in a month, fresh evidence that the dollar's fall may have bottomed out and foreign investors were returning to American assets. 
 Surprisingly strong earnings reported by General Motors may also have provided a psychological lift to the market. But G.M. contributed only a slight lift to the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index, of which G.M. is a main component stock.
The Dow rose 10.36 points, to 3,730.83, while the broader S.& P. 500 rose 1.67 points, to 454.24. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.30 point, to 712.43.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 246.6 million shares. The volume was far below the year's average, which is 287 million shares, but closer to the more cautious trading volume posted by traders since June 1, which is about 259 million shares.
 
Financial Markets Confusion
 The week so far has reflected the confusion in the financial markets after last week's testimony by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who expressed concern about the economy without being explicit about what the Fed would do about it.
Stocks were up on Monday, and down on Tuesday and Wednesday in swings that were more drift than real changes in direction. Bonds mirrored the stock market.
But today will likely be the decisive session, at least for the week, as traders sift through data in the second-quarter gross domestic product for clues to the economy's direction and whether the Fed will raise interest rates a fifth time this year.
Inventory levels, an indication of whether consumers and businesses are buying more or less than in the strong first quarter, will be especially scrutinized.
 
U.S. and Japan Trade Talks
 The dollar's rise reflected short-term optimism that a breakthrough was possible in trade talks between the United States and Japan. Yesterday, for the first time since June 28, the dollar rose above 100 yen, closing at 100.10 yen, up from 98.45 yen. The dollar also rose to 1.5920 German marks, from 1.5749 marks, but was mixed against other European currencies.
The dollar rose against the yen from the start of the session in New York all the way to the close. A Japanese news service reported that the Japanese Government was considering concessions in the trade talks.
A main factor behind the weakness in the dollar is the United States-Japan trade deficit. The billions of dollars paid by American companies and consumers for Japanese goods are more often converted to yen rather than into dollar-denominated American stocks, bonds, goods or services. The resulting strong demand for yen and weaker demand for dollars have led to a post-World-War-II low in the value of the dollar.
The dollar's lift had an immediate effect on bonds, which essentially returned to Monday's price levels after a sharp drop on Wednesday. Also helping was speculation by traders that the Saudi Government had bought more than $1 billion in 10-year bonds, a fact not of enormous consequence by itself, but an indication that foreign investors were confident in the dollar and dollar-denominated assets.
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 7.54 percent, from 7.61 percent.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.76 point, to 250.60, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,079 to 999. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.14 point, to 433.88.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 16 rose, led by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which rose 1 1/8, to 52 1/2, on no immediate news.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 236 stocks rose, led by General Electric, which rose 3/4, to 49 1/2, on no immediate news.
The most active stock, at four million shares, was Ford, which rose 5/8, to 31, also on no immediate news.
Stock prices sometimes move for reasons related to individual portfolio managers' priorities rather than external news events.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Fall

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Workers returning from summer furloughs in the automobile and textile industries helped push first-time claims for state unemployment benefits to their lowest level in four months, the Government reported today.
The Labor Department said initial claims dropped 59,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, to a seasonally adjusted 331,000 from the previous week's revised 390,000. The decrease was the biggest in five months and much larger than the modest 7,000 decline that most economists had predicted in advance of the report. 
 It was the first drop in three weeks and followed rises of 25,000 and 21,000 in the two previous weeks.
Many applicants in the weeks that ended on July 9 and July 16 worked in the auto and textile industries, which have summertime furloughs, and the latest number reflected the return of those workers.
The decrease was the biggest since Feb. 26, when a decline of 61,000 was reported. It was the lowest level since March 26, when 331,000 claims were filed.
