HEADLINE: PHARMACISTS HELP DRUG PROMOTIONS

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
Without explicitly telling doctors or patients, major drug companies are enlisting pharmacists to promote their drugs rather than those of their competitors. And some doctors and medical ethicists don't like it.
Take the many neighborhood pharmacists who serve participants in Medco, a company that buys drugs from manufacturers and sells them through pharmacies and mail orders to 38 million Americans. 
 When customers appear with prescriptions for high blood pressure medicine, for example, the pharmacist often advises them that they could receive another, similar drug for less money, under their Medco plan. Would it be O.K., the pharmacist might ask, if they called the doctor and had the prescription switched to the other drug?
But what the patient and doctor may not know is that Medco is owned by Merck, the other drug is made by Merck, and Merck will pay the pharmacist a cash commission for arranging the switch.
Some say there is nothing wrong with this. Why not pay pharmacists for helping patients to get the best drug at the best price? John Doorley, a Merck spokesman, said pharmacists would suggest a switch only when it would help the patient.
"In no case will we ever permit a Merck product to be prescribed over another medicine if it is not better," he said.
But others complain that when pharmacists make money on particular choices of drugs, they are no longer disinterested parties. It is no different, some say, from the doctor who owns the diagnostic laboratory down the street from his office and so benefits financially each time he sends a patient there for lab tests. Or it may be no different from the doctor who is wined and dined by a drug company representative and then prescribes the company's drugs.
 
 
'Manipulative' and 'Dishonest'
 "It's outrageous, it's manipulative and it's dishonest," said James Love, who follows the drug industry as director of economic studies at the Center for the Study of Responsive Law, a consumer advocacy group in Washington.
"Traditional medical ethics is being replaced by traditional business ethics," said Dr. Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Medical Ethics at the University of Pennsylvania.
He and many other critics urge that at the very least any and all arrangements between pharmacists and drug companies should be explicitly disclosed to both doctors and customers. Others go further, saying that the arrangements should be barred on antitrust grounds. They argue that separating the drug companies and the drug distributors is the only way to insure that patients don't get medicine they don't need and that they pay the best prices for what is necessary.
Merck blazed a new trail when it bought Medco last year. In May, SmithKline Beecham bought Diversified Pharmaceutical Services, which handles prescription drugs for 11 million people. Earlier this month, Eli Lilly announced it would buy PCS Health Systems, which has enrolled 50 million Americans.
Drug companies say the mergers will insure that their products make the list of favored drugs the supplier offers to its many patients, often at a very good price for the patient and the employer, who each pay part of the bill. Although the supplier will also sell drugs not on the list, they will cost the patient more, sometimes much more than the listed drugs.
The drug companies say the new arrangements are more than money-making ploys. By using huge data bases that include prescriptions that may be written by different doctors and filled at different pharmacies for individual patients, the pharmacists can, for example, alert patients and doctors to dangerous drug interactions.
But some doctors and medical ethicists are leery.
Dr. Alan L. Hillman, who directs the Center for Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania, said that drug suppliers used to select the drugs they would offer by looking for the best drug for the best price without regard to which company manufactured it. But the whole point of the new arrangement, he said, is to prefer one maker's drugs over another's.
"Now that these companies are aligned with pharmaceutical manufacturers, it is not fair to assume or to expect them to give all manufacturers equal treatment," Dr. Hillman said. "And, in fact, that's not why they were bought. They were bought so they can have pharmacists and telemarketing people call and try to get prescriptions changed.
"That is exactly the opposite of what they were at least theoretically doing when they were independent. It's not a good development."
Dr. Hillman acknowledged that doctors could refuse to go along with requests to change prescriptions. But he said most doctors would not question a pharmacist's motives in suggesting a switch. When they think of drug marketers, he said, they think of clearly identified salespeople who come calling or invite doctors to professional seminars to learn about a company's drugs.
 
Trustworthy Profession
 Mr. Love agreed. He added that pharmacists were always at the top of the list of national polls asking Americans which professionals were most trustworthy.
Dr. Hillman said he did not fault the drug industry for the new direction it was taking. "There is nothing illegal or unethical about it, " he said. "It's just American companies trying to get a leg up on the marketplace."
Pharmaceutical companies have increasingly needed that leg up. They are saddled with a legacy of the 1980's, when companies began making "me too" drugs -- competing and all but identical patented versions of popular medicines like anti-ulcer drugs or cholesterol-lowering drugs. These drugs now account for half to three-quarters of the revenues of large drug companies, said Robert N. Merold, a vice president of IMS America, a Totowa, N.J., company that analyzes drug company data.
But now, with many similar drugs on the market, companies realize that they must control not just the manufacturing but the distribution of their drugs. That way, they can place their products on the list of favored drugs offered by pharmacies participating in the prescription-drug plans of suppliers. Hence the acquisitions of suppliers.
Studies show that 80 percent of the time, doctors agree to requests that their patients be switched to a similar drug, Mr. Merold said. And, he added, there is an additinal benefit to the drug manufacturer. When a doctor is called repeatedly by one drug plan asking about a switch, the doctor eventually starts writing all prescriptions for that medicine.
 
The Turning Point
 Mr. Merold said the turning point seemed to be when about 15 percent of a doctor's patients were with one medical plan whose pharmacists kept calling. At that point, Mr. Merold said, "the doctor throws in the towel and says, 'Enough! Uncle! I give!' "
What about financial incentives for pharmacists to initiate such switches? Merck said it had several in place. The other companies, while providing no details, said they saw no reason not to compensate pharmacists.
Merck gives rebates of 6 to 10 percent of the wholesale price of each drug sold to pharmacists who dispense the company's line of generic drugs in preference to other companies'.
In a separate program, it also pays pharmacists $5 a prescription for increasing their sales of the total line of drugs, generic and patented, from the Medco formulary.
And it has started an education program that compensates pharmacists for helping patients learn about managing their chronic diseases. Pharmacists are paid $3 for reviewing a patient's prescription record, and for counseling; they are paid $9 more if the counseling results in a new prescription, and they are paid 50 cents each time the prescription is refilled, up to $3.
The rebate program that pays $5 a prescription was begun in October 1992 and the two others were begun last Jan. 1.
 
 
Began With Asthma Aid
 The education program began with asthma management, and Merck does not make asthma drugs. But next year, it will include conditions like ulcers and high cholesterol, where Merck's drugs face strong competition.
Some experts see nothing wrong with compensation programs. Dr. Devra Marcus, an internist in private practice in Washington, said that as long as she could approve, or disapprove, of a drug substitution, and as long as her patients saved money, "it's O.K. with me."
Dr. Jerry Wing, a professor of marketing at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said, "Everyone is compensated for what they are doing." If pharmacists "are spending time, why not be compensated?" he asked.
But Dr. Stephen Brenner, an internist in New Haven who has received some calls from pharmacists, disagreed.
"It's offensive," he said. "There's a very clear ethical issue here," he added, explaining that there is the same conflict of interest for the pharmacist who gets an incentive for calling doctors and patients as for the doctor who sends patients to a diagnostic lab where he or she has a stake in the profits.
"Legislation says I can't refer patients to my own lab or my own physical therapy center because I'm alleged to be getting something out of it, even though it may be 'in the patient's best interest,' " Dr. Brenner said. The same reasoning says that pharmacists should not be allowed to steer doctors or patients to drugs when they have a financial interest in the switch, he said.
Dr. Alan Garber, an internist and an economist at Stanford University and head of the formulary committee at the Veterans hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., also saw a conflict. Payments to pharmacists are "extremely troubling," he said.
Mr. Doorley of Merck said critics have to consider the drug industry's point of view. Something has to be done to restore profits. "The industry is getting murdered," he said. "Our company was worth $60 billion a year and a half ago and now you could buy it for less than $40 billion."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. to Help Ukraine to Rejuvenate Economy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, July 28

 BODY:
The head of the International Monetary Fund met with Ukraine's new President this week and said they would work together to develop an economic program that could open the door for the $4 billion aid package promised to Ukraine at the economic summit meeting this month in Naples.
The fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, announced "the beginning of something important and positive for Ukraine" after meeting on Wednesday with President Leonid D. Kuchma, who took office on July 18. If the program is successful, the first part of a $700 million loan could be issued by October, officials said. 
 The I.M.F.'s cooperation is important because it sends positive signals to private foreign investors. Ukraine, where economic reform has been more sluggish than elsewhere in the former Soviet Union, has received very little investment.
Vice President Al Gore has also accepted an invitation to visit Kiev next Tuesday after a visit to Poland to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Warsaw uprising. Washington has been concerned with Ukraine's unstable economy, and Mr. Gore's visit is seen as an effort to give a boost to the new President.
Mr. Camdessus said he was "impressed with the determination of the President and the Prime Minister," adding that Mr. Kuchma had drafted a "document which really touches upon the key issues."
Mr. Camdessus made his first visit to Kiev to keep a promise made to Mr. Kuchma last spring in Washington. Mr. Kuchma challenged Mr. Camdessus to come if he won the election and had concrete economic proposals ready.
"I said 'O.K.' " Mr. Camdessus recalled. "Then the President sent me an invitation the day after his inauguration, and here I am."
Asking for help is Mr. Kuchma's personal acknowledgement that the economy, despite an inflation rate below 4 percent a month, is in terrible shape. National income fell 28 percent in the first half of this year from the year before.
I.M.F. officials are to work with the administration in Kiev this summer to develop a program to keep monthly inflation in single digits, reduce the budget deficit and free prices. "We're talking of a far-reaching program," Mr. Camdessus said.
He cautioned, however, that this kind of program will require "ambition," a reference to the reluctance by the previous Government to carry out reforms. But Mr. Kuchma must also deal with a Communist-dominated Parliament that has already shown its aversion to market reforms like privatization.

HEADLINE: City and State to Announce Program of Arts Grants

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE 

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani are to announce a program today in which New York City and the state would provide a total of $10 million to cultural institutions in the city that can raise matching private money.
The program is intended not only to increase financing for the arts, but also to encourage arts groups to raise more private money and improve the public's access to the arts. It is a result of an agreement made in February between city officials and leaders of the arts world, who offered to raise $10 million in private contributions if the Mayor restored $4.2 million in arts financing that he wanted to cut from the city's budget and if the city and the state matched the pledge with $5 million each. 
 While the city put $5 million for the program in its new budget in June, the state, which has a different fiscal year, allocated half its share. Governor Cuomo says he plans to ask the State Legislature to provide the remaining $2.5 million in the next fiscal year.
Details of the program, which is to be jointly administered by the New York State Council on the Arts and the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, are to be announced today at a news conference at the Brooklyn Museum.
 
'First Joint Effort'
 "New York State and New York City are working together in the first joint effort we have ever made to strengthen the city's status as the nation's arts and cultural capital," the Governor said in a written statement. "This joint investment will help draw more tourists and New Yorkers to arts attractions, strengthening our economy and creating jobs."
Under the program, a cultural group's operating budget would be used to determine how much money it could receive. Organizations with operating budgets of less than $500,000 could request up to $50,000, half from the state and half from the city. Institutions with budgets of up to $2 million could request up to $100,000, and organizations with budgets more than $2 million could get up to $500,000. Proposals for the program, which applies to institutions in the city's five boroughs, must also provide more opportunity for the public to enjoy culture.
The deadline for applications is Sept. 13.
Norma Munn, the chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, an advocacy group, said, "I think this was put together with a great deal of hard work from all of the people who've been working on it these last few days and together they took a vague idea and have improved upon it considerably."
She added: "I have two caveats. We will continue to monitor this program very, very closely, especially in terms of how the city makes its decisions. Second, we're pleased the city and the state are looking at the question of economic development and the arts, and we hope that now that the difficulties around the challenge program have been eliminated we can have a more serious and substantive discussion with the city's elected officials as to what constitutes substantive economic development in the arts."
In its budget, the city is providing financing for more than 400 cultural groups, including the 31 major institutions on city property (known as the Cultural Institutions Group). Any group or artistic program would be eligible to apply for the matching grants, but according to city legislation, $3 million of the city's $5 million must go to members of the Cultural Institutions Group..
Money for the arts in the city budget is being distributed by a formula in which some 60 percent goes to members of the Cultural Institutions Group, which includes, for instance, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the New York Shakespeare Festival. Roughly 20 percent is going to the other arts groups in the city who have received money in the past, and another 20 percent is going to cultural institutions that had not previously received city money, including the Whitney Museum for American Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. In recent years, the major institutions received about 85 percent of the arts money and the other recipient groups got the remaining 15 percent.

HEADLINE: Where Generations Created Memories Of Summer

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
THERE was a time when the best one-wall handball in the world was played at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn. Thousands would crowd into its three swimming pools; men would smoke cigars and pat one another on the back; women would vie for the title of prettiest expectant mother.
On weekends, performers from Milton Berle to Lionel Hampton to Herman's Hermits entertained in a band shell resembling nothing so much as half a bagel. Scores of mah-jongg players clicked their 144 tiles with the concentration of nervous assassins. People competed so furiously in egg-cream and knish-eating contests that you can guess what happened. Each endless summer, the vain would wrap reflectors around their neck to capture a perfect tan. 
 Brighton Beach memories. The smell of roast chicken and ocean air. Tallulah Bankhead beguiling a war-bonds rally. Bobby Riggs dropping by to hustle a little paddle tennis. The parade of politicians: Mayor John V. Lindsay diving elegantly from the high board, Senator Jacob K. Javits beaming in his tennis whites.
Neil Sedaka, who grew up across the street, remembers hearing Jeannie Clair and Harold Stern, who played accordion and fiddle, sometime in the 1940's. Years later, he says his memory of their tunes inspired his hit songs "Love Will Keep Us Together" and "Solitaire."
"I love looking back," he said. Mr. Sedaka, who now has homes in Manhattan, Los Angeles and Westport, Conn., was recently crowned King of Brooklyn and had his boyhood street named after him. "I wish just for a day I could turn back the clock and relive those years," he added.
Sylvia Deutsch, former chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, remembers going to the baths years and years ago. She would ride the trolley from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and spend long days in the sun, staying to dance in the evening. "We'd sit by the pool and meet nice boys," Mrs. Deutsch said. Then her father and the fathers of her friends would arrive at 9 P.M. sharp to drive the young women home.
"The precious little jewels couldn't go home alone," she said with what sounded like a giggle.
The truth is that the baths will soon be nothing but memory. Membership has dipped to 1,136 from more than 13,000 in the late 1960's, and it appears certain that the baths will soon be replaced by an apartment complex. So it seemed a good idea to visit the 15-acre, table-flat recreation area that bills itself as the World's Largest Beach Resort while there is still time.
On a recent sweltering day, my family packed a picnic basket, slathered ourselves with sunblock and took the D train to the Brighton Beach stop. Guy, my 4-year-old son, surveys the brightly colored Adirondack chairs, the playground equipment and the cool blue pools, and immediately pronounces, "We like how it looks."
Well, yes, though perhaps through the same brand of wistful lens that filmed "The Flamingo Kid," about a similar old-time beach club. There are row upon row of wooden lockers, thousands of them, as well as steam rooms, card-playing-only areas and a solarium. From any vantage point, you can look out on the Coney Island boardwalk and see walkers and bicyclists floating by as if they're in another world, which, of course, they are.
After eight years of effort, the owners of the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club -- it changed its name 15 years ago to differentiate itself from the many steam rooms then catering to homosexuals -- have received all necessary city approvals and won a court fight to build a 1,489-unit apartment complex on this site, scaled back from the original proposal of more than 3,000 units. Both owners and opponents agree that next summer will almost certainly be the baths' last, as one of Brooklyn's most famous institutions follows trolley cars, Ebbets Field and Lundy's restaurant down the lane to legend.
 
What Happened Here?
 "We've been in a holding pattern," said Hyman Cohen, the vice president and general manager of the baths. Explaining that he needs a working business against which to write off insurance, taxes and other costs, he said, "I lose less by keeping it open than closing it."
Opponents charge that the Miami developer that owns the baths, Alexander Muss & Sons, has deliberately run it into the ground to enhance the attractiveness of the development proposal. Paint is chipped, maintenance has lapsed, food is now available only from vending machines, and the high board from which Mayor Lindsay dived has been replaced with a modest low one. Last year, the season was cut to 8 months from 10.
"The people I know have just gotten disgusted and left," said Irwin Fruchtman, a board member of the Committee to Preserve Brighton and Manhattan Beach (the neighborhood just east of Brighton Beach), the apartment project's most vigorous opponent. He adds that price increases have not helped. An adult yearly membership is $1,050, compared with $35 for adults and half that for children in the mid-1950's, when many current members first joined. Children with two parents to supervise them today are charged $50 if they are 3 to 11, and $350 if they are 12 to 18. Younger children of single parents are charged $300, and older ones $400.
Mr. Cohen scoffs at charges that the baths haven't tried to make money. When times were good, he said, major investments were made. At one point, a $150,000 television ad campaign was even waged, he said. But promotion and upkeep have suffered in recent years as a dwindling membership supplied less revenue. One of the baths' biggest money-makers now is renting space to a summer camp for children.
"Older people are afraid to ride the trains and buses to get here," Mr. Cohen said. "There's no parking. Today people go to Florida or California or Arizona."
Other changes were also at work. In the mid-1970's fiscal crisis, many firefighters, police officers and other civil servants dropped out, never to return. While reporters and pressmen from New York's eight newspapers who worked nights spent lazy days at the baths, few Russian immigrants, who increasingly dominated Brighton Beach, joined. "The ocean is free," Mr. Cohen noted.
 
Changes for the Worse
 The socio-economics of the neighborhood have also been transformed as the successful have migrated to the suburbs and many old-timers who have stayed became relatively poorer. Dan Klores, a public relations executive who grew up in Brighton Beach and worked at the baths as his first job, says those who frequented the baths in the 1950's and early 60's tended to live in two-room apartments with a rollout couch, however large the family. "This was the upper stratum of the lower middle class," he said. "If you went to the baths, your parents were at least aspiring to be upwardly mobile."
Today's baths seem proof of humankind's downward mobility, of our corporal mutability, of how fast time flies. Entering the baths, you first encounter a lobby lined with fading photographs of generations of bathing beauties and athletic champions, each wearing a smile as wide as July. But the members shuffling past carry the load of years of living: walkers are not infrequent; today's smiles are creased with earned wisdom. Indeed, some of these veterans swear that the best way to make it to 85 is to come here regularly. Who could argue?
 
A Diverse Crowd
 Not everybody is an octogenarian, of course. A young Spanish-speaking couple arrives, pushing a baby in a stroller. They converse for a while, giggle, then pay the weekend day rate of $30 each; the baby is admitted free. The day charge is $25 weekdays. Included is nothing: no towel, no locker, no pillow for the Adirondack chair.
Day guests usually number only a dozen or so a day. Sometimes they include a man who arrives early at the entrance to wait and see if his favorite handball partners arrive. If they do, he pays the day fee and goes in.
After paying the day rate ourselves, my wife, Suzanne, goes into the ladies' locker area, and I head for the men's with our two sons. The first man we meet is an elderly chap looking for the cane he has lost. We then notice some old, old signs proclaiming the de facto men's clubs that existed on different rows of lockers. "Gentlemen's Alley -- Great Men Only," reads one. Others are "Jerry's Bar" and "Mustache Al's."
In the old days, not a few gentlemen deigned not to toddle beyond these aisles of conviviality, except perhaps to take the occasional steam bath a few steps away. The repartee remains sharp: one man allows as how he prefers not to play handball with a friend who clearly intends to continue smoking his cigar.
"I can throw my cigar away, but what are you going to do about your underwear?" is the reply.
There are 6,437 wooden lockers, each 4 feet wide, 4 feet deep and 8 feet tall. In the old days, people had to double up in the lockers. But today the vast majority have been covered with plastic to shut them off, thereby cutting cleaning expenses. We beg to use one, even though we are day-raters. The clerk is kind enough to acquiesce. Roy, our 6-year-old, thinks we should live in ours, at least until the weather turns cold.
Emerging from the immense locker area, we notice the handsome trees planted in the mid-1950's when the current owners bought the property. Signs define areas by use. "Sitting and Smiling, Yes. Card-Playing, No," reads one. One section is for mah-jongg only. Neil Sedaka as a young boy made a game of this geography of separation, calling one part of the baths the jungle, and other parts desert and forest. He would lead his cousins on detailed tours of this imaginary kingdom. Later, as a teen-ager, he said, he took Carole King to the baths on dates.
 
Songs and Innuendo
 By popular demand, our family's first stop is the miniature golf course, for which balls and clubs are provided. The 18-hole course never had windmills and other moving torture devices peculiar to this odd sport. But it is hard enough, particularly with Suzanne setting the stage. "Let's watch Dad," she purrs. "He knows how to do this."
That becomes demonstrably questionable as I hit my ball up hill after hill, only to watch it roll slowly back down. This, it develops, is a pretty stodgy approach in this foursome anyway. Roy is hitting his ball on the run, in something like field hockey. "Give it a kick, Roy," Suzanne yells. "Kick it right in the hole."
Play then bogs down when Guy decides he is a bird. He puts all four balls in the 12th hole and sits on them, tweeting periodically and refusing to move. After being all alone, we notice a group of men beginning to play. They are studying their shots before giving the ball a stroke -- not a kick -- and even keeping score. Fearful we might be less than amusing, we bribe Guy with the promise of a soda to move on to the next thing.
The next thing is the show at the band shell, held each weekend and holiday afternoon at 2 P.M. People take their own lawn chairs there, then politely fight for the better vantage points. Long gone is the tent that used to protect viewers from the sun. The faded flag on the stage commemorates the nation's Bicentennial.
Today's star is Tina Robin, the Little Songbird With the Big Voice. This self-described Dolly Parton wannabe wears a rhinestone tiara in her oodles of blond hair, and sings such favorites as "By the Light of the Silvery Moon" and "Secondhand Rose" to tunes her husband plays on the tape recorder. There is enough fast humor and sexual innuendo for the Catskills, not a little of it in Yiddish.
She announces that they are putting the faces of missing elderly people on prune-juice bottles. She asks if anybody likes calypso, then says she will do "a song of the islands: Long Island, Flushing." She also directs some of her jokes in this mostly elderly audience to "virgins only."
 
'Sexy Seniors Only'
 But the sun is bearing down. Time to hit the pools, all of which are filtered salt water. Guy's favorite is the baby pool, which varies in depth from 2 inches to 2 1/2 feet. Roy prefers the big one, 60-by-165 feet. We decide to live dangerously and invade the roped-off area designated "Sexy Seniors Only." The big pool, built in 1907, is wonderful summer fun, different from the way it was in the old days, when it was wall-to-wall people.
The afternoon ambles forward. A man with a mahogany tan, a flowing white mustache and a mat of white chest hair lies motionless in a courtyard. Some 20 older women struggle through an exercise class as 6 friends watch from lawn chairs. A handball thuds against a wall. A laughing group lays out a feast on two picnic tables. The 3 tennis courts and 15 paddle-tennis courts are well used. Dancers in a class in front of the bandstand kick their legs like chorus girls. A couple with a young boy splash in the pool, chattering in Russian. Everywhere is the sound of cards shuffling.
Suzanne takes the boys to play miniature golf one last time. I go to the steam room and listen to male pleasantries I imagine date back to the time Teddy Roosevelt was President, the Brighton Beach Baths were new and summers crawled by like fuzzy caterpillars. Leaving, I pass row upon row of empty chairs and notice the sun has dipped low in the sky.
Still searching for ghosts, I notice an elderly couple holding hands. "The end of a perfect day," she says.
"Yeah, perfect," he answers. "It almost could have been Florida."
 
 
Getting There
1
The Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club is at 3205 Coney Island Avenue, at Brighton Beach Avenue, Brooklyn. Hours: daily, 9 A.M to 7 P.M. Daily fee: $25 Mondays through Fridays; $30 Saturdays, Sundays and holidays; free for children 3 and under. Visitors should take bathing suits, towels, food and sporting equipment; miniature golf equipment is provided.
To reach the club by subway, take the D train to Brighton Beach; the Q train also stops at Brighton Beach, but only Mondays through Fridays. By bus, take the No. 1 or 68, both of which stop in front of the club, or the No. 4, which stops nearby on Neptune Avenue. There is no parking lot. Information and driving directions: (718) 743-1600.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
The Struggling Class Hops Across the Channel

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STONY BROOK, L.I., July 27

 BODY:
When Al, the unemployed Yorkshire construction worker in John Godber's "April in Paris" at the Staller Center here, wanly describes himself as redundant, he's referring to his professional status. But the adjective has far broader applications in this slight, wistful two-character comedy, performed by the Hull Truck Theater Company, the troupe from northern England of which Mr. Godber is artistic director.
For Al (Iain Rogerson) and his wife, Bet (Susan Cookson), life in their tiny, blank-walled home is indeed an anesthetizing series of redundancies: repeated squabbles over household chores and limited options for filling time. The view to the grave stretches before them as an uninterrupted, monochromatic corridor. And Al, who has taken up painting since losing his job, finds that no matter how hard he tries, he always creates the same picture: a gray-toned landscape showing a tree and a factory. 
 The play itself, which has been directed here by Jane Thornton (Mr. Godber's wife, who created the part of Bet in England), is redundant in another sense altogether. The story of how the couple is transformed by a fleeting visit to Paris, on a trip to France that Bet has won in a magazine competition, rings only minimal variations on the theme of blue-collar innocents abroad.
With its time-honored jokes about ordering the wrong thing from a bistro menu and wandering blindly into a transvestite revue in Pigalle, "April in Paris," which will be at the Staller Center through Sunday night, exudes an almost claustrophobic sense of cozy familiarity. But that may be precisely the objective of Mr. Godber, one of England's most widely performed playwrights.
The spiritual malaise of the lower middle class has been endlessly rehashed by British writers since the aggressive kitchen-sink dramas of the 1950's. More recently, innovative film makers like Mike Leigh, Ken Loach and Terence Davies have brought a joltingly sharp-edged, stylized perspective to the same subject.
Mr. Godber, best known in the United States for "Bouncers," a manic portrait of aimless British youth in a provincial discotheque, takes a far less cerebral approach. And his Hull Truck productions, which tour Britain to popular acclaim, probably find a more receptive ear among the types of people he portrays onstage.
Mr. Godber has said he wants to make British theater "less of a middle-class icon and truly popular in the Elizabethan sense." Accordingly, since he knows that his audiences spend most of their leisure time in front of television screens, his plays are only one step away from the domestic sitcom. (Americans watching "April in Paris" may find themselves thinking of Ralph and Alice Kramden.)
But Mr. Godber also incorporates something far more elemental to theater. Battling spouses have been a favorite subject of popular entertainment in England since Punch and Judy. And "April in Paris" -- like Mr. Godber's earlier two-character plays, "September in the Rain" and "Happy Jack" -- is built around the push-and-pull rhythms of marital argument.
Accordingly, the play unfolds as a series of alternately feisty and dispirited exchanges that suggest vintage music hall put-downs by way of the modernist terseness of Pinter and Beckett. ("Give us a cuddle, then," says Bet. "Why, are you cold?" answers her husband.) And Al and Bet come across less as specifically detailed characters than as class archetypes, sort of latter-day, North Country versions of commedia dell'arte figures.
That classical sensibility is underlined by Robert Jones's ingenious, minimal sets, rendered in bleak black-and-white for the English scenes and splashy Impressionist colors for the Paris segments, with a backdrop inspired by Renoir's "Sunday in the Country." (Al and Bet's costumes also change to match their environment.)
There's not much point in describing what happens onstage. You've seen nearly all of it before -- the stomach-churning sea crossing, the couple's wide-eyed giddiness in gay Paree -- in "Mrs. 'Arris Goes to Paris," Willy Russell's "Shirley Valentine" and innumerable variety sketches.
But amid the sentimental corn, there's a visible sense of the melancholy born of stunted expectations and an anger with the country that produced it. Mr. Godber is at his best when he allows his characters moments of lyrical insight, usually delivered in narrative asides to the audience. And both Mr. Rogerson and Ms. Cookson find the tug of pathos in Bet and Al, although their characters remain broadly generic.
I wondered how accessible "April in Paris," with its Yorkshire dialect and scattered references to British brand names, would be to a Long Island audience, so I eavesdropped during intermission. One white-haired man, with an English accent, said he found it "quite tedious." But two young American women, in floral-patterned sportswear, offered another take:
Woman 1: "What do you think?"
Woman 2: "It's cute."
Woman 1: "I think it's depressing."
Woman 2: "Yeah."
Woman 1: "Like everyday life."
Woman 2: "I know."
Mr. Godber could have written the dialogue.

APRIL IN PARIS

With: Iain Rogerson (Al) and Susan Cookson (Bet).

HEADLINE: U.S. Wants Quick Retaliation Against Serbian Attacks;
Russia Is Hopeful

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 28

 BODY:
With a weekend deadline approaching on Bosnia, Russia still expects the Bosnian Serbs to accept the peace plan drawn up by the major powers, the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, said today.
"There's still time," Mr. Kozyrev said in an interview before heading to Geneva for a weekend meeting of foreign ministers. "There're still two days before we meet in Geneva. And I hope in these days the message we communicated through General Grachev will be properly understood by the Serbs. We expect them, like the other sides, to say yes." 
 The Russian Defense Minister, Pavel S. Grachev, returned today from a trip to Serbia in a coordinated Russian effort to get the Bosnian Serbs to change their minds and accept the "take it or leave it" peace plan that they rejected last week.
Mr. Kozyrev said the Russians decided that General Grachev, better than any diplomat, would be able to speak to Bosnian Serb military commanders, like Gen. Ratko Mladic, in terms they would understand.
 
'No One Controls Them'
 "We're trying to provide them as persuasive an argument as possible," Mr. Kozyrev said. "That's what the international community wants and expects us to do, as traditional friends of the Serbs."
But he admitted to frustration with the Bosnian Serbs, saying, "No one controls them."
The United States, Russia, Britain, France and Germany, which drafted the current Bosnia peace plan, have warned the Serbs that they face tighter economic sanctions, increased military pressure and a removal of the international arms embargo if they do not back the plan.
But Western diplomats say there is reluctance on the part of the Russians, as well as the British and French, to start punishing the Serbs immediately if the plan is rejected. That is a topic Mr. Kozyrev refused to discuss.
Mr. Kozyrev said the Russians were offering the Bosnian Serbs another inducement to agree: a larger contingent of Russian peacekeeping troops, not only around Sarajevo but also in other areas the Serbs may specify.
But he emphasized the Russian position, also stated by General Grachev, that any Russian peacekeepers must be under the command of the United Nations, not NATO. "Who on earth would commit their forces under the command of an alliance they don't belong to?" Mr. Kozyrev said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Wants Quick Retaliation Against Serbian Attacks

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
In the face of renewed attacks by Bosnian Serbs on Muslim enclaves and United Nations peacekeepers, the United States is pressing for quick retaliation, American and European officials said today.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher is scheduled to meet in Geneva on Saturday with the Foreign Ministers of Britain, France, Germany and Russia, and is expected to urge tighter economic sanctions and stricter enforcement of United Nations-designated safe areas. 
 "I'm very concerned about the situation that we will confront this weekend frankly," Mr. Christopher told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.
The United States has long suggested lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia as one step in deterring the Bosnian Serbs, who are now much better armed than the Muslim-led Bosnian Government. But Britain and France, both of which have soldiers in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia, have opposed such a step since it could put those troops in danger should the Bosnian Serbs retaliate. British and French officials have expressed concern that the United States, which has no troops in Bosnia, may again pursue lifting the arms embargo in addition to the other punitive measures.
"It remains to be seen if the agreement in principle will be converted to practical steps," a senior Defense Department official said.
 
War of Nerves Seen
 Indeed, a war of nerves is developing. In what Western officials view as an effort to rattle the allies in advance of Saturday's meeting, Bosnian Serbs in recent days have attacked a United Nations convoy, killing a British soldier; shot and damaged a United Nations relief plane, and fired on Muslim enclaves in violation of United Nations ultimatums threatening air strikes.
"They're trying to intimidate the international community, and we need to rise to the challenge," an Administration official said.
Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters today that he was "very alarmed by the decreasing security situation, specifically in Sarajevo and Gorazde."
"It's very important that this come to a very quick stop," General Shalikashvili said. "That means there needs to be more vigorous enforcement of the safe zones than has been necessary in the past."
 
Russian Meets With Serbs
 The Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, met with Bosnian Serb leaders in Belgrade this week, and delivered a letter from President Boris N. Yeltsin urging the Serbs to accept the compromise. In addition, Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, has also favored the deal as a way to lift international sanctions against Serbia.
But the speaker of the Bosnian Serb assembly, Momcilo Krajisnik, wrote Mr. Yeltsin back today and rejected the plan as too sketchy. "Acceptance of an unfinished and unknown peace plan would be the beginning of the end for the Serbian people on its centuries-old territories and a prelude to national suicide," Mr. Krajisnik wrote.
The Serbs have cut the only commercial route into Sarajevo, apparently trying to show they can squeeze the Bosnian capital at will. Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, the United Nations commander in Bosnia, called the Serbian action "very, very negative," adding that the "statement that they're making to the world is that they're no longer interested in pursuing the path to peace."
The Bosnian Serb rejection of a peace plan put forward by the so-called contact group of five nations sets up a showdown in Geneva this weekend. A senior French official said France would support tighter economic sanctions and stricter enforcement of the designated safe areas. "If we show strong determination on enforcement and on economic sanctions, I think we can achieve results," the official said.
 
Concern About Time Line
 But American and other European diplomats were less optimistic that the first two punishments would dent the Bosnian Serbs' position. American officials acknowledged that the new Serbian attacks had compressed the time in which Washington would phase in the punishments.
"We never had any set time line, but whatever it was, it's gotten shorter," an Administration official said. "Clearly those countries with forces on the ground, and the Russians, are inclined to take things more gradually. Our view is that the Serbs' behavior has made things a bit more urgent."
Administration officials said lifting the arms embargo remained a last resort, and only if done multilaterally. But the officials acknowledged that there was a limit to how long they could continue to deny arms to the Muslims. The United Nations has said it would pull out its peacekeeping force out of Bosnia if the arms embargo was lifted.
"We face a very practical deadline because Congress has told us their patience is running out," one Administration official said. "The pressure is already high in Congress, and it does not diminish over time."

HEADLINE: Legal Services, Still Embattled

 BODY:
The election of Bill Clinton ended 12 years of White House abuse and neglect of the Legal Services Corporation, the Federal body that subsidizes hundreds of law offices devoted to representing the poor. The program still has enemies in Congress, however, and only last week had to rally to survive an attack on the Senate floor.
In debating a $400 million appropriation for the program, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas sought to deny funds for lawsuits challenging any law "which seeks to reform welfare." That looks civic-minded: Why let Federal money pay for litigation to block "reform?" The answer is that not all reforms are legal or constitutional and that governments often break their own laws. They need the policing the poverty lawyers provide. 
 Senator Gramm was especially offended by a lawsuit attacking New Jersey's refusal to pay benefits for new children born to mothers on welfare. That law may be tolerable as an experiment but it is almost certainly misguided -- it will simply victimize innocent children without discouraging illegitimate births. But whatever its merits, the law's constitutionality and legality need testing. Legal Services of New Jersey is right to bring that test.
In another public service, the Western Center on Law and Poverty persuaded a Federal appeals court two weeks ago that California's welfare cuts were being administered unlawfully by officials who ignored pleas to consider the impact of the cuts on children and the disabled.
Even the Justice Department, which endorses welfare reform, opposed the Gramm assault, which failed on a 56-to-44 vote. Such attacks have been the lot of the program for two decades and will doubtless continue. Fortunately, the Clinton Administration has appointed new leadership to fortify the program -- a welcome change from the years when Reagan appointees lobbied to kill or sharply curtail their own agency.
The corporation deserves the added security that can come only from a law re-authorizing the program and insulating it from political interference. Congress must also provide a realistic budget that keeps pace with inflation and the growing needs of the poor for civil justice.

HEADLINE: Police Went to Israeli Sites After Tips On Bomb Plots

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Out of concern over the possibility of a bomb attack by terrorists, the gray brick office building that houses the Israeli Mission to the United Nations and the Israeli Consulate was cordoned off yesterday by heavy concrete barriers and squads of New York City Police officers.
Security was also stepped up at more than a dozen other places in Manhattan where the Israelis or Jewish organizations have offices, as well as other locations in Brooklyn and the Bronx, including the headquarters of the Lubavitcher Hasidic movement on Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights. 
 "We're here to stop a kamikaze," said an officer on guard in front of the Israeli Mission to the United Nations.
A colleague added, however: "It's been calm all day. And with all these cops around, I doubt anyone will try anything."
But the situation outside the Israeli Mission was far from calm in the hours before dawn on Tuesday when the Federal Bureau of Investigation notified the New York City Police that a trusted informant had said that terrorists were planning to strike two targets in New York: The Israeli Mission to the United Nations on Second Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets, and the Israeli Defense Mission on Third Avenue at 51st Street. Another target on the list, the informant said, was the Israeli Embassy in Washington.
Only the day before, terrorists had exploded two bombs in London, one near the Israeli Embassy and the other outside the headquarters of the Joint Israel Appeal, a fund-raising organization, prompting Israeli officials to warn of an international campaign by radical Islamic groups opposed to Middle East peace efforts. Eight days earlier, an explosion at a Jewish cultural center in Buenos Aires killed at least 96 people. The same day, a bomb exploded on a Panamanian commuter plane killing 21 people, including 12 Jews.
At 1:15 A.M. on Wednesday, Louis R. Anemone, the chief of patrol forces for the New York City Police Department, got a phone call at home from the police operations center. He knew about the bombings abroad and he listened intently as a sergeant spelled out the details. The sources of the information sounded reliable.
"I looked at the whole package," Chief Anemone said yesterday, "and I said, 'Louie, this might be the real one."'
Working on his home phone, Chief Anemone dispatched dozens of officers to the two spots in Manhattan, some of them Emergency Service Units equipped with shotguns and submachine guns.
He needed barriers, quickly. The Department of Sanitation loaded 10 dump trucks with sand and lined them up nose to tailgate in front of the two buildings. Later, the trucks were replaced by three-foot-high slabs of concrete that usually serve as highway dividers.
Before dawn, the bomb squad swept through both of the buildings with technicians and dogs trained to detect explosives. They made a second run through the Defense Ministry building later in the morning. But they found nothing.
By 2:45 A.M., Chief Anemone was on Second Avenue, in front of the Israeli Mission to the United Nations, directing his troops. A few minutes later he ordered that a message be sent to all 75 precincts in the city: Check on any facilities that might possibly be vulnerable to Middle East-oriented terrorists and step up security.
As the day progressed, Chief Anemone extended special protection to other possible targets, including Temple Emanuel-El at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street and the Israeli Tourism and Economic Development Office in the Empire State Building.
Yesterday morning at City Hall, about 150 leaders of Jewish organizations, concerned about the terrorist threat, met with top aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and senior police officials. Afterward, Mark J. Miller, the executive director of the New York Jewish Community Relations Council, said, "They're on top of the situation."
Chief Anemone said he thought his officers had been a "calming influence.
"I anticipate this crisis period will pass," he said, 'that we will get through this and that there will be a gradual return to normalcy."
Outside the Israeli Mission to the United Nations yesterday, the police wore their usual pale blue short-sleeved summer shirts and service caps. There were no helmets or heavy weapons in sight.
"The idea is to make people feel safe, not to frighten them," said John Miller, the Deputy Police Commissioner for public information, "Just because you don't see the hardware doesn't mean it isn't there."

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE COST;
From Budget Office, Surprising Findings

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office has found that the health insurance bill from the Senate Finance Committee would insure 20 million of the estimated 39 million Americans who now lack coverage and save the Federal Government money in the process.
The Finance Committee bill would not require either employers or individuals to buy insurance, relying instead on changes in insurance laws and on subsidies for people with incomes up to twice the Federal poverty level, or about $28,000 for a family of four. The bill provides that if 95 percent of Americans are not insured by 2002, a commission would recommend what Congress should do next, and Congress would be required to consider the proposal quickly. 
 The study was released as House leaders put the final touches on a very different measure, relying on employer payments and promising universal coverage, that they will unveil on Friday to House Democrats.
The report on the Senate Finance Committee measure by the Congressional Budget Office, on which Congress relies for estimates of the cost of measures it adopts, makes it clear that the bill would miss the 95 percent target its sponsors set. It concludes that the bill would raise the percentage of Americans insured from the current 85 percent to 91 percent by 1997 and 92 percent by 1998 -- and then not increase it further.
The report was something of a surprise, because when the committee considered the bill it cut taxes and added benefits liberally. But the budget office found that this bill would not only be in balance, but would also provide $13.3 billion in savings through 2004 to reduce the Federal debt.
The bill includes an automatic reduction in subsidies, and thus insurance coverage, if spending is about to exceed receipts. The budget office found that this provision would work if needed. But it concluded that without a deep recession, those cuts would not be necessary because the bill's taxes on tobacco, payrolls and insurance premiums would leave it solidly financed.
The findings are certain to fuel the debate between those who advocate universal coverage, with required insurance purchases and employer payments, and those who contend that almost as much progress can be made, much more simply, with voluntary changes.
 
White House Unimpressed
 The White House weighed in immediately on the critical side. Lorrie McHugh, its health care spokeswoman, said, "We doubt that leaving tens of millions of hard-working middle-class Americans without real health security will be acceptable to the public."
But supporters of the Finance Committee bill were surprised and pleased by the report. One of the two chief sponsors of the approach taken in the bill, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, called the report "shockingly good news. For the first time, the federal bureaucracy is realizing that marketplace reforms can work."
The report, like the Congressional Budget Office studies of other health care proposals, also offered widespread criticism of the plan. It expressed concerns about additional burdens the bill would place on state insurance departments. It said the dual systems of subsidies, one for low-income families and another specifically for low-income children and pregnant women, would offer "a confusing array of options from which low-income families would have to choose." And it found that the taxes on high-cost insurance might be higher than sponsors expected and would cause serious administrative problems for companies that provided such insurance.
There was no immediate reaction either from the committee chairman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, or from the majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine. With the cost estimates in the report, however, Mr. Mitchell can move ahead with final drafting of the proposal he will put before the Senate next week. That measure will combine elements of his own invention with provisions of the Finance Committee bill and a more liberal measure approved by the Labor and Human Resources Committee.
 
House Closes In
 On the other side of Capitol Hill, House committee chairmen met with their leaders tonight and emerged saying they were close to completing their bill, which would remain closely modeled on the measure passed by the Committee on Ways and Means.
That would reach universal coverage by requiring employers to pay 80 percent of the cost of their workers' insurance and by creating an extension of Medicare to cover people who cannot get insurance at work.
Issues still unresolved, the leaders said, included how to deal with abortion, whether government should pick up coverage for early retirees and when to implement fully the requirement that employers contribute to their workers' insurance. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, was expected to resolve most of those issues overnight.
Representative Sam Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who is acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said the House was ready to lead. "I am 74 years old, and I've watched Congress for many years, and I've yet to find the Senate do any heavy lifting on those kinds of issues," he said, putting health care in the same category as Social Security and Medicare.
"The heavy lifting starts over here," said the 31-year Congressman.
 
Political Science
 Today the leadership gave the members a double-barreled lesson in the politics of the issues. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington attacked Republicans for "crass political obstruction of a problem that the American people think should be solved."
Earlier a pollster, Mark Mellman, went before a party caucus to tell Democratic members that even if health care was not at the top of their constituents' agenda yet, it would be if they failed to pass a bill. He said that to overcome anti-incumbent feeling the members needed to run "on a platform of accomplishment," and health care should be its centerpiece.
But even as Democratic leaders were concluding efforts to turn bills passed by committees into measures for consideration in the House and Senate, Republicans pressed for delay. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, told a meeting at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, "The American people are going to insist, they are insisting that we not rush to judgment."
He said that the Congress need not hurry, because there was no crisis in health care. "If you want to see a health care crisis," he said, "go to Sarajevo, or go somewhere in Rwanda.

The report said 20 million, not 23 million, of the 39 million Americans without health insurance would be added to insurance rolls by the Finance Committee bill.

Representative Richard A. HEADLINE: ACCORD REACHED ON SWEEPING BILL TO BATTLE CRIME

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators today approved a sweeping $30.2 billion anti-crime bill providing for 100,000 new police officers, a ban on some assault weapons and the death penalty for scores of crimes.
 President Clinton hailed the bill as "the toughest, largest, smartest Federal attack on crime in the history of our country." But critics, including some law-enforcement officials, called it a social-welfare boondoggle and, in the words of Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, "the whole Emerald City of Oz." 
The bill, which is about seven inches thick, would spend roughly equal amounts of money on prevention, punishment and new prisons. It provides money for drug courts and to fight violence against women. It pays for sports leagues and provides anti-gang grants to give young people positive alternatives to crime.
 It also helps states pay for the cost of incarcerating illegal aliens, and it would expand the application of the death penalty to about 60 Federal crimes, including carjacking. But it no longer contains a House provision to allow death-row inmates to challenge their sentences as racially motivated.
 After a marathon session that started on Wednesday morning and broke up at 2:15 A.M. today in a dispute over money for prisons, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic chairman of the Judiciary Committee, called his colleagues at 5:30 A.M. to meet before the full conference was to resume at 8 this morning.
 When the negotiators reconvened, they zipped through the remaining hurdles and forwarded the bill to the two chambers. The House is expected to act on it next week, and the Senate shortly thereafter.
 Despite some misgivings over the bill, most Democrats and some Republicans appear eager to pass anti-crime legislation in this election year. Congress has been on the brink of passing crime bills in the past, only to see them fall to partisan bickering.
 The President is anxious to sign the bill, which represents one of the few major promises he made as a candidate in 1992 that he has been able to turn into law.
 A happy Mr. Clinton, at a rally at the Justice Department celebrating passage of the bill, said, "This is one of the reasons why I ran for President."
 The money for the bill, an extraordinary amount at a time when Federal spending is stagnant, is supposed to come from a trust fund set up specifically to fight crime. "These are real dollars," Senator Biden said today at the news conference with Mr. Clinton. "This isn't funny money."
 The Administration says the trust fund will not increase the deficit because nearly the same amount of money -- about $30 billion to be spent over the next six years -- will be saved by the anticipated retirement of 265,000 Federal workers over the same period. But the Congressional Budget Office has said the Administration vastly overestimates its savings from the work-force reductions, and some Republicans remain dubious about the financing.
 The bill also authorizes programs that would cost an additional $3.1 billion, which would not come from the trust fund. Those programs would have to be financed, if at all, at the expense of other appropriations.
 An example would be a police corps proposed in the bill, a program that would provide partial college scholarships for students who agreed to serve as law-enforcement officers after graduation. The bill says it would cost $400 million for an unspecified number of students, but since the plan would not be financed from the trust fund, Congress would have to appropriate the money to implement the program.
 Mr. Clinton and the bill's supporters in Congress said the legislation was the first to meld prevention and punishment into one package. Representative John Conyers, Democrat of Michigan, said, "While this bill extends the harsh penalty approach, which hasn't worked but is politically popular, this is more than offset by a powerful set of prevention programs, including education, drug treatment and job training."
 The bill also represents the first major attempt by the Federal Government to deal with crime, which has traditionally been left to state and local governments.
 Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who steered the legislation through the House, said, "We are at a stage in America in the 1990's where we were on economic issues in 1910; state and local governments are unable to deal with the problem, and the Federal Government has to jump in."
 
Prevention and Punishment
 The bill divides the money equally over six years for prevention programs, punishment and new prisons.
 The bill gives $10.7 billion to state and local law enforcement, including money to put 100,000 new officers on the beat. The police officers are to be allocated on the basis of need. Mr. Schumer said that meant "New York will do very well." The city could hire 3,000 to 5,000 new officers, he said.
 Charles Moose, the chief of police in Portland, Ore., said at the rally, "This bill will allow local police officers to begin operating from a position of strength."
 Publicly, senior officials at Federal law-enforcement agencies have supported the crime bill. Privately, officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Bureau of Alcohol, Firearms and Tobacco complain that they are being forced to hold their budgets in line while billions of dollars are going to the many programs in the crime bill.
 
Seen as Political Gesture
 Many law enforcement officials say they doubt that those programs will put much of a dent in violent crime and view them as a political gesture by President Clinton to make him seem tough on crime. They are also fearful that the huge bill will mean many added responsibilities for Federal law-enforcement agencies without additional financing to carry them out.
 The bill would require mandatory life sentences for someone convicted of a violent Federal crime who had two previous convictions for serious felonies, Federal or state.
 Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, said the session in the early hours had produced a mess of a bill, one that "could have been concocted by a university sociology department" because of its $9 billion for prevention programs like midnight basketball. But he stopped short of saying he would oppose the bill.
 The measure that has received a disproportionate amount of attention wound up not being in the final bill. That is the so-called Racial Justice Act, which would have allowed death-row inmates to challenge their sentences as motivated by racial bias.
 It was supported by members of the Congressional Black Caucus and various liberals but was adamantly opposed by a majority in the Senate, including by several Democrats. The measure was approved by House negotiators on Wednesday night, but in the final meeting, negotiators excised it for fear that including it would bring down the whole bill.
 "Our efforts were not in vain," said a disappointed Representative Don Edwards, the California Democrat who pushed for the provision. "It did bring to the attention of the American people and President Clinton the fact that this remnant of slavery, this ugly remnant where the judicial system considers a black life not as important as a white life, does exist."
 Money for prisons proved the sticking point early this morning as negotiators met at a closed session for what they said would be 20 minutes but which turned into three hours.
 Everyone agreed that states should have more money for prisons, but they disagreed over the requirements for the states to get the money. The Senate negotiators said the states should agree to stiff sentencing policies, while House wanted less stringent sentencing.
 They had already agreed on two other provisions that had blocked the conference from occurring for more than a month. Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and a strong opponent of gun control, had threatened to hold up the entire bill if it included a ban on assault weapons, which had been approved by both houses. Mr. Brooks raised the issue in conference, calling the ban a "vendetta" against legitimate gun owners, but he lost.
 The ban covers 19 assault weapons as well as models altered to skirt the ban. The bill also makes it a Federal crime to sell handguns to minors or for minors to possess a handgun under most circumstances.
 As a consolation to Mr. Brooks, many members of the House negotiating team, and subsequently the Senators, agreed to a measure that would exempt pawnbrokers from the Brady law. The law requires people buying guns to undergo background checks; Mr. Brooks's exemption says pawnbrokers do not have to conduct such checks.
 Another gun-related measure is also included in the final bill. This is the "hunter rights" amendment, also drafted by Mr. Brooks, which prohibits even peaceful anti-hunting protests on Federal lands.
"It was a political chit that they fed to Brooks to compensate for the assault weapons," said Wayne Pacelle of the Humane Society of the United States.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 30, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Con gressional agreement on crime legis lation characterized the bill as "one of the few major promises President Clinton made in the 1992 campaign that he has been able to turn into law."
The characterization of Mr. Clin ton's record was overly broad. A number of initiatives for which he promised support in 1992 have been passed since he took office. Some of the most important were a deficit reduction bill, the North American Free Trade Agreement, rules allow ing abortion counseling in federallyfinanced clinics, a waiting period for handgun purchases and a national service program.

HEADLINE: Channel 13 to Pare Budget By Laying Off 60 Employees

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Facing a need to cut its budget once again, WNET-TV announced sweeping layoffs yesterday that will affect every department of Channel 13, the public television station that serves New York.
 Sixty of 480 positions will be eliminated, station executives said, as Channel 13 pares its budget to $105 million a year. Two years ago the station's budget was $137 million.
 The layoffs are the second the station has announced since 1991. That year 69 employees were eliminated.
 William F. Baker, the president of WNET, said the station had been slow to be hit by the economic recession that struck commercial television outlets in the last five years, but had been equally slow pulling out of that recession.
 The station continues to face economic pressures, Mr. Baker said, "because we have no operating margin, no cushion to ride out this storm."
 
Production Center Phaseout
 He said Channel 13 was close to a decision on phasing out its production center in Manhattan. If that happens, two national public television programs, "The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" and "The Charlie Rose Show," would have to find other studios.
 Mr. Baker said Channel 13 had subsidized both programs by providing production facilities for fees that do not cover Channel 13's costs. "We can't subsidize them anymore," he said. "We don't have the money."
 The staff cuts are extremely painful, Mr. Baker said, but the station had no choice.
 "We have to maintain a balanced budget," he said. "We don't want to get into a situation where we get into the red. Then we'll just constantly be adding bills we can't pay."
 The main shortfall in the budget has come about because of a decrease in corporate grants to the station, Mr. Baker said. "We have 325,000 members; that's more than we've ever had," he said, though another Channel 13 executive said that the income from memberships was actually flat.
 
No Long-Term Promises
 The cutbacks will be across the board, Mr. Baker said, and an effort will be made to keep the effects of the downsizing from showing up on the air. "In the near term, our hope is that viewers will not notice," he said. "But I can't make promises for the long term. If we have to phase out the production facilities, viewers are going to notice some effects on the shows we've been producing here."
 But he restated Channel 13's commitment to both "MacNeil/Lehrer" and "Charlie Rose." He said, "Those shows will have to continue, especially 'MacNeil/Lehrer."'
 Despite the continuing financial problems, Mr. Baker said, Channel 13's long-range future is secure. He said that a capital campaign to support the station, begun three years ago, has already obtained commitments of $40 million. That money will be used in the way that universities use endowments, Mr. Baker said.
 "When we have access to the money it will begin throwing off interest that we'll use in a variety of ways," Mr. Baker said. "But mainly it will give Channel 13 the financial cushion it has never had before."
 Mr. Baker said that Channel 13 hoped to have the funds from the capital campaign in place in three years. "The next three years are the tough years," he said.

HEADLINE: 10,000 Stampede as Russian Stock Collapses

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 29

 BODY:
Russia's largest investment company virtually collapsed today as more than 10,000 outraged stockholders stampeded the colonnaded headquarters of Moscow's commodities exchange, smashing windows as they tried desperately to unload their shares in the plummeting fund.
After promising on Thursday that it would begin to buy back stock for the equivalent of about $60 a share, officials of the troubled company, MMM, announced this morning that they had cut the value to almost nothing. 
 Investors crowded the exchange building, where windows were broken. Told that they were at the wrong place to redeem their shares, they then raced across the city to the company's headquarters, hoping against all odds that somebody there would purchase their shares at a decent price.
But by this evening, a share of the nation's most popular stock -- owned by between 5 million and 10 million people -- cost less than 50 cents.
"Those who have been trading MMM stock have been gambling," said Sergei K. Dubinin, the acting Finance Minister, speaking after the Government held a special session of the Cabinet to discuss the dimensions of free-market Russia's most spectacular financial disaster, and how seriously it would mar the struggling image of capitalism here. "Sooner or later the game had to come to an end," he said.
That is because MMM was built on sand. It was the most aggressive and successful of the country's many new stock funds, with television ads that were becoming as well known here as Coke or Pepsi ads are in the United States. The Government has called MMM a classic pyramid scheme: its soaring stock prices were fueled only by the people who bought shares. The company reported no earnings, revealed no investments, explained no financial strategy.
It never had to. Until today at least, Russian capitalism, only really active since the collapse of Communism, remained almost wholly unregulated. Pyramid schemes, not uncommon in confused or troubled economies like those of Russia and the former Communist countries of Eastern Europe, offer higher and higher returns to lure new investors.
Shares that cost the equivalent of about a dollar in February had rocketed to about $50 by Monday. Unlike the United States, where earnings and revenues are reported in many daily newspapers, this country has almost no such published information.
For most people, the facts didn't seem to matter. Even after repeated warnings from the Government, and after President Boris N. Yeltsin announced at a nationally televised news conference in June that he certainly would never invest in MMM, ordinary people kept buying the stock, attracted by promises of ever increasing prices and convenient salesrooms around Russia.
Asked what the company did to earn its income, not one of more than a dozen people interviewed this week could say. All, however, shared a firm belief that the problem lay not in the stock fund but in the country's leaders.
 
Investor Blames Government
 "This is a Government of liars and thieves," said Monya S. Yaliknova, as she stood along with 10,000 others outside the MMM headquarters in southern Moscow today. "They are attacking one company because it was able to make people prosperous and happy." Then, distilling the confusion that has affected so many investors in the new Russian economy, she added this: "Anyway, if there was a problem the Government should have stepped in and done something about it."
Now it may have to. MMM has so many investors -- the Government says five million, the company claims twice that number -- that its perils have become as much a political issue as a financial one. The president of MMM, Sergei Mavrody, has been artful in describing the crisis as one the Government made by harassing him. Although the assertion was made without a shred of evidence, a remarkable number of people here said they believed him.
The crisis came to a head last week when the Finance Ministry issued a stern warning about the questionable stock of MMM and other companies that are springing up across the country. Tax inspectors fined the company $29 million, closed some of its provincial offices and said Mr. Mavrody, who had suggested he would declare bankruptcy if the authorities did not leave him alone, was trying to blackmail them.
"The governmental persecution of MMM provoked a panic and the massive unloading of MMM shares," Mr. Mavrody said today in a statement to stockholders, some of whom had camped outside his headquarters for days. "Under such conditions it would be senseless to continue to buy up the shares. That would only lead to the firm's bankruptcy."
Mr. Mavrody asked shareholders to keep their stock for two or three months and said that despite the fact that the price was cut a hundredfold in a day it would soon soar again. "We, unlike the state, have never deceived you, and never will."
Most economists said today that despite many Government entreaties during the last month imploring buyers of MMM to beware, it would be very difficult for the Yeltsin Administration to ignore the plight of millions who have now lost their savings and their belief in the free-market system. They said the most damaging effect of the collapse could be to turn people away from free enterprise permanently, before they have had time to learn the meaning of risk and reward.
"MMM's collapse will certainly undermine people's confidence in the market economy in general," said Stanislav Shatalin, a well known economist here. "The Government will also suffer from this crisis, despite all its warnings."
Several members of Parliament, which is on vacation, suggested that a special session be called for next week to discuss the affair. Government tax officials, financial auditors and political leaders said they would begin investigations. Even Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev and Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev, made public comments that MMM was a fraud and people should stop supporting it.
But one influential group, the Russian Business Round Table, a loose association of employers and unions, said both the company and the Government were ultimately to blame.
"The Government did nothing to protect the population against violations of the principles of business ethics," the group said in a statement. "As a result unscrupulous businessmen were able to use the opportunities that opened up before them."
