HEADLINE: Economy Is Up 3.7% but Signs Hint of Slowing

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
In a report that cheered the Administration and financial markets for different reasons, the Commerce Department said today that the nation's economy grew at a brisk annual pace of 3.7 percent in the second quarter. But the report also showed that while businesses were expanding their production, unsold goods were piling up on store shelves as consumer spending slowed sharply.
The stock and bond markets rallied strongly on the announcement as investors decided that well-stocked retailers would stop ordering new goods and, as a result, the pace of economic growth might slow in the months ahead. Slower growth would help keep inflation, which is now just below 3 percent, in check and could reduce the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.67 points today to 3,764.50, while the interest rate on the closely watched 30-year Treasury bonds plunged to 7.39 percent from 7.54 percent, the biggest one-day drop in months. [Page 35.]
But as the markets welcomed the prospect of a slowdown, the Administration saw the report as signaling that economic growth was still robust and creating new jobs. Officials predicted that retailers and wholesale distributors would quickly sell their extra inventories, clearing shelves for factories to fill again.
"The U.S. economy continues to turn in a fine performance," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "So far, everything we've seen in 1994 confirms our forecast of a sustainable investment-led expansion with low inflation."
Despite the enthusiastic reception from the financial markets and the Administration, some analysts warned that both could be disappointed. Still unclear is whether the economy is really as strong as a 3.7 percent growth rate might suggest. And a price index in the economic figures today showed that inflation may be beginning to creep up again because of brisk economic growth and low interest rates last winter.
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said that "all the aspects of the report that were happy were questionable." He said personal income growth was still strong, hinting at a rebound in consumption. As soon as next Friday, when the employment report for July is released, Mr. Lipsky said investors hoping for slower growth could be disappointed.
The most compelling figures in today's report concerned inventories. But because analysts offered differing explanations for why they increased so much, it was still unclear what the inventory buildup meant for economic growth the rest of this year.
The nation's stores and warehouses filled up with an extra $50 billion in unsold goods during the quarter. It was the biggest increase in inventories since the fourth quarter of 1987, when the stock market crash produced a drop in spending.
Slow sales were partly to blame. Consumer spending plunged, falling to an annual rate of just 1.2 percent in the second quarter from 4.7 percent in the first quarter. In a sign that this year's rising interest rates may be starting to have an effect, the slowing was most pronounced for big-ticket purchases for which consumers often borrow money. Sales of cars and car parts, for instance, fell slightly.
But Ms. Tyson said that much of the increase in inventories took place because business managers believed that they could sell a lot more merchandise -- an interpretation of the data that points to steady or more growth, not less.
She contended that business executives were reacting to polls showing high consumer confidence and to the nation's rapid growth in jobs, which means that more Americans have spending money. She also pointed to historical evidence that inventories have stayed unusually low during the current economic expansion.
"I think there are a number of indicators that really are consistent with the view that this inventory accumulation we've seen in the second quarter is actually a planned phenomenon responding to the belief in the longevity of the expansion and in the size of its continued forward momentum," she said.
Congressional testimony last week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested that he might agree with Ms. Tyson. But that view could prompt him to raise interest rates at some point, because continued momentum in the economy would raise the risk of inflationary bottlenecks in production, with companies bidding up the price of scarce materials and skilled workers.
"To be sure, some hints of moderation in the growth of domestic final demand have appeared, and the recent indications of accelerating inventory accumulation may suggest an unwanted backing up of stocks," Mr. Greenspan said, drawing out the word "may" in a tone that suggested skepticism. "Conversely, the inventory accumulation may reflect pressures on firms who had brought inventories down to suboptimal levels and now need to replenish them. In the latter case, stock-building may continue at an above-normal rate, supporting production for quite some time."
A further interest rate increase could set the stage for a confrontation with Administration officials, who have made it clear that they believe the Federal Reserve's four increases this spring in short-term interest rates have already been enough to forestall inflation.
Taking the other view, some Wall Street economists said that retailers might cut back their orders sharply until the inventory backlogs were cleared. James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan, said that he reduced his estimate today of third-quarter growth to 3 percent from 4 percent because he expected retailers to draw down their stocks now before ordering more goods.
David B. Bostian, the chief economist at Herzog, Heine, Geduld Inc., a New York brokerage firm, predicted that economic growth could drop sharply because of the inventories. "I conclude from this report that we're really on the precipice as far as the economy slowing down," he said.
But Mr. Bostian added that he doubted that this risk would dissuade the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates yet again, particularly because the price index in the report rose 2.9 percent, suggesting that inflation was no longer falling and might be creeping up again..
Rising exports also buoyed economic growth during the second quarter, as did a slowing in the shrinkage of military procurement of goods and services.
 
Statistics Are Revised
 The Government today also revised slightly its statistics on economic growth for the last three years. Using information recently compiled from annual surveys of various industries, the data showed that quarterly and annual fluctuations in economic growth were less than previously thought.
For instance, last year's torrid fourth-quarter growth of 7 percent was revised down to 6.3 percent. But the department also revised first- quarter growth last year up to 1.2 percent from eight-tenths of a percent. The figures produced no change in the department's previous estimate of overall growth last year of 3.1 percent.
The Commerce Department also revised its figures to show that the recession in 1991 was a little milder than previous estimates, and the recovery in 1992 was a little less brisk.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the second quarter of 1994 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE OVERVIEW;
HOUSE DEMOCRATS UNVEIL PROPOSAL FOR HEALTH BILL

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders unveiled a national health care plan today that promises universal coverage by 1999, and they immediately embarked on what is expected to be an epic, two-week legislative struggle to assemble a Democratic majority behind it.
"This bill is about the courage of this Congress," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, who urged his colleagues to step up to a moment in history, just as previous Congresses did with Social Security and Medicare. 
 As expected, the plan announced today was modeled on the measure passed last month by the Ways and Means Committee. It would achieve universal coverage, in large part, by requiring employers to pay 80 percent of the cost of their workers' insurance, with subsidies to cushion the burden on small, low-wage companies. It would also create a vast new extension of the Medicare program to serve as "a safety net" for people who are unemployed, have part-time jobs, or otherwise cannot get coverage through work.
It would enact sweeping new rules for the insurance industry intended to make coverage easier to get, particularly for people with "pre-existing conditions." It would also define a new basic benefit package that would be guaranteed every American, and create a new system of subsidies to help low-income working people afford coverage.
President Clinton hailed the plan as "simpler, more flexible and more sensitive to the needs of small business" than his original proposal, but achieving the same goals of universal coverage and holding down costs. "The House bill tells the American people that they have been heard," Mr. Clinton declared, underscoring the recent drumbeat from the White House and Capitol Hill that the President's own much-maligned plan is no longer in play.
But even the most committed partisans of the House leaders' plan acknowledge that getting the 218 votes necessary for passage is an extraordinary challenge. They face fierce and unrelenting opposition from businesses to any new requirement that employers help pay for insurance. The United States Chamber of Commerce characterized the plan today as a "Bride of Frankenstein" proposal.
Democratic strategists also face House Republicans who made it clear again today that their votes are simply not to be had for a bill from the Democratic leadership. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said the leadership's plan "lunges too far, at too great a cost, with too much government, and the truth is, it will do irreparable damage to the American system."
But of greatest concern to House Democratic leaders is the unrest and apprehension in their own ranks: among moderate and conservative Democrats who argue that the plan goes too far to the left, and among the many members who seem torn between their desire for universal coverage and their fear of the political cost of voting for an employer mandate.
That fear was articulated in a closed Democratic caucus today, when Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee and a staunch critic of the leadership on health care, warned his colleagues that this kind of plan did not have a prayer in the Senate. Thus, Mr. Cooper asserted later, House members would "walk the plank one more time," only to be overturned by the Senate.
 
Dueling Debates
 In the Senate, where resistance to the new requirement on business is, in fact, considered to be far greater, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, announced today that he would unveil his plan on Tuesday. He also announced that floor debate, originally expected to begin in the Senate next week, would be delayed until the week after.
That means that both the House and the Senate will take up the health care bill in the week of Aug. 8. The House, with its tighter rules, is expected to complete action by the end of that week; no one has a firm prediction on how long the Senate will take.
Democrats in the House have been imploring their leaders to wait for the Senate to vote on the controversial employer requirements before asking the House to act. But Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, said today that the House would push ahead regardless of the Senate schedule. Tying the House pace to the Senate, leadership strategists suggest, would cede operational control of the Congress to Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, who has vast powers to slow down the Senate.
"We have never, ever keyed our action in the House to any schedule, possible, probable, potential, or otherwise, in the Senate," Mr. Foley said today. "Frankly, we could not do it if we wished to."
Amid all the political scrambling, House leaders today tried to reach for the broader significance of what they are attempting to do. "This is truly, in my judgment, a bill of the magnitude of the Social Security Act and the Medicare Act and other seminal acts taken by Congress that have redounded to the benefit of our citizens," Mr. Foley declared at a leadership news conference this afternoon.
Leaders also underscored, again and again, how much this bill has changed during its six-month journey through the committees, followed by the process of final drafting and melding by the leadership. "This is not the Clinton bill," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the majority whip. "Our plan cuts bureaucracy, cuts the cost to taxpayers, cuts the alliances that everyone calls big government, cuts the automatic price controls, cuts red tape and cuts the burden on small business."
 
No Purchasing Alliances
 There are, in fact, some important differences with the Clinton plan: The large insurance purchasing pools known as alliances, which most Americans would have been required to join and which had substantial regulatory powers, are gone.
Democratic leaders also argued that they have taken pains to respond to the concerns of small business. The mandated employer financing would be phased in, applying to companies with more than 100 employees by January 1997 and to smaller companies by January 1999. Moreover, businesses with 25 or fewer employees would be eligible for subsidies up to 50 percent of their costs, and those with 26 to 50 employees would be eligible for subsidies up to 37.5 percent.
Mr. Gephardt argued that the hourly cost of this employer mandate would be "not unlike a minimum-wage increase." And, he suggested, it might take the place of one, arguing that if the plan passed, "we won't have a minimum-wage increase."
 
Unresolved Issues
 In addition to contributions from employers and employees, officials said, the plan would be financed by slowing the rate of growth in Medicare and Medicaid, raising the tobacco tax by 45 cents a pack and imposing a 2 percent surcharge on private health insurance premiums.
Even as the bill moves toward the floor, there are some issues unresolved; chief among them is how abortion should be treated in the basic benefit package. The lobbying is expected to escalate dramatically in the coming days, particularly on issues that affect how vast segments of the health industry do business; one of those is a provision requiring health maintenance organizations and other networks to work with "any willing provider" in a region.
Leaders today acknowledged, however, that the debate is still on the fundamental issues: Should the country move toward guaranteeing coverage to every American, or should it settle for more incremental approaches? Mr. Gephardt warned today that more modest insurance reforms would only result in higher premium costs to the middle class, as sicker people enter the system and the young and healthier opt out because of rising costs.
But there is an influential contingent in the House, led by Mr. Cooper, among others, that is working on an incremental bill that neither promises universal coverage nor requires employers to contribute. Those members today described the leadership's plan as to the left of the Clinton plan. "I didn't think the President's would fly, and I don't think this will either," said Representative Roy Rowland, Democrat of Georgia.
These members are working with a handful of Republicans on a bipartisan bill, which they said will be ready next week. This could be the real rival to the leadership's plan.
For now, ready or not, Democrats are heading toward a historic debate -- with great uncertainty on whether the outcome with be another Social Security or a legislative catastrophe.
At the news conference today, the leaders and the whip organization, ordinarily a loose and jovial crew, seemed solemn and intense. "We're going to have a debate," Mr. Gephardt said. "This is going to be a fire and light show. We're going to debate this bill and we're going to test our adversaries and they're going to test us. And when it's over, we're going to vote."

HEADLINE: Americans in Haiti Fear an Invasion

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 29

 BODY:
More than a dozen American warships are now stationed just off Haiti with the stated purpose of protecting the Americans living here. But many of the people who are supposed to feel reassured say they would be a lot happier if the ships would sail away and leave them alone.
"We are safe down here, and have been for many years," said Mickey McLaney, who came to Haiti two decades ago to run a hotel and a swimsuit business, neither of which is now open. "We don't need that kind of help. Before they put this embargo on, we were doing just fine." 
 Disagreement with most aspects of the Clinton Administration's policy toward Haiti is widespread among Americans living here, especially executives who resent the American-sponsored economic sanctions that have cut them off from markets and suppliers in the United States and forced them to close their businesses.
 
Anxiety and Depression
 "We can't put money in banks, and we can't write checks," complained Ed Gollon, an Arkansas native whose interests here range from maintaining sewing equipment to making alcoholic beverages. "The whole country is kaput, and there is a great deal of frustration, anxiety and depression as this thing drags on and on and on."
The sanctions against Haiti will turn a notch tighter on Saturday with the departure of the last regularly scheduled airline flight.
But many Americans here say they are especially leery of becoming pawns in Washington's struggle to force the military leadership under Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras to step down and to restore the country's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, whom many of the Americans do not trust or like. They recall previous American invasions of Panama and Grenada, when the safety of Americans became the justification for sending in the troops.
"I don't think that any American in this country wants American soldiers to die for the return of this man," said Don Moore, operations manager for Brasserie Nationale d'Haiti, the country's leading brewery and beer and soda distributor. The real solution to Haiti's crisis, he said, "is to keep that priest in the United States, not here."
But another, probably smaller, group dismisses the complaints of their fellow Americans and is more sympathetic to Father Aristide and the social changes he espouses.
 
'The Expatriate Life-Style'
 "A lot of these people have gotten used to the expatriate life-style, with the big houses, the servants and the parties, and don't want to see it threatened," said one relief worker, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The United States Embassy estimates that about 3,000 Americans remain in Haiti, less than half the number who were living here before the economic sanctions were imposed. The expatriate community, most of whom live in the capital and maintain a system of neighborhood "wardens" to act as intermediaries with the embassy, includes black, white and mixed-race Americans.
Many are businessmen who came to Haiti with their families to start or run the assembly plants that sprang up here during the Duvalier dictatorship, though a few have lived here longer. Others came to work for international aid and relief agencies on development projects, or at hospitals and feeding stations, while some are naturalized citizens of Haitian descent.
The American community here ranges in age from Victor Wynne, 95, a former Navy engineer who arrived during the 19-year American military occupation that ended in 1934, to hundreds of young children born in New York or Miami to parents who fled Haiti under the Duvaliers and their successors and later chose to return.
 
Many Young Children
 Mr. McLaney said that about 70 percent of the more than 700 Americans for whom he was responsible as a warden were children 10 or younger, a fact that worries him.
"What am I supposed to do about a 2-year-old who is an American citizen, but whose parents are not?" he asked. "If there really is an invasion and we have to have an evacuation, how do I tell the rest of that family the child is entitled to protection but they are not?"
As tensions between Washington and the military government here have mounted, there have been a few isolated incidents in which Americans have complained of being harassed by government supporters, as well as one in which a black Canadian was beaten by the police. But overall, Americans have been relatively immune from the horrible violence that has affected Haitians, said Stanley Schrager, a spokesman for the American Embassy.
But some Americans fear that the barrage of talk about military intervention could make things dangerous for them.
The crisis has to some extent strained relations between American residents and the embassy, which some expatriates see as a center of efforts to topple the military government. Several complain that the United States Government has been treating them almost as a hostile force -- for instance, opening mail they have sent to the United States, looking for checks and money transfers that might violate the embargo.
But most of all, they complain that official Washington is ignoring them.
If there is a single piece of advice they have to offer the Clinton Administration, Americans here said over and over, it is this: Stay out of Haiti. Don't invade and, above all, don't get mired in a repeat of the 1915-1934 military occupation.
"We did that already, and what did it solve?" asked Wally Turnbull, whose family has operated a Baptist mission in the hills above the capital since the 1940's. "You can't impose democracy with a big stick. The Marines were here all those years, but Haitians are not interested in following the American way. They have their own agenda, and they don't like to be told what to do."

HEADLINE: Rates Fall And Stock Prices Rise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday and stocks jumped, as traders and investors concluded that the most recent economic reports indicated that the Federal Reserve Board would not push up interest rates as much or as quickly as they had previously thought.
 The catalyst for the markets was the Commerce Department's early morning report that gross domestic product, the sum of economic activity in the second quarter, grew by only 3.7 percent after inflation. Because consumer spending grew by only 1.2 percent in the second quarter, down from an average of 4.2 percent over the previous three quarters, while business inventories rose rapidly, economists said that businesses might soon cut back on production, thereby helping reduce economic growth in the current quarter to less than 3 percent.
 
 Such a slowdown in growth would be welcome news in the bond markets. Bond investors generally believe that the Federal Reserve favors a 2.5 percent growth rate, viewing that rate as one that would allow employment to grow while keeping inflation in check.
 
Market on a Gallop
 "The market took off on a gallop because some traders were fearful of a much stronger economic report," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, an affiliate of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 The gallop was fastest for long-term Treasury bonds, where the bellwether 6 1/4 percent issue due in 2024 rose nearly 1 3/4 points, or slightly more than $17 per $1,000 bond, to 86 /15 32 to yield 7.39 percent. That yield was the lowest since June 23, and down from 7.54 percent a day earlier.
 Stocks also rallied across the board, decisively reversing losses earlier in the week. All the leading indexes were up sharply, led by the Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 33.67 points, to 3,764.5. [Page 36.]
 Many traders said yesterday's bond trading was dominated more by securities firms and other speculators, than by institutions, which bought only modest amounts.
 Mr. Fine noted that the slower economic growth reported for the second quarter, which is widely expected to continue in the third quarter does not mean the end of the Fed's six-month push to raise short-term interest rates. Inflation is sure to rise in coming months, he said, and the Fed will be more concerned about the risk of accelerating inflation than about the risk that higher rates could cause economic growth to falter.
 Marshall B. Front, a managing director at Trees Front Associates, a Chicago investment counseling firm, said fears of inflation and rising interest rates, were overdone in recent weeks. Now that there are signs of slower economic growth, Treasury bond yields could drop as low as 7 percent, he predicted.
 But because the Federal Reserve will continue raising short-term interest rates, he said, most investors will continue buying intermediate-term issues due in seven years or less, rather than long-term bonds, which suffer the steepest price declines when interest rates rise.
 Many analysts are now debating whether the Fed's next move to raise interest rates is likely to come at its next policy-setting meeting -- on Aug. 16 -- or afterward. Until yesterday, they had been debating whether the next increase in rates would come on or before Aug.16.
 
Federal Funds Rate Watched
 The Federal funds rate, which is charged on overnight loans between banks and is a benchmark for other short-term interest rates, has been about 4 1/4 percent since mid-May. The Fed controls the rate closely, and traders are now debating whether the Fed's next move will be to 4 1/2 percent or 4 3/4 percent.
 Yesterday's rally came as securities firms were beginning to look ahead to one of the largest Treasury financings of the year. Next Wednesday, securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce plans to sell more than $17 billion of three-year notes on Aug. 9, followed by about $12 billion of 10-year notes on Aug. 10, and $11 billion of 30-year bonds on Aug. 11.
 In yesterday's trading, the most recent three-year issue, the 6 1/2 percent notes due in May 1997 rose one-half point, to 100 5/8 to yield 6 1/4 percent, while the 7 1/4 percent notes due in about 10 years rose 16/32 to yield 7.10 percent.
 
Muni Bonds Rally, Too
 The rally in Treasury bonds spilled over to the municipal market. Despite a flurry of warnings this week by the New York State Comptroller and the Financial Control Board, an oversight agency, that New York City's budget for the coming year could become unbalanced, traders said prices of city bonds increased enough to reduce their yields by a tenth of a percentage point or more.
 "The market has heard it all before," said Duncan Smith, a mangaging director at Lebenthal & Company, when asked about the impact of recent warnings that the city might not collect some revenues it expects or fail to control spending. "People seem to think that the mayor is tough and will make the right choices when he has to," Mr. Smith said.
 The Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, for one, remains confident that the city will handle its budget woes without any defaults. On Thursday it told securities dealers it would sell an undisclosed additional amount of insurance to guarantee principal and interest on outstanding city issues. Insured bonds carry top-notch triple-A ratings and carry yields that are about four-tenths of a percentage point lower than bonds backed by only the city's promise to pay.
 City bonds now have medium grade ratings of Baa-1 from Moody's Investors Service and A- from the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which has warned that it might reduce its rating.
 By late Friday, New York City bonds due in five years were available in the wholesale market at yields of 5.30 percent, or about 5.10 percent for smaller orders. Bonds due in 10 years were about 6.05 percent wholesale and 5.90 percent retail, and yields of 6 percent or higher were available to individual investors for bonds due in about 15 years or more.

HEADLINE: Ambitious Plans for Iraqi Oil

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 28

 BODY:
Expressing confidence that the United Nations embargo on Iraqi oil exports will be lifted by early next year, Iraq's Oil Minister is preparing to triple oil production over the next few years from an initial two million barrels a day.
 Revenues from the increasing oil production could offset the cost of the reparations that Iraq must pay for its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. But it could also put pressure on world oil prices, unless demand keeps growing and production declines elsewhere.
 
 In an interview here, the Iraqi Oil Minister, Safa Hadi Jawad Habubi, estimated that Iraq would have the capacity to export slightly more than two million barrels of oil a day after the embargo is lifted.
 But he said Iraq intended to raise production to its OPEC quota of 3.6 million barrels a day, the same level as Iran, within 10 to 14 months, once it obtains the parts needed to repair oil installations damaged during the Persian Gulf war. Iraq was producing an estimated 3.3 million barrels a day before the war.
 
Plans for More Oilfields
 In the next six to eight years, the minister said Iraq would almost double this level of output, increasing production to six million barrels a day by developing new oilfields in the south of the country in joint ventures with foreign companies. Southern Iraq's undeveloped oil reserves are estimated at 20 billion to 30 billion barrels.
 Iraq's hopes have been bolstered by recent movement within the United Nations toward relaxing the embargo on Iraqi oil exports. Although the Security Council agreed not to remove the trade sanctions when it reviewed them recently, a number of countries, led by Russia and France, made clear that they would like to see sanctions relaxed early next year if Iraq continues to cooperate with United Nations disarmament efforts.
 Dr. Habubi's optimistic projections come at a time of rising oil prices. In the United States, crude oil for current delivery has surged above $20 a barrel from about $14.50 in late March.
 If Iraq succeeds in pushing up its oil production sharply, and if oil prices do not plunge because of increased supply, Iraq may by the end of the century be offsetting the painful economic consequences of invading Kuwait. It would be pumping enough new oil to compensate itself for the 30 percent slice of oil revenues that it must pay in reparations under the United Nations Security Council's terms for the gulf war cease-fire.
 Assuming Iraq can produce six million barrels of oil a day, it will be required to hand over the revenue from two million barrels a day to the Kuwait compensation fund, but it will still retain control over the other four million barrels a day. That would give it oil revenues comparable to those it reaped before the war, assuming oil prices remain unchanged.
 So far, compensation claims exceeding $100 billion have been filed with the United Nations against Iraq arising out of its attempted annexation of Kuwait.
 To reach an output of six million barrels a day, Dr. Habubi said Iraq and its foreign partners would need to invest $30 billion to $40 billion in its oilfields. "The investments will be shared between Iraq and the foreign oil companies," the minister said.
 Iraq has already signed agreements with two French oil companies, Total S.A. and Elf Aquitaine, to develop two big southern oilfields once sanctions end. Dr. Habubi said he would announce agreements with other foreign oil companies "in the next two or three months."
 To insure that Iraq's return to the oil market did not depress prices, Dr. Habubi said he expected Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to accept lower production quotas from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
 In the longer term, however, he predicted that Iraq's plans to raise oil production would not weaken oil prices because rising Iraqi exports would merely fill the gap left by expected production declines in Algeria, Indonesia and the North Sea.
 
Outlook on Consumption
 World demand for oil is also likely to increase as North America and Europe continue to rebound from recent recessions and China and the Asian economies keep up their present rates of growth, he said.
 [Analysts in the United States did not seem surprised by the Iraqi Oil Minister's projections. Joseph Stanislaw, managing director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said Iraq's goals were only somewhat more ambitious than what his firm was forecasting. "Give or take a year or two, they were more or less in line,' he said.
 [Mr. Stanislaw said he doubted that the extra production would cause an oversupply of oil or a decline in oil prices beyond a momentary dip because demand was rising worldwide. "The Prime Minister of China was just in Germany saying all Chinese families should have a car," he said.]
 Dr. Habubi, a French-trained engineer who wears an olive green military uniform, as do all high officials of the ruling Baathist Party, appeared confident that the oil embargo would be lifted by early 1995 at the latest. The Security Council would act, he contended, because Iraq was fully complying with its demands.
"Yes, I'm very hopeful that it might be earlier than that," he said, sitting beside a big black desk in his office furnished with spotless white leather sofas and armchairs.
 Under Resolution 687 setting out the terms for ending the Persian Gulf war, the Security Council said the oil embargo would have "no further force or effect" once its 15 members were satisfied that Iraq was disarmed of its most dangerous weapons and could build no more weapons of mass destruction.
 A United Nations commission has almost completed the disarmament part of its mission and is now installing a system for monitoring Iraqi industry intended to insure that Iraq does not again try to manufacture nuclear, chemical or biological weapons or build long-range rockets.

HEADLINE: Airwaves Auctions Bring $833 Million For U.S. Treasury

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
The Federal Government set out to sell blue sky this week, and it succeeded beyond anybody's wildest expectations.
Concluding an unprecedented experiment to auction off the nation's airwaves, the Federal Communications Commission raised $617 million today from the the sale of 10 licenses for nationwide advanced paging networks. On top of that, it took in $216 million from the sale of some 300 licenses that may be used for interactive television services in the future. 
 The biggest winners today were companies already prominent in wireless communications.
Since the auction began on Monday, Paging Network Inc., the nation's largest paging company, dueled in round after round of bidding with McCaw Cellular Communications, the nation's biggest cellular telephone company. Today each ended up buying two advanced paging licenses for $80 million each -- some 20 times what anyone had expected a license to bring when the bidding began.
A fifth $80 million license went today to a company backed by the Microsoft Corporation and its billionaire founders, William H. Gates and Paul Allen.
These big licenses will be used for nationwide two-way paging networks that will go beyond today's paging systems by letting customers send and receive both spoken and written messages through small wireless devices. The companies expect these networks to be built within five years.
Most of the companies that won paging licenses today plan to offer a new service called "acknowledgment paging," in which a pager automatically responds to a message with a signal indicating that the message got through. But holders of the most valuable licenses also plan more elaborate networks that would allow people to type messages on their computers or hand-held communicators and transmit them anywhere in the country.
Five other nationwide paging licenses, for less powerful networks, were sold for $37 million to $47.5 million each. Paging Network, based in Plano, Tex., also won one of these, giving it 3 of the 10 licenses auctioned.
 
 
'Huge Potential Appetite'
 Today's results vividly demonstrated how precious the nation's airwaves are at time when the wireless communications business is seeing explosive growth.
"This is very valuable spectrum," said John Chapple, executive vice president of McCaw Cellular. "There is a huge potential appetite for two-way paging and messaging services."
But this week's sales prices may seem like pocket change compared with the levels expected in an F.C.C. auction set for later this year. The real money and true frenzy will be unleashed around December, when the Government starts to auction off a much bigger portion of the airwaves for a rich array of new wireless telephone, fax and data services.
Nobody knows what those auctions will yield, but there is no doubt they will involve billions, rather than millions, of dollars. Last year, the Clinton Administration drew snickers from the communications industry when it predicted that this invisible real estate would be worth $10 billion. Now skeptics are not so sure.
"As much as I hate to see so much money being voluntarily handed over to the Government, I think it's plausible that they could raise the $10 billion," said Ira Brodsky, president of Datacomm Research Inc. in Wilmette, Ill., a consulting firm that specializes in wireless communications.
 
 
Dominated by Big Companies
 Despite their value in whittling the Federal budget deficit, the auctions raise questions of whether contests of raw financial muscle are really the best way to manage the radio spectrum -- a precious public resource that has always been viewed as having a social value beyond its economic worth.
Indeed, the main criticism raised during this week's bidding was that small and minority-owned concerns were quickly overwhelmed by large bids from big companies, even though the F.C.C. rules would have given the small bidders a 25 percent discount on any licenses they won.
And even for the winners, the amounts they are spending for licenses raise questions about whether the competing networks will earn enough money to justify the high bids. Time, and the communicating public, will determine that.
By any measure, this new embrace of market forces represents a fundamental break from past practice. Until now, the Government has given radio licenses away. They have done so either by trying to select the company most likely to serve the broad public interest, as is done with broadcasting licenses, or by holding winner-take-all lotteries, which is how most cellular licenses were awarded in the 1980's.
The new policy of using auctions for most nonbroadcasting licenses has been strongly supported by both Democrats and Republicans. Last year, Congress authorized auctions amid a growing consensus that the "public interest" was so amorphous that marketplace mechanisms were better suited to identify the best use of the airwaves.
Auctions are also seen as ending what many critics have described as a billion-dollar give-away in airwave licenses, which allowed lucky speculators to make fortunes while depriving taxpayers of compensation for their largess.
"This is a window on the future," Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said the other day as the bidding escalated. "What you see in this auction is a slugfest. But what it means is no-holds-barred competition for providing wireless services."
The companies are drawn by the popular demand for wireless services. Already, more than 18 million people subscribe to paging services. Another 16 million people own cellular telephones, and despite high prices for the service, the number of cellular customers is rising about 40 percent a year.
Yet, auctions pose enormous financial risks for companies rushing to stake out claims on the wireless frontier.
When the next round starts in December, for licenses for personal communications services -- called PCS networks -- there will be more than 2,000 licenses up for grabs. Some will be for single metropolitan markets, others for large regions.
Companies hoping to put together enough licenses around the country to create a nationwide PCS network will probably have to bid hundreds of millions of dollars. And then they will have to raise billions of dollars to build the systems. And they must do this at precisely the time when the competition among wireless communications is rougher than ever before.
The biggest of the coming PCS licenses will offer enough capacity, or "band width," on the airwaves to start at least three full-fledged competitors to today's cellular telephone networks. PCS is expected to expand on cellular service by adding data communications, and perhaps even limited video capabilities, to conventional voice transmission.
Today, the cellular business is a $10-billion-a-year industry with rich profit margins. At least two of the nation's billionaires -- John Kluge, the head of Metromedia Inc., and Craig O. McCaw, the founder of McCaw Cellular -- made their fortunes by snapping up cellular telephone licenses, whether winning them by lottery or subsequently buying them from the lottery winners.
The National Telecommunications and Information Administration estimated several years ago that the combined market value of cellular telephone franchises was somewhere between $40 billion and $80 billion. Currently, the AT&T Corporation is trying to complete its acquisition of McCaw Cellular for $12.6 billion.
But in the cellular industry, competition has been limited because the F.C.C. a decade ago created only two cellular licenses for each local market. Industry experts warn that many companies may fail to appreciate the enormous competitive challenges ahead for the new rivals.
"This is where auction theory leaves off and company egos kick in," said Janice Obuchowski, president of Freedom Technologies Inc., a telecommunications consulting firm in Washington.
"You have a whole, large tranche of people who may come in here and think this is a reprise of cellular, which it will not be," she said. "These companies are going to have to gut it out through some very tough times."
In the advanced-paging auction that was concluded today, the winner of three licenses, Paging Network of Dallas, already has 3.3 million paging subscribers.
KDM Messaging, which won two of the $80 million licenses today, is owned primarily by McCaw Cellular -- which has extensive paging operations in addition to its cellular holdings.
Nationwide Wireless Network, which won an $80 million license today and one for more limited service for $47.5 million, was formed by Mobile Telecommunications, the big paging company in Jackson, Miss., that is known as Mtel. Microsoft has invested $30 million in the venture, along with its founders, Mr. Gates and Mr. Allen.
Before the auction began, Mtel had already been given an F.C.C. "pioneer's preference" license for one-way advanced paging, because it was an early developer of the technology.
Another winner today was BellSouth Wireless, a subsidiary of the BellSouth Corporation, the regional telephone company, which has extensive cellular and paging properties and owns part of a wireless data service called RAM Mobile Data. It paid just over $47 million for a license to operate a lower-capacity two-way network, as did Airtouch Communications, a wireless company recently spun off from Pacific Telesis, another regional Bell company.
The other company winning a license today was Page Mart II Inc. of Dallas, a paging company with $60 million a year in sales. It has been developing a wireless messaging service for use with personal computers and paid $38 million for a one-way paging license.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar In a Broad Decline But Is Steady Against Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark and other currencies yesterday after a Government report showing slower-than-expected economic growth convinced many traders that the Federal Reserve is less likely to raise interest rates soon.
But the dollar remained steady against the Japanese yen on speculation that American and Japanese negotiators are making progress in talks aimed at curbing Japan's swollen trade surplus with the United States. 
 The dollar's slump against the mark started after the Commerce Department said United States gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the second quarter, slightly below what many economists and traders expected.
With the economy growing at a moderate pace, the Federal Reserve will have less incentive to raise rates on overnight bank loans in order to keep inflation under control, traders said. Higher rates would make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
"The numbers show that there is no need to raise rates in the U.S.," said Victor Polce, head of foreign-exchange marketing at Commerzbank A.G. in New York. "Now the Fed may grant a stay of execution until the last quarter of the year."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5840 marks, down from 1.5920 marks on Thursday. But it was unchanged at 100.10 yen.
Speculation that British interest rates are poised to rise next week for the first time since 1989 also helped drive the British pound higher yesterday. It rose to $1.5440 from $1.5274.
Mr. Polce and other traders suspect the dollar's losses against the mark will be temporary because prospects for steady, noninflationary growth helped stocks and bonds to rally strongly yesterday.
Treasury bonds and the dollar have been locked in a tight embrace for much of this year. The slumping bond market meant that foreign investors sold dollars as they bailed out of American assets. In turn, the weak dollar prompted more bond sales as investors sought to stanch losses from currency depreciation. With bonds rising, the dollar's prospects appear brighter.
"The bond rally should keep the dollar in demand," said Jim Raphael, assistant vice president in currency trading at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Troubles in Nigeria Send Oil and Cocoa Up Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Rioting and labor strife in Nigeria drove crude oil and cocoa prices up sharply yesterday on worries the unrest would disrupt exports from the African nation.
Striking Nigerian oil workers demanded that Royal Dutch/Shell's Nigerian subsidiary halt all production in the country. 
 On other commodity markets, cotton futures plunged and precious metals fell. But most grain and livestock futures rose, helping to push up the Commodity Research Bureau's index 1.45 points, to 233.65.
Nigerian tensions have roiled crude oil prices since the country's two oil labor unions went on strike on July 4. The turmoil escalated into chaos yesterday after the police killed a top human rights official and protesters emptied a prison amid rioting in Lagos, the capital and largest city, and surrounding towns.
 
Oil Rises by 53 Cents
 Shell said the strike would probably reduce by one-third its Nigerian crude output of 900,000 to one million barrels a day -- about half the country's production of 1.95 million barrels a day. It did not respond to the strikers' insistence that it shut down operations.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for September delivery rose 53 cents, to $20.30 a barrel.
Other energy contracts also surged, with September heating oil gaining 1.78 cents, to 53.25 cents a gallon, and September unleaded gasoline rising 1.55 cents, to 58.71 cents a gallon.
The Nigerian situation also contributed to a sharp rise in cocoa futures on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, where September cocoa beans rose $45, to $1,490 a ton.
Nigeria is the world's fifth-largest cocoa producer but harvesting will not begin there for about two months, said Arthur Stevenson, an analyst at Prudential Securities Inc.
"Only if the current unrest were to persist into the harvest period would it become a serious factor," he said.
Of greater concern, Mr. Stevenson said, is the Brazilian secondary cocoa crop, currently being harvested, which could be the smallest in 20 years.
Elsewhere, October cotton plummeted 1.5 cents, to 71.60 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange after the International Cotton Advisory Committee raised its estimate for 1994-95 world production to 18.77 million metric tons from 18.26 million.
And gold and silver weakened in reaction to a report that the gross domestic product grew at a 3.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, which was slower than traders expected. The news eased inflation anxieties. August gold fell $1.80, to $383 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while September silver fell 2 cents, to $5.332 an ounce.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
XEROX CORP. (XRX,N)

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits jumped 50 percent, in part because of rising productivity and higher equipment sales.
Xerox, the giant copier maker based in Stamford, Conn., earned $168 million, or $1.31 a share, in the three months that ended on June 30, compared with $112 million, or 96 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues rose 4 percent, to $3.58 billion from $3.43 billion. 
 The gains were driven in part by an increase of 11 percent in equipment sales. In addition, the results from the comparable period of 1993 reflected a revamping of the company's 3,500-member American sales force and the weak European economy, the chairman of Xerox, Paul A. Allaire, said.
Xerox cut about 1,400 jobs from its core document processing business in the second quarter, part of a revamping announced in December that eliminated 5,600 positions, or 6 percent of the work force, in the first half of the year.
For the first six months of the year, net income fell to $297 million, or $2.36 a share, from $301 million, or $2.73 a share, in the first half of 1993. Six-month revenues rose 3 percent, to $6.86 billion from $6.66 billion.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Bright Skies in Mexico Bode Well for A.D.R.'s

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
IT'S getting sunny in Mexico again, and one way investors can bask in the warmth without heading south is through American depository receipts.
 But they should know that the storm clouds have just parted. In Mexico earlier this year, "everything that could go wrong did go wrong," said Maria-Elena Carrion, a vice president at Bankers Trust. Kidnappings, the Chiapas rebellion, a political assassination and nail-biting over the Aug. 21 presidential election brought the Mexican market, the Bolsa, 20 percent off its all-time high of 2,895, reached Feb. 9.
 
 Lately, everything is going right. Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, candidate of the governing party, has emerged as the probable next president; investors like the relative certainty and his pro-growth platform, too. Interest rates may be peaking. And second-quarter earnings were not as bad as expected, said Gene Frieda of NatWest Securities.
 The Bolsa responded with a 7 percent rise last week, to 2,462. And many, at least on Wall Street, predict new highs. "We expect it to go to 3,100" by June, Mr. Frieda said.
 To join in, investors can try international mutual funds, but diversification, currency hedges and fees dampen fund returns. No fund can match the run-up of a single hot stock; Cemex, a Mexican cement company, grew nearly 300 percent from July 1991 to December 1993.
 Because the direct purchase of foreign stocks is impractical, the risk-tolerant investor may seek A.D.R.'s -- foreign stock certificates that trade here like domestic equities. The number of Mexican A.D.R.'s -- nearly 50 companies, big and small, listed and unlisted -- adds to the appeal.
 Which A.D.R.'s carry the most promise? Growth-related ones.
 For Mr. Frieda, that means construction, an industry sorely needed in emerging nations. He favors Bufete Industrial, Mexico's fourth-largest builder. Bufete dominates energy construction and "is diversifying well, building factories in Mexico and hotels in Uruguay," he said.
 Jay Pelosky, director of Latin American research at Morgan Stanley, likes Grupo Tribasa, another big builder. And Ms. Carrion -- noting the nation's shortage of hotels and housing -- likes Cemex, which has 63 percent of the Mexican market and has acquired cement operations in Spain, Venezuela and the United States.
 Growth is good for banks, too, and high interest rates have pushed their prices down to attractive buying levels. Mr. Pelosky likes Grupo Financiero Serfin, which closed yesterday at $17.375 -- 51 percent off its 1994 high.
 No economy can grow without phones, and Telefonos de Mexico, with both listed and unlisted A.D.R.'s, is a favorite despite the looming loss of its monopoly in 1997. "Lots of the potential competitors are in long distance," said William F. Truscott, co-manager of the Scudder Latin America Fund. "Telmex should still do very well in local phone business." Cautious investors use Telmex, which constitutes 26 percent of the Bolsa and often tracks it, as an index play.
 Growth also means rising consumer demand. In soft drinks, for example, "we expect 4 percent growth annually for 14- to 45-year-olds," Mr. Frieda said. His pick is the Pepsi bottler, known as Grupo Embotellador de Mexico, or Gemex. While Coca-Cola Femsa has 56 percent of the market to Gemex's 23 percent, "we like the Pepsi story better," he said. Gemex "just opened a $50 million plant in the Yucatan tourist area, and it refines its own sugar -- one of soft drinks' biggest costs."
 A growing Mexico will need stores, too. "There are 500 square feet of selling area per 1,000 inhabitants of Mexico, compared to 19,000 square feet per 1,000 inhabitants in the U.S.," said Alberto Montagne, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. After accounting for income differences, Mexico would need 3,000 square feet for 1,000 people to be comparable.
 Mr. Montagne has buy recommendations on two companies vying to fill the gap. In a joint venture with Wal-Mart, Grupo Cifra, Mexico's largest retailer, will spend $900 million on new outlets by 1996. And the third largest, Controladora Comercial Mexicana, plans to add 73 sites to its existing 156 stores. Like Cifra, Controladora has an American ally -- the Price Company, owner of Price Club discount centers.
 Advisers have many other A.D.R. picks. Mr. Pelosky likes Grupo Industrial Maseca, a major tortilla maker with listed and unlisted A.D.R.'s. Ms. Carrion favors Desc Sociedad de Fomento Industrial, a conglomerate in auto parts and agribusiness, and Grupo Industrial Durango, a maker of fiberboard and corrugated boxes.
 But Wall Street is not completely sunny about Mexico. Surprise election results or credible claims of vote tampering could darken the market, it says. And advisers warn that their bullishness applies to the long run. For in emerging markets like Mexico, the short-term forecast is always iffy, even if it is sunny today.

HEADLINE: Americans Buying More On Credit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Americans are piling on the debt, with monthly totals for car loans, credit cards and other installment loans growing at a ferocious pace in recent months.
 The increase, in part a result of pent-up consumer demand, casts some doubt on the widely held notion that consumers emerged from the last recession financially savvier and less willing to take on high-cost debt.
 
 "Apparently, everyone is charging away like crazy," said Ruth Susswein, executive director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group based in Salem, Va. "I think it is definitely a cause for concern."
 Not everyone expresses alarm, but the numbers are striking. Consumer installment debt, which includes credit cards and auto loans but excludes home loans, grew more than $10 billion each month in March, April and May, ending the period at $838 billion, according to the Federal Reserve. The heady growth, at an 18.7 percent annualized rate, harks back to the conspicuous consumption heyday of the mid-1980's.
 During the recession, officially dated from July 1990 to March 1991, such debt contracted slightly, producing the first sustained decline since the Depression. As consumers paid down and consolidated debt, financial advisers saw signs that educational efforts were paying off. Consumers appeared less willing to skate on the financial edge, wary of what could happen in tough times.
 The new credit boom appears to be fueled not by distress borrowing from consumers who have exhausted all other options, but primarily by discretionary borrowing. People have grown more comfortable with the idea of shouldering additional debt and in some cases more willing to run up purchases on credit in return for frequent-flier miles and other credit card perks.
 "Consumers feel the economy's doing much better," said Gary R. Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons, a brokerage firm based in St. Louis. "There's been a lot of pent-up demand," he added, noting that American households reaped a bonanza last year from refinancing mortgages that gave them cash for down payments on big-ticket items like cars and appliances.
 Likewise, Thomas A. Layman, research vice president for Visa USA, sees no credit binge, merely the usual rebound that occurs when business expansions take hold. Visa card charges in this country leaped 22 percent, to $240 billion, in the 12 months ended in March, he said.
 But it doesn't come as any surprise to Louise Shaler that Americans are taking on prodigious amounts of debt. "My salary is no longer keeping pace with the cost of living," lamented Ms. Shaler, a baby boomer who designs continuing education courses at Pennsylvania State University. "And when you have a cash flow problem, the credit card is the only option."
 Ms. Shaler carries several thousand dollars in debt on five Visa and other credit cards, which she periodically replaces with similar ones promoting lower interest rates. Among people who maintain a balance on their bank cards, the average amount is $1,700, up from about $400 10 years ago, said Robert McKinley, president of RAM Research in Frederick, Md.
 Credit cards are the largest portion of the mounting debt burden, and generally the highest-cost debt. At the end of May, the latest period for which Federal Reserve figures are available, revolving credit on bank cards and store accounts represented 37 percent of installment debt and automobile loans 36 percent, with the rest split among education, mobile home, vacation, boat and other loans scheduled for two or more payments.
 Many bankers are disinclined to fret about the mounting debt, suggesting that consumers have become not only more proficient managers of their finances, but also good judges of prospects for jobs and incomes.
 Richard Aspinwall, a senior vice president at Chase Manhattan, attributed the credit surge to job growth, the benefits of mortgage refinancing and improved confidence. "The distress argument lacks underpinning," he said, implying that people like Ms. Shaler, though vociferous in bemoaning hard times, are in the minority.
 Among the positive indicators, installment debt as a proportion of disposable personal income peaked at about 18.5 percent in mid-1989, eased to less than 16 percent in late 1992 and remains under 17 percent. Moreover, lenders report that charge-offs of debt that cannot be collected and late payments by consumers have fallen significantly this year.
 And more people are watching their credit card balances. Mr. McKinley of RAM Research said 32 percent of bank card holders paid their bills in full each month, up from 29 percent two years ago. He suggests the trend will continue through the 1990's, although the portion will probably remain far shy of the 55 percent recorded 10 years ago when annual interest charges exceeded 20 percent.
 Interest rates, however, are ticking up for card holders. About 70 percent of bank cards now have variable interest rates, with adjustments generally made quarterly. That means July statements also herald significant rate increases for many card holders. The average interest rate on a bank card is now 17.66 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor of North Palm Beach, Fla.
 Ultimately, the shift toward higher interest rates could curb credit card purchases, but Ms. Susswein of the bank card holders group does not expect consumers to modify their behavior unless rates truly soar. "The danger with credit card debt is the increases are incremental," Ms. Susswein said. "You don't feel the pain until the damage is done."
 She and many others find it unsettling that so many American families live right up to and beyond their means, only a job loss or illness away from financial disaster. "A dangerously consumerist attitude is still part of our culture," said David F. Seiders, economist at the National Association of Home Builders. "I can see it in my own kids. Nobody seems to have any concept about saving."
 As financial advisers routinely point out, the best return on an investment is often paying off credit card and other high-rate debt. On a bank card at the current average rate, paying the bill in full results in an effective annual return of 17.66 percent. Not many investments have come close in the choppy financial waters of this year.
 Another strategy popular with rate-sensitive consumers like Ms. Shaler is to churn cards, shifting balances to cards that have low initial rates for six months or a year. Mr. McKinley noted that inquiries to RAM Research and its Card Track unit have risen recently as consumers search for lower-rate cards.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Rates and Bond Funds
 
Q. How will a change in interest rates affect the dividend amount of my municipal bond fund?
ROBERT KANDEL, Little Ferry, N.J.
 
A. There is no immediate relationship between interest rate changes and the dividend paid by a municipal bond fund. That's because such a fund is composed of individual bonds that have their own fixed interest rate. The total of these individual interest payments is the dividend paid by the fund, which is generally stable even during shifting markets. Of course, when interest rates rise, the net asset value of the fund falls.
 
 "A municipal bond fund's dividend will change as the composition and the fixed interest rates of the portfolio change over time," said Tom Spalding, a portfolio manager at John Nuveen & Company. "As a result, turnover in bond portfolios will tend to lead to dividends that reflect broad market trends, though dividend changes lag market changes."
 
Zeroes and I.R.A.'s
 
Q. In an individual retirement account of only Treasury strips maturing 1997 through 2001, how do I determine the total money in the account in December 1996? Can the accrued interest of the strips be figured at that time and is it essential to know?
ARTHUR MESIBOV, Brooklyn
 
A. United States Treasury strips are zero coupon bonds, whereby interest is not paid periodically, but accrued until maturity. Most brokerage firms give the current market value of these strips in their monthly statements, and some newspapers also publish their value.
 "It is not necessary to know the amount of interest separate and apart from the total value of the strip, since the I.R.A. is not taxed on any gains," said Edward Mendlowitz, a partner in the accounting firm of Mendlowitz Weitsen in New York and East Brunswick, N.J. "The participant is taxed based on the full value of the distribution at the time of the payment from the I.R.A."
 
Financial Planners
 
Q. Are all financial planners accredited by a single governing body?
J.T. PHILLIPS, Manhattan
 
A. Financial planners are not regulated by either the Federal or state governments, meaning anyone can use the title of financial planner. Many of them are registered investment advisers with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but because of infrequent inspections, there is little supervision of their activities.
 Some colleges offer degrees in financial planning. And a number of professional organizations grant designations to those who have met specified educational and experience requirements.
 The five leading financial planning organizations, the designation used by their members and their toll-free numbers for information are: the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, personal financial specialist, (800) 862-4272; the American Society of CLU and ChFC, chartered financial consultant, (800) 392-6900; the Institute of Certified Financial Planners, certified financial planner, (800) 282-7526; the International Association for Financial Planning, (800) 945-4237; and the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, (800) 366-2732.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Labor Negotiations: Ball's in Whose Court?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
On the day major league baseball players set Aug. 12 as their strike date, Richard Ravitch put the ball in Donald Fehr's court. But yesterday, Fehr deflated the ball. A salary cap by any other name, he said, is still a salary cap.
Fehr, the players' labor leader, was responding to Ravitch's repeated request to the players that they respond to the owners' desire to know "what it will cost us to play baseball." 
 A salary cap is the owners' way of making that determination, but Ravitch, their chief labor spokesman, has said he would listen to any idea the players might have, and after the players set their strike date on Thursday, he said, "I consider the ball to be in Don's court."
Asked yesterday if the players would respond in the manner Ravitch has requested, Fehr said: "It's like saying, 'We don't need a salary cap, but if you can come up with an absolute restriction on salaries by any other name, we'll talk about it.' So this business of the ball being in our court gets ridiculous."
 
Meetings Next Week
 The two sides tentatively plan to resume their negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement next Tuesday, then meet again Wednesday and Thursday.
With the owners and the players on opposite sides philosophically and economically, what might they talk about at the next bargaining session?
"Hopefully, people will continue to work and re-examine what's there, keep trying to search for avenues," Fehr said. "Sometimes you go through what you said before. You keep plowing on. We'll probably discuss why owners are still reluctant to come to meetings because Dick says he has no objections."
The absence of owners from negotiating meetings has angered players, a group of whom always attends sessions, depending on when and where they're held.
"We keep raising it," Fehr said. "Players are absolutely mystified and teed off. They want to know why people won't talk to them and treat them as equals at the bargaining table. That's meaningful in terms of demonstrating the kind of good faith players want to see. One conclusion players draw from their refusal to attend is they don't care enough to show up."
 
Players in Attendance
 A contingent of players from the Boston Red Sox attended Wednesday's meeting, and Mike Greenwell was especially interested in the owners' absence, pressing Ravitch for an answer.
"When are the owners going to come?" Greenwell asked repeatedly.
Finally, Fehr said that Ravitch replied: "It's not me. I have no personal objection to their coming." But the owners obviously have made the decision to leave the negotiating to their negotiator.
"In multi-employer negotiations," Ravitch said yesterday, "people pick a negotiator. The board of directors of General Electric does not participate in negotiations. They designate someone to negotiate for them. That's what the owners have done here."
 
Owners Have Been There Before
 Owners have attended bargaining sessions in previous negotiations. In 1990, for example, Fred Wilpon of the Mets, John McMullen of Houston, Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox and Carl Pohlad of Minnesota sat at the table at various times.
If the owners came to the table, Fehr said: "There would be a much more real dialogue. We don't have any decision makers there or anyone involved in operations. Let's say a club has lost money and is one for whom relief is being sought. Maybe we could discuss what has occasioned that. Does it have to do with league structure? What are the facts of relocation? You could have a lot of discussions you otherwise couldn't have."
 
Fehr Has the Access
 Ravitch said Fehr does not need owners to come to the table to talk to them.
"Don tries to communicate with owners all the time and he succeeds," Ravitch said. "It's not like he doesn't have access to them. He meets with them. I know of quite a few owners he has met with over the last year. Some have called and asked me if there's anything wrong with meeting with him and I say no."
Players, though, have not attended those meetings.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Redefining The Yankees' Community

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
THE walk to Yankee Stadium took about 10 minutes: Down the 155th Street viaduct, over the blue Macombs Dam Bridge, over the Major Deegan Expressway, down and around the street leading to the employees' parking lot.
 This was yesterday morning and I was on the way to an impromptu meeting with Brian Smith, the Yankees' new director of community relations.
 
 Twelve days ago, it's doubtful that many people in the Bronx knew that the Yankees even had a community relations department. Then Richard Kraft, the department's former director, was quoted as speaking of "monkeys" hanging on basketball rims in the park adjacent to Yankee Stadium, and of "colored boys" losing their roots.
 Kraft resigned under pressure last Saturday -- although he denied making those statements -- and the job was rightfully given to Smith, his energetic assistant.
 I put in a call to the Yankees on Thursday hoping to set up an interview with Smith, who turned 25 on June 19. I wanted to find out what plans he had for reaching out, connecting with the community. But the team's media relations director said that the new community relations director would not be communicating at this time.
 They're protecting him. The man explained, "We don't want to throw him into the fire."
 Sorry. He's already in the fire.
 I arrived at the Stadium around 8 o'clock and sat in the outside bleachers, in back of the handball court next to the employees' entrance.
 What troubled me, more than anything Kraft said, was the reaction from various circles to Smith's being named to replace him. There were a number of comments to the effect that it was an "affirmative action" move, intended to appease black and Hispanic fans. A Steinbrenner ploy to blunt deep-rooted, long-standing anger directed at the Yankees for demonizing the community in order to extort favors from the city.
 Certainly the fact that Smith is African American wasn't lost on Steinbrenner, but neither were his credentials for the job.
 Smith was raised in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and played football at Mount Vernon High School. He earned a scholarship to the University of Tulsa where he played linebacker for four years and as a senior was a member of the 1991 team that defeated San Diego State in the Freedom Bowl.
 Smith earned his undergraduate degree in four years and received his master's in sports management in 1992. When he returned to New York, Smith taught math and economics in a development program in the Bronx. Last April he took a gamble: he quit the teaching job and accepted an internship with the Yankees. In two months, the Yankees hired him full time for their marketing and public relations department. Last October, they promoted him to assistant community relations director. On Saturday he replaced Kraft.
 Dave Rader, Tulsa's head football coach, isn't surprised by Smith's accomplishments. "He will get the job done," Rader said. "As a coach, Brian's the type of guy you want to point to. The focus is always on the kids who drop out, flunk out or don't make it. A kid like Brian is the essence of college football. He leaves Mount Vernon, comes to private school in Tulsa, Okla., doesn't really play a whole lot, gets his undergraduate degree in four years, stayed and got his graduate degree. Went home, beat the bushes, found a job, making the most of it.
 "All I can tell people who don't know him is to stand back and watch him go," Rader said. "We need to hear more about the Brian Smiths."
 We will. But not now.
 Smith arrived at the stadium at 9:15. Neat, clean-cut. Surprised. He didn't expect his day to begin with me. He politely declined my request for a formal interview. "I just want to get started, get organized, get things going," he said. Maybe down the road, when things get settled, we would talk.
 Smith looked at his watch and said, "I don't mean to brief with you, but I have to go." He disappeared into the employees' entrance.
 Brian Smith doesn't have an easy task. He must convince a community that someone at Yankee Stadium truly cares at a time when many are convinced that no one does.
 Smith has the personality and energy to pull it off. Whether he'll have the support and sincere backing of Steinbrenner -- beyond this highly publicized juncture -- is a different matter.
 By promoting Smith, the Yankees took a step toward making their community relations department more than a whistle stop on the ol' boys network. The next step is letting him answer his own phone.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Conference Officials Weighing Bowl Bids

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
As conference commissioners began weighing bids yesterday that could bring college football more than $50 million a year from just three bowl games, four Florida State football players were suspended for taking part in an agent-financed shopping spree last year.
The two developments pointed up the economic anomalies of college football, a multibillion-dollar business built upon players barred from receiving more than their scholarships. 
 There seemed to be no limits in Dallas, where nine bowls backed by corporate sponsors and television networks submitted big-money bids for designation as one of the three bowl games the College Football Bowl Alliance hopes will dominate post-season play.
The alliance, organized by eight major conferences plus Notre Dame, plans to anoint three premier bowls, which will virtually be guaranteed annual games involving the six top teams in the nation.
 
A Jan. 2 Championship
 But the Big Ten and Pacific-10 champions will continue to meet in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day under a contract running through the 2000 season.
Under the alliance plan, which is to take effect for the 1995 season, the three designated bowls will rotate holding a putative national championship game on Jan. 2 each year. After the Jan. 2 bowl makes the first two selections, the Jan. 1 bowl would have the third and fifth picks and the Dec. 31 bowl the fourth and sixth.
A day after the nine bowls made their presentations, Gene Corrigan, the Atlantic Coast Conference commissioner who serves as the alliance chairman, said yesterday that the commissioners would consult with member schools before coming to a decision, perhaps late next week.
As the Dallas participants were making their multimillion-dollar moves, Talbot D'Alemberte, the president of Florida State, announced that Derrick Brooks, an all-America linebacker, and tailback Tiger McMillon had been suspended for the first two games of the season for their part in a sporting goods shopping spree financed by sports agents last year. Offensive guard Patrick McNeil was suspended for three games and offensive tackle Forrest Conoly was suspended indefinitely.
 
Violating the Rules
 "These players knew that they violated the rules and they must suffer the consequences of their actions," D'Alemberte said.
But D'Alemberte also suggested that the rules might be excessive. On Thursday he told a House committee that college players should be allowed to receive more than their scholarships, a proposal that offended some high-paid coaches.
"Players are well-paid now, when you consider the value of a college education," said Bill Curry, the Kentucky football coach.
Indeed, like National Football League players, big-time college players are paid to play football, but unlike their N.F.L. counterparts, most of whom earn more than their coaches, even the best college players are limited to scholarships valued at between $10,000 to $25,000 a year.
"There's a lot of money being made off us," said Jack Jackson, a Florida receiver. "There's a lot of people being paid megadollars to run this sport. But they don't see fit for the players to be compensated."
