SECTION: Section 2; Page 3; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2177 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Blacklist: Memories of a Word That Marks an Era

 BODY:
AGAINST THE BACKDROP OF THE cold war in the 1940's and 50's and increasing anti-Communist sentiment in the United States, the House Un-American Activities Committee, set up in 1945 as a standing committee, carried on Government investigations of Americans suspected of being Communists or of having sympathy with the Soviet Union. The entertainment industry, especially in Hollywood, and unions were major targets of hearings that began in 1947.
Ultimately, 10 blacklisted screenwriters, directors and producers were imprisoned for their refusal to answer questions from the committee. Along with this group, known as the Hollywood 10, several hundred others in the movie industry lost their jobs for actual or suspected Communist affiliation. While television and radio also felt the committee's influence, the New York theater world seemed to be affected least. 
 A current exhibit about the period that focuses on theater, television, radio, concerts and nightclubs -- "The House I Live In: American Performance in the Era of Blacklisting" -- is on view through Aug. 27 at the Vincent Astor Gallery at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.
As part of the exhibit, five people whose lives were forever changed by the hearings and the blacklist, talked about their experiences at a symposium at the library, moderated by its executive director, Robert Marx. The participants in "Remembering the Blacklist" were the author and screenwriter Ring Lardner Jr.; Frances Chaney, an actress who is married to Mr. Lardner; Merle Debuskey, a theatrical publicist; Madeline Lee Gilford, an actress and the widow of the actor Jack Gilford, and the actress Kim Hunter. Here are adapted excerpts from the symposium.
 
RING LARDNER JR.: In 1947, 19 of us were subpoenaed to appear before the committee. We discussed among ourselves the various alternatives we had and determined that the choices were not very good. If you were not a Communist, you could say no to that question but you would be acknowledging the committee's right to ask the question. If you were a Communist and said yes, the next question was all about who else was, and asking you to name names where you had even less constitutional protection than about yourself.
We went to Washington. We appeared before the committee, which included a new Congressman, Richard Nixon, and the chairman of the committee, J. Parnell Thomas, Republican of New Jersey, with whom I later became reacquainted when I went to the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., where he was already an inmate, having meanwhile been convicted of misappropriating Government funds. Ten of the 19 of us did appear before the committee. We did take the attitude that they had no right to ask these questions. We were all cited for contempt. We did lose the case in the courts and were convicted.
A month after the hearings, the heads of the motion picture companies met in New York and decided that they would fire any of us who were working -- five of us were at the time -- and not hire any of us until we cleared ourselves. And so we became the first blacklisted people of several hundred more in Hollywood and in New York in radio and television.
 
FRANCES CHANEY: At a very young age I was marching in a May Day parade. And that's when my career as a leftist began. After that came the Spanish Civil War. All of the young people I knew were terribly involved in what had happened in Spain. And then before we knew it, Jews were being incarcerated in Germany and we began hearing all about that.
Many of us had our leftist leanings strengthened by the events in the world. They were already fairly strong because before all this we had gone through a very terrible Depression in our country. So young people in those days marched under banners that said "Black and white, unite and fight" and "We want scholarships, not battleships." The world was very clear: you were either bad or good. You were either pro-working-class or you were against them. And we understood that.
In 1946 I married Ring Lardner Jr. and he was blacklisted. And everybody assumed poor Frances, she never would have been blacklisted if it hadn't been that she married Ring. Not true.
When Ring and I came to New York in 1954, I was determined that I could work. I kept saying: Blacklist or no blacklist, I'm going to get a job and, by God, I did. I got a lead on the Philco Playhouse in 1954. And then Paddy Chayefsky, who had written that script, wrote another script with me in mind. And I was called to please come in and talk salary. And then the phone calls started. And somehow or other this whole thing dissolved. And it dissolved with a program called "Marty." And that was 1954 or maybe 1955 by then. And I didn't have a nighttime television show again until 1963.
 
MADELINE LEE GILFORD: I not only had a dossier from the time I was around 14, but my parents were very active socialists and pacifists and my father was a terrific union member. They were immigrants and very proud of the union tradition. From the time I was a child actress I was involved in Equity and then the American Federation of Radio Artists, which preceded the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA). It was a very exciting time. You were proud of being invited to participate in benefits, concerts, plays with ideals about bettering things for the greater good. Here was a profession in which you were supposed to be egocentric and self-seeking and instead they were people of good will who banded together.
As we got blacklisted, we laughed at it. We thought it was ridiculous. New York, unlike Hollywood, was not a company town, so it was almost never implemented in theater because the people who were in theater -- Kermit Bloomgarden, Arthur Miller, Herman Shumlin and Lillian Hellman -- they were almost as blacklisted as we were, certainly in Hollywood.
 
MERLE DEBUSKEY: Unlike the others here, I don't know if I was blacklisted. I also don't know if I was not blacklisted. But what I do know is I should have been blacklisted.
Wondering how come nothing bad happened to me, I went to get my records under the Freedom of Information Act. And this is one of quite a number of sheets that came back [see photograph on page 3]. And this is under the Freedom of Information Act. So I had my lawyer appeal and asked again. And we got back a rejection based on the fact that this information was in the interest of national defense.
There was absolutely nothing that came out of this except exploitation. No plot was unfolded. It was a hollow drum that was being beat, and beat loudly, which gave rise to headlines. Nothing happened. The whole thing was a hoax. And the First Amendment, which had been in existence since the creation of this Government and was one of the great documents in the history of man, was diminished. And the right of people to have their political convictions and not have to reveal them if they didn't wish to do so was destroyed.
There are reasons why the theater was not subject to the rigors of the blacklist as was television and radio and Hollywood. It was never an industry as one would imagine Hollywood as being an industry. The theater always was made up of some of the strangest bedfellows you can imagine. In one year I represented Mike Todd, Cheryl Crawford and Arthur Laurents, I think it was. If you put them in one room and told them to agree on anything, you were wasting your time. Except they had one thing in common: all of them were not going to let anyone tell them what to do. That's what the greater part of Broadway was. They were not subject to an industry fear of anything, except the Times review. So it was really difficult to come down on them in a fashion that would inhibit them and their choices.
I represented many shows that did have people in them who were blacklisted. I think that the theater was probably the last refuge for people who could no longer work in film or television or radio.
 
KIM HUNTER: What started it for me was that when I was in "A Streetcar Named Desire" in 1949 I got a thing in the mail, at the Barrymore Theater, asking me if I would become one of the sponsors of a world peace conference at the Waldorf Hotel sponsored by the National Council for the Arts, Sciences and Professions. They were bringing people from all over the world -- in 1949, the cold-war era, it wasn't easy -- to come and share opinions and see if we couldn't figure out a way to somehow clear up this cold-war problem. I agreed to do it. I thought it was a good idea. But I learned later that they noticed that and said uh-oh, watch out for that one.
Gradually it became sort of clear. I think CBS was first. I was on the blacklist at CBS. No more CBS television. Then I think ABC dropped out and then finally it was NBC, and then by the time I won my Oscar for the movie of "Streetcar" I could not work in films. The last film I made was in 1951.
I was curious about it, wondering: Am I making this up? Is it happening to me? And why should it? I went to Bill Dozier, who was one of the executive producers at CBS, and said, "Am I dreaming it? Can you hire me here at CBS?" And he said, "No, Kim, we cannot." And I said, "Is there anything you can do about it?" And he said, "No, I'm sorry, my hands are absolutely tied."
I went to AFTRA and they said talk to the F.B.I. So I called the F.B.I. and they came to my apartment and said: "You have no problem as far as we're concerned with your Government, with the country. You're not anti-American. But we think you have a problem with your union." What that really meant was the unions not fighting the pressure on the sponsors.
 
MADELINE LEE GILFORD: You have no idea of the impact on personal lives, on families. Divorces, suicides, illnesses, heart attacks. That impact, because people were not working, was the price we paid. And there was a lot of anti-Semitism underlying a great deal of this blacklist.
The F.B.I. followed me the first Tuesday of every month; this was the 1950's. How did I know it? The superintendent had a son in jail for armed robbery and she hated the F.B.I. So she considered us in trouble the same way she was. She would tell us that they would come on the first Tuesday: "They've been here. They wanted to look in your garbage. They wanted to look at the mail that has been thrown out."
I had to walk my daughter to school because Jack would be working somewhere in the theater and he would be sleeping in the morning. One of these cold windy days in January, the two F.B.I. guys were in their thin raincoats and their hats. So I said, "O.K., I'm going to give them a run for their money."
I had gained 45 pounds with my last pregnancy and had gotten a huge blue fuzzy coat in a thrift shop that made me look like a giant navy blue bear. It was early January -- Sam Gilford was born Jan. 17 -- and it was terribly cold. I couldn't tie my shoelaces, so I don't know how they thought I was going to overthrow the Government. Anyway, they went to school with me and then I decided to swing around Washington Square Park.
It was Alger Hiss's first day in Washington Square Park, with his son, Tony. He had just gotten out of jail. I didn't know him, but I knew what he looked like, so I said, "Oh, I think I'll give the F.B.I. something to write about."
And I went up to him -- they couldn't hear what I was saying -- and I said: "Mr. Hiss, I'm Madeline Lee Gilford. I'm Jack Gilford's wife." Oh, yes, he knew him. And he was tall and thin and handsome in the cold. And I wanted to chat with him long enough so that they would think that I had a date to meet him in the park away from phone taps. And I said, "I want to welcome you back to the Village, and may I kiss you?" So I kissed Alger Hiss in Washington Square Park. And I sent for my file under the Freedom of Information Act but so much of it is blacked out I don't even know.
 
RING LARDNER JR.: I don't think there is any danger of the kind of blacklist that existed then on political grounds. But there certainly is a great threat of censorship today. The people behind it are basically the fundamentalists, the Christian right, and I think the First Amendment is being threatened in a great many ways from this censorship effort. The same sort of struggle may emerge.
 
MERLE DEBUSKEY: I have no conviction whatsoever that it won't happen the day after tomorrow. Things happen and they happen very quickly. I'm still in shock about how the most recent ex-President to be buried was buried with full honors. I don't know how long ago or how long after the blacklist Nixon was still around with his hit list. There was an enemies list. Which is no different than a blacklist.
I have no conviction that something analogous couldn't occur once again because the root of it is that if you challenge the economic security of the Hollywood studios or the networks, they will turn in a second. So it's important that we have assemblages like this.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Janet Piorko

 BODY:

Fall Events in Mexico
Q. I am planning a fall trip to Mexico's colonial cities of Guanajuato, Queretaro, San Miguel de Allende and San Luis Potosi. Can you tell me of any interesting events during October or November? -- Louise Lander, New York, N.Y. 
 A. Your timing seems to be good; several events are taking place then.
In Guanajuato, the 22d annual International Cervantino Festival will take place Oct. 5 to 23 and will feature art exhibits, dances, concerts and films. This year's performers include the Kiev Ballet and the Montreal Symphony Orchestra.
Organizers are expecting over 1,400 performers and artists from 33 different countries to participate, and urge anyone interested in attending to make hotel reservations and buy tickets as far ahead as possible. Tickets range from about $3 to $27, figured at a rate of 3.3 pesos to the United States dollar. For more information write to: The International Cervantino Festival, 273 Alvaro Obregon, Cuarto Piso, Colonia Roma, 06700, Mexico D.F.; telephone 533-4121 in Mexico City or 209-59 in Guanajuato. (The country code for dialing Mexico is 52; the local code for Mexico City is 5, for Guanajuato 473.) Closer to the festival date tickets may be bought through TicketMaster in Mexico City; telephone 325-9000.
A festival celebrating the patron saint of San Miguel de Allende will be held there in late September and early October. St. Michael's Day is Sept. 29 this year; festivities will run into the weekend of Oct. 1 and 2, centered around the plaza and the cathedral, and will include bullfights, fireworks, religious processions and dances. No tickets are needed, but hotel reservations are recommended.
On Nov. 1 and 2, all of Mexico celebrates the Day of the Dead by erecting shrines and visiting cemeteries. Nov. 20 is Revolution Day in Mexico; there are parades of students and athletes in many larger cities (including San Luis Potosi) to celebrate the Mexican Revolution.
 
Cultural Tours of Greece
Q. I am interested in joining an educational tour group planning a trip to Greece next spring. Can you provide information about such groups? A tour geared to older travelers would be fine. -- Mrs. David M. Goldring, Red Bank, N.J.
A. There are abundant educational tours of Greece. Here are a few that are planned for next spring:
Classical Cruises, which arranges voyages with sponsoring educational institutions, has an Undiscovered Greek Islands cruise, co-sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution, April 30 to May 13, starting at $6,845 a person, based on double occupancy, on the all-suite Queen Odyssey (the former Royal Viking Queen). The itinerary includes Athens, Nauplia, Seriphos, Siphnos, Naxos, Amorgos, Astypalaia, Leros, Patmos, Chios, Skopelos, Thasos and Samothrace. The guest lecturer has not yet been confirmed.
Classical Cruises, 132 East 70th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; (212) 794-3200 or (800) 252-7745.
Elderhostel, a nonprofit educational organization based in Boston, runs programs for travelers 60 and older combining classwork with field trips; there are about 20 trips to Greece departing from March to May. Accommodations are generally in modest local hotels with private baths.
Elderhostel's 18-night Ancient World of Greece program, in cooperation with the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, visits major sites in the capital, Eleusis, Corinth, the island of Aegina, Nauplia, Mycenae, Epidaurus and Crete. The price of $3,080 a person, double occupancy, includes air fare from New York, room and board. There are several departure dates, including April 7.
Some Elderhostel programs combine land tours with study cruises on topics such as Aegean Civilization and the Greek Island Society. The cruises are on air-conditioned motor-powered sailboats averaging 116 feet in length. The double-occupancy cabins have private baths.
For example, a package combining a week's study tour focusing on Greek Philosophy, based at the Hellenic American Union in Athens, with a week's Aegean Civilization cruise, departs April 6 and costs $3,501.
Elderhostel is at 75 Federal Street, Boston, Mass. 02110; (617) 426-7788. Mail queries are preferred; specify international or domestic catalog.
Interhostel, a travel-study program for adults over 50 sponsored by the University of New Hampshire Division of Continuing Education, is planning to repeat this year's Athens and the Greek Islands tour from May 10 to 24, 1995, in cooperation with the American College of Greece, Deree Campus. The 1995 price has not yet been set, but it is expected to be higher than this year's rate of $3,295 a person, which included round-trip flights from New York.
In Athens, the group will stay in dormitories at the American College, about three miles from the city center. Shared bathrooms are on each floor. In addition to sightseeing while based in Athens, the tour also includes a three-day stay on the Aegean islands of Mykonos and Delos. Ancient Greek culture, modern history, economics, philosophy, music and dance will be among the study topics.
Interhostel: University of New Hampshire Division of Continuing Education, 6 Garrison Avenue, Durham, N.H. 03824; (603) 862-1147.
 
Downtown Digs in Manhattan
Q. My son lives in TriBeCa and when I visit I've been unable to find a place to stay in the area. Do you know of a nice hotel or bed-and-breakfast that would be convenient to Chambers Street, preferably within walking distance? -- Judith Hietter, Atherton, Calif.
A. There are several large hotels in the neighborhood that cater to business travelers in the financial district; you may be able to get a good discount on weekends.
Millenium Hilton, 55 Church Street, (212) 693-2001 or (800) 835-2220; fax (212) 571-2316. With 561 rooms, the hotel has a fitness center, 24-hour room service, two restaurants and a bar serving light meals. During the week room rates start at $195 for single rooms, $220 for doubles; on weekends, a rate of $129 for singles or doubles may be available.
New York Marriott Financial Center, 85 West Street, (212) 385-4900 or (800) 242-8685; fax (212) 227-8136. The hotel has 504 rooms, an indoor pool, sauna, exercise room, a restaurant and two lounges. Regular rates are $255 for a single room, $275 for a double; weekend rates start at $119 a night, single or double.
New York Vista, 3 World Trade Center, (212) 938-9100 or (800) 445-8667; fax (212) 938-1948. Closed since the bombing of the World Trade Center in February 1993, which damaged the basement of the hotel, the Vista is scheduled to reopen Nov. 1 after a major renovation that encompasses all public spaces and guest rooms. Operated by Hilton International, the hotel has 820 rooms, two restaurants, an indoor pool and fitness center. An introductory rate of $170 for a single or double will be available through February; there will also be a weekend rate of $139.
 JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Mexico Moves to Limit Projects Along Its Coast

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
AFTER 20 years of favoring big developments like Cancun that gobble up miles of coastline and pave over thousands of acres of sensitive wetlands, the Mexican Government is trying to switch directions and limit what can be built on the beach.
A new accord among federal, state and local governments reached in June will drastically curtail building on the 60 miles of coast from the high-rise hotels and chain restaurants of Cancun down to the 1,000-year-old walled city of Tulum. 
 Until recently, the Cancun-Tulum corridor, with its unspoiled white sand beaches, was probably under more development pressure than any other area on Mexico's long coasts, though to some extent the situation is similar at the tip of Baja California and nearly all Mexican beach resorts. Putting the brakes on development between Cancun and Tulum sent a strong message that Mexico has recognized the tradeoffs that come with commercially successful -- but environmentally disastrous -- projects like Cancun, where the construction of 120 hotels in 20 years has obliterated sand dunes, contaminated a large lagoon and led to the disappearance of large numbers of fish and shellfish just offshore.
"The new law clearly represents the need to control tourism development and avoid the excesses, to reduce the deterioration of the environment and to try to preserve as much as possible the natural resources of the area," said Jesus Silva Herzog, Mexico's Secretary of Tourism. "It's an accord I would consider historic."
Investors might consider it differently. The new law on development comes just as Mexico is trying to attract foreign capital with a new foreign-investment law that liberalizes land purchases on the coast, and the implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which brings the economies of Mexico, Canada and the United States closer. But Mr. Silva Herzog said it was necessary to do something before the very attributes that attract tourists were lost. "Some developers have been planning to build at much higher densities than this ordinance allows and now they're going to have to reduce their densities and probably redesign their projects," he said. "This might make the projects less attractive financially but they'll have greater respect for the environment."
For a long time, Cancun was considered the benchmark of Mexico's modern, computer-guided approach to developing tourism. Before 1973, when officials put data on climate, water temperature and beach conditions into a computer and hit on Cancun as the place to build a huge new tourist mecca, that far-eastern part of Mexico was largely uninhabited and almost totally unknown. In 1970, the population of what was then the territory of Quintana Roo -- it became a state in 1974 -- was only 8,850.
With Government assistance, more than 115 hotels have been built in Cancun, and now there are more than 250,000 permanent residents just in the resort. More than 1.5 million tourists a year visit, making it Mexico's most popular tourist destination.
Perched dramatically on a seaside cliff, Tulum is now the most visited site in the Maya world, receiving more than one million tourists a year. Tour buses from Cancun pass through the corridor, presenting developers an irresistible target. Already, the narrow two-lane highway cuts through areas pockmarked by failed housing developments and a few attractions like Xcaret, a water park with an underground river.
Some critics have long seen Cancun's success as excess and fought against the spread of megadevelopments. Homero Aridjis, head of the Group of 100, one of Mexico's leading conservation organizations, said the corridor is a natural breeding area for marine turtles and other rare species. The organization tried through much of 1993 to convince President Carlos Salinas de Gortari that allowing intense development in the corridor would undo previous laws he had signed to protect the turtles there. "It would turn the coast into a concrete paradise," Mr. Aridjis said, "and turn away precisely those tourists Mexico is trying to attract."
Mr. Salinas signed the agreement limiting development on June 5. Essentially it establishes 45 zones along the Cancun-Tulum corridor, from development areas with densities of from 5 to 25 rooms per acre, less than half of that allowed in Cancun, to a couple of conservation zones inland and right on the beach, especially in the area around Tulum, in which nothing can be built.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Brooklyn Paramount;
Once a Rococo Palace, Now a Citadel of Learning

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
A MODERN axiom is that the movie palace of the 1920's has vanished. But many survive -- as performance halls, as churches, as multiplexes and, at the Long Island University campus in downtown Brooklyn, as a basketball court.
Now, after three decades of ad-hoc alterations to the 4,124-seat Brooklyn Paramount, the university is beginning a $5 million program designed to finally change a palace for fantasy into one for learning. 
 It was in the 20's that the movies finally overwhelmed the older, traditional uses of the theater building, as the growing film conglomerates developed into businesses of national scope. Earlier theaters had often aimed towards an individual elegance, often reflecting the personality of a particular producer or star, but the 20's movie palace was a corporate affair, designed with no less calculation than a Disney project.
Although the interior formula was almost always rococo or Renaissance, the basis of the movie palace was very modern economic engineering, selling the maximum number of tickets to the maximum number of people, and processing them with peak efficiency. Cost per seat, location analysis and orchestra overtime were of far greater concern to architects than the gilt and velvet that the patrons saw.
Paramount Pictures was one of the new conglomerates, formed in 1916 by the rivals Jesse Lasky and Adolph Zukor who, by the 20's, controlled an empire of motion picture production, distribution and exhibition.
Unlike, Loews, its chief rival, Paramount favored building combination theater and office buildings, like the 1926 Paramount Building it built in Times Square.
In 1928 Paramount built a new theater/ office building at the corner of DeKalb Avenue and the Flatbush Avenue Extension, designed by the Chicago theater architects Rapp & Rapp. This was Brooklyn's theater district; A.D. Buttler, a theater photographer and archivist, estimates that, with the new Paramount, there were 25,000 seats within a few blocks.
The exterior of the building is not much, a factory-style facade of buff brick, where the huge signs and marquees once constituted the only real decoration.
THE interior followed most of the conventions of movie palace design: a giant, rectangular "grand foyer" 147 feet long and 42 feet high, leading to the auditorium and also to the many lounge and ancillary spaces that served the huge crowds.
There is mild variation in the styles of the still existing lounge areas -- ranging from Renaissance to Art Deco -- but the auditorium is in a rococo both more ostentatious and effective than usual.
The theater opened Thanksgiving week in 1928, with "Manhattan Cocktail" starring Richard Arlen. At the same time the Brooklyn & Manhattan Rapid Transit Company -- which built the subway line known as the BMT -- was moving into 8 floors of the adjacent 11-story office building.
Perhaps it was bad timing to build just before the Depression, or bad strategy to throw another few thousand seats into a sea of velvet, but in the 1930's the theater closed on at least one occasion, and in 1936 The New York Times reported that the Brooklyn Paramount had lost $1.5 million since its opening.
But it continued operating, later offering stage shows with Little Richard and other rock 'n' roll acts. Long Island University bought the building in 1950 and took over the office space for classes and administration. But the Paramount remained open, and in 1959 announced a modernization plan that included "streamlining" the theater.
This did not go through, and in 1963 Long Island University took over the auditorium for a gym.
In two stages, the projecting balcony and box seats have been cut back, and now the basketball team plays in what is one of the few, if not the only, gilt, rococo-style college athletic facilities in the country.
At the same time the steep, upper balcony was walled in and converted to lecture halls, and the college sprinkled what other uses it could throughout the building. But the wide, long corridors and the huge stairways meant to accommodate a single rush of 4,000 moviegoers represents a considerable loss of usable space.
This summer the university, working from plans by Mitchell/Giurgola Architects, begins a more methodical reworking of the spaces. One of the wide banks of stairs has already been cut out to accommodate a third floor walkway, part of a network the university hopes will unify its broken, urban site.
The surviving lounges downstairs will be spiffed up and the wide hallways ringing the back of the balcony will be converted to student clubrooms. The ticket and entry area at the corner will be converted to a cafeteria. And the grand foyer will become a combination eating-studying area, with quiet-study areas along the sides.
In a later phase, the university will have its name in lights, much plainer this time, with a single sign running eight floors to the top of the 11-story building.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

LIVELY STREETS OF SONO
It has been 18 years since the first SoNo Arts Celebration was held on Washington Street in South Norwalk. Growing annually and spreading to neighboring streets, it attracted more than 80,000 visitors last summer, with more than that expected this weekend. Washington Street will be closed to traffic during that time.
More than 25 performance groups will keep the music, dance and storytelling flowing continuously, free of charge. The festivities begin on Friday at 6:30 with a parade of antique automobiles and music of the silent screen era, starting at the Maritime Center on North Water Street, proceeding up Washington Street to the SoNo Cinema where the Silvermine Guild of Artists Moving Image Society has scheduled a silent film fest at 7 P.M. The guild has also provided a selection of films and videos produced by emerging comedy talents, to be shown on Saturday at 1:30 and on Sunday at 11:45 A.M. and 1 P.M. Free tickets are available today at 29 South Main Street. 
 More than 200 artists will exhibit their work in a sidewalk show stretching across four or five blocks, and SoNo's many art galleries will be open as well. Festival hours on Saturday are 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. and on Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. A dance party will take place under the stars from 8:30 to 11:30 Saturday night with live music from Milo Z and EO, Funk and original pop-rock ensembles.
The Kinetic Sculpture Race, the festival's most popular attraction, will begin at noon on Saturday. Artists who create the weird contraptions must propel them over a one-mile course through South Norwalk Streets by any human-powered means, vying for prizes totaling $1,400.
Children will have their own section for innovative hands-on art projects, entertainment, and a puppet parade at 4 P.M. Saturday. Food will be plentiful and varied, and the soon-to-open New England Brewery and Restaurant on Marshall Street will conduct preview tours and tastings of their brews on Saturday and Sunday at 1, 3, and 5 P.M.
For more information call 866-7916.
 
DISHING UP THE PAST
 A four-day festival featuring foods from America's past will begin on Thursday at Mystic Seaport. Each day from 11:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. the costumed staff will dish up 19th-century recipes in various locations on the 17-acre grounds of the riverside maritime village.
For example, a meat and vegetable stew called scouse can be sampled on board ship, where it was once served to the seamen, while a proper afternoon tea will be available in the parlor of one of the cottages. Blueberry pudding, molasses cream cake, corn soup, fish chowder, smoked ham, bread and freshly made ice cream are among the many other dishes. Visitors may also try the clams, shucked to order and slurped from the half-shell. Foods range in price from $1 to $4, and can be washed down with a variety of beverages including beer and wine.
All the tall ships, shipbuilding workshops, craft shops, village houses and the planetarium will be open, with children's games and outdoor activities on offer. Admission is $15, $7.50 for children over the age of 5. Tickets may be validated for returning the next day in order to see all there is to see. For more information, 572-5315.
 
KENTUCKY FOLK WORKS
 Minnie Adkins, a recent recipient of the Folk Art Society of America's Annual Award of Distinction, makes her living by carving, painting and selling sculptures of animals made from rough-hewn logs supplied by her husband, Garland. Along with the work of a dozen or so other self-taught artists from the Kentucky mountains, her sculptures may be seen in "Kentucky Folk Artists," opening today at the Silo in New Milford, and remaining through Aug. 28.
Primitive acrylic paintings of detailed rural scenes by Janice Harding Owens, and large wood carvings of Uncle Sam and Santa Claus by her husband, Ron, will also be on display. The Owens and their seven children are making their first trip out of Kentucky to attend the opening today from 1 to 3 P.M.
Handmade quilts, walking sticks, textiles, watercolors, oils and a wide variety of wood carvings make up the more than 60 items that will be sold for prices ranging from $100 to $2,000.
The Silo, at 44 Upland Road, is open daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and the phone number for directions or more information is 355-0300.
 
AGGIES' OPEN HOUSE
 Willam W. Ginsberg, Assistant Secretary for Economic Development at the Federal Department of Commerce, will deliver the principal lecture at the annual Plant Science Day in Hamden on Wednesday.
Each year the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station holds an open house, free to the public, during which pertinent issues for Connecticut growers, scientists and backyard gardeners are explored. The session will be held at Lockwood Farm, Kenwood and Evergreen Avenues in the Mount Carmel section, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
A sampling of talks by several experts in various fields, and barn exhibits, includes mosquito-borne viruses in the state, growing healthy pumpkins, understanding dogwood diseases, improving plants by genetic manipulation, reducing tick-bite risk and new crop technologies.
Among the field experiments to be viewed with the guidance of maps are tick and lyme disease, potatoes, compost, rhododendrons, bees, chestnut trees, eggplants, asparagus and many other plants and vegetables.
Shuttle buses are provided for tours of the plots, walking tours will be scheduled, and sandwiches are available for those who do not bring lunch. Coffee, punch and parking are free. Call 789-7272 for more information.
 
OLD LYME FEST
 The 1994 edition of Old Lyme's midsummer festival opens next weekend. Art and music are featured, beginning with a free concert of George Gershwin and Leonard Bernstein music on Friday at 7 P.M. on the lawn of the Florence Griswold Museum.
The museum, designated a National Historic Landmark last fall, was a favorite summer haunt of many American Impressionist painters during the late 19th and early 20th century. Artists are invited to recreate that scene on Saturday by taking their equipment to the site and painting whatever appeals to them.
A walking tour of Lyme Street will step off from Town Hall on Saturday at 10 A.M., and a tour of William Chadwick's studio begins at 2:30. Maritime crafts will be demonstrated on the museum's front lawn by the Connecticut River Museum, including paddle- and sailboat-building, marlinspike seamanship and uses of 19th-century shipbuilding tools.
Nearby, at the Lyme Academy of Fine Arts, the 93d annual Summer Juried Exhibition will be in progress on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Sunday from 10 to 4:30, along with a sale of artwork by alumni and students.
From 1 to 1:45 on Saturday children will be entertained with stories presented by the National Theater of the Deaf, and at 3 P.M., an all-Mozart concert will be performed with an ensemble of pianists, string instrumentalists and vocalists. Tickets are $12. A second concert, of works by Alban Berg, Samuel Barber, Glazounov, Beethoven and Haydn, is scheduled on Sunday at 5 P.M., when admission will be $15.
Sales of homemade foods, toys and children's clothes as well as pony rides and a barnyard of goats, rabbits and miniature horses are some of the other features. For concert tickets call 434-0131; for more information call 434-7802 or 434-5542. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Frugal Choices

 BODY:
To the Editor: Susan Spano seems to enjoy carrying her suitcase all over town while looking for a suitable low-cost hotel. Wouldn't she have done better by taking a package trip?
Pascha Tours recently offered an eight-day package to Istanbul for $590, which I took late in March. This included air, hotel, transfers, porterage and breakfast that would have satisfied even the most frugal as well as those not so frugal. 
 A three-hour cruise on the Bosporus cost about a dollar; dinner at fine restaurants averaged $5; a pleasant hour at the Pierre Loti Cafe sipping a Coke and admiring the view cost 80 cents; and an exhibit of some fine work by Turkish cartoonists was free. Also free was the economics lesson on runaway inflation.
 
ARTHUR L. JOSELSON
Somerset, N.J.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Inventories Are Rising for the Right Reasons

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
JUST in time is justly starting to vanish.
That is probably the real meaning of the bulge in business inventories that has left economists shaking their heads, and that on Friday sent bond prices soaring. 
 The Government's first estimate of economic growth in the second quarter showed surprisingly slow final demand, and a big surge in inventories. One way to look at that -- the traditional way -- is to suspect that falling demand has caught businesses by surprise, leaving them with mounds of unsold products. If so, then one can expect a slowing economy as production is cut while all that inventory is worked off.
But there is another explanation. The era of "just-in-time" inventories, in which everyone from manufacturers to retailers kept as little inventory on hand as possible, may be coming to an end. That fad was based on the assumption that more could always be ordered, and quickly delivered, and that the price for such new inventory was likely to be no higher than the price of the old. If those assumptions are true, then why would anyone want to tie up good money in inventory?
The trouble is that the mini-boom of last winter exposed the wishful nature of the theory. There have been shortages, and rapid price hikes, in some commodities. Some companies have been unable to meet demand for their products. Suddenly, higher inventories seem to be prudent.
At the same time, companies that were having trouble meeting demand chose to raise prices, particularly in consumer products. Inflation in the second quarter is estimated at 3.2 percent a year, or twice what it was in the third quarter of 1993, before the surge in growth that surprised everyone and helped send the bond market into a panic.
Thus both the inflation and inventory figures can be read as indications that businesses saw signs of economic strength -- not weakness. Some may have overreacted, but the probability is that business is better than was indicated by the figure in Friday's report that so encouraged the bond market -- that final sales of domestic products grew at a slow 1.5 percent rate in the second quarter. There is a good chance those sales will rebound in this quarter.
The stock market in 1994 has had to deal with two big negatives: rising interest rates and some fears that those rates would shut down the recovery. Perhaps it is remarkable not that stock prices suffered but that they fell so little, with the Dow keeping its maximum decline under 10 percent. A big reason is that mutual fund investors plowed more into American stock funds in the first half of this year -- $43 billion -- than they had in the last half of 1993.
If the above analysis is accurate, it is quite possible that the bulls will be vindicated as it becomes clear that the Federal Reserve's moves to tighten credit are not threatening a new recession. If the perception spreads that interest rates will stop rising while the economy stays healthy, a new surge in the stock market could follow.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
In Mexico, a Case of Political Jitters

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
UNCERTAINTY is getting to be an unwelcome economic fixture here. Last week offered a mirror image of last year. Through most of 1993, Mexico's stock exchange and money market were whipsawed by the changing fortunes of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had so much riding on passage of the pact that when any obstacles arose, the Mexican stock exchange plummeted. The more likely approval seemed, the more spirited was trading on the floor of the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores. 
 Mexico's economy now has another case of the jitters, caused this time by a nightmarish collection of political problems leading up to the Aug. 21 Presidential election and the possibility that for the first time in 65 years the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party (known as PRI) could lose power.
The Bolsa's week began with the kind of upswing that set analysts to presenting rosy scenarios and buy recommendations. A dip Thursday was cause for a reassessment. By week's end, the realists here were saying that not much had really changed, despite the fact that the market closed at 2,462 on Friday, up 1.4 percent on the day and 7 percent for the week.
Overall, since Jan. 1 the battered Bolsa has lost more than 18 percent of its value in dollar terms, and the Mexican peso has dropped almost 10 percent of its value. Interest rates for Government securities have hovered around 17 percent, stemming the outflow of foreign investment but strangling a nascent economic recovery. Second-quarter company reports filed last week indicated sluggishness, and many analysts believe it unlikely that the economy grew much more in the second quarter than the 0.5 percent first-quarter increase.
"No financial market anywhere in the world likes uncertainty," said Jonathan Heath, director of MACRO Asesoria Economica, a Mexico City financial consulting firm. "If you want to understand the Mexican financial market at this time you have to understand Mexican politics."
Many investors already have taken money out of the Bolsa and the American Depositary Receipts for Mexican companies that are traded in New York. Some have tried to hedge by shifting to fixed equity instruments.
But even such drastic moves have proved inadequate because of pressure on the peso and doubts about whether Mexico can avoid a devaluation. So the Central Bank recently started issuing notes called Tesobonos, backed by a pledge that they will be redeemable upon maturity for United States dollars at a fixed exchange rate.
The new guarantees have proved attractive, especially to foreigners. At the end of last year, the amount of Government securities held in tesobonos was 4 billion new pesos, about $1.3 billion, while the regular 28-day treasury notes called cetes equaled 47.7 billion new pesos, around $16 billion.
By June 19, cetes holdings had dropped to 32.3 billion new pesos, about $10.5 billion, while tesobonos had surged to 34.7 billion pesos, around $11.3 billion.
Foreigners holding Mexican notes basically just shifted from cetes to tesobonos. But many Mexicans involved in the market were much more skittish. Many of them simply took their money out, went to exchange houses, and cashed in pesos for dollars. Exchange levels indicate that most of them were small- and medium-sized investors.
According to Deborah Riner, chief economist of the American Chamber of Commerce in Mexico City, through the first six months of the year, there has been an outflow of about $1 billion from the Mexican equity market, while during essentially the same period there was an inflow of $1.5 billion into Government obligations.
"That means that in spite of everything that's happened, foreign investment in Mexico is pretty much sitting tight," she said.
Other such mixed signals abound. Despite the peso's problems, exports are up, but so are imports. Foreign reserves are believed to have dropped below $18 billion dollars, the lowest point since 1982, but the Central Bank remains committed to defending the peso. In recent days, the interest rate for 28-day cetes dropped .66 percentage points, to 17 percent. Meanwhile, second-quarter earnings, while disappointing, were not as bad as had been expected, fueling the Bolsa's slight rebound.
As the election nears, opposition candidates are showing surprising strength, although the ruling party's replacement candidate, Yale-trained economist Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, is considered to be in the lead. Concern has focused on the possibility of chaos or violence after the election.
Opposition parties have vowed to take to the streets if the governing party wins in a way that seems fraudulent. A new President will not be confirmed until a new Congress is installed in November, and then he doesn't officially take office until Dec. 1. The pact between the Government, business and labor that controls wages and prices, and sets the band of peso exchange rates is due for renewal in October. Analysts expect that could be the time for an adjustment of the exchange-rate band, thus avoiding the harmful political effects that followed previous devaluations.
"All the uncertainty caused by the Nafta was cleared in one day and then the next day the sun came out," said Abel Beltran del Rio, president of Ciemex-Wefa, an economic study organization in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., that focuses on Mexico. "This time, after the election, it won't be resolved so quickly."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1430 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: July 25-29

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
If G.M.'s Making Billions, Why Is Its Stock Just Sitting There?
In the spring, Americans' fancy turns to wheels -- wheels, that is, with alarm systems, sunroofs and CD players. The spring quarter is always the strongest for auto makers, and when you mix that with Detroit's recent good times, the numbers become potent. Last week General Motors said its quarterly earnings were the highest ever: $1.92 billion. (A day earlier, Ford had also posted record profits: $1.71 billion.) G.M. could have earned even more, it said, but it just couldn't build light trucks fast enough to feed voracious buyers. Not that this gave G.M. money to burn. It's billions short on its pension i.o.u.'s, so it immediately socked away $2.5 billion for retirees. So why is G.M.'s stock looking less than spectacular? Perhaps, as one analyst put it, "most of the cost-cutting has already been accomplished" and the momentum of this spectacular comeback is easing. And it still earns far less on each car than Ford or Chrysler. 

One Investor Who Likes Viacom
When a big investor buys a chunk of a company's stock, sometimes it's time to worry, sometimes to celebrate. Viacom hoped it was the latter last week when Kirk Kerkorian, the financier who keeps buying and selling MGM/UA, said he'd bought 5 percent of Viacom. He said it was an investment, but wolves have been known to wear such verbal clothing. There seems little worry of takeover, though, because Sumner Redstone owns more than half of Viacom, so the hope was more that Mr. Kerkorian's magic investing touch (he bought Chrysler when most people wished they'd bought Chrysler) would sprinkle down on Viacom. Viacom's stock was bruised by the Paramount battle, and a rising stock price -- because of the terms of that deal -- would save Viacom some money.
 
The Cellular Mating Game
If you want to get into the cellular phone business, you'd better be quick, because the big guns, like hyperactive Monopoly players, are rapidly joining forces to carve up the territory. First there was an AT&T-McCaw deal, followed quickly by MCI-Nextel and Nynex-Bell Atlantic. Then last week U S West teamed up with Airtouch to create another cellular giant. Sam Ginn, head of Airtouch, saw "the landscape of the wireless industry for the next century" being shaped by these deals.
 
Biotech, From Cold to Hot
Biotech investors are like teen-agers in love -- their mighty passions come and go in an instant. Just recently, one former star, Synergen, plunged to ugly-duckling status when its key drug proved flawed; its stock price was halved. And last week investors flocked to a new love. After Biogen said its multiple sclerosis drug was looking good, its shares vaulted more than 50 percent. It was a "home run" for Biogen, one analyst said, the sports metaphor proving this was serious stuff indeed. And sure enough, the whole biotech stock index rose, though it's unclear what help Biogen's drug will be to other companies.
 
If They Only Had Hair
It's common knowledge: a bald man has no future. Only those with blow-dried plumage need apply at the corner office. (Just think what Barry Diller, say, or Laurence Tisch could have done with hair.) No wonder men take desperate measures -- wearing ill-fitting wigs (the pre-jail Michael Milken) or sending those lonely strands on a meandering tour of the offending scalp (and living in fear of a brisk wind). Or the truly desperate can try drugs, like Rogaine. Upjohn, which makes Rogaine, wants to make it easier for men to try it and has asked the F.D.A. to let it sell Rogaine without a prescription. But last week an F.D.A. panel urged the agency to say no, saying people should not be encouraged to waste money on a drug with limited effectiveness.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
What's Russian for 'Pyramid'?
In America, capitalism has evolved into such a flawless creature that investors are never led astray by out-and-out scams -- well, hardly ever. But for investors in Russia -- where capitalism is still on all fours -- things can get wild. A company called MMM promised the world, effortlessly and risk-free, and for a time its stock had so many buyers that it delivered. But last week those investors got a crash business course. Lesson No. 1: pyramid schemes. And when the MMM pyramid collapsed, investors acted like jilted lovers, camping on the company's grounds to be among the first to sell their shares, and saying things like "They promised everything."
 
Now They Lend Ford Money
When the American auto industry was down a decade ago, Japan had no qualms about kicking it some more, dangling all those good, cheap Hondas and Toyotas before car buyers. So by some odd logic, now that Detroit is definitely up -- just look at last week's record earnings at Ford and G.M. -- Japan extends a hand. Showing just how badly Japan wants to shed the villain's cape in the trade drama, Japan's Export-Import Bank wants to lend Ford $300 million to help it build right-hand-drive cars for export to Japan. And with an interest rate that's a gift -- just over 4 percent -- it will be hard for Ford to resist.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
The July Sky, On the Block
In simpler days, no one gazed at a July sky and wondered what it would sell for by the inch. But simpler days are history; anyone worth his pinstripes has a pager, and even cows have beepers. So a while ago the Government looked at that sky and realized it was giving away something it could easily sell. And last week, in the first auction of the nation's airwaves, the F.C.C. received more than $600 million in bids just for scraps of the radio spectrum for fancy paging services -- an amount so high it surprised just about everyone. And that was just the beginning. Around December it will auction off a bigger chunk of thin air -- for a wide array of wireless telephone, fax and data services -- and then the numbers will be in the billions.
 
The Politics of Sand
Republicans put it in almost existential terms, saying the need for protecting a California wilderness didn't exist because elitist Democratic environmentalists never went there -- they just liked the sound of the word "wilderness." Or, if there are no Democrats in a desert, does that desert exist? And for years the Republicans got their way. But California's got two Democrats as Senators now, and that turned the tide -- or rather the sand. Last week the House voted to turn 9.4 million acres -- including Joshua Tree National Monument -- into a national park, the largest bit of land conservation since the 1980 Alaska Lands Act. Passage is virtually certain, since the Senate has passed a similar bill.
 
The Buck Stopped There
Financial markets think in round numbers; crossing a threshold always commands attention. Sure enough, when the dollar slid below 100 yen recently, people suddenly stopped talking about derivatives and mutual funds and QVC and mourned the poor, wounded American currency. On July 12, it hit what one trader called its "drop-dead low," 96.6 yen, the lowest since World War II. But take heart: last week, with the possibility looming of eased trade tensions with Japan, the dollar clambered out of that pit, hitting 100.1 yen.
 
Good News? Yes and No (Pick 2)
Anyone trying to tell if the economic glass is half full or half empty faced a muddle last week. (Remember, of course, that good economic news is bad market news, since growth signals inflation.) But when word came that the economy grew at a brisk 3.7 percent pace for the quarter, the quick qualifier was that inventories were piling up because consumer spending was off. So: good news or not? Fortunately the financial markets sorted it out for us, as stocks and bonds rallied -- so, of course, it's bad news.
 
At Kidder, He Was in Charge
When the Joseph Jett case exploded, the instant reaction was, "Who's in charge here?" What supervisor could possibly be oblivious to a bond trader inflating profits by hundreds of millions of dollars? And many eyes turned on Edward Cerullo, Mr. Jett's boss at Kidder, Peabody. But Mr. Cerullo wasn't talking -- at least not until last week, when, right after resigning from Kidder, he came out swinging. "It was I who questioned Jett's profitability," he insisted. "I took the initiative." And: "If I need to fall on my sword, fine." But what he clearly wanted was to turn that sword firmly toward his critics after having it pointed at him for so long. And he no doubt wanted to get his licks on the record before the results of an inquiry come out this week.

LENGTH: 2910 words

HEADLINE: The New Deal at American Express

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
IMAGINE Tiffany's admitting that most of its customers don't need gold necklaces and would look just as elegant in beads. Or that Saks reacted to flagging couture sales by opening a discount warehouse.
Well, that's essentially what Harvey Golub is about to do at the American Express Company, a little more than a year after taking over as chairman and chief executive of the giant financial services business. 
 Mr. Golub has concluded that more than half of the 11 million people who carry American Express charge cards in the United States would be better off with a much less expensive credit card.
And so this fall, he is going to turn American Express's product line on its head. No longer will the company depend on a card that trades prestige for a hefty annual fee and the obligation to pay bills in full each month -- the classic charge card. Instead, Amex will issue the first of a dozen or more revolving credit cards, traditionally the bailiwick of banks affiliated with Mastercard and Visa. The new cards will come in all flavors, with some carrying no fees and some issued in conjunction with another company, like a car maker.
The change is overdue -- and essential if the company's card business is going to grow again, Mr. Golub said. "Affluent business travelers like the charge card," he said. "But we took a product that was very upscale, added frills to it and sold it to an increasing number of people who didn't need it in a utilitarian sense. An ideal product meets actual needs."
The needs have changed -- as have the times. When Mr. Golub was named president of the company and head of its card business in 1991, the card operation was rapidly crumbling after a decade of explosive growth, with tens of thousands of cardholders canceling their accounts each week. Consumer psychology had turned against the snob appeal that worked so well for the company in the 1980's. And banks that issue Mastercard and Visa cards were in the midst of a vicious price war: lowering interest rates, eliminating cardholder fees and enticing customers with all manner of goodies from airline miles to free gasoline.
Making matters even worse, American Express botched its first venture into credit cards with the Optima card, racking up more than $1.5 billion in unpaid charges since Optima was introduced in 1987. Largely because of that, profits from cards plummeted to $243 million in 1992, from $956 million in 1990.
Mr. Golub put the brakes on the free fall. He sharply reduced Optima losses and overall operating costs, and he cut fees charged to merchants, who were starting to boycott American Express. He was also bailed out by Amex's mileage program, which started just before he took over and which increased spending per card. By the time Mr. Golub succeeded James D. Robinson 3d in February 1993 as head of the whole company, card profits had started to rebound.
Still, Mr. Golub has been unable to stanch the loss of cardholders -- two million dropped away from 1991 to 1993 -- making the future uncertain. Enter the company's new deck of credit cards, each meant to offer more "value" to a specific segment of customers.
Yet as American Express takes on the banks, it lags badly in the number of places its cards are accepted.
"The strength of the hand they have is to be a real force in the travel and entertainment market," said Peter S. P. Dimsey, president of Mastercard International for the United States. "Now they are trying to be all things to all people and make themselves look like a bank card, where they have a disadvantage."
And by offering cards that appear to be aimed more at mass than at class, American Express risks diluting its brand name, and losing more of its remaining base.
"In the past, they have been revolving-credit bashers," said Carl F. Pascarella, president of Visa U.S.A. "Now, all of a sudden, they come in with a revolving-credit product. It creates confusion in the minds of consumers. At the same time, merchants may say this is no different from Mastercard or Visa, so why should we pay a premium for it."
Mr. Golub argues that the American Express brand name is broad enough to incorporate both credit and charge cards. Indeed, he is hardly giving up on the elite market, with plans to offer a new charge card with enough extra services to warrant a $100 fee. And he insists that the company will be much more savvy in avoiding bad credit risks than it was with Optima. Still, he acknowledges that the company's cards need to be accepted by more merchants, so for the first time Amex is trying to sign up virtually every place its cardholders might go to spend money. (Wal-Mart is still a holdout, but not Sears and Kmart.)
One thing is clear: Mr. Golub increased the stakes of his bet on credit cards when he got rid of the Shearson and Lehman brokerage units, ending Mr. Robinson's failed effort at fashioning a financial supermarket. Now 70 percent of the company's earnings come from its card and travel agent subsidiary, Travel Related Services. The rest comes from IDS Financial Services, a mutual fund and insurance company.
This year, Travel Related Services will earn about $1 billion, analysts estimate, up about 10 percent, mainly because of the reduction in Optima losses and the pickup in spending from remaining cardholders. The company's charge cards, known as travel and entertainment cards, will take in about $4 billion in fees from merchants -- amounting to about 2.8 percent of purchases -- and another $1.7 billion from fees paid by holders. Those range from $55 for a standard green card to $300 for platinum. (Some corporate accounts are free.)
Mr. Golub's only avenues for growth are new customers, more spending from existing customers and, perhaps most promising, interest charges on unpaid balances, the main revenue source for bank credit cards. Over the next five years, Mr. Golub hopes to increase those balances to about $30 billion, from $7 billion, earning another $450 million to $600 million a year. At the same time, he expects even faster growth from corporate travel cards and new cards specifically designed for corporate purchasing agents.
These are ambitious goals in a highly competitive business. Still, as a single entity, American Express should be able to produce more effective advertising and offer more sophisticated card features than the fragmented Mastercard and Visa systems, which are associations of competing banks.
HOWEVER powerful the American Express franchise may be, when Mr. Golub took over the card business in July 1991, he felt company executives were not paying enough attention to its problems.
"We were headed toward marginalization -- becoming a largely irrelevant factor in the marketplace," he said last week in his wood-paneled office in lower Manhattan overlooking the Hudson River. "I thought that at least some people said things about the business that were not related to marketplace reality. They were saying things like our relationships with merchants were in good shape and that competitive actions had not hurt the company."
Mr. Golub disagreed, and did so in a far more confrontational way than the smooth and cocky charge card executives were used to. Big, blunt and brainy, Mr. Golub has not lost the in-your-face style of the Brooklyn streets on which he grew up.
"You could get into some real battles with Harvey where he would be pounding the desk and yelling," recalls Jill M. Considine, then a top executive at the company and now head of the New York Clearing House, a commercial banking group.
Still, some found him to be a refreshingly direct and honest change for a culture that had long been known for its slick and intricate corporate infighting. "Everyone at American Express was polite, but there was always a leitmotif of subterfuge," Ms. Considine said.
Among other things, the 54-year-old Mr. Golub, a former McKinsey consultant, demanded that charge card executives back up their arguments that the business was not in trouble. As a result, Bain & Company, the Boston-based consulting firm, asked customers why they were canceling their cards. It confirmed Mr. Golub's suspicions: many customers wanted to borrow money with credit cards and wanted to shop in places that accepted bank cards but not American Express.
"There were a lot of rationales given that said the problem is not as bad as it seems," said Kenneth I. Chenault, whom Mr. Golub put in charge of the United States card business. "Harvey forced the company to face the reality that we had a substantial problem."
Armed with this research, Mr. Golub decided that it was futile for the company to try to hold on to yuppies and other cardholders who signed up in the 80's and instead should concentrate on keeping the loyalty of business travelers.
The best customers were identified and given better treatment by customer service representatives. More important, the company used its Membership Miles program to counter similar programs by bank cards that had attracted many of its biggest-spending customers.
More frightening, however, merchants began to rebel against Amex's high fees, which averaged 3.2 percent of every purchase, compared with about 2 percent for the Visa and Mastercard systems. Indeed, in 1992, a group of Boston restaurants attracted national attention when they all agreed to drop American Express.
THIS time, Mr. Golub commissioned McKinsey to determine what Amex is worth to merchants in terms of how much sales go up by accepting the card.
It found that Amex didn't need to cut fees much for travel-oriented merchants, like rent-a-car companies, even though they were its biggest accounts. But Amex did cut the rate sharply for mass-market retailers, who gained less from the card.
This tough pricing strategy allowed American Express to limit its fee cut to 0.3 percentage point, on average, instead of the 1 to 1.5 points some had feared. Moreover, the lower fees in some categories permit it to sign up more merchants. Indeed, its sales force is now calling on a prospect list of one million businesses, ranked by order of priority.
The effort is paying off. In 1992, American Express holders could use their cards in only 70 percent of their purchases, company studies showed. That number has risen to 80 percent, although it is still far from Mr. Golub's target of 95 percent, or virtual parity with the banks.
Even as he was calming the merchants and trying to slow the losses from Optima, Mr. Golub concluded that the company's fate increasingly was going to be tied to credit cards.
"There was one point of view that the lending business did not fit with the company's T&E business," he said. "I did not share that view. All during the time we were fixing the lending business we were fixing it for growth."
By the end of 1992, it was clear inside the company that the crisis with Optima was ending. And so Frank Skillern, a longtime associate of Mr. Golub who was put in charge of the Optima rescue, quietly began to develop the approval systems necessary to offer credit cards to new customers.
It quickly became apparent that the initial plan to introduce a souped-up version of Optima wouldn't work.
"The original quest was for one great credit card," said Phillip J. Riese, who took over credit cards last summer. "But when we did our research and showed customers a broad array of products, different customers went for different products. There was no silver bullet."
By the beginning of this year, American Express came to the conclusion that it needed 10 to 15 different cards, each meant to attract about 1 million customers.
The one premiering this fall, which will use the Optima name, is meant to appeal to people who want to borrow a lot and will feature low interest rates, although the company won't reveal the details. Next year it will likely introduce a card with no annual fee and additional cards with benefits tailored to various demographic groups, including students, yuppies and middle-class people who are not frequent business travelers.
At the same time, Mr. Skillern, who replaced Mr. Riese as head of the green, gold and platinum cards, is trying to revive that business by breaking it up into half a dozen smaller customer groups.
The most important group, of course, are the frequent business travelers, who represent about 45 percent of charge card customers.
"These are customers we make the most money from," Mr. Skillern said. "We will treat them differently."
For example, Amex is reprogramming its approval system to accept charges for these top customers that would previously have been denied because they were unusually large.
Amex is also creating special versions of the charge card for customer groups that don't want a credit card but aren't served well by the traditional card. For example, Amex cut the card fee for senior citizens to $35 and added such benefits as an "ask the pharmacist" information line.
ON the other hand, the company is cooking up a card that will have an annual fee of at least $100 -- $25 more than the gold card -- and will offer even more features for business travelers. Also in the works is something called "The Plan," a program that will allow customers to use one card as a charge card, credit card or debit card. The latter deducts purchases as they are made from the customer's bank account.
With all these card programs in the works, the biggest risk facing American Express may be the very complexity of its plans. The sheer range of proposed card programs increases the chances of making another mistake on the order of Optima or creating a different kind of snafu. Moreover, the company risks muddying its message to the consumer.
In response, American Express plans to continue to emphasize the charge card in its advertising even as it hopes more of its customers use credit cards to go further into debt. "The charge card is going to remain as the central part of the positioning of the brand," Mr. Skillern said. "It is our equity and our history."
In other words, put the gold necklace in the window but put the beads out to sell.
 
 
 
GOLUB'S AGENDA
 HARVEY GOLUB has put American Express on a diet, selling its Shearson brokerage house to the Travelers, spinning off its Lehman brokerage to shareholders and selling most of the First Data Corporation, a processing company. As a result, he has mostly disassembled the financial supermarket built by his predecessor, James D. Robinson 3d.
"A financial supermarket says anybody can buy anything from the same organization," Mr. Golub said. "I don't think that's possible."
Yet in a narrower way, Mr. Golub does see the potential to sell much more than credit cards to his customer base. He has appointed Pete Talbott, a veteran of Citicorp and First Boston, to develop a new business in "virtual banking," offering banking and investment services over the phone and through computers, much as Fidelity Investments sells mutual funds.
More immediately, he wants to tie IDS Financial Services far more closely into the corporate family, with more aggressive marketing to the company's card customers. One way is a new name: American Express Financial Advisers.
Mr. Golub is so confident that the American Express panache, along with access to the charge card customer list, will improve IDS sales that he is cutting off one of the unit's main sources of new clients: unsolicited phone calls.
"Customers hate cold calling," Mr. Golub said. And he is afraid that disgruntled recipients of such calls might cut their cards in protest.
 
 
 
MOVING THE MERCHANDISE
 THE card business at American Express is rapidly becoming more than a financial service, turning into an advertising medium as well.
Because the company has a wealth of information about its customers gleaned from their buying habits, it already mails all manner of precisely targeted offers, like a coupon for a new Chicago hotel to those who travel frequently to that city.
Now it is developing a far more significant system that will print these offers right on the monthly card statements. The system is already in use in Britain, where Harrods has offered sales only to American Express holders who regularly shop there.
Soon the company will be able to offer bonuses based on spending over time, sort of mini-frequent-buyer programs appearing unsolicited on a statement. For example, Brooks Brothers might offer a free shirt to those making purchases of, say, $1,000 within six months.
Merchants generally will not be charged for these programs, but of course Amex gets a cut of everything cardholders spend.
American Express is also planning to make its Membership Miles program more of a promotional vehicle. In some countries, including Canada, the program is already known as Membership Rewards, providing customers with points good for merchandise or services other than frequent-flier miles.
As envisioned, companies that have products with excess inventory -- say soon-to-be-outdated computers or unreserved hotel rooms -- would sell them at a deep discount to American Express, which would offer them for points. Some companies might even offer products to American Express at no charge just to induce its affluent customers to sample their wares.
Harvey Golub, American Express's chairman, even envisions the day when the company would be paid to run frequent-buyer programs.

LENGTH: 255 words

HEADLINE: Closing of Flea Market Would Add to Jobless

 BODY:
As a resident of East Meadow and president of the Roosevelt Raceway Flea Market Merchants' Association, I feel compelled to respond to "Flea Market Plan Raises Opposition" [July 3] regarding the proposal to shift the current flea market to the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum.
Regardless of the weather, my members engage in a tradition older than the Bible, selling their wares at an open-air market where they are audited regularly by the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. 
 Some merchants are single parents determined to make a go of it. Others are new American citizens, using the time-honored pushcart strategy in order to become part of the economy. Some are East Meadow storeowners who need the extra retail income to make ends meet.
So it is no small irony that my community's own Chamber of Commerce now opposes the survival of the flea market and the preservation of some 2,000 jobs.
As reflected in your article there is a growing awareness among members of the East Meadow community that the flea market deserves to survive. It is unfair and unconscionable to simply "red line" thousands of people into unemployment because a Chamber of Commerce president has decreed it so.
Unlike some corporation told by residential neighbors they can't build a headquarters locally, our merchants can't simply relocate. If the chamber puts us out of business we will walk past their membership on our way to unemployment everyday until the bank takes away our homes.
GARY ROMANOFF
East Meadow
