HEADLINE: Beyond Security;
The Hopes for Peace Begin To Build Upon Themselves

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
DAN MERIDOR, a former Justice Minister, was chatting last Tuesday about how much Israel has changed -- how its economy has taken on vigor and its people self-confidence, how the nation itself is emerging triumphant from decades of conflict to be recognized as a regional superpower.
 As he spoke in Parliament's cafeteria, a sprawling room set against a panoramic view of Jerusalem, Mr. Meridor kept glancing at a most striking illustration of this new Israel: its legislators staring, transfixed, at televised images of King Hussein of Jordan and their own Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, addressing a joint session of the United States Congress. In the audience was Rehazam Ze'evi, leader of a far-right party that advocates the expulsion of Arabs; barely 10 feet from him were a dozen photographers jostling to shoot pictures of Yasir Arafat's sister-in-law, Hala Tawil, paying her first visit to Parliament as the guest of another legislator. "These are good days for Israel," said Mr. Meridor, a leading figure in the right-wing opposition Likud Party, flashing a mischievous smile of appreciation at the scene.
 
 Indeed they are. As the reality of a negotiated peace between Arabs and Jews keeps unfolding in dramatic chapters, Israelis are finding themselves less obsessed with the question of security that has dogged them so insistently for nearly 50 years; instead, they are turning toward other aspects of life. And as the siege mentality of the ordinary person lifts, the new optimism in turn is accelerating the peace process.
 Even the considerable roadblocks that remain on the path to peace and that were so evident in recent days -- Syria's hesitance about joining in, Yasir Arafat's lack of a sure hand in administering self-rule, and terror bombings against Jews in Argentina, Panama and Britain -- do not hold the public imagination prisoner as they might once have. Attention, instead, remains on the country's relentless climb toward the elite status of a first-world nation, where people think first of things like travel, cable television, new cars, portable phones, and the next visit to the latest high-fashion shopping mall.
 "I have been here for 30 years," says Hirsh Goodman, editor-in-chief of the bimonthly Jerusalem Report. "There is change at every level. The economy is being privatized. People have more disposable income. The country's population has increased by nearly a million new immigrants in the last three years with unemployment falling at the same time.
 "After the Madrid conference it seemed everyone wanted to reach out to Israel. We could do business anywhere. We are exporting more than $20 billion of goods from high-tech to swimwear. I can go to Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim nation."
 To a reporter who has covered the Arab world for much of the last 15 years and has also traveled regularly to Israel, this sense of Israeli self-confidence helps explain the most stunning revelation of the unfolding peace process -- the widening acceptance of each other by former enemies on both sides of the Mideast divide, as the politics of peace achieves breakthroughs in the psychology of peace, and this in turn paves the way for the next political agreement.
 Last week, for example, as Mr. Meridor's colleagues in Parliament watched the address in Congress on live television in Jerusalem, so did millions of Arabs across the Middle East -- even in Syria. For the first time, it turned out, President Hafez al-Assad felt that it was wise to let his people witness such a spectacle.
 Meanwhile, in Jordan, television commentators referred to Mr. Rabin as "the Israeli leader," "His Excellency the Prime Minister" and "Mr. Rabin." There was none of the "Zionist entity" venom of past years. Israeli reporters were greeted in Amman warmly, if sometimes awkwardly. Saudi newspapers gave the event banner coverage. Once-militant Algeria proclaimed its support publicly for the agreement to end hostilities between Jordan and Israel. Only in the capitals of the most radical regimes -- Teheran, Baghdad and Tripoli, for example -- was the old abusive language still in use.
 
Seeking to Talk
 Zeev Schiff, who writes for the Israeli daily Haaretz and who spent a week in Jordan this month as the personal guest of Crown Prince Hassan, said the most important change he has tracked in the Arab side of the Middle East equation has been a broadening of appreciation that a relationship with Israel is necessary. "They need to have a dialogue with the Israeli people," Mr. Schiff said. "The Palestinians understood that when they went to Oslo for secret talks and so did the Egyptians long before, as do the Moroccans, Tunisians, Qataris, Omanis and others in the Arab world now."
 Syria, of course, has not been so forthcoming, but last week President Assad, even as he opened the airwaves to peace oratory from Washington, also used friendly journalists to put out a tantalizing signal: that he would not mind if a joint Lebanese-Syrian delegation began direct talks with Israel.
 Among Arabs, the drive to make peace is in strong measure the result of economic necessity; if for Israel the cost of security had become painful over the years, for many Arab lands the cost of permanent war had become unbearable. Egypt was practically bankrupt when it made peace in the late 1970's. Saudi Arabia and the gulf countries are not as wealthy as they were, and the Palestine Liberation Organization had lost the ability even to pay its employees' salaries. Jordan faces a worsening economy and accumulated debts.
 In Israel, a year after beginning to deal openly with the P.L.O., economic pressures of a different kind underpin Mr. Rabin's aggressive moves toward peace, as a newly affluent population of 4.5 million begins to see life with more optimism.
 It is one of those moments in a nation's history in which military prowess and economic prosperity conspire to alter a country's image of itself and of its neighbors. And the more Israelis come to believe in their own future, it seems, the more willing Arabs are to believe they can deal with Israel to their mutual benefit.
 In recent months, the hottest issues consuming Israeli attention have been efforts to reform the health care system, lower import duties on consumer goods and create the country's first private university, as well as a boom in the building of new highways. Abroad, the country has been fascinated by the crack medical team it has sent to help Rwandan refugees. Per capita income has climbed to $13,000, placing Israel among the top 10 nations in the world, and since 1990 the economy has been growing at a remarkable 6 percent a year. Even as 500,000 to a million immigrants arrived in the last three years, Israel managed to lower its unemployment rate from 11 percent to 8 percent.
 The blossoming of Israel has triggered envy and soul-searching among its neighbors. More and more, Arab commentators have stopped blaming outside conspiracies for Arab problems. The new message in Arab intellectual circles is that the Arab world must learn to negotiate differences because the ideology of all or nothing has cost too much.
 Meanwhile, Israel's military might remains unquestioned, and this has been the other essential ingredient for the optimism that Mr. Rabin is capitalizing on, as he leads his people ever further into coming to terms with their enemies of a half-century.
 "It is not a new Israel," says Meron Benvenisti, a historian and former deputy mayor of Jerusalem. "It was all there except that people never allowed the reality of our strength to penetrate their psyche because it would betray their paranoia. Now this dichotomy is over. What we see now is that Mr. Rabin is bringing Israel into its proper regional superpower role."
 As long as peace still seems attainable, the process continues to strengthen itself. Barry Rubin, a political scientist, says military service has been quietly cut from 36 months to 32 months for men and from 24 months to 20 months for women, further changing Israelis' lives as manpower is gradually cut in favor of high tech. "People no longer want their lives to revolve around conflict," he said. "They now perceive peace as possible and the status quo as impossible to preserve."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
In Search of a Vision For the City of the '90's

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
WHERE have you gone, Lewis Mumford and Jane Jacobs? A nation's cities turn their lonely eyes to you.
 O.K., granted Mr. Mumford and Ms. Jacobs, the most insightful prophets and critics of the 20th-century American city, are no Joe DiMaggio. For Paul Simon, the songwriter, Joe was the larger-than-life icon of a lost age of American innocence. But something has also been lost from what passes these days for the art of urban planning. And that is precisely what those two intellectuals once brought to the field: a vision of the future of the big city.
 
 This is a particularly critical issue today. With the vast expansion in the last two decades of multiple "edge cities" well away from the traditional downtowns, big cities no longer dominate the industrial and commercial life of the United States. "Given new communications technologies, relentless shareholder pressure and mobile labor markets, many large corporations no longer believe they require an urban presence," writes Joel Kotkin, a Los Angeles-based author and senior fellow at the Center for the New West. "Many are retreating to smaller cities and rural locales, where they enjoy special tax breaks, slavish local governments, weak union movements and feeble environmental controls."
 In response, city planners and policy makers from Boston to San Francisco have sought to keep big companies from leaving by pouring vast resources into rebuilding their tired old downtowns. But for all the success of megaprojects like Baltimore's Inner Harbor, they have failed to reverse a broader decline or put much of a dent in inner-city poverty and crime.
 What is needed instead, contend some of the new thinkers about urban issues, is more attention to bringing vitality to those small businesses and urban communities, largely ignored by real estate developers and city planners, where millions of immigrants and minority families have settled in search of opportunities to get ahead.
 "Two themes dominate the conventional wisdom about cities: the effort to revitalize downtown office centers and despair over inner-city poverty," says Richard P. Nathan, author of "A New Agenda for Cities," and provost of the College of Public Affairs at the State University of New York at Albany. "But the real hope for the future of our big cities rests on the rebirth of the old neighborhoods by new immigrants and working families of blacks and Hispanics. We can't afford to neglect them anymore."
 There is only so much, of course, that city planning can do alone. In contrast to many European cities, most American metropolitan areas have been shaped far more by powerful economic and technological forces than by any master planning.
 But the obsession with downtown development that still animates most urban planners appears to have blinded many city officials to possibilities elsewhere.
 
'A Different Direction'
 "Throughout history, the central city was always the central focus of urban areas," says Witold Rybczynski, a leading urban theorist at the University of Pennsylvania. "That is no longer true."
 "You can't blame Mumford and Jacobs for not dealing with this," he adds. "Cities have just taken off in a different direction."
 Urban theorists like Mr. Mumford and Ms. Jacobs helped define and influence the unruly shape of the American city that emerged from the crucible of the auto-industrial age. For all their differences, both shared a critical outlook toward Robert Moses, the master builder whose mixed legacy of vast public construction and equally vast private destruction still rests uneasily over New York and other big cities affected by his example.
 
Mumford and Jacobs
 To Mr. Mumford, the ideal urban area was something like the small town writ large. He championed a nostalgic image of a rational, orderly moderate-density city nestled within broad swaths of greenery. While far from anything that Mr. Mumford envisioned, much of upper-middle-class suburban life today and such planned garden cities as Reston, Va., and Columbia, Md., outside Washington, D.C., represent imperfect expressions of that model.
 By contrast, Ms. Jacobs, author of the seminal 1961 book "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," was the anti-utopian exponent of the unpredictable, even anarchic jumble of the traditional urban neighborhood. To her, the ideal -- also writ large -- was something like the bustling diversity of the Greenwich Village where she lived in the 1950's and 1960's.
 Almost singlehandedly, Ms. Jacobs inspired the opposition to massive urban renewal schemes. And out of an amalgam of ideas propounded by Ms. Jacobs and other social critics like Herbert Gans and William F. Whyte, there emerged a new approach to city planning. Density and active street life was good, went the new litany, autos were bad. Planned superhighways that would have bulldozed still-thriving city neighborhoods were stopped; the building of large-scale public housing projects placed in bleak and forbidding plazas was halted. But, faced with the powerful forces that have been loosening the ties that once bound corporate America to its traditional urban bases, something more is needed.
 To Mr. Kotkin and others, a fresh approach to the cities would start with the recognition that most Americans live elsewhere. Cities no longer can be all things to all people. As forums for trade, travel and art, however, big cities like New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles still serve as centers of economic creativity that can only be fostered in an atmosphere of intense competition and person-to-person contact. Instead of trying to compete with the dozens of big new peripheral job centers built primarily for white-collar, middle-class workers, urban centers can focus on their own unique abilities to bring diverse groups and cultures together.
 "From ancient times," Mr. Kotkin says, "urban centers are unique for their ability to nurture what could be seen today as outsider groups -- minorities, immigrants, women entrepreneurs, gays, young singles -- who could have an extraordinarily difficult time thriving in the more conventional and homogeneous society in the hinterlands." But without some rethinking of the role cities should play in American society, they could end up even further from center stage than they are today.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS ATTRACTING NEW MONEY POOL

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
The United States has found an unlikely benefactor to replace Japanese investors in paying for the nation's continuing budget and trade deficits: foreign government banks, mainly in developing countries.
The flood of money from these unlikely sources into the United States is the latest shift in the powerful currents of capital flows that underlie the global economy. In the 1970's, Arab nations flush with oil money recycled their profits into American investments. 
 In the 1980's, Japanese investors, riding their country's export boom, plowed hundreds of billions of dollars in trade surpluses into the United States, buying everything from Treasury bonds to Columbia Pictures to control of Rockefeller Center in New York. Their investments in the United States propped up the dollar and held down interest rates here.
Now a new trend has appeared, Government and International Monetary Fund figures show. While net private investment in the United States has dropped 89 percent in the last seven years, to $12.8 billion last year, net government investment here nearly doubled last year, to $70 billion, according to Commerce Department statistics.
International monetary officials say most of that new investment has come from the central banks of countries like India, Malaysia, Taiwan, Brazil, Mexico and Chile. According to figures released this week by the I.M.F., nine-tenths of the increase in central bank dollar holdings occurred in developing countries.
These central banks are similar to the Federal Reserve, printing money and setting interest rates. They are flush with cash because Western pension and mutual funds have invested heavily in their countries, seeking higher returns than they could find in industrialized countries, which are growing more slowly.
Officials in developing countries said in telephone interviews this week that they were buying the dollars flowing into their economies to keep the money from feeding inflation or driving up their currencies, making their exports too expensive in world markets. They pay for the dollars by selling government bonds, and invest the dollars in American bonds.
But the long fall of the dollar this summer has inflicted losses on these central banks and their taxpayers, giving American policymakers a new worry. They fear that if the dollar continues its slide, foreign central banks may switch to other currencies.
If foreign central banks shed dollars on a large scale, economists say, the dollar will fall further, prices will rise for imported goods and interest rates will climb.
Foreign central bank investments now equal one of every 12 dollars of savings in the United States. But these investments have not reached the levels of the late 1980's, when the flow of capital from Japan was at its peak.
Japanese investors cut back their investments in the United States during the early 1990's. But the effects were less severe than expected, because the retrenchment coincided with a recession in the United States that pushed down interest rates. As the American economy has expanded, rising central bank investments have filled the gap left by Japanese investments.
 
Strong Dollar Sought
 Clinton Administration and Federal Reserve officials are loathe to test the patience of the foreign central banks. In recent testimony to Congress, some officials have said they want a strong dollar that is attractive to currency reserve managers at foreign central banks.
"We are going to be, will have to be, and as far as we at the Federal Reserve are concerned, need to be the principal reserve currency in the world for the indefinite future," Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Banking Committee on July 20. "And if we allow the dollar to weaken as a reserve currency, we will have consequences not only within our domestic system, but I think we will have significant problems with the necessary responsibilities that we have as a world leader in financial markets and in the economy."
Already there are warning signs for the American reliance on these funds. On July 12, Taiwan, which holds the largest amount of dollars in the world, said the portion of its $90 billion portfolio invested in dollars had dropped by three percentage points, to a record low of 56.73 percent, because of the declining value of the currency.
 
Large Reserves Held
 Other central banks retain large dollar holdings because they want to pay for their country's imports in dollars if exports suddenly drop. The Reserve Bank of India, for example, keeps three-fifths of its reserves in dollars, but reassesses the ratio weekly to determine if it is hurting its balance sheet, said O. P. Sodhani, the bank's executive director.
"Over 90 percent of our trade, exports and imports, is in dollars, but some changes do take place depending on how the currency is moving," he said in a telephone interview from his home in Bombay.
The Reserve Bank of India is one of two dozen central banks in developing countries that have spectacularly increased their reserves in the last few years. India's reserves have soared tenfold since 1990, to $16.19 billion in May of this year, from $1.55 billion, as new, free-market economic policies have brought a surge of foreign investment.
But foreign central banks are becoming increasingly sophisticated investors, and no longer dump reserves into the dollar automatically.
"Central banks 10 years ago put their money into Treasury bonds," said Charles H. Dallara, who was the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs in the Bush Administration and is now the managing director of the Institute of International Finance, the research and lobbying arm of the world's biggest multinational banks. "There's no longer the passive tendency that there was 10 years ago."

HEADLINE: Crossing the River: The Israel-Jordan Pact -- A special report.;
Amid Debt, Doubt and Secrecy, Hussein and Rabin Made Peace

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
On the evening of May 19 in a quiet London living room, two war horses of the Middle East -- men who were present at the creation of the conflict between their countries nearly half a century ago -- met secretly to end it once and for all.
As King Hussein remembers it now, he looked across at Yitzhak Rabin and said to himself, "You know, Yitzhak, you and I have been at this a long time." 
 The King of Jordan and the Prime Minister of Israel had met before, in secret places and often in disguise. But, always, either Jordan wasn't ready, or Israel wasn't ready or the Palestinians weren't ready.
That night in London, the King was visibly distraught. For months both the Americans and the Israelis had accused him of dragging his feet. "How am I not serious?" he asked Mr. Rabin directly.
Mr. Rabin, the King recalled in an interview this week, said that he knew Jordan was serious about the concept of peace, but that it was time to do business.
"Fine," the King replied, "Let's get on with it."
And so they did.
Over the next few hours the two worked out the basis for the Israeli-Jordanian pact signed last Monday at the White House. The King agreed to take small but meaningful steps toward normal diplomatic relations, to move toward direct, high-level public contacts and to begin work on a formal peace treaty; Mr. Rabin agreed to discuss Jordan's territorial and water claims even before securing a formal peace.
When Mr. Rabin returned to Israel from London, he told his aides: "We found the way for the breakthrough. Something happened to Hussein. He passed a psychological barrier."
What the two old adversaries produced in more than a year of secret diplomacy has ended the state of war between their countries and opened the way for a normal relationship.
But its effect goes beyond the borders of Israel and Jordan: it has left Syria isolated as the only major party to the Arab-Israeli conflict that has not reconciled with Israel, and it has created a competition between Jordan and the Palestinians for areas of the West Bank and East Jerusalem over which Israel might cede control.
Interviews with Jordanian, Israeli and American participants disclosed many details of the secret diplomacy.
The crucial link between King Hussein and Mr. Rabin was not, as it had been so often, an American mediator, but rather the deputy director of the Mossad, Israel's intelligence service. Mr. Rabin has described the official, who has worked with King Hussein secretly for 25 years, as the Israeli whom the King trusts most. The official -- whose name the parties declined to disclose -- arranged the secret contacts, made several visits to Amman and even briefed Americans on the King's thinking.
The pace and scope of the breakthrough were directly tied to the talks between Mr. Rabin and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
When King Hussein detected progress between those two men, he speeded up his own negotiations with Israel to insure that he would not be frozen out of the West Bank or East Jerusalem. When the King sensed that Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat were having problems, he slowed down.
The other key factor motivating King Hussein was economics. Facing a crushing debt, he desperately needed relief that only Washington could provide. Throughout the talks, money came up more often than missiles, and economic security was talked about as much as national security. Even on the day of the White House signing, Israeli officials pleaded with Washington for aid for Jordan.
 
Jordan, Early 1993
King and Clinton Exchange Letters
 In the spring of 1993, King Hussein was in a bad way. He was recovering from cancer surgery. He was estranged from his natural protector, the United States, for siding with Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. His country had run up a foreign debt of $6.5 billion, larger than Jordan's $4.5 billion gross national product, but he had been told by other countries that if the United States forgave its $700 million in debt, they would follow suit.
It was in that context that King Hussein, while in the United States for a medical checkup, came to the Oval Office on June 18 to meet President Clinton for the first time -- and to put Jordanian-American relations back on track.
The meeting went well, and six days later King Hussein wrote Mr. Clinton a long personal letter, sharing what he described as the peaceful vision of his grandfather King Abdullah, who was assassinated in 1951 in Jerusalem by a Palestinian as the young Hussein stood at his side.
"I am determined to fulfill that part of my grandfather's legacy and leave my own," the King wrote. Last week, recalling the letter, he said he asked himself: "What is life all about? What is my responsibility? What will I be remembered for?"
On July 4, 1993, Mr. Clinton wrote back, saying how moving the letter had been, and assuring the King of his "full support."
"You will not be alone as you proceed with your efforts to make peace with Israel," Mr. Clinton said. A short time later, the Administration asked Congress to resume military aid to Jordan.
 
Norway, August 1993
Israeli-P.L.O. Pact Startles Hussein
 At the same time, unknown to either King Hussein or to the Americans, an informal Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Norway had grown into formal negotiations between Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat. When an accord was announced at the end of August, King Hussein was thunderstruck.
For 26 years the King had counted on Israel to control the P.L.O. for him, at least in the West Bank, and he was worried that Mr. Arafat was going to take up residence there in some sort of independent capacity. The King urgently summoned Mr. Rabin to Aqaba, the Jordanian port, for a secret meeting at which the Israeli tried to reassure him that Israel was not forming an alliance with Mr. Arafat.
Nevertheless, the King recalled, the accord "finally drove home to me the need to look at Jordan and look at its future, a Jordan that has shared with the Palestinians everything, that gave them a home."
In early October, the King sent Crown Prince Hassan to Washington to a conference called to raise money for the new Palestinian entity, and to meet with the President. The White House responded that a meeting was possible on one condition: that it include Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.
After checking with the King, the Crown Prince agreed. The three men met in the Oval Office and pledged to set up a working group to deal with economic concerns. Mr. Peres even joined the Crown Prince in appealing to Mr. Clinton for debt relief.
At a news conference that day, Mr. Clinton spoke for the first time of the importance of easing Jordan's debt burden. But Jordanian officials found little sympathy in meetings with Treasury officials. "Everyone put a damper on it," said one senior Jordanian official. "They said it couldn't be done."
 
Amman, Nov. 3, 1993
Trip to a Palace Across the Border
 As the Israel-P.L.O. talks quickened, King Hussein decided to take his own relationship with Israel to another level. With the mediation of Israel's deputy intelligence chief, the King arranged a secret meeting with Mr. Peres in Amman, the Jordanian capital.
On the evening of the meeting, Mr. Peres voted in municipal elections in Israel and then secretly drove with a top aide to the Allenby Bridge, on the border, where a Jordanian limousine was waiting. Talking in the palace until dawn, Mr. Peres and the King drafted and initialed a four-page document that laid the foundation for what would come later.
It included a commitment to sign a peace agreement as soon as possible, a plan to hold an Arab-Israeli business conference in Amman to discuss regional development and a vague Israeli reassurance to respect Jordan's historic role in maintaining the Muslim holy shrines in Jerusalem.
Mr. Peres, locked for decades in a fierce competition with Mr. Rabin over credit for breakthroughs, could not control his excitement. Upon returning to Israel he told a television reporter, "Remember this date" -- Nov. 3, 1993. And he began what he called a "storming strategy" to push peace with Jordan and temporarily elbow Syria aside.
 
Amman, Winter 1994
King Paces Talks To the P.L.O.'s
 King Hussein was furious with Mr. Peres's indiscretion. In the document he had signed with the Foreign Minister, he had not agreed to any specific dates. Facing parliamentary elections at home and with the Syrians monitoring his every move, the King wanted to proceed slowly.
More important, Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat were making little progress in negotiating the details of their agreement. The King saw no incentive to take risks as long as those talks could still collapse.
For the next five months, the King took a tough line. He told the Israelis he would move forward with them only if they first agreed to create a border commission to discuss Jordan's demand for the return of about 147 square miles along the border and for more access to water from the Jordan River.
Mr. Rabin arranged delivery of a blunt message: "You can forget about it."
The King insists he was not stalling. The Israelis and Americans, preoccupied with the Syrian and Palestinian talks, simply "did not take us seriously," he says.
Still, Jordan and Israel did move forward in two small areas: an agreement to open branches of a large Jordanian bank in the West Bank and Gaza, and a strategy to control infestations of flies that breed in uncovered manure pits in the Jordan Valley.
But the Americans were so irritated with the King that when Secretary of State Warren Christopher visited the Mideast in late April and in May, he did not stop in Jordan.
 
London, May 19, 1994
West Bank Worry Provides Impetus
 On May 4 the political landscape changed. To the King's astonishment, Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin reached agreement in Cairo to carry out the accord they had signed on the White House lawn eight months earlier.
More important for the King, the May agreement spelled out in detail an economic relationship, including how to manage trade with the West Bank. It specified which goods could be imported into the West Bank from Jordan -- and excluded many in which Jordan specializes, like cement.
At the same time, Mr. Arafat's talk about setting up a Palestinian currency and banking system, a plan the Israelis later rejected, prompted many West Bank residents to sell Jordanian dinars into dollars, and the dinar briefly plunged.
"Their agreement with the Israelis affected us," King Hussein said. "People began to speculate. We were headed for another serious situation."
Suddenly the King revived the Israel-Jordan channel. On May 19 Mr. Rabin, his deputy intelligence chief and two other senior officials donned disguises and boarded a corporate jet on the private runway of Israel Aircraft Industries for the trip to London, where the King and his aides were waiting.
 
Washington, June 1994
Focus on Debts And Military Aid
 Still, there was a long way to go. The Israeli intelligence official was skeptical whether this secret understanding worked out in London would survive. "This is where they are," the official told the Americans about the Jordanian position. "But I cannot tell you when you talk to them, when you see them, that this is where they will be."
On June 7 in Washington, the Israelis and Jordanians disclosed the rough outlines of their deal. Under the cover of the Trilateral Economic Committee, comprising the United States, Jordan and Israel, the two countries agreed to discuss borders and specific economic projects, to transfer their economic and bilateral talks to Jordan and Israel and to elevate the level of their public meetings -- but not yet to the level of heads of state.
The first hint that the King was willing to meet Mr. Rabin in public came during the King's visit to Washington later in June. In talks in his hotel suite with Dennis B. Ross, the chief American negotiator in the Mideast, and Martin S. Indyk, the chief Mideast specialist at the White House, the King made clear what he wanted from the United States: debt forgiveness and assistance in modernizing Jordan's military.
The deputy Israeli intelligence chief was also in Washington, sent by Mr. Rabin to assist the King and to serve as a liaison with Jerusalem and with the State Department.
 
'Never Been Afraid of Daylight'
 In daily meetings with Mr. Ross and other Administration officials, the Mossad officer pressed the King's case so hard that at one point Mr. Ross turned to him and said: "Look, I understand what's going on here. The Jordanians are using you to try to convince us to do more. But they have to understand that if they want us to do more, they have to give us more to work with."
On June 20, King Hussein began to do just that, saying in a news conference that he would have no problem meeting Mr. Rabin. "I've never been afraid of daylight, sir," the King told an Israeli reporter.
Two days later, when the King visited Mr. Clinton to appeal for debt relief and military assistance, the President was ready.
He said he understood Jordan's difficult economic situation and was eager to help clear the debts -- but at a price. Given the budget constraints and the hard lobbying it would take to persuade Congress that such an investment in Jordan was worthwhile, the President told the King, "I'm not going to offer something that I can't deliver on."
 
Clinton's List
 Mr. Clinton suggested the King do "something dramatic that unmistakably accelerates the process toward a peace treaty," like a meeting in Washington with Mr. Rabin.
But there was another aspect of the meeting that impressed the King. Mr. Clinton referred from memory to a letter from the King delivered the night before that requested help in eight specific areas, and he listed precise ways the United States could meet them, including an expansion of agricultural assistance and risk insurance for private investment, Export-Import Bank financing for purchases of Boeing aircraft and military equipment from surplus stocks.
By the time the King left Washington, the Americans had concluded that he would be ready to meet Mr. Rabin by October.
 
The White House Finale
Former Enemies Frame an Accord
 Once again the King had broken a psychological barrier. "I had it in my mind when I spoke to the President," he said. "When I left the U.S,, I had already made up my mind." En route home, he decided to go forward as soon as a meeting could be arranged.
In Amman on July 9, the King warned the lower house of Parliament that there were pressures on Jordan and no superpower to support him. If a public encounter with Mr. Rabin would serve Jordan's interests, he added, "I will not hesitate and I would consider that a duty."
Three days later, the King wrote Mr. Clinton that he was ready to invite Mr. Rabin to the opening of bilateral meetings between Israel and Jordan on July 18 on the border, as long as Washington was willing to support the forgiveness of Jordan's debt.
Mr. Clinton replied that the way to get the greatest impact from the meeting both in the Mideast and with Congress was to come to Washington. He did not state the obvious: that the realization of a major foreign policy success on the White House lawn would provide an immediate boost to Mr. Clinton's sagging popularity.
Neither the King nor Mr. Rabin objected.
 
10 Days to Communique
 On July 15 Mr. Clinton announced that the two leaders would meet for the first time in public on July 25 at the White House. That would let Washington codify points of agreement so the event would not be dismissed as a dressed-up photo opportunity.
But when Secretary Christopher arrived in the Middle East the following week with the draft declaration, he discovered that such help was not needed: Mr. Rabin and the King wanted to write the declaration themselves.
To allay the King's fear of a leak, a secret Israeli negotiating team set up shop in a Mossad site north of Tel Aviv where Mr. Rabin came to consult. Even Mr. Peres was left out.
So were the Americans. While Mr. Christopher, Mr. Peres and Jordan's Prime Minister, Abdel Salam al-Majali, met at a Dead Sea spa, the first time Israeli and Jordanian officials had met officially on Jordanian soil, a Christopher aide stayed behind in Amman to offer his ideas to Crown Prince Hassan. Every time the American side raised a point included in the American draft, the Crown Prince would say, "Yes, we've covered that."
Finally, last Sunday, Mr. Rabin showed the declaration to Mr. Christopher at the Israeli's suite at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington. The Americans did not get an official copy of what would be called the Washington Declaration until 11 P.M. Sunday, just 12 hours before the ceremony.
 
Washington Follow-Up
Hussein Succeeds In a Key Demand
 When King Hussein and Mr. Rabin shook hands at the White House, they came not only as former adversaries, but by now also as old friends.
And it was not simply the history of the moment that was on their minds. After the handshake for the cameras, they retreated with Mr. Clinton to the White House cabinet room for their first official session together. They had many things to discuss.
The top item was cash -- how to get the Congress to wipe out Jordan's debt. After King Hussein explained once again the importance of this step, Mr. Rabin picked up on the theme and in his deep, slow baritone told the Americans: "It is essential."
In the days that followed, the Administration came up with a three-year plan to wipe away Jordan's debt to the United States, a gesture meant to free King Hussein to accelerate the pace of peace with Israel.
"As far as the future is concerned, for us to be able to get on with it, we have to receive the assistance of all those friends of ours to remove this burden," the King said in the interview. "Our people have got to feel -- apart from their conviction and commitment that peace is so important -- that peace means a change from where we are to where we should be."

Chronology/Map: "CHRONOLOGY: Steps to the Israel-Jordan Peace Accord"
 
1993
 
June 18 -- King Hussein meets President Clinton for the first time.
 
June 24 -- The King follows up the meeting with a long, personal letter to Mr. Clinton describing a vision of peace.
 
July 4 -- Mr. Clinton responds, pledging his full support. Soon after, he asks Congress to resume military aid to Jordan.
 
Aug. 20 -- Israel and the Palestinian Liberation Organization initial a peace plan they have negotiated secretly in Oslo.
 
Sept 13 -- The P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, shakes hands with Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, as they sign Oslo accord at the White House.
 
Sept. 14 -- Israeli and Jordanian delegations sign their own agenda at State Department
 
Oct. 1 -- Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan meets with Mr. Clinton and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel in the Oval Office.
 
Nov. 2-3 -- Mr. Peres, and King Hussein meet secretly in Amman to sign a four-page document laying the groundwork for further talks. Little progress follows.
 
1994
 
May 4 -- To Jordan's surprise, Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin reach agreement in Cairo on carrying out the Oslo accord.
 
May 19 -- Mr. Rabin and Mr. Hussein meet secretly in London and work out rough agreement.
 
June 5-7 -- Israel and Jordan reveal details to United States, under cover of trilateral talks.
 
June 22 -- Mr. Clinton suggests to the King that he make a "dramatic" gesture, such as meeting Mr. Rabin in Washington.
 
July 15 -- The President announces plans for a public ceremony. Israelis and Jordanians begin drafting "Washington declaration" three days later.
 
July 25 -- King Hussein and Mr. Rabin shake hands on the White House lawn.
 
July 29 -- Congressional leaders agree to speed up relief of Jordan's debt to the United States by up to $220 million.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Goes to Truman Land In Push to 'Give 'em Health'

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 30

 BODY:
Trying to draw some magic from the lodestar of political scrappers, President Clinton came to Harry Truman's hometown today to start a homestretch push for a health care bill that provides universal coverage.
Wrapping himself in the reputation of the first President to propose legislation to guarantee universal health insurance, Mr. Clinton likened the opponents of such legislation today to Truman's opponents. He said that both relied on appeals to division and fear. 
 "All this screaming and yelling, what's really hurting America today is that we're shouting too much and listening too little, and speaking in respectful tones too little," Mr. Clinton told a crowd of several thousand in the courthouse square.
Mr. Clinton tried to cast the health care fight as a battle against nay-sayers against the President. Speaking in front of a statue of Truman, whose feistiness has worn well with history, Mr. Clinton jabbed his finger into the podium and offered an impassioned defense of his overall record as President.
"They said we would wreck the economy," he said. "Instead we brought it back because we wouldn't give in to this hatred and rhetoric of division and destruction and we moved forward."
He said that just as Truman had to guide Americans in the transition after World War II, he was trying to guide Americans into the 21st century. Just as Mr. Truman faced attacks, Mr. Clinton said, he faces attacks.
"When people leave one era, when everybody can look at the future through the same set of glasses and they have to pick up another set of glasses to figure out how to understand things, we are always vulnerable," he said. "You think about your own life. Every time you've been asked to change you may have a mixture of hope and fear. And the real test every time is, are your fears going to overtake you and are you going to give in, or are you going to live by your hopes and your courage and charge forward and grow and become better? That is the test for the United States today."
Comparing the attacks on Mr. Truman to those he now faces, Mr. Clinton said: "What did they say? 'Harry Truman's a radical liberal. He's for socialized medicine. He's for big government. He's going to take this country down.'
"Well, the truth is, Harry Truman had Independence, Mo., values. He had this old-fashioned notion that we value work and family and faith. And people who work hard and play by the rules ought to help one another when they need it, ought to join together to help themselves and to help their children have a better life."
 
Political Double Date
 The President arrived holding hands with his wife, Hillary, and Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, were right behind. It was the first time the two couples had gone on a political double date since the 1992 Presidential campaign. They hoped their appearance would provide a spritz of excitement for a final push for some version of a health care plan to be passed this year, as both the Senate and the House prepare to take up bills before their summer recess.
Mr. Clinton praised the bill unveiled on Friday by leaders of the House, and he stressed its differences from the plan he introduced in September, which has proved unpopular even with Americans who support its goals.
"It is simpler, more flexible, more sensitive to small business," the President said of the House bill. "Gone is the bureaucracy people didn't like. All Americans can keep their health plan and their doctor, and everybody will have coverage."
Though the final version of a health bill may no longer be in their control, the Clintons were still pushing one facet. "The bottom line is, the President wants universal coverage," said Ginny Terzano, a White House spokeswoman. "So he and the First Lady and the Gores and the Cabinet will be pushing Congress over the next two weeks to provide universal coverage."
The two White House couples met up with four buses that had traveled from Portland, Ore., as part of the Health Security Express, a caravan of health care supporters, paid by for unions and advocacy groups, wending its way to Washington with the message "Pass it now!" The caravan has been drawing less enthusiastic crowds than the one that inspired it, the Clinton-Gore campaign bus caravan, when the two men attracted so many admirers out this way that one newspaper crowned them the Heartthrobs of the Heartland.
Susan Crowthers, the mother of Rachel Crowthers, a teen-ager who has serious health problems, alluded today to the protests the caravan had attracted when she said it had experienced both affection and conflict.
As Rachel, who has cancer and epilepsy, talked to the crowd today, the jeers of the protesters outside the square could be clearly heard.
 
'She Kept Working
 Mrs. Gore, recalling the routine during the Presidential campaign, took the podium first to warm up the crowd. "Well, hello, I'm Tipper Gore and it's great to be back in the Show Me State," she said in her bubbly style.
Telling the crowd how much she loved the First Lady, she introduced Mrs. Clinton, pointing out that "she lost her father and that did not deter her -- she kept working day in, week out to help every single American" get health care coverage.
Then it was Mrs. Clinton's turn. She held up a letter she had been handed when they landed in Kansas City, Mo. The letter, she said, was from 8-year-old Jennifer Dawn Lucas and was written in pencil on stationery with a picture of the St. Louis Zoo train.
Jennifer told Mrs. Clinton that she had needed surgery as a baby because she had been born with a hole in her heart. "Insurance don't want to mess with me because I have a pacemaker," she wrote.
Holding up the letter, Mrs. Clinton told the crowd, "I don't want our country to have a hole in its heart anymore when it comes to taking care of sick children like Jennifer."
 
Attack on Dole Plan
 Vice President Gore made the blunt attack on the opposition. "What we don't need is Bob Dole's plan," he said. "It cripples the middle class; it hurts the middle class. It gives insurance companies the final say on what gets put in and left out. The Dole plan tells insurance companies it's all right to charge older Americans up to four times as much as younger Americans."
The crowd seemed to reflect the total range of support, opposition and confusion about health care. "Give 'Em Health, Hillary" signs warred with ones reading "Hillary's Health Care Makes Me Sick." As the Presidential motorcade turned to Osage Street from Truman Street, the White House delegation could see about 200 protesters lining the street, holding signs denouncing abortion coverage in the health plan and socialized medicine.
Gerry Ray Carl, a 57-year-old school bus driver from Independence who had managed to wangle six tickets to get inside the event, said she had not come to support the President on health care. But she had not come to oppose him either.
"I came to see Willie Nelson, what else?" Ms. Carl said.
Mr. Nelson performed his old favorites like "Whiskey River" and "Mama Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Cowboys" before the President spoke.
Margaret Emefiena, 47, a Kansas City secretary, held a protest sign that read, "Abortion is the ultimate child abuse."
Describing herself as part of the working poor, Ms. Emefiena said, "Government should not have no part in it; government should not take another dime out of my paycheck toward abortion or socialized medicine."
 
Inspired by Canada
 On the other hand, Vickie Riddle, 46, who was eating a bratwurst with mustard as she waited to get into the square, believed that the President was not going far enough. A social worker, she said that she wanted a system like the one the Canadians have, and that she was pleased to see one protester, a man with an anti-abortion placard, wearing a T-shirt that said, "Help, I've fallen and I can't reach the beer."
"That says it all," Ms. Riddle said, biting her bratwurst.
The White House planned today's event to evoke memories of the ceremony 29 years ago today, when President Lyndon B. Johnson flew to Independence to sign the Medicare-Social Security bill and offer a tribute to Truman, who was beaming at his side. Johnson chose Independence, as Mr. Clinton did, because Truman was the first President to propose a Federal program of health insurance under Social Security.
Mr. Clinton said today: "Folks, 60 years ago this fight started. "Fifty years ago, Truman tried it three times and failed. Twenty-nine years ago, President Johnson came to this city to sign Medicare into law and to give Harry and Bess Truman Medicare cards 1 and 2.
"Let's finish Harry Truman's fight. We're halfway home, and we can go all the way."

GRAPHIC: Photos: President Clinton spoke about health care yesterday in Harry S. Truman's hometown, Independence, Mo. With Mr. Clinton were, from left, Tipper Gore, Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton. (pg 1); President Clinton held a rally yesterday in Independence, Mo., to generate support for his health care plan, but some people showed up to protest. (Associated Press) (pg. 24)

HEADLINE: The Push Is On for Link to Airports;
Port Authority Confident of Rail Plan Despite Opposition

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Standing before a plastic model of the sleek automated train the Port Authority plans to run from Manhattan to the airports in Queens, an elderly woman took one look during a public hearing last week and turned away. "It'll never happen," she said, in a sneer of weary dismissal.
Edward J. O'Sullivan, the director of the Port Authority's airport access program, rolled his eyes. 
 "That's what we're up against," said Mr. O'Sullivan, the rail link's most tireless promoter. "No one thinks you can build anything like this in New York anymore. But they're wrong. This time, it's going to get built."
A growing coalition of opponents and critics is working to thwart Mr. O'Sullivan's prediction, raising significant questions about the effect on neighborhoods and whether the proposal fits properly with the region's existing rail system.
Nonetheless, the Port Authority remains firmly, even sunnily optimistic about its $2.5 billion plan. First proposed three years ago, the project got favorable marks in an environmental impact review just completed by the Federal Aviation Administration and the New York State Department of Transportation.
If built and opened on schedule in 2003, it would be the city's largest transit project since the construction of the IND subway in the 1930's, and skeptics are already comparing it with such unfinished promises as the Second Avenue subway or the 63d Street Tunnel system. Many recall that rail service to LaGuardia and Kennedy International airports has been discussed and studied for more than 20 years, with the only concrete attempt -- the Transit Authority's unbeloved Train to the Plane -- shut down in 1990 after years of losses and low patronage.
But there is something quite different about this project, one that may give it a greater likelihood of completion: it has its own dedicated source of capital funds, quite separate from the shallow pool of tax money that pays for transit and road projects and can barely keep the subway system operating.
Since 1992, the F.A.A. has collected a $3 fee added to the ticket of every passenger at the three major regional airports. The funds can be used only for airport-related purposes, and the agency has ruled that improved access to the airports is an eligible purpose.
But there is one catch: such projects cannot serve general transportation uses; they can be used only by patrons or employees of the airports. That is why the Port Authority designed a system independent of the existing rail network. Though it allows transfers to and from the subway and Long Island Rail Road at several points, it would use incompatible trains, and it could not feasibly be used by riders whose trip does not begin or end at an airport. The one-way fare is expected to be comparable to express-bus fares, currently $9 to $12.
The line would begin at an underground station near East 59th Street and Lexington Avenue. Trains would move above ground just before the Queensboro Bridge, and would cross the East River on the lower outer roadways of the bridge. Through Queens, the trains would use existing railroad or highway right-of-way, first to LaGuardia (stopping at all the terminals except the Marine Air Terminal), then south to Kennedy.
In addition to the airports and 59th Street, there would also be stops and rail connections at Queens Plaza in Long Island City, Shea Stadium in Flushing, Jamaica station and Howard Beach. To conform to Federal limits on non-airport riders, the system would double the fare for anyone who did not start or stop at an airport. (Computerized turnstiles and fare cards would record where riders got on, and would demand extra money to get out.)
Anyone who has spent more than an hour and $45 to take a taxi from Manhattan to Kennedy can appreciate the lure of a comfortable train that will get to Kennedy in 35 minutes, or to LaGuardia in 12. For years, transportation planners have bemoaned the congestion and air pollution caused by airport traffic on the Van Wyck Expressway or the Grand Central Parkway, and economists have produced studies showing that the problem is hurting the region's economy and future growth. Travel time to Kennedy is the longest of the country's top 20 airports.
 
Integration Urged
 But many of those same planners are leery of the Port Authority's proposal. Because New York is in desperate need of improvements and expansions to its crumbling, overcrowded transit system, the idea of a 22-mile system strictly for airport passengers does not sit well with rail advocates. Many are urging the Port Authority to integrate its proposal better with the existing system.
Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, notes that his private organization has long urged the construction of an airport rail link. But he agrees with East Side residents that the proposed 59th Street station would cause too much taxi and limousine congestion in the already overburdened area, and says the authority would be better off using existing transit links, like the 63d Street Tunnel, rather than remove car lanes from the Queensboro Bridge.
"The lower half of that tunnel was designed to bring railroad access into Grand Central Terminal," he said. "It's been sitting there unused for 20 years. We built it, we paid for it, it's ours. So let's use it."
Mr. O'Sullivan of the Port Authority said he would love to use the tunnel in order to begin the airport rail line at Grand Central. But he cited the Long Island Rail Road's figures that building the connection from Long Island City through the tunnel to the terminal would cost $2.4 billion, almost the cost of the entire airport rail system. And he said the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had sent the Port Authority a letter saying the tunnel was not available for airport rail.
John Bennett, the L.I.R.R. vice president for infrastructure and systems, said the railroad hoped to use the lower half of the tunnel for its own trains to Grand Central, sometime after 2010. He urged the Port Authority to consider scaling back its plans, building only a rail system from Jamaica Station to Kennedy, and from the Woodside station to LaGuardia. Manhattan passengers could take regular L.I.R.R. trains to those stations and transfer, he said. (Proponents of the Port Authority plan say travelers with luggage will never transfer.)
 
Grand Cenral Platform
 William Wheeler, the head of planning for the railroad's parent body, the M.T.A., said the Port Authority should simply extend its tunnel from the planned 59th Street station around to Grand Central, thus alleviating the congestion and much of the political opposition from the East Side. But Mr. O'Sullivan said that would cost an extra $600 million and would not substantially change the congestion.
Given the disagreements between government bodies and the inevitable opposition from neighborhoods -- all part of what Mr. Yaro calls the "stylized Kabuki theater" of building public works in New York -- it is no wonder that proponents of the rail system are eager to run with a proposal that might actually be built, even if it is flawed. Much of the Queens business and political establishment is solidly behind the plan, despite the fears of some residents living near the route.
Claire Shulman, the Borough President of Queens, said the system would provide a vital boost to the borough's economy by improving the popularity of the airports and reducing congestion and air pollution. Aviation-related companies would be able to locate in struggling neighborhoods like Jamaica and still have easy access to the airports, she said.
"Those folks in Manhattan want to kill the project because of a few extra taxicabs," she said. "Well, we live with these airports every day of the week, with their congestion and their noise. I would hope they would have some sense of cooperation, considering that they are the ones who use these airports."
The impact study prepared by a consultant to the F.A.A. confirmed that Manhattan residents are the largest single bloc of airport patrons, constituting 48 percent of LaGuardia's market and 35 percent of Kennedy's. A quarter of all airport users, in fact, live in the two zip codes immediately adjacent to the 59th Street station. But the study also showed that of the 32,000 riders expected to use the system in 2003, 42 percent would get on at 59th Street, and most of those would get there by car.
 
Well-Organized Opponents
 Neighborhood residents fear those idling taxis, in combination with the loss of two lanes on the bridge, would make their streets permanently impassable. Wealthy and well-organized, they have already begun to enlist their politicians and to mount a strong campaign against the plan. In this effort, they have found natural allies in the airlines, which want to see the $3 ticket fee used exclusively for improvements at the airports themselves and are working with some of the neighborhood groups.
The system must still be reviewed by the city next year, and given the climate in New York, no one involved would be surprised to see a flurry of lawsuits once the plan moves toward detailed engineering work and bids in late 1995. Mr. O'Sullivan acknowledges that possibility, but is counting on the mystique of a fast train and an extensive public relations campaign -- including a staff that publishes a regular airport rail newsletter and has addressed hundreds of community meetings -- to sway a majority of the city.
"There is a logic to this that will appeal to most people," Mr. O'Sullivan said. "New York City has been trying for 40 years to implement some sort of air access system, and here we have a window of opportunity we have to take advantage of. If people step back from their parochial concerns, we can work together to minimize the intrusion on various neighborhoods and make this thing work."

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE ADVOCATES;
Many Health Groups Fight House Democratic Leaders' Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
A broad assortment of doctors, hospitals, private insurance companies, health maintenance organizations, state officials and big employers said today that they disliked a central element of the House Democratic leaders' health plan, which would more than double the size of the Federal Medicare program.
Under the proposal put forward Friday by the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Government would create a new Part C of Medicare, open to people who are unemployed, receive welfare, work part time or hold jobs at companies with fewer than 100 employees. The new program is one of the Democratic leaders' main tools to guarantee health insurance for all Americans. 
 Mr. Gephardt's proposal differs from President Clinton's plan because it calls for a new Federal program. The President's plan calls for private health insurance.
Democratic aides to the House Ways and Means Committee estimated that 40 million to 60 million people would join the new program. Experts at the Congressional Budget Office said enrollment might exceed 90 million in the year 2004. Medicare already finances health care for 32 million elderly people and 4 million who are disabled.
 
A Concern of Businesses
 The new Part C of Medicare is intended to solve one type of concern created by requiring all employers to buy health insurance for their employees. But in trying to minimize business opposition to the bill, House Democratic leaders have left some supporters of universal coverage deeply unhappy.
The National Governors' Association, the American Medical Association, the American Hospital Association, the Health Insurance Association of America, the Group Health Association of America and the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group that represents many Fortune 500 companies, criticized Mr. Gephardt's proposal to expand Medicare.
The proposal for a new Part C of Medicare confronts these groups with difficult questions of tactics and strategy. On the one hand, the groups share Mr. Gephardt's desire to expand coverage and control health costs, and they will fight to achieve these goals. But their deep reservations about the new Medicare program may cool their enthusiasm at a time when the White House is counting on them to lobby aggressively for the overall bill.
 
Option for Some Employees
 Mr. Gephardt's bill offers another option to people who work for companies with fewer than 100 employees: they can sign up for a private health plan offered through the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. The conservative Heritage Foundation described that program as "a showcase of consumer choice," and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said today that he liked this feature of the Gephardt bill.
But Mr. Dole scorned the proposal for a new Part C of Medicare, saying it would enlarge the Government's role to an unacceptable degree. Nearly half of all Americans would be enrolled in some type of Medicare program, he said.
Mr. Gephardt's hopes for success depend on moderate Democrats. Representative Jim Cooper, a conservative Tennessee Democrat, said: "In many respects, the leadership bill is more liberal than the Clinton bill. Part C of Medicare would lead to a single-payer system for about half the U.S. population." In a single-payer system, the Government raises taxes to pay medical bills, and there is little role for private insurers.
 
Hospitals' Opposition
 Richard J. Pollack, executive vice president of the American Hospital Association, said there were several arguments against Part C of Medicare. First, he said, hospitals are rushing to link up with doctors, clinics and other hospitals in health care networks that can provide a full range of services to customers.
"The new Medicare program moves in the opposite direction," he said. "It perpetuates the fragmented fee-for-service system" in which hospitals are paid separately for each admission and patients can go to virtually any doctor.
Moreover, Mr. Pollack said, hospitals have had 12 years' experience with a process in which Congress sets Medicare payment rates, and they do not like it.
"Medicare rates are set in the middle of the night behind closed doors, based on what's necessary to meet deficit-reduction targets that have nothing to do with health policy," he said.
 
Same Method of Payment
 Under the new Medicare program proposed by Mr. Gephardt, doctors and hospitals would be paid in the same way they are now paid under the regular Medicare program.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said the new Medicare program "would perpetuate cost-shifting to the private sector" because Medicare pays less than most private insurance plans.
If the new Medicare program was limited to companies with fewer than 20 employees, he said, "it would be more palatable, though not necessarily acceptable."
Supporters of the Medicare C plan say it is crucial to the political and practical success of the bill.
 
No Haggling With Insurers
 It does give small employers a relatively easy way to get insurance for their workers; they will not have to haggle with private insurers. And it gives people a way to pool their purchasing power without forcing them to join the purchasing cooperatives, or alliances, proposed by President Clinton.
The main argument for Part C of Medicare is that it is simple to administer and easy to understand because it is modeled on Medicare, which has become immensely popular with beneficiaries since it was created in 1965. "Medicare is simple: no new rules, no new bureaucracy," said Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, the chief architect of Part C.
But Mary Nell Lehnhard, senior vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, criticized Part C of Medicare as "a huge expansion of a Government program." It "fragments the market and picks people out of the big insurance pools we are trying to build," she said.
 
'Insurer of Last Resort'
 Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Stark evidently believe that "the Government needs to establish an insurer of last resort, a safety net available to small employers," said Ms. Lehnhard. But, she said, that view was wrong because the health care legislation moving through Congress would require insurers to provide coverage to all applicants at standard rates, regardless of any medical problems they might have.
When the Federal Government imposes such requirements, she said, "every health insurance company, every managed care company will be an insurer of last resort."
The National Governors' Association criticized the Gephardt plan on the grounds that it would limit states' flexibility to deal with health care costs.

HEADLINE: Last Flight Out of Haiti Strands Some

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 30

 BODY:
Haiti's last commercial air link to the rest of the world was severed today. The final regularly scheduled flight, an Air France jet bound for French Guiana, departed just ahead of a Monday deadline that was intended to increase both the economic pressure on the country's military-backed government and its isolation.
Though the suspension of commercial flights does not affect the vast majority of Haiti's seven million people, most of whom are too poor to afford foreign travel, it promises to have an important psychological impact, especially on the country's commercial and governing class. 
 "We are sealed in, the whole country," Raymond Lafontant, executive director of the Association of Haitian Industries, said in an interview Friday. "I have a sense I am in jail."
 
Looking for Letter-Carriers
 Aware that the flight was their last chance to leave or to ship cargo abroad, many Haitians arrived at the airport early, including some who did not intend to travel but were merely looking for passengers willing to carry letters.
Radio stations here, citing postal officials, have been saying in recent days that mail deliveries to and from foreign destinations will have to be suspended unless the Government finds a way to bring in mail from overseas aboard charter flights.
In a radio interview this afternoon, a postal official said the Government hoped soon to begin using boats to bring in overseas mail. But he also said it was proving difficult to find shipping companies willing to take on the job, because they feared problems with American naval vessels patrolling just offshore.
Originally, Air France refused to join American Airlines and other carriers that suspended their flights to Port-au-Prince on June 25 as part of the economic sanctions against Haiti. But when the Haitian military expelled a combined United Nations and Organization of American States human rights monitoring mission on July 11, France retaliated by announcing that service would end by Aug. 1.
 
Mothers Seeks to Get Home
 At the airport this morning, the police allowed only passengers with confirmed reservations or boarding passes to enter the terminal, turning away more than a score of people who arrived with valid tickets only to be told their seats had been given to others. Among them was Yolande Brunache, who was planning to fly to Cayenne, French Guiana, to join her husband and year-old son.
"I don't know what to do now," Ms. Brunache, 31, said, clearly stunned after being turned away at the terminal entrance by an Air France ticket agent. "This is the last flight, and I have got to get on it."
In a similar situation was Erla Desrameaux, who flew here from her home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn last month to care for her 22-year-old daughter, who was ill at the time. Ms. Desrameaux, 48, a housekeeper at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, said she had bought a ticket with an open return but had been unable to reserve a ticket back to New York, where she has lived for 25 years.
"For the last three weeks I've come out to the airport every day there has been a flight, but every day it's been the same thing," she said. "I need to get back, because I have an 11-year-old son who I left with a friend, and he needs his mother."
As the deadline for the suspension of service approached, plane reservations became a coveted black market item, trading for more than 10 times their face value.
 
U.S. Hopes to Charter Flight
 On Wednesday's flight, American officials here said, Air France bumped about 100 Haitian political refugees who have been granted asylum in the United States to give seats to other customers, many of whom appeared to be French nationals.
A man who identified himself as the Air France manager here, but declined to give his name, refused to discuss the company's ticketing procedures. "My company says no interviews here, only in Paris," he said.
American Embassy officials said they hoped to obtain permission from the military government for charter flights that would take those refugees, and more than 1,000 others whose applications for political asylum are being processed here, to the United States. "We are confident that will happen," Stanley Schrager, a spokesman for the embassy, said earlier this week.
Also left behind are a large group of foreigners. Diplomats here estimate that about 3,000 Americans, 2,000 Canadians and 1,500 Britons are in the country, most of them residents who remain willingly.
 
Consulate Closes Doors
 In addition, the American consulate has closed its doors as of Friday. From now on, United States officials here said, the consulate will no longer grant visas of any type to Haitians, and will only be open to provide emergency services to American citizens.
The United Nations embargo of Haiti is likely to tighten even further next month, when an international force is expected to begin patrolling the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic. With American vessels sailing the waters off Haiti and interdicting shipments of goods proscribed by the sanctions, the country has been receiving essential items like gasoline mostly through that porous land frontier.
But the United States has authorized $15 million to improve the policing of that border, and is ready to send helicopters, vehicles and technical advisers as part of the effort. American officials said an agreement with the Dominicans had been in the works for several weeks and was awaiting the approval of President Joaquin Balaguer, who in the past has been friendly to the Haitian military.
