HEADLINE: Signs Of Life In County's Economy

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
NEWS this month that I.B.M. profits jumped during the second quarter of the year appeared to signal more than just a fresh start for the once-beleaguered Armonk-based computer giant. Analysts said the announcement from the county's largest private employer ended weeks of speculation that the economy in general in Westchester was finally pulling out of a slump.
There continued to be a growing list of indicators this summer that the recession -- which hit hard and lasted so long in Westchester -- was finally loosening its grip here, as it had much earlier in other parts of America. 
 Among other suggestions of better times to come for the county was a report this month from the Westchester County Board of Realtors that spring home sales hit the highest level for any quarter on record, despite rising interest rates.
Also, numbers released last week showed the county's unemployment rate for June was 5.5 percent, the lowest figure for June since 1991. Although the latest figure was up from the 4.4 jobless rate in May, the increase in June reflected a temporary influx of summer job seekers rather than a trend, the State Department of Labor reported.
There were more glad tidings in the Rostenberg-Doern Midyear Corporate Real Estate Report, which said that the June office-vacancy rate in the county dropped to 25.4 percent, from 27.1 percent at midyear in 1993. Moreover, close to 330,000 square feet of office space was absorbed in the last six months, the report said.
Also, Mastercard International, the credit card company, reported this month that it would relocate its world headquarters and 450 employees to the county by late 1995. In addition, there were queries from other big companies scouting relocation sites here, the county's Office of Economic Development reported, although it would not reveal the names of the other companies.
"Let's just say we're having lots and lots of good news lately," said Noreen L. Preston, an economist with that office. "It looks like the economy here is shifting into second gear."
Throughout the county, analysts reported stirrings of a recovery, although no one said that the economy had returned to full swing. Job recovery, especially, is expected to be slow as those companies that downsized during the recession remain cautious, along with consumers who were keeping a watchful eye on expenses, said Frank M. Surdey, an economist with the State Department of Labor.
 
Brighter Picture for I.B.M.
 For International Business Machines, its report on July 21 that second-quarter profits jumped to $689 million, or $1.14 a share, came in sharp contrast to the massive shortfall reported for the year-ago period, when the company announced an $8.9 billion restructuring charge to cover job and property reductions, among other things. Although the picture has brightened, I.B.M. has not completed its restructuring, and there are more staff reductions -- through retirements and layoffs -- to come, said Scott Brooks, a spokesman.
The company, which employs about 235,000 people worldwide, has set a target of 215,000. In 1986, I.B.M. employed 15,000 workers in Westchester; it now has only 7,300 employees here. Mr. Brooks said he did not know what the job losses would be locally during the rest the year.
I.B.M.'s most recent earnings report followed a corporate trend in many parts of the country, with companies finding that after years of downsizing, their efforts had begun to pay off in profits and earnings.
Some Westchester-based corporations, however, continued to struggle, Ms. Preston said. Among them, Texaco in Harrison announced last week that after restructuring costs and a loss on the sale of its chemicals business, earnings dropped sharply for the second quarter. Texaco reported earnings of $28 million, or 1 cent a share, a 90 percent drop from last year's $309 million, or $1.10 a share.
"Let's not isolate I.B.M.," Ms. Preston said. "We have a number of large employers in Westchester, and most of them had to downsize. What that has meant is that collectively they reduced the number of jobs available in the county."
But Mr. Surdey, at the State Department of Labor, said that the "steady erosion of jobs" in the last several years had at last begun to level off, and that 5,000 new jobs were added in June in Westchester, bringing the total to 378,700. That was the largest May-June increase in three years, he added.
"We've gone through a lot of pain, but it appears that we're on our way back," Mr. Surdey said. "Let's say we're on the runway waiting to take off.'
Although many companies were cautious about rehiring, Mr. Surdey called I.B.M.'s announcement "good news for Westchester County as a whole and hopeful for the future."
Lawrence E. Dwyer, president of the 800-member Westchester County Association, said the county, which has many big corporations within its borders, had been "a victim of all of its companies struggling to get to the right size for this economy."
He noted that while he welcomed good news about major companies -- Mastercard's relocation plans, for example -- "greater activity among small and medium-size companies was equally important."
"It's not just the outward signs of big businesses relocating here, it's a new enthusiasm from many parts of the economy that we're feeling," he said, adding that the banking community was joining in the economic optimism, specifically in terms of its growing willingness to help start-up companies and take on higher-risk loans.
At the Westchester County Board of Realtors, P. Gilbert Mercurio, the executive vice president, said sales of 1,900 homes were finalized during the second quarter of the year, which represented close to a 41 percent increase over the same period last year.
He said the the median sale price of a one-family house was $292,00. compared to the late 1980's, when prices soared above $300,000 -- making sale prices "flat now and affordable."
Realtors reported that the market appears to be dominated by first-time buyers who seem to feel secure in the current job market -- as opposed to "more senior employees who by and large are not as optimistic," Mr. Mercurio said.
 
$200 Million Shopping Mall
 Looking at the commercial real estate market, the Rostenberg-Doern Company, in its midyear report, noted that Greenburgh-based Ciba Corporation's decision earlier this year to remain in the county and to lease 425,000 square feet at the Tarrytown Corporate Center for its new headquarters -- including a 150,000 square-foot laboratory -- was "one of the largest lease deals in the county since the early 1980's."
Ciba, which has 1,000 employees, now occupies 59 acres in Ardsley and 6 acres in Hastings-on-Hudson.
In the county's central business district, downtown White Plains, the office-vacancy rate remained higher, and at the midyear point it had dropped only to 33.7 percent, compared with 34.9 percent a year ago.
But George J. Delaney, president of the Westchester Business Partnership, a nonprofit public-private venture promoting the county to prospective businesses, noted that despite the city's vacancy rate, it was thriving economically. He added that a $200 million shopping mall in the city will generate 2,500 full- and part-time jobs when completed.
 
Ripple Effect From Manhattan
 As the economy in general appeared to regenerate, the hotel industry, which has been hard hit by slowdowns in other business sectors, also noted stirrings of activity. Marcia Dmochowski, president of the Westchester Hotel Association, which represents 20 area hotels, said there had been a 2 percent growth rate in recent months. "Companies are having to feel optimistic before they plan product roll-out meetings or increase travel budgets," she said. "Traditionally, the hotel industry lags behind other sectors."
The state's elimination in September of the 5 percent tax on hotel rooms costing more than $100 a night is expected to further benefit the industry, Ms. Dmochowski said, although she added that it would "take some time for the word to get out."
While Westchester appeared to be emerging from the recession -- although "riding the crest later than the rest of the country," Ms. Preston said -- it was finally feeling a ripple effect, especially from Manhattan, where new jobs were being generated in financial and computer services.
Ms. Preston said Westchester lagged behind in large part because its job base was tied directly to the large companies situated here. "We've had all of our eggs in one basket," she said.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Summer Boot Camp For Budding Executives

BYLINE: By Deborah L. Jacobs; Deborah L. Jacobs, an independent journalist based in New York, specializes in legal and business topics.

 BODY:
WHILE her friends went to field hockey camp, baby-sat or worked as lifeguards this summer, Kacie Croson, 16, spent millions of dollars -- much of it borrowed -- in a struggle to turn a fledgling computer company into a profitable venture.
Thankfully, it was a hypothetical venture, the central challenge of a two-year-old all-girls program called Camp Entrepreneur, based at Seton Hill College in Greensburg, Pa. Kacie, who lives in the suburbs of Columbus, Ohio, was one of about 40 girls who signed up for the camp. At first, she recoiled at the idea. "It would be like a camp for geeks," she told her father, an engineer and owner of his own business. But by the end of the program, she had drafted a business plan, made a pitch for financing from venture capitalists and heard tips from bankers about how to apply for a business loan -- and she was enthusiastic. 
 "If you enjoy what you're doing and learn from it, then you can succeed," said Kacie, who thinks she might be the president of her father's company someday. For the moment, she is working her way up through the ranks, filing, typing and sorting mail.
Camp Entrepreneur is sponsored by the National Education Center for Women in Business, which studies and promotes opportunities for women business owners. The camp offers two one-week sessions for high school students -- one at the center's headquarters at Seton Hill, the other at the University of Denver -- as well as a new weeklong session for 10- to 14-year-olds at Seton Hill.
The enrollment in all three sessions is so far limited to girls, said Cynthia Iannarelli, director of the women's business center, because many of them "get shortchanged" in coed classrooms. While boys in coed classes learn competition, strategy and teamwork, she said, girls tend to sit back and listen. By the time they become teen-agers, girls "rate themselves as less smart than boys," she said.
At Camp Entrepreneur, girls meet role models like Ms. Iannarelli, who has helped to run her family's dry-cleaning business since her father died 15 years ago. At that turning point, the company's lawyer proposed putting all the stock for the family's five Pittsburgh stores in the name of Ms. Iannarelli's younger brother; the lawyer predicted Ms. Iannarelli would get married and lose interest. The family found a new lawyer.
At least half the girls who go to Camp Entrepreneur, which costs $490 for the week, including room and board, are children of business owners. Emme Barfield, 17, whose mother is a seamstress and owner of her own business in Macon, Ga., liked to play store as a little girl and hopes to own a restaurant. Kristen Kart, 16, from Pittsburgh, is editor of The Next Generation, a newspaper for teen-agers that her father, Harvey Kart, started.
Mr. Kart said he encouraged his daughter to attend the camp because he wants her to be better prepared than he was to enter the world of business. A former teacher, he said he was discharged from a variety of sales positions before settling upon his current career as a publisher. "I'm not trying to push her," he told friends who suggested Kristen might be happier this summer working as a lifeguard. "I'm just trying to be realistic."
After a teary farewell when her parents dropped her off at the camp, Kristen, like Kacie, became enthusiastic. "I learned that jobs can be exciting," said Kristen, who volunteered last summer in an occupational therapy program and said she found it boring. The guest speakers at Camp Entrepreneur, including Ms. Iannarelli, "loved their jobs," she said. What's more, the camp "teaches you how to work in a team with people you never met before and how to make decisions that could affect your life," she said.
The course relies heavily on a computer game called "The Marketplace," which simulates the steps of starting and running a computer company for two years. Students work in teams of three, making all decisions from coming up with a name to advertising and raising capital for expansion. Players must be mindful of income and expenses. If expenditures exceed revenues, a loan shark offers a bailout at 25 percent interest.
Students start the game with $2 million in capital, but soon exhaust it and must borrow, said Ernest R. Cadotte, a professor of marketing and author of the software. This forces them to answer loan officers' "tough questions," said Mr. Cadotte, who teaches at the University of Tennessee's College of Business Administration in Knoxville.
Some elements of the software grew out of Mr. Cadotte's own unsuccessful effort in the 1970's to market an electronic suggestion box for restaurant customers. After making an unprofitable licensing deal for the product, Mr. Cadotte left the business but wrote "The Marketplace" to help others learn from his mistakes.
Among the lessons for users at Camp Entrepreneur: don't be afraid to say what you think, be willing to take risks and "you have to spend money in order to make money," said Jennifer Oldham, 17, from Hilliard, Ohio. She worked with Kacie on the "New Era Computer Company," which doubled its sales after increasing spending for advertising.
What insights emerge from a single-sex program for high school students? Sarah Eichorn, 15, from Sayre, Pa., said that it "wasn't as competitive as it would have been if there had been boys there" -- and that that was good. Sometimes boys don't understand "you need to cooperate and not just be like the touchdown winner," she said.
Still, plans for Camp Entrepreneur include the possibility of a similar program for boys, Ms. Iannarelli said. In addition to teaching entrepreneurship, she said, the camp would prepare boys to do business with a growing number of women-owned enterprises.
